description: So tried their lamb and eggplant sandwich for lunch, and it was delicious. The sandwich bread was a warm, focaccia bread, the lamb was very tender and juicy, and the sandwich was a good portion. Great place for take out!!!
author: Raj D.

description:
I work nearby and get lunch here around once a month. Sandwiches are okay but there are much better options around.

Being a mostly lifelong San Franciscan, I don't appreciate the anti-environment, anti-HIV prevention, and anti-SF message on their menu. Poor attempt at humor.
author: J K.

description:
The Sentinel likes to mock a public health crisis and the opioid epidemic by stating at the bottom of their menu "napkins, straws, and bags are available upon request, you can still get needles for free though. Welcome to SF."

I have friends who love their food but are rightfully repulsed by their attitude and have opted to no longer dine here. To quote one "I don't ask public health experts for their opinions on where I should eat lunch; I don't need restaurateurs weighing in on public health crises." 

https://www.sfgate.com/local/article/needle-litter-sf-sentinel-sandwich-menu-commentary-13161416.php#photo-7057613
author: Winston P.

description:
Back in the day I purchased a sandwich from the Sentinel and I was very disappointed.  But, for some reason today I must have forgotten my disappointment because I purchased a roast beef sandwich from the Sentinel, and although the sandwich felt sizable -- it was anything but!

I am having a crappy day (locked myself out of my home) and left my phone at home so I have no way to take a photo to post here on Yelp to show Yelpers the LACK of roast beef.  However, you can take my word for it!

When opening the nicely packaged sandwich I was SHOCKED to say the least.  What I received from the Sentinel was an OVERSIZED BUN, a few very lean strips of roast beef, a small amount of onion slivers, and generous amount of lettuce and that was it.  

I had to reconstruct the sandwich and what I did was take the few slices from one-half of the sandwich and place the slices atop of the other half of the sandwich and basically ate HALF A SANDWICH for $12.50 plus tip.  And needless to say, I AM HUNGRY and peeved because I could BARELY taste the beef not to mention the horseradish.  I did however taste the picked onions (menu read cooked) and lettuce.

Will I ever go back -- NOPE, NEVER!
author: Cris B.

description:
For about $10 (maybe $1-2 more sometimes) The Sentinel offers a really high quality lunch. This is quality food. 

Their menu changes regularly, usually comprised of 4-5 sandwich options, a salad choice, and a soup or stew. Everything is super fresh and gourmet-inspired. 

For example:  Spicy Trout stew; chopped cauliflower sandwich, lamb on frisbee salad. 

It's just a window with no seating, and your meal is usually hand-prepped to order in a matter of minutes. 

Like getting the food of a very good restaurant's kitchen and taking it to go.
author: Lanny B.

description:
$10 will get you a darn good sandwich served by a couple friendly gentleman who work in this establishment. This place gets tasty sandwiches out quickly as well. 

I've walked/ran by this venue on many occasions 

I go with the Roast Beef which has horse radish and mayo I believe and was/is very good. 

The only quibble I have with this place is the lack of drink options. I don't usually drink Coke or Sprite but have heard people on several occasions ask for Coke's at this place and they don't seem to carry them. I've tried the Lemonade but it isn't very good. 

Note to Owner: Carry cokes/7-ups and better yet the Mexican bottled version which people seem to love even more and will pay a premium for.
author: Rod M.

description: I tried this place once, but I don't believe in second chances. If they clean up on their own, maybe I'll go back, but I'm not giving this place any free tips on how to improve.
author: Zach P.

description:
I'm definitely not normally a sandwich fan but I love this spot.

The roast beef sandwich was heavenly. The roast beef is extremely rare here, so perhaps it's more like beef sashimi, which I was a huge fan of. The bread, sandwich, onions, and horseradish flavors all perfectly blended together. 

They cut the sandwich into two and half a sandwich is plenty given the amount of meat and other fillings they pack into here. $10.50 is a tad expensive for a sandwich, but if it lasts you two meals like it does for me, it might be worth it. It's definitely a huge sandwich if you tried to eat this in one sitting.

Protip is to grab these sandwiches and head over to the rooftop park over at Crocker Galleria. If it's a windy day, the atrium at Crocker Galleria heats up fairly quickly.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Used to be THE PLACE, I'd go to for a particular sandwich. It started to lose its quality several years ago from the 1st time having it to the last. But now it's only on FRIDAY'S. 

They changed up the flow of the pop up shop causing it to crowd MONTGOMERY, scrunching everyone, when it was busy to begin with. 

Lastly, no signage. Can't see what they are selling anymore. These are the pillars of any food establishment. 

Guess the owner did a lot of research to make all these changes. Just because your running a business, doesn't mean your any good at it. 

Good luck in your future foodie endeavors, I won't be one a loyal customer base anymore after 6 years. You just made too many bad decisions that get in the way of my food joy.
author: Jessica M.

description:
I was excited to try this place after walking by it on a lunch run one day. The line at 12:30 was long, but it moved relatively quickly. After reading through Yelp reviews, I settled on the roast beef sandwich - the tender, juicy-looking homemade roast beef I saw in others' photos looked irresistible. Also, given the size of the sandwich - it looks HUGE in photos - I figured I could split it into two meals, thereby taking the sting off the $12 price. I also splurged on a fresh baked walnut chocolate chip cookie. The cashier was friendly and fast in taking my order and ringing me up. 

Verdict:
1. Roast Beef Sandwich: the roast beef was cooked really well and definitely met my high expectations, but there was so little of it on the bread (maybe 1-3 slices) that all I could taste was bread and pickle. Also, despite the size of the sandwich, most of the volume was bread, which meant I had to eat the entire thing to feel not hungry. Without being able to split it across two meals, $12 for an attractive but unsubstantial sandwich seemed high. 
2. Walnut chocolate chip cookie: this $2.50 splurge was the best decision I've made in recent memory! It was mind blowingly delicious - slightly crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside, and the chocolate was melty throughout. I would go back to The Sentinel in a heartbeat, just to buy cookies. 

Overall, I appreciated the friendly cashier and fresh ingredients, but food-wise it was a wash between the delicious cookie and the rip off roast beef sandwich. Before writing it off completely,
I'll probably give their sandwiches a second chance another day. 

Note: Bring cash! There is a $.50 up charge for using credit card.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Order at a counter. No seating. This is a grab-and-go kind of spot.

I was originally interested in trying the lamb and eggplant sandwich ($10), but I asked the staff and she recommended the spicy pork sandwich ($11). I was kind of surprised by the sliced pork, which didn't make it dry, but perhaps less flavorful. The sauce was not really spicy. Even though it was bright red, it was actually pretty mild. There was also a layer of slaw, which added a little sweetness and tartness. The bread was fluffy and held up well to the ingredients in the sandwich. Overall, an okay sandwich, but not likely one that I would go back for.
author: Alice T.

description:
Definitely a great place for sandwich lovers. They're not your regular sandwiches either. The bread is fresh, the taste is unique (in a good way), and the portions are huge! 

This is tiny shop so there's no place to sit during lunch hours. The line is usually out the door so I suggest preordering your meal. If you are in line, they're pretty quick with their sandwich making abilities! They run out of their specialty sandwiches so I would keep that in mind if going later during the day.

One of my favorite sandwiches here is the lamb and eggplant sandwich. This comes on a soft but sturdy roll, with lamb,eggplant, and pesto sauce on the inside. The lamb isn't overwhelming so if you're expecting a intense lamb flavor, I would be disappointed. The chickpeas complement everything well. This is definitely a satisfying meal that keeps me full all day. Also, it is pretty saucy and messy to eat so make sure you have tons of napkins around you.
author: Mehak D.

description:
WELL for the sandwiches they did have, I was pretty impressed by the variety! We came after the rush, around 1pm, right before they closed, and there's no way to see their menu of the day. There was a woman that had looked online, but they let her know that's not updated regularly. So they just had a sheet for their menu on the door to their window. They were out of one item, but they had a lot of other options. I couldn't decide. So by the time we got to the window, and ordered, he said they were out of the one I wanted too! (He made it sound like they had been for some time though.)

So I wish they updated that. I got their veggie sando and oh man. So much flavor was packed into that, it was also a MONDO sandwich lol. I couldn't really finish it in one sitting! Due to the size, it makes sense that their average price is $11.

I think they mentioned cash is a discount, but we didn't have any at the time. They do take card however.

Would be back to see their other unique sandwiches!
author: Rachel W.

description:
One of my favorite sandwich shops in Financial District. Such a good and quick place! I recommend going around 11:45 or right at 12, as the small place can have a long lines. Unlike other reviewers, I haven't experienced sell-out on something I wanted to order. Perhaps that's because I go early enough! 

Menu changes with the season. My favorites include: 
- Egg salad sandwich (vegetarian)
- Basil, avocado, lettuce, tomato (vegetarian)
- beef stew sandwich (messy but so so good!)
- corned beef sandwich (good as a treat from time to time)
author: Anna M.

description:
Being a few blocks from the office, this place is a popular joint for a quick lunch. I was fortunate that the line wasn't long on a sunny spring day at noon, but lines can get pretty lengthy. I always opt for the lamb and eggplant sandwich. It reminds me of bolognese - so minced pieces of lamb and eggplant in something pretty herby and saucey. I love their system of using post its for their ordering process and food comes out pretty quickly though sometimes not in order. The sandwich is definitely on the heavier side and can be pretty messy to eat, so I do recommend grabbing some extra napkins. But it definitely fills you up.

Would recommend if you are in the area for lunch!
author: Alan N.

description:
Basically just a sandwich counter, no seats or anything.  A very good sandwich counter though, using their own cooked meats instead of mass produced deli blocks.  Thankfully there are a lot of nice outdoor POPOs to eat at nearby.

Corned Beef Sandwich: Not a traditional corned beef sandwich but still very tasty.  The bread is thick and chewy like focaccia.  There is a decent amount of raw shredded cabbage, which adds a slight bitter contrast to the meat.  The thinly sliced meat itself is flavorful and tender, but not too salty.

Strawberry Lemonade: A generous amount of strawberry and not too sour (hate when places go heavy on the lemon).
author: Adam B.

description:
This is a simple lunch staple that typically has a surprising menu that delights those who venture out to try new creations on the menu. They have a standard "sentinel" bread that you can expect to see as the basis many of their meals. It's pretty great, a little sweet, nicely seeded and holds up well to the dense and saucy sandwiches you will typically find at The Sentinel.

So why 3 stars? Something changed. They are trying a new menu and who knows what else, but the menu is not as exciting and service has slowed down considerably. The line was around the block, and we foolishly thought they would move quickly. After 15 minutes we were already committed and stuck it out to order. The meal was not the same exciting twist on old favorites that I have come to expect. 

I look forward to updating this to a 4 star review... but it may be a while before I try The Sentinel again. I'll keep an eye and ear out for positive changes and come back after.
author: John W.

description: Is this a fancy, hipster sando? Sure is! But don't hate. Good veggie options and well done throughout. Good bread, solid ingredients and at $10 is a bit on the high end but not that crazy. It's also not so tiny I'm still hungry when I'm done. Recommend for a lunch spot.
author: Jason P.

description:
This place went downhill when they got rid of the corned beef sandwich.
Why would you get rid of the thing that put you on the map?
author: Alfred M.

description:
Not a sit down place, more of a grab and go type of place with bomb sandwiches.

I got the turkey sandwich with lettuce, LOADS of turkey, cranberry sauce, and provolone I think. Add eggs!! Bread was a little too soggy and lacked the crunch factor, but the sandwich was really flavorful. My friend got the corned beef sandwich and that one looked crispy and salty and delicious. Will come back to try other types
author: Jenny Q.

description:
Tiny little place on the inside but they work with what they have really well. Super efficient and can really pump sandwiches out of there. Don't be scared off by a long line. There are no seats at all so plan to eat elsewhere. 

I got the corned beef sandwich. The bread was the highlight by far. Really amazing flavor, texture and depth. The cabbage and dressing was solid too. The main course of the sandwich, the corned beef wasn't quite as good. It wasn't bad but I would have preferred more meat and thicker slices like you find on the East Coast. It was still a good sandwich though.  For $12 it was an average value. I'd come back again and try another sandwich since the bread was soooo good.
author: Scott M.

description:
4.5 Stars

Spicy Pork - super tender, flavorful, meaty (can see why it came back by popular demand). Ratio of meat to bread is spot on and the vegetables really brighten up the dish

Overall Thoughts

If I worked in the area I would easily be back at least once a week just to see what they are serving
author: Eddie W.

description: The Sentinel gets it.  Enabling drug addicts is not an act of compassion.
author: Surley G.

description: We were sad to roll up to this place and have them just run out of breakfast sandwiches as it was 10am and we had been up since 4am catching our flight up from San Diego and were starving.  The server offered a free muffin to my young kiddos to share which was a huge gesture and they really enjoyed it.  What kind of place does that?!!  A genuine and legit place...hope we get to try some other fare from this sweet establishment before we leave.
author: Gena L.

description:
Sentinel is a great hidden gem!  I come here for muffins at least twice a week for breakfast.  So far I've tried the blueberry, pear, strawberry, sour cherry and rhubarb.  They are all really good but the sour cherry is the Best!!  

The muffins are a really moist and packed with fruit.
author: Richard G.

description:
From the egg salad to the corned beef to baked goods, I'm kind of in love with this place right now. A haiku....

I was quite hungry
When muffins for Jen's birthday
Made it all okay

I was psyched to find out these delicious muffins were from The Sentinel.
author: Russ S.

description: Great place for lunch. The lines are usually long so head out there early. Their sandwiches are so good! Especially how they made the sesame buns!
author: Yennie L.

description:
Wow! They put the Deli in DELI-CIOUS! 
I finally decided to stop by at this wonderful place after passing by it so many times and smelling the enticing food that just tingles the taste bud senses. No regrets!

I order the corn beef sandwich and paired it with a watermelon-lemonade drink (I believe it was called watermade or something like that). The drink itself had fresh watermelon juice and lemon juice. Simple, yet refreshing on a warm day. As for the sandwich itself it comes out fast! Like Jimmy John's can't touch them fast (could be pre-made, but you won't know the difference). The bread was perfectly toasted and the Russian dressing added a good tang to it. The swiss cheese was melted perfectly and the corn beef was tender and flavorful. As Raj in Big Bang Theory once said, "Sweety and meaty!" Kind of like a cuban sandwich. They also provide a slice of pickle and to top it off an Andes mint chocolate!

Price:
$15 ish for Sandwich and drink.
author: Paul C.

description: Very good, solid sandwiches, though a bit pricey especially $2 for a bag of normal chips. But the quality of the sandwiches are very good. Particularly like the fresh baked rolls they use, really makes the sandwich.
author: David L.

description: Directly across from the Palace Hotel, this is a tiny hole in the wall on the corner near the parking garage. Every day they post the sandwiches that they are making, and as they run out they will put a line through it on the piece of paper on the door. It is kind of fun to go there, the combinations are really good and an usual. My kids every time we come to San Francisco want to go to the Sentinel.
author: M M.

description:
Wow! This place was very good! I came  on a quick lunch break doing some work in the area. I wanted something quick and could eat in my hands while I worked a little as well and The Sentinel fit the bill.

I was a bit intimidated by the line that was about 10 people but I was surprised it went by really quick. As I got into the door and got my  in I retreated to the crowd of people waiting for their sandwiches right outside as well. I got my  super fast,  I literally turned around and looked at my phone for 30 seconds and they were calling my name already. That's some awesome fast service! 

I ordered the corned beef sandwich because I love corn beef and don't believe I've had it before in a sandwich so I was  on how it was going to be also many of you Yelpers seem to recommend it as well. The sandwich was absolutely one of the best sandwiches I had ever had. They toast the outer side and it is definitely the highlight of the sandwich. The corned beef however was a little dry for me but with taking a bite with the whole sandwich together was pretty balanced.

I love that they give you an Andes with your sandwich to finish your meal with.
author: Daniel Q.

description:
The Sentinel is home of San Francisco's best muffin tops!

This place is mostly known for their sandwiches but many people do not know that they also serve muffins and coffee in the morning! Since I work right around the corner, grabbing a muffin is a positive carbby way to start the day - especially after a frustrating and delayed BART commute. 

They usually only have 1 or 2 flavors available - blueberry being the staple muffin flavor. So far I've tried blueberry, pear, apple, and squash. Believe it or not, although I love pear muffins, the squash is my favorite by far. It has a warm, sugary, hearty taste, perfect for those cold mornings in the FIDI. 

Protip: bring exact cash so you can bypass the cashier and pay the baker in case there is a line
author: John L.

description: Roast beef sandwich was bland. No Zip to it at all. Roast beef was rare & fresh but not seasoned. Bread was super soft and fresh, so was the lettuce...problem was the sandwich didn't have much taste or flavor at all. I think they need to season the food, kosher salt on black pepper on the beef, worst part was the Horseradish had zero heat or spice. I ate half and gave the other half away. Maybe it was just an off day. Who knows.
author: Kevin K.

description:
The first time I went here I got this really tasty soup! It wasn't super soupy...more like a curry. Chick peas and other things (vegetarian) curry flavor over rice. Came with this huge piece of dense wheat bread that was pretty good. $7

I came here again today and got their special of the day and was so disappointed! Poke over rice. It didn't seem like the type of place that would pull of poke but I thought what the hey. Sounded good. Ugh, so wrong!! SO many tomatoes. It was all tomatoes. I could hardly find any poke. And it was a weird mixture of flavors: Mexican type ingredients (tomato, avocado, cilantro, chilis) with a mediterranean type of rice, and then the poke. I'm just not sure those 3 cuisines go together. $12

Signing off,
Sad & still hungry
author: Kelly G.

description:
Pretty delicious sandwich place in downtown but make sure you go there early. They sometimes run out of food if you come in late, like after 1pm. 

It's also nice that they always give you a free mint chocolate. Small gesture but makes me smile :)
author: Joseph L.

description:
The sandwiches are the bomb diggity! 

Long lines (especially during weekday lunch) is a huge indicator for its amazing quality! Also-- fret not, the lines move so quick! The ladies running the line know what they're doing! 

I've tried the egg salad (YUM), corned beef (they are famous for this for a reason!), and my favorite is the cuban! The bread to filling ratio is just totally on point! 

My favorite end to this as a lunch option is the small Andes mint they include with each order. How sweet. (:
author: Maggie Y.

description: Went on a Monday afternoon around 12:30. There was a short line that moved fairly quickly. It's counter service only with no seating. The cashier was friendly. I ordered the grilled eggplant sandwich and pomegranate juice for a total of $12. They ran out of mozzarella so substituted it with goat cheese. Overall the sandwich was okay. The bread was dried out and the eggplant was all the sides with the skins. With the skins on, its impossible to bite into without the sandwich falling apart. It's not a place I would return to or recommend to anyone.
author: J P.

description:
Lunchtime FiDi/SoMa sandwich staple with the lines of hungry workers to prove it.

Really decent sandwiches with an evolving menu. I really like their salmon sandwich. I believe it's a combination of smoked and baked salmon mixed into a fennel salad. It's got a really interesting texture with the different chunks of salmon and the flavors marry well together. Also love that the bread holds up to all the fillings well. Also really like the roast beef sandwich. It's such a classic combination of pretty rare slices of beef with onions and horseradish. The sandwiches here fill you up without holding you down. 

Expect long lines at lunch but you can beat the crowds a little if you arrive before noon. Plus you get first dibs at what you want before items start selling out.
author: Jon L.

description: We walked to The Sentinel for lunch while in San Fransico for work. You wait in line, outside, since it's taken out only. The building is super small with just a counter to place an order with the kitchen behind. There were about 10 people in front of us, but we only waited maybe 7 minutes before we were able to place our order. I choose the Ruben Sandwich with Russian Dressing and Swiss cheese, a side of chips, and a watermelon lemonade. Our orders were ready within a couple minutes. My sandwich was HUGE! Lots of meat and cabbage and the bread was thick. I actually had to just eat the meat and cabbage because the bread was that big. It had good flavor for take-out. The watermelon lemonade actually just tasted like watermelon juice, and I didn't care for that at all. Overall, it was a quick & tasty take out lunch!
author: Leeann C.

description:
Bomb oatmeal. 

If you want a sandwich for lunch don't wait too long, they will sell out.
author: Jonathan K.

description:
So you think your closet makes good sandwiches? Well, you haven't had a good closet sandwich until you've had a sandwich from The Sentinel. Which is the size of a closet. And makes sandwiches. 

The menu is short, the line is long (but moves fast), and the sandos are tasty. That's pretty much what you need to know. There's no reason you should be going to any of the chain places around here if you're going for a sandwich. That's a waste of time. Go here instead.
author: Don B.

description:
Went to The Sentinel again for lunch today. Figured I should finally write a review.

First off, don't expect to be able to eat inside here. The lineup goes outside the building, along the alleyway, which is only an issue when it rains.

I ordered the Cuban sandwich today, which was a great. The pork, cheese and mustard combo was exactly what I was looking for after the weekend. My only gripe with the meal is that you now have to ask for pickles (make sure you do!), instead of receiving them by default. At $11 a sandwich, this is a nice treat every couple of weeks.
author: Rajeev S.

description:
I've been working in the city for about 7-8 months now and each day I like to randomize a restaurant on Yelp to which I look at the pictures and just order what seems to be the most popular item - at the Sentinel, such was the roast beef sandwich.

This warm, sandwich which I carried all the way back to my workplace (a quick 5 minute walk, actually, very beneficial for those who work on Market St.!) and sat down to enjoy this. The first bite shows the absorbency of the bread they use as the barely structurally-sound sandwich made its way into my face. Roast beef was smoky, chewy, beefy and the Russian sauce that came with it was not overbearing at all. It did justice to the veggies on my sandwich and it left and for that, I thank it.

Thank you, Sentinel, for providing me a delicious roast beef sandwich for lunch. I'll be back for the rest.

p.s. the cashier working lunch today was really, really cute but also a super friendly staff member!
author: Brian L.

description:
Came on a Thursday afternoon around 12:15 pm - the line was maybe 5 deep, but moved very quickly. The menu is pretty short: 3-5 cold sandwiches, a few hot ones, and a few salads. Not in the mood for a corned beef sandwich or something heavy, I scanned the menu and (without paying too much attention to descriptions) ordered the B.A.L.T. ($9.25). 

A California spin on the classic BLT, right? So, so wrong. It should be illegal to use or repurpose the "BLT" acronym unless you're building off of the holy trinity of Bacon, Lettuce, and Tomato. 

Sentinel's BALT is a Basil, Avocado, Lettuce, and Tomato sandwich on a doughy roll with a heaping spread of cream cheese and a horrifying amount of mayo on it. From the first bite this was a nightmare of a sandwich - I saved half for my bf, who also didn't finish it. If you'd like the rest of it, it's still sitting in our fridge, decomposing into a cream-cheesy, mayo-soaked wad of wilted basil and sadness. 

One star extra for the free pickle spear, the Andes mint, and what looked like a decent corned beef sandwich ordered by my coworker. Pickles aside, I don't plan on returning - $10 is better spent elsewhere.
author: Laura B.

description:
Five stars for the quality of the sandwiches. When I'm looking for lunch places, I want a combination of good quality for the price. By this, I mean I want a meal under $10 that will be of decent quality and a decent portion. 

Sentinel sandwiches are a little pricey, but the portions are very generous. I'm giving it four stars because the portions are a little too big for me and as a result, the price is a little steep for me. You get what you pay for, but the food always gives me food coma for the afternoon. That's why I tend to stay away unless I want the same sandwich for lunch and dinner. 

However, the sandwiches I've had here are some of the best sandwiches I've had in FiDi. They always pack it full of filling. I've tried both the deviled egg sandwich and the Vietnamese pork shoulder. They change their menu based on the season so the sandwiches are not always available. 

I love deviled eggs and the sandwich did not disappoint. I would totally recommend it too if you like deviled eggs. The Vietnamese pork shoulder was also very delicious. The pork shoulder is flavorful and tender and the fillings of jalapeños and cilantro and a few other veggies really rounded out the flavor of the sandwich nicely.
author: Lin Z.

description:
What a great find. This little sandwich shop had amazingly fast service & delicious sandwich options. There is no seating so you have to take your food to go. I got the BALT (basil, avocado, lettuce, and tomato) and it was to die for. There was also a generous hunk of cheese (maybe goat?) that tied everything together. 

Remember to ask for a pickle on the side. It's free- but you have to ask. :)
author: Lindsay L.

description: Been eating here since 2013. Great prices. Great sandwiches. My only gripe is they rotate the menu fairly often. Also, they just changed the bread. It's way worse than before. Still 4/5 for me!
author: Matt H.

description:
A sandwich starts with great bread, and Sentinel has this down. In fact, it was my memory of the sandwich I ate last year that drew me from the line at a highly favored neighboring establishment and made me choose The Sentinel for lunch today.

Golden brown, soft, seeded, and slightly sweet and eggy, this roll is the kind of bread I crave. The interior is pillowy soft, while the exterior provides just enough substance to hold in all of the goodness they pack into these sandwiches. The combinations are perfect, and you really can't go wrong with any of them.

Not surprisingly I chose the same sandwich as I had last year, despite trying desperately not to do it. The specials were looking mighty fine but the spicy pork with carrot and celery root slaw looked too tasty to pass up again! That sandwich has a gravitational pull all its own, and it could not be avoided.

Now an artisan sandwich like this deserves a side that measures up, and while Vickies potato chips are good, I opted for the house Cale chips with raisins, hazelnuts, and cumin. Turns out these are more like kale clusters, packed with all the goodness above. They were good, but not the savory accompaniment I had hoped for, though not a disappointment.

The shining star at the end of the meal though are the incredible cookies! They have the perfect texture, have a lot of chew to them, are quite large and are chock full of goodies! 

Mmmm. Since I failed at my mission today, I may have to return again during this trip. This sandwich shop is worth a visit from anywhere in the city. Make a trip and take it over to the gardens nearby to enjoy!
author: Michael T.

description: Boy was this a miss for me! A couple co-workers had recommended this spot for my friend and I, so we decided to give them a try for lunch. We called ahead and ordered the corned beef sandwich. It was ready at 12pm and the short walk from our office was easy enough. We got there paid for our food then brought it back to our lunch room at work. I wasn't too impressed by the look of the sandwich right off the bat. Not only was this sandwich very pricey ($12.00) it wasn't very appealing to the eyes and apparently my tummy (more on that later). The sandwich didn't seem like it had the best meat on it, there was way too much cabbage and the red Russian dressing was way too salty for everything overall. I ate the whole thing still, but immediately regretted it. I must have stayed the remaining four hours of work inside our local bathroom because my stomach did not like what I put in! I know gross, but just saying I probably wouldn't come back here again! There are much better sandwich spots closer and cheaper than this spot!
author: James R.

description:
Got the spicy pork sandwich - it was good, but it was a monster sandwich with lots of bread. I was a bit surprised... and felt that there wasn't as much flavor in the spicy pork as I was expecting. 

I'd love to come back and try the other sandwiches though!
author: Cal C.

description: Their menu is short and straight to the point. The turkey sandwich is amazing! Combined with the cranberry sauce and the fluffy milky bread, this sandwich is definitely a go to option if you work in the area. Line is often out the door and the store is easy to miss (it is at a small corner) but the line goes by fast and it is so worth it. I've also had the pork sandwich as well but to me, personally, it felt s bit heavy and too filling. Still super delicious though! Probably not something I'd get as often as the turkey sandwich.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
Their deviled egg sandwich, omg their deviled egg sandwich. So good! If you are looking for a satisfying, full stomach type of lunch then this place will not disappoint. 

There usually is a line during lunch hours but do not let that scare you away. They work very fast and efficient and it will be your turn before you can decide whether to go with the egg or the chutney sandwich. Have yet to try the latter, but it's definitely on my to-eat list.

They are pretty pricey but around here it's hard to find a place that isn't.
author: Ellen H.

description: The bread here is so soft and delicious. Good sized portions, would visit again.
author: Rachael S.

description: Really good place to pick up a quick lunch on a workday in this area. Even when the line appears a bit long, the turnaround for ordering and picking up your meal is pretty fast. They've got cold/hot sandwiches and salads but so far I've only tried the sandwiches. The corned beef sandwich (hot) and roast beef (cold) are both pretty good. It's a pretty big sandwich which is great because you'll either have leftovers for later in the day or you'll be full for the afternoon stretch of work. They have other cold sandwiches that sound interesting (the pear chutney specifically) that I'll want to try in the future, but usually when I end up here I prefer a hot sandwich - maybe one day!
author: Wayne H.

description: OMG. They have the best coffee cake and muffins, especially the seasonal butternut squash and I don't even like butternut squash.
author: Jen S.

description: Don't let the long lines deter you from coming here!! They're SO fast, my food was out in literally less than 2 minutes after I ordered. The menu is small so they've got a very efficient assembly line in the back going. The lady at the front recommended that I try the corned beef sandwich, so that's what I got. It was delicious!! Definitely on the heavy side, but man that was one flavor-packed sandwich. I was pretty much full after eating the first half so I saved the rest for later. But I would advise to eat the whole thing at once...or get it with someone else to share. After an hour or so, the sandwich starts to get extremely oily/soggy and it's harder to eat (and feels grosser lol). Still tastes great though, but not as good as when its freshly made, of course. I'm looking forward to trying more sandwiches here!
author: Ashley Y.

description:
I think I've made peace with the fact that I will more than likely die before ever trying half of the places that I'm bookmarking on Yelp.  And it certainly doesn't help when friends (*cough*Ruben*cough) post articles like this on my Facebook wall:

http://www.thebolditalic.com/articles/5901-read-this-if-youre-obsessed-with-sfs-sandwiches.  

Another friend (*sneeze*Justin*sneeze*) and I have an ongoing disagreement when it comes to sandwiches.  He loves 'em; I kindabutnotreally feign disgust.

But, in the name of friendship, I'm trying to learn to heart them too.  And what better place to start... than with a list from The Bold Italic??

First Up - The Sentinel!

Thanks to all the tips from fellow Yelpers, Jacque C. and I phoned in an order at 10 AM for pick-up at 11:45 AM.  There was no line when we got there so we paid for our sandwiches and went to look for a place to eat.  

Here's what we got:

1) For Jacque C.
CURRIED EGGPLANT with roasted peppers, tomato puree, green curry, and queso fresco- 8.75  

2) For Me
LAMB AND EGGPLANT with chickpeas, curry and herb pesto- 9.50

This ain't no Subway.  

Yes, you'll eat fresh.  
No, you won't get away with paying $5.
No, they aren't a foot long.

But still.

You might consider splitting one with a friend.  These sandwiches are no joke.  (see photos)  They're hefty (good for doing bicep curls as you walk down Market), and extremely flavorful.  I ate half of my sandwich, and then just the filling on the second half.  The bread was so good, though... what a shame I couldn't save it.  :(

They also pack in a pickle and Andes mint per sandwich.  Very cute surprise.  :)

I'm reading lots of great things about their corned beef so I'll probably be back for lunch some other time.
author: Iona C.

description: Delicious and gigantic sandwich! Great for lunch on the go but this is not a sit-down lunch spot.
author: Nick B.

description: One of the best place I have been to, i stopped there for a quick lunch and the place proved to me that can be done along with great food! Will definitely drop by again if i'm not with my fatty always hungry girlfriend because she will just eat hers and steal mine!
author: John C.

description:
I legitimately come to the Sentinel every day, sometimes every twice a day. They are incredibly efficient, friendly, and clearly know what they're doing. It doesn't hurt that they're in the base of my building.

They make incredible sandwiches. Literally all of them are good, and they sometimes has specials. I had a shepard's pie that blew my mind.

In the mornings, they make excellent muffins but mediocre coffee.
author: Christina S.

description:
I prefer to stop by here in the morning now, and it's all because of their muffins. Just the right amount of fluffiness and not dry at all. The fruit to muffin ratio is just right - not too much fruit nor too doughy. The sour cherry muffin is my favorite since it is sweet and sour and goes well with a flavored coffee. I have also tried the strawberry, blueberry, peach, and tart apple -  all are good really.

Note for lunch, it is all about the corned beef sandwich. The version with gruyere is so much better so ask for it.

Strictly a to-go spot since there are no seating. It is like a kiosk, and I wish there were seats because I don't like bringing soggy sandwiches back to the office.
author: Peter L.

description: Corn beef sandwich is awesome! Juicy and warm. Great flavorful buns! Haven't tried other hot sandwiches here but those cold sandwiches are not as good as the hot sandwiches. There can be a line sometimes but the service is fast - you can be in and out in 5 mins - a great place for a causal work lunch!
author: Frank W.

description: Simple selection small menu, the best, SF priced (3.50 for a small cup), chai that's worth the cost for the experience but not every day
author: Robin H.

description:
The turkey sandwich was literally just deli turkey slapped on bread and some spread, took the guy 10 seconds to make. I mean, make an effort!

Plus, the online menu is never updated. I walked a mile for this mediocrity. Just sad.
author: Anshul P.

description: Their chicken salad sandwich is legit.  One of the best sandwiches I had in my life. Definitely worth the price of SF food.
author: Rebecca V.

description:
Small hole in the wall joint. Don't let the line outside scare you as it goes very fast. They also take orders online as well so you can pick up and go.

Very good deviled egg sandwich which I loved when I was here about a month ago and I'd come back here to get it again if I want the protein sandwich. 

Today I had the Cuban sandwich which I wasn't impressed with. Maybe it was just me but a little too much mustard on here and the bread isn't the usual for a Cuban. It was pressed tho but if I was allowed to make a substitution then it'd be the bread. It almost seemed like a focaccia type bread which I wasn't fond of. Maybe it's me but that's my 2 cents.
author: Ryan C.

description:
This tiny sandwich spot always intrigued me when I walk to my gym right around the corner and very attempting too for the long line that goes around the block during lunch hour. Today I finally had the time to step in to see what is all the wait is about. To my disappointment, their famous pastrami sandwich was already sold out at 2PM.... So, I went for their Vietnamese BBQ Pork Sandwich. It costs me $10.50. 

The end result you might ask? It was surprisingly good! Does it taste authentic? It doesn't. Still, it is a good sandwich on a dark kaiser roll lightly toasted with nice dressing and damn good BBQ pulled pork. It was also a satisfying portion. I saved half for another day. 

I am excited to return to try their signature sandwich another time, hoping it will not run out!
author: Athena C.

description: Tried their veggie sandwich- it was great! Very fresh ingredients. They had my order pre-packaged and ready to go.
author: Robert B.

description:
If you're in a rush and need to find good food fast, this is a great choice. Located steps from our building, it was super convenient, and although the line was around the corner, we got in and out of there  in under ten minutes.

You order at the counter and they call out your order, and be ready, because this place runs like a well-oiled machine. I'm partial to any of their turkey sandwiches, and the bread is always heavenly.
author: Andrea B.

description:
I love this place. I cannot resist their muffins in the morning, which rotate flavors from day to day. In the fall, there's a butternut squash muffin that sometimes appears which is truly divine. If you go there right when they open around 7:30am, the muffins are hot out of the oven. They're pretty warm even around 9am. A warm, juicy, moist muffin, full of stuff, is a wonderful way to start a morning. Blueberry is my favorite. 

Their lunch is fabulous as well. I enjoy their corned beef sandwich, one of their staples. Their menu rotates daily on lunch as well. Don't be afraid of the lines as they move very efficiently. Service in general is very efficient, so don't get put off if they don't engage in extended conversation. One lady even gave me Berber Credit one morning when I dropped by after finishing a 3-mile run and forgot my cash (credit cards $10 minimum). 

Overall, I think the service is excellent and the food amazing.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
STILL my alltime fav Egg Salad Sandwich (The Deviled Egg), I'm totally loving The Sentinel!

Huge hunks of egg & butter-lettuce w/ a slight kick from delish chili paste - all on a freshly-baked sesame bun.......yum!

This latest visit also had me indulging in their still warm-out-of-the-oven chocolate chip cookie.  Not sure what kind of flour they used - this wasn't like any old Toll House I've ever seen.  Still a bit grainy but not in a bad way, there was texture & gooeyness all at the same time - would def get this cookie again!

If you call ahead of time to place your order, you don't have to wait in the ginormous line.  They start handing out sandwiches around 11:30am so plan accordingly!
author: Adrienne G.

description: Highly recommend this place for sandwich connoisseurs. They have a very simple menu that gives you some great options to choose from. The line moves fast so don't worry about waiting too long. If you're a Subway kind of person, this not for you.
author: Kora O.

description: I ordered the corned beef sandwich ($12) which was unbelievably good. The bread tasted like a cross between toasted challah and corn bread, the meat was well sauced providing a nice tang, and the slaw was the perfect touch. The food was served immediately and the staff were very friendly. Would highly recommend for anyone working in downtown SF and looking for a quick, but well-done sandwich for a brief lunch.
author: Ethan K.

description:
Have to get here before 1:00pm to get their specialty sandwiches. The most popular items run our first so the earlier you get here the better. This is coming from the lady at the register not me! 

I got here at 1:30pm sadly, but there was no line at all! That was nice as I was in a hurry and with every warm sandwich sold out I opted for the roast beef cold sandwich. They popped my order into a brow lunch sack in under 60 seconds. Here's the breakdown:

Bread - reminded me of a Hawaiian sweet roll or brioche. Paired well with the roast beef. 

Meat - rare tender juicy. Generous portion. Brine-y flavor. Lots of pepper grounds that bring out the flavor. Too much meat for my personal taste. 

Other fix-ins - frisée pickled onions and horseradish cream cheese... Made every bite extra juicy! 

Although I didn't get the most popular thing on the menu I enjoyed what I ordered. The quality was clear from the first bite and the portion was huge (I only ate half). I usually opt for the standard turkey, bacon and avo on a dutch roll when I pop into random delis. Overall I still prefer my usual sammy to the hyped Sentinel offers.
author: Manisha S.

description:
Finally got around to trying this place, after sitting in my bookmarks for some two+ years. Hey, like I said, sandwiches aren't something I really seek out anymore. But, coming about a quarter after noon, I was surprised to find that the line was only about five people long, and that it moved very, very quickly.

A few minutes later, I head out with my spicy pork on wheat sandwich, which was, overall, pretty solid: good flavors, a bit (just a bit) of kick, and filling, with half the sandwich enough to tide me over until dinner.

That said, they're definitely on the pricier side, all around the $10 mark. So, imagine how bummed I was when I woke up the next morning, having blacked out the night before, to find that I had left the other half of the sandwich in the microwave and passed out before I had a chance to eat it :(

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A small shop on the corner, without any noticeable seating. You wait in line on the sidewalk, go up to the counter to order, and walk out with your sandwich. Plenty of space inside the shop, so no real accessibility issues here.

Bathroom - Give the aforementioned, I'm not entirely sure they even had a public one.
author: Johnny W.

description: Second best sandwich shop in SF.  Only detractors are its popularity and limited availability of sandwiches. Get there early if you want the roast beef!
author: Chris S.

description:
My coworkers brought me here because they said the sandwiches are fantastic and they were absolutely right. The foccassio bread alone seemed so fresh that I could nibble on it without anything. Then, mine was toooed with chickpeas eggplant and lamb. Imagine you've hit Mediterranean food heaven on a sandwich. I usually stop after the sizable half yet my gluttonous tummy made me scarf down the second half just as quickly!! 

Most sandwiches are $10-12. Pretty good portion if you're starving, gluttonous, or if you want to split with a friend!
author: Shubhra S.

description:
They do it right here. Long lines, but a short wait. Small menu, but well done. If these sammies were Domino's pizzas, I'd totally b*ng em. Wait, no. Nope. Wouldn't do that. 

Anyway... My go-to 'wich here is the not-too-salty or dry corned beef on rosemary with cabbage, Swiss and Russian. Extra props for just placing the raw cabbage on top and not making it slaw in addition to the Russian. Adds a nice crunch. Drool. Yum. I asked my buddy to hold my phone for a second and then ate some of his sandwich after I finished mine. Yep, MI6 sandwich agent here. Stealth. 

My only complaints...
-No water. Only lemonades :/
-Pork n figs was a bit dry :/

Need a quick lunch? Want to eat outside or in your office? Do it.
author: Drew A.

description:
I confess. 

The sentinel made the best sandwich I've had in a long time. 

Being from the east coast and even worse being Italian I was finally not disappointed or left with the feeling I just paid $10 for crap. 

The line out the door moves very quickly along, the girl immediately took my order and I waited street side. 

I ordered the capicola with fresh mozzarella. The description just didn't do it justice. Fresh romaine lettuce, a peppery pepper spread, melted and crispy Parmesan on the top of the bun. Dear lord was the capicola melt in your mouth peppery good. The mozzarella wasn't some kind of gimmick either, it was the fresh made in a steel bowl that day soft goodness one freaks out over. 

Needless to say, this was the best sandwich I've had in 2015.
author: Andrew T.

description:
Super scrumptious, savory sandwiches from a small shop that does takeaway only. Although there may be lots of people in line, things move along very quickly. You can't go wrong with most anything here, although my favorite is the corned beef hash for the amount of meat they put in and because it's just so sinfully goopy. You might want to have a wet napkin on hand just in case. 

A great choice for quick, delicious takeout in SoMa/FiDi.
author: Vincent L.

description:
It's funny how you can build a relationship with a menu. It's like a game of cat an mouse where someone on the other side of the paper is thinking two steps a head of you, "How are you going to react, if I call it Country Pork, and what you get is..."

In this case, they threw a curveball. And I swung for it.

Finding the Sentinel was easy enough, just a block off Market on New Montgomery (though it can be difficult to navigate via GPS with all the concrete around). And this is much more of a sandwich stand than a restaurant; on the one hand there isn't really anywhere to sit. But even with a line, you're in and out of there pretty quick.

So back to that country pork.

The special sandwich of the day.

Just think--pillowy soft and seeded brioche bun, crunchy and acidic slaw, and smothered in between, a thick slab of rustic pork pâté with chunks of gelatinous bits visible from the sides.

It wasn't bad. It just wasn't what I had in mind.

I think next time I'll try one of their not-so-special sandwiches instead.
author: Tony L.

description: Ordered the lamb, egg plant and chick pea sandwich with curry and pesto - nice hearty portion, really fresh soft bread with a nice sturdy exterior but the filling was underwhelming. I was expecting slices of lamb meat but instead the meat was macerated into very small pieces to the point of not really being able to see the pieces at all. The lamb flavor was there but faint so if you didnt know it was in the sandwich, you might have overlooked it all together. There was a noticeable spiciness to the filing but it was also overly salted.  Had the salt not been an issue, this would have been a fantastic sandwich.
author: Julia K.

description:
4 stars for this small corner sandwich maker

I was able to sample there corned beef sandwich, the bread was dense enough to hold all the moisture in from the slices of corned beef and slaw, there was an orange sauce that I could not decipher but on a whole the sandwich was very filling, 1/4 of a full pickle was given in a plastic baggie also...? 

Let me go into a bit more detail, the bread was good, flat bread kinda reminded me of mediterranean bread where the outside is a tad coarse but the inner portion was soft like a cake, good choice for holding all the moisture in from the sandwich, in between the bread slices was several slices of corned beef neatly stacked, helpful amount, salty, tender, juicy, the slaw added was good tasted tadly pickled but not overpowering, again there was some orange sauce that dripped from the sandwich that I could not decipher, on a whole decent sandwich I will need to come back for the lamb sandwich if not few of their other options

if you are in the area definitely something you want to try, if you do not get there before 12 noon expect to wait more then 10 min

food **** decent sandwich
price $$ 10bucks for the corned beef sandwich
service **** quick, efficient
ambiance *** walk in one door place your order then walk out the other side, no seating available, definitely place for pick up and go
author: Clarence A.

description:
If you don't like Disneyland then The Sentinel may strike a nerve. The line is like the bathrooms at an under port-a-pottied Jimmy Buffet concert. That being said, if you've got longer than a half hour for lunch they do a pretty amazing sandwich. 

It's a small but creative menu with slight twists on some classics and unique flavor combos such as lamb and eggplant or pear chutney and cheddar. 

Despite the sometimes lengthy lines they do a decent job running through 'em and you're only looking at about $10 for a pretty awesome lunch so overall it's a solid choice amongst all the lunch options in the area.
author: Danny W.

description:
In the search for the SF's greatest sandwich, I happily found myself here grabbing pick up for a work lunch. It's a take out only spot, and lines can be long, but if you heart sandlers it's worth the wait. 

Had I not had Ike's on the same trip, this would likely be a five star establishment. But I did, sorry (not sorry), Senny. 

I had the deviled egg salad on a big ol' soft bun. It was huge, dilly and delicious. It comes with a tiny pickle in a plastic bag. Nice touch.
author: Evelyn A.

description:
Best fast sandwiches in the city. Would eat here every day if it weren't for "being healthy" or "not gaining a million pounds".

Fixed menu every day with a few awesome sandwich options. I would marry the Cuban sandwich if I were already committed to my lovely wife.

Cookies you can pass on. Drinks too.
author: Will C.

description:
My dad has a sentiment he utters often. He just can't understand why the lunch rush seems to be a 'surprise' to some fast food joints. He makes an excellent point. I think the owners of The Sentinel must have a dad who hammered that same point home. 

The only waiting happens in line. Once you order and pay, your sammy is ready to go. I mean, I think I waited something like 22 seconds from payment to sandwich in hand, ready to roll. Impressed. 

I ordered the pork and figs with escarole and manchego on wheat. The sandwich was large, with the meat stacked high, with yummy condiments that were a perfect fit. 

For those of you watching your waistline: see if you can share with a fellow co-worker. It is plenty of food to share, especially if you want to also split chips or a cookie.
author: Julie S.

description:
I love the Sentinel! It's a hidden gem that is easy to miss if you're rushing down New Montgomery street but I would highly recommend you slow down and stop in! The Sentinel is a tiny, quaint spot on the corner that creates delicious muffins and sandwiches (these are the only things I've sampled on the menu, but I keep coming back for more!). 

The muffins are big, freshly made, and sell out quickly. I've had the blueberry muffin and the apple cinnamon muffin, which are both so good. I'd like to try more flavors but they do sell out pretty fast.

The corned beef sandwich, which comes as a warm hot sandwich, is a personal favorite of mine that keeps me coming back. It comes with Swiss cheese and Russian dressing (and a pickle!) and is quite filling. If you time your visit right, you won't have a wait at all, but make sure to go early enough or right after the lunch rush to ensure they still have them and haven't sold out for the day. I also love that they have a special lunch that changes daily so you know it's fresh. Friendly staff and not bad prices either - really great option if you're in FiDi!
author: Frankie I.

description:
Get there early! By 11:30am the line starts out the small corner.  The sandwiches are hot right off grill. Bread is fresh. Staff super fast and efficient.  Interesting ordering system using post it's!  Swipe your cc sign on the iPad. Your set to go.  Don't go far cause the call your name out when rose is ready.

Go out and get your fix !
author: Brian W.

description:
I've eaten here twice in the past week - I think that makes me a fan!  

I had the hot corned beef sandwich on my first visit.  It was good, but not great.  I really don't like focaccia bread, so maybe I should have known better or asked for a different bread - but my biggest complaint was the blandness of the toppings.  The meat, however, was great.  

On my second visit, I decided to try the cold roast beef sandwich.  This is THE BOMB.  Again, really high-quality, delicious meat - perfectly rare - and then the various toppings are great.  In this case, I'm glad the toppings aren't super bold because the horseradish sauce isn't overpowering.  I also really like the soft roll it's served on.  

I think I'll continue to be a customer here, although I need to start going earlier so I can try these strawberry muffins that they're always sold out of by lunchtime!

P.S. Make sure to ask for a pickle to go in your order - they're a nice half sour variety!
author: Tay H.

description: Only words  I can say is I'm in LOVE with their cheesesteak and blueberry muffins. Get one are both you will not be sorry. REALLY!!!
author: Linda S.

description: Sandwiches are still the bomb, but a word of caution: they don't start selling 'em until 1130am.  Yes, the website sez 730am.  But I went by @1030 and was told 11130.  Snif!  Still worth the wait!
author: Chet M.

description:
The Sentinel seems to be loads of locals go-to for a quick lunch option. And while I throughly enjoyed the efficiency in which the employees here move people in and out; I appreciate the consistency in quality they seem to have mastered; I dig the reasonable prices for the quantity of food (I should have shared my sandwich with someone else, because there was too much for me to handle); but, in the end, I'm not a huge fan of the sandwiches themselves. 

Vegetarian options seemed a bit sparse: I could either order the Deviled Egg Salad (egg salad with chili paste) or the Spicy Roasted Cauliflower (with curry, raisins, and goat cheese). I had no basis of comparison for the Cauliflower option, nor were there any solid reviews about it (let me summarize everyone else's thoughts for you here: "it's good", "It's what I ordered," or "I could make this at home"), so I went with the Deviled Egg. 

If you like classic, old school, basic, no frills egg salad that tastes like every other egg salad you've ever eaten in your life... this sandwich is for you.

If you are excited at the prospect of a spicier egg salad with some serious heat to it because of the mention of chili paste... this sandwich is not for you at all.

(The Sentinel's explanation of it is misleading; there's no heat - not even a crackle of black pepper - in any bite. Talk about disappointment. However, each bite did make me nostalgic for elementary school lunches, so there's that.).
author: Steff D.

description: You can tell that a sandwich is probably good when eating it makes you feel a little ashamed.
author: Jim M.

description: I really really love the Vietnamese pork shoulder sandwich here. The pork is super tender and I think the lime zest is a really nice touch! Don't fear if there's a long line, it moves incredibly quick. I've never seen anyone make sandwiches this fast. I've also tried the spicy cauliflower curry soup which is also really delicious! The corned beef sandwich I didn't like, though, because I find the russian dressing too overpowering. Sometimes they'll carry these kale granola bite things (it'll say 'Eat kale, die anyways' on the package) and if you're lucky to see them you should pay an extra few bucks and try them, too. But don't expect your life span to extend.
author: Andrew D.

description:
I was in the rare opportunity of grabbing lunch on a weekday in SF, so I had to stop by this place to try it. There was a line about 10 people, but I ordered, paid, and received my sandwich in only 5 minutes. The turnaround time is ridiculous here.

I ordered the corned beef hash since it seems to be one of their most popular sandwiches and I'm sure glad I did. It was quite filling for a sandwich.

I didn't like that the sandwich bread was oily, but thankfully the vegetables weren't too pickled. I'll definitely come back here for lunch.
author: Edward W.

description:
Corned beef sammie, I must have you again...

Layers upon layers of warm, tender, perfectly cured beef complimented by gruyère and tucked between freshly baked focaccia. Cabbage adds a refreshing crunchiness. You get one of those Andes chocolate mints with your 10 dolla sandwich too. They're fast, only took a few minutes for me to get my food. Good thing I came before noon because a line started forming as I left. It's a hole in the wall with no seating so I snarfed my sandwich down at Crocker Galleria. 

My poor lunch date watched me with remorseful eyes as she picked at her salad.
Tastes so good, make you wanna slap yo momma!
author: Jenny Q.

description:
What is this line for? We shall see...

***CORNED BEEF with cabbage, Russian dressing and Swiss cheese

I wasn't particularly impressed with this sandwich as I was consuming it, but upon reflection it was actually pretty good, at least above average in the boring world of the sandwich. The focaccia-like bread was soft and satisfying. The corned beef was chunky and sufficiently moist. The cabbage was a bit boring--it should've been pickled or something. The Russian dressing was a nice touch, but the Swiss cheese was barely noticeable, which is a bummer because it really should've been the star of the show. 

All in all it was generally positive experience in a kinda meh way.
author: Elliott D.

description:
Had the smoked trout salad. It did not have much flavor, relying mainly on the relatively rare pieces of smoked trout, which seems to over power the banality of the greens. It left me wanting.
I guess I'm not a salad guy. Should've stick to trying the sandwich itself the next time.
author: Sonny W.

description:
Friday lunch date with my husband, as we continued our efforts at eating "low carb": we skipped the sandwich offerings and instead got the chicken salad (with gigante beans, guacamole, tortilla strips) and the salmon salad (with asparagus, potatoes, peas). 

We both thought the chicken salad was tastier, with its tender chicken, spicy guacamole, and creamy gigante beans. But the salmon salad was also very good- I kept thinking, wow, they made this with a lot of care. The varied greens included frisée and mint (not something you see every day), and the salmon and potato were both cut into tiny cubes, to match the peas. Just ... really carefully done, was my impression. 

My husband really enjoyed the fresh, cold lemonade (though I would have preferred it less sweet/more sour), especially as we were out in the sun at the 1 Kearny rooftop "popo", and our complimentary Andes mints totally melted as we split the complimentary hunk of flavorful wheat bread. 

Lastly, we had a very sweet/nice touch from the cashier, as she gave us a free cookie (a large sugar cookie with a jam thumbprint). My husband was surprised and then happy and thoughtful: "wow, that one gesture made such a difference. Now I'm going to tip them and write a Yelp review." Beat him to it! 

The menu items are a wee bit pricey- lunch for two (2 salads, 1 lemonade) came to $27- so I'll continue to think of this spot as a "once in a while" destination for lunches during the workweek. But I dig this place because the menu is both unique and ever-changing, and I really appreciate the extra touches (pickle, chocolate mint). Despite the fact that it shows up on the first page of Yelp results, it still feels a bit "locals only". "Yay! I'm a fan" sums it up entirely.
author: S R.

description:
I was so hungry when lunch time for me at 1:30pm came around!  It was a late lunch than the usual 12 noon so when I got here, there was no wait to get my order in and my sandwich packed to go quickly.

I got their pulled pork sandwich and I am more on the unsatisfied side of the spectrum.  It was a good sandwich, but the pulled pork was too dry to my liking.  The bread was not toasted or crisp and the light sauce used for additional flavor for the pulled pork was not special or memorable.  They provide a quarter of a dill pickle, which helps with the dryness of the pulled pork...I guess.

$9 was pretty pricey for a sandwich that was NOT above average and for a normal sized one - the size reminded me and looked like a burger patty.  They didn't pack the sandwich with thick layers of pork goodness, which I usually favor! 

No dining area either!  I have to go somewhere else to enjoy my sandwich! How inconvenient.

Overall, my 9 bucks could have been spent on a better, more flavorful sandwich!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I'm here from Ohio for my second time for a convention and rather than having the "provided lunch" for the convention, I wanted something local. That's the only way to roll in another city.

While everyone else is eating what is most certainly quality food and listening to some "Awards" speech BS, I ran over to the liquor store, grabbed me a small bottle of Jameson for later tonight (okay, a little with lunch, too) and then ran into "Sentinel" ....although I saw a lot of "Cigar" signs, I saw people with containers while a lovely aroma wafted out the door. Unless their cigars smell of delicious meat, they had to have food, right? 

Right in the door is a little printed menu with several fine sounding sammiches. I quickly eyed a corned beef, and a spicy pork. I only had seconds to decide. Holy smokes they're fast! I went with the spicy pork. It comes on some sort of cool pretzel looking bread along with a healthy stack of stringy carrot cole slaw type stuff.

For me, this could definitely be spicier. If I had some hot sauce I'd be slapping it on. But I don't, and I do like things overly spicy. But I give 4/5 because it's really damned good. It's a lovely mix. And there's a pickle that is garlicky. Awesome. AND they gave me a little Andes mint AND I LOVE THOSE DAMN THINGS!

Super friendly - super good - I like these people and this place. I may come to this convention again next year just so I can try their corned beef!
author: Michael S.

description: I had high expectations for this place because of the Yelp reviews, but I thought my lamb and eggplant sandwich was just okay. I usually love saucy sandwiches, and I love curried flavors, but I wasn't really into the flavor combo. The main flavor profile coming through to me was tomato sauce, and the crunchiness of the chickpeas didn't work well with everything else. The bread it was served with was absolutely amazing though, so I feel fairly confident that this is a solid place for sandwiches; I just wasn't that impressed with my particular order.
author: Lily T.

description: I wanted quick breakfast and that's certainly what I got coming to Sentinel. I was craving something more savory like eggs but they only have 5 options for breakfast; 2 different muffins and yogurt + fruit combos. More variety would be nice but I enjoyed the grape, strawberry and granola yogurt with honey that I got. It was $6 and a good amount.
author: Sheereen S.

description:
Still my lunch spot everyday!
They do change their recipe a lot! Chicken salad has changed to avocado version other than mango spicy version before. Pork sandwich has changed to BBQ pork shoulder sandwich other than spicy pork before. But still tastes good! Even daily special items, they also changed recipe by adding some food ingredients into the salad or soup. For some items, they even taste better than before. Btw, food price goes up by $1-1.5, but same or even better quality. It is worth every penny I spend on!
author: Nina H.

description:
Not your average sandwich shop. The Sentinel has an awesome menu of gourmet hot and cold sandwiches.

I'm particularly impressed by the Vietnamese pork shoulder sandwich. Besides being really tasty, it manages to be light and refreshing. It reminds me of a banh mi version of a tuna salad sandwich or something. 

Deducting a star because the Cuban sandwich was pretty average. Can't wait to try other sandwiches on the current and future menus, and see if their lemonade tastes as good as their iced tea.
author: Sara M.

description:
What a find.

I attended training on New Montgomery recently and due to time constraints on my lunch hour, I choose not to stray too far away in order to avoid the inevitable humiliation of walking in late and having the rest of my classmates and teacher throw me the evil eye.

This sandwich shop is truly a gourmand's great find.

Located on the busy corner of New Montgomery and Stevenson, the layout is simple = walk in from the left and walk out the right.  The flow of traffic is inherent except in that one must/should be in line about 15 minutes before noon otherwise the sandwiches are sold out or you will be in line a lot longer than 15 minutes.  

The sandwich list is short yet famously fortuitous.  So far, I have had the Corned Beef (thick cut corned beef with cabbage/onions and mustard) and the Deli Ham with Gruyere cheese.  Both of these were on their wheat bread which is perfect for those looking to cut down on processed carbs.  These are not your average sandwiches so do expect a not average price for a sandwich. Do, however, be prepared for the amazing thick slab of baked starches plating warm juicy corned beef that is as good as the carving hot from the boiling pot on St. Paddy's Day.  The Deli ham sandwich was holding its own :  2 inches thick with savory ham.  The Gruyere cheese will pack the final wallop to the taste buds.  I added in a bag of kettle chips from a nearby shop and headed straight to the public rooftop across the street.

Try a Zagat rated sandwich.

Your palate will thank you.
author: Miika M.

description: Spicy pork sandwich is tasty and a good size. Not huge, but the right size. It's NOT pulled pork, it's more like pork slices, but still tastes great. VERY FAST service as mentioned many times.
author: David S.

description:
I was so happy to discover this place a few days ago - I've already gone twice.  

I had the house chicken salad of the day and they even made it into a sandwich per my request.  The lamb and eggplant is also fantastic.  I recommend this for quick pick up sandwiches that will shake up your routine.  Be warned that they run out of the specials pretty early so don't wait!
author: Dean I.

description:
I've only had the meatball and roast beef sammies, but I get them because they are always good.  The meatballs are HUGE and in a nice tomato sauce.  You get a big portion of roast beef and it's very tender.  Still haven't tried the corned beef, but that's because I usually order one of my "go to" sammies.  

Went here the other day to try their breakfast items and what a treat it was.  Had the blueberry and strawberry muffins.  They were loaded with fresh blueberries and strawberries inside and served hot.  Also had what might be the best coffee cake I've ever had.  It was Heaven!!  Also had the lemon pound cake, which was also very good.

The sammies are a bit pricey, but the portions are good size.  If you need a breakfast item, go early since they run out.
author: Lon H.

description: Early worm gets the fish!  I ordered the smoked trout sandwich for pick up using Eat 24 app around 1 PM and received a text about 5-10 minutes later that the shop was out of that sandwich.  So I texted back if I could have the hot corned beef sandwich instead and started walking the half mile from my office not knowing if that would be acceptable or not via text.  On my way there I received a text that my order was ready so I thought that either way I was going to have something to eat right away.  Now to the sandwich, I received the hot corned beef and it was hot and tasty with a good amount of meat and accouterments.  Apparently focaccia bread is the thing in SF which was a pleasant surprise to me.  Good service on the pick up and from Eat 24 and a good sandwich for lunch.  Next time I'll order or get there earlier to get the smoked trout.
author: Eric N.

description: I knew this place had to be good with the consistent line out the door everyday for lunch!  I tried the corned beef sandwich - it was so yum!  The flavors come together and I was instantly a fan of this place at first bite!  I also tried the pork shoulder sandwich - mind you, I had it a little later in the day for dinner, but it was still super yummy!  I initially intended to stop eating it halfway to save some for my bf later, but uh that didn't happen as it was just too yummy!  I will get him one another day!  :)  I will be back, oh I will be back!  And I just saw you can order online here on Yelp for pick-up or delivery - woohoo!!  Even better!!
author: Maile N.

description:
I loooove this place to itty bitty bread crumby pieces. Now that I've literally tried all their sandwiches, I can say this: EVERY SINGLE ONE IS DELICIOUS!!! The moment I get to work I am daydreaming about which sandwich to get for lunch. Am I in a meaty mood? Their seasonal lamb meatball is out of control good. Especially with that fluffy sesame brioche bun that mops up the gravy oh-so-perfectly. Beef of the corned and roasted varieties are solid staples. If you're in a veggier mood, the deviled egg is among my top 3 - generous hunks of whole egg, wonderfully stuck together by devilly mustardy goodness. Curried cauliflower with goat cheese also phenomenal. 

Their fresh-baked bread is really worth a separate paragraph. Whether it's their sesame bun, focaccia, or whole wheat, it's always fluffy, warm, and good to the last crumb. 

The service is quick & efficient, and prices are great for the area. Even if the line is down the block, you'll have your sandwich in no time! Guess where I'm going for lunch today!
author: Carol C.

description:
The sandwich I had was tasty. The bread was soft, the goat cheese fresh, but when they say BBQ Eggplant, they meant some eggplant smothered in BBQ sauce. Like I said, didn't taste bad, service was fast, but I was sadly disappointed because it seemed a little hyped for such a small spot (if you come during the lunch rush the line goes to half the block), and I just wanted more in the actual dish. It was definitely not an amazing sandwich, but the price was ok and I didn't regret eating it. Sorry I can't say how much I loved it, I wasn't expecting to have a BBQ sauce sandwich with a side of eggplant and cheese. Oh there was a piece of lettuce on it. Man I wanted more lettuce. Maybe some onion? IDK. Would I eat it again, sure. Would I go out of my way for it? No. If I'm on the block I'd probably go get something more substantial half a block over.

TL;DR
It's ok. Don't go out of your way. Order ahead on yelp to avoid waiting in line.
author: Astrid V.

description: three stars for the sandwich, the veggie option (goat cheese, heirloom tomatoes, butter lettuce, and artichoke hearts), because i felt skimped on all those delicious ingredients. all bread. but five stars for a message on the menu: "middlemen are thieves."
author: Ronny K.

description:
They serve fast and delicious sandwiches here. My dad and I got the spicy pork sandwich and corned beef sandwich to share. 

Corned beef: 4/5. If it's your first time, I definitely recommend getting the corned beef. The focaccia bread melted in your mouth, the corned beef was perfectly cured, and the cabbage added great texture. Definitely would get this sandwich again. It also came with a pickle and a mint chocolate.

Spicy pork: 3/5. It's good, but boy was it messy. Be sure to have a lot of napkins with you. The pork was sliced thin and dipped in a tangy buffalo chicken wing sauce. The celery root and carrot coleslaw added a nice crunch. The layer of mayonnaise was just extra calories in my opinion -- it didn't add anything to the sandwich. Another Yelper had mentioned that their spicy pork sandwich was cold and mine ended up being the same as well, which was disappointing. The pork was also not spicy at all. 

This place is small and easy-to-miss so keep your eyes open! They also don't have any seating so have some place to go to eat it. They don't have many drink options,  just coffee and lemonade (regular and pomegranate flavored). Overall a great place to get a quick bite!
author: Hana K.

description:
They are one for two for me as of two tries. The first one was the spicy pork sandwich, which turned out to be a delicious monster sandwich and practically flew out of the tiny back kitchen just as I was paying; it was almost like magic! 

Well that had me hooked. So when I went back, I had the corned beef sandwich, that was served between two thick focaccia slices. Unfortunately, unlike the pork sandwich, the corned beef was very thinly layered. Maybe because like 5 people ordered that same sandwich in a row that the kitchen was trying to make all the sandwiches with a limited amount of corned beef.

The flavor was good, but the ratio of meat to bread was way in favor of the bread. The small half pickle was good, but for $10 (and that was more than the spicy pork sandwich) this was not a very good value.

I'll try them again for sure. Service was as usual, very prompt and polite but the quality of each sandwich apparently varies depending on the day.
author: Glenn H.

description: Hot corned beef sandwich is phenomenal!  Need I say more?
author: Sameer R.

description:
From both a recommendation and a reference in a bold italic article, The Sentinel had been on my mind to try recently. Given that it is only open on weekdays for lunch, we met up at their shop around 12:30 on a Tuesday afternoon. While there was a small line, it moved incredibly quickly and we had our order placed in no time at all.

Roast beef sandwich - 2/5 - From the cold selection, this seemed like the best option to try. It made a special note on the menu that the beef was rare in this sandwich, although none of the meat in ours was pink at all. It was all brown. The taste was average for this item and was definitely overpowered by the horseradish slathered on. I thought the beets were a strange addition and did not contribute much to the flavor, although they did alter the consistency considerably. I wouldn't order this again.

Spicy pork sandwich - 3/5 - Although, I'm fairly certain that the flavor of the sauce here was mostly sriracha, it did turn out decently enough to enjoy. There is a good amount of pork here mixed in with a bunch of shredded carrots on the same bun that the roast beef came on. This bun is definitely quality bread added a lot to the taste. Eating this item was very messy and it easily fell apart, which is fine with me. Although good, I wouldn't order this again.

Corned beef sandwich - 4/5 - This is the reason you will come to The Sentinel and for a few reasons it is quite impressive. One reason is that it is served on their house baked focaccia bread which is delicious. Secondly, the size of this is quite large and is served in a separate takeout container which it fills completely. The corned beef itself was good, but not the best I've had in the city. It is all mixed in with some russian dressing and cabbage. If I were to come here again, this is what I would order.
