Overall, The Sentinel was mostly good and I enjoyed my meal here. I'm interested to see what other sandwiches they rotate in over time, although their limited hours may prevent me from finding out. "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description:
This place is crazy fast. Don't be intimidated by the line at lunchtime. The lines are as long as Sushirrito on the next block but somehow the Sentinel line seems to move several times faster. Really got to applaud the staff here for their organized ordering system and sandwich-making efficiency.

The sandwiches are delicious and hefty. Two of my favorites are the corned beef and cabbage and the spicy pork. Both come with a slightly ridiculous amount of meat and bread, and arguably not a lot of vegetables (oh well!). The sandwiches come with a delicious pickle, which in my wishful thinking counts as a vegetable.

Note that there's no seating so take your sandwich to a nearby park or rooftop (or back to the office) and enjoy! Oh, and don't miss the piece of candy/mint that's usually in the bottom of the bag!
author: Brittany C.

description:
Ohh Sentinel, I have mixed feelings about you.
On one hand, I really enjoy your corned beef sandwich. The beef tastes great and it's super flavorful. Comes with a pickle and Andes mint, that's always good.
Now the bread ... while it is fresh, it's super soft hence it soaked up a lot of the juices and made the bread rather wet. I miss the crunchiness to it.
Besides the corned beef sandwich, all of the other sandwiches and salads taste somewhat flavorless.
Service is a ok ... the line moves pretty fast. But you would still have to wait after paying. If I do come back next time, I'll probably just stop by in the morning to grab the muffins (after reading the reviews, I have high expectations for them now) :/
author: Xin W.

description:
I looked at other reviews that state that it cost $9, but just letting you all know, prices went up. 
Came here to try the corn bread beef sandwich, and it was sooooo good! I talked to my coworker about it, and she stated that when she tried it, it was bloody. She went again the day after and notified me that it was not bloody and it was even better than before. When you are craving a hefty delicious lunch, look no further! 
The shop is a little small and be ready to wait in a line if you don't beat the lunch crowd.
author: Mayra E.

description:
This place is a little corner store that knows how to make a pretty mean sandwich. Having tried most items on the menu at least once, it's definitely the case that few of the items are a lot better than others. The corned beef sandwich has never disappointed. Even though a little salty, its definitely the most delicious. Tons of meat and the sauces add a lot of flavour to it. The sandwich itself is huge but good till the last bite. 

The service is always amazing with the food being ready even before youve had the chance to pay from time to time. For $10 it's totally worth it. 

Don't forget to ask for your complimentary pickle and mint chocolate!
author: Zoher Z.

description: Truly disappointed when I opened up the box to find this. Salmon Salad!? Where's the salmon? Am I missing something? This is my first time ordering this salad here but i have seen other pictures. I had thought there would be like sashimi style salmon on top. Paid $13 something for this (including tip) and they're just all greens. No bueno!!!
author: Len P.

description:
Ah.... YUM. Walked over here about 12:30, hoped I was standing in the right line (which went very quickly), ordered my sandwich while still standing in the doorway, paid immediately and efficiently, waited about 1.5 minutes for my order, and CHOWED down. Lamb and eggplant all mixed together with chickpeas, curry, and an herby pesto on super light and fluffy brioche. Not really what I was expecting?? But awesome all the same. Big sammy too!

And an Andes mint too. Didn't even know they still made those.
author: Laura B.

description:
The Sentinel is one of my favorite hidden gems of the SOMA. I know that this place is very popular as a lunch spot, but did you know they have really good breakfast food?? 

If you work around here or need to pick up a snack for breakfast, be sure to try their MUFFINS! I've tried sour cherry, blueberry, and strawberry, and have to say that their strawberry muffins are the best of tried in my friggen life. Come here for a muffin and a cup of coffee and you will be set for the day!
author: Stephen D.

description:
When I die and go to heaven, they will be serving Sentinel sandwiches. Or, if I go to hell, they will force me to watch other people eating Sentinel sandwiches, while I'm stuck with, I don't know, Quizno's.*

They don't always serve it, but the smoked trout with fennel is my favorite sandwich I have ever eaten or will ever eat. This may sound like an exaggeration. Believe me, it is not. I do not exaggerate. In fact, I have never exaggerated, not once in my entire life. I don't even know what the word "exaggeration" means. That's how little I am exaggerating right now.

* No ill-will to Quizno's. I just chose it here because it's a funny word. Try saying it out loud: Quizno's. See? Ha ha!
author: Greg P.

description:
This is a very efficiently run business but doesn't fulfill the concept of having something for everyone. If you don't like lamb, pork, or corned beef, then you're pretty much out of luck if you want a hot sandwich. Their sandwiches also tend to skew on the richer and heavily-sauced side. If you're into that, this is the place for you.

Don't be intimidated by the long line - you'll be in and out faster than at a fast food joint.
author: Michele L.

description: The Cuban sandwich was made up of two thick slices of bread toasted to perfection on the outside. There was just enough mustard give that kick of sourness. The meat came in thick slices. The cheese was not as stringy as I expected.
author: James S.

description: There are a lot of sandwich shops in SoMa, but this is a standout.  I had the bbq beef sandwich and it may have been the best bbq beef that I've ever had.
author: Cody R.

description:
Hot corned beef sandwich will totally make you feel like you've figured out the meaning of life. 
On a serious side, it's a cheesy greasy generously sized sandwich. Comes with a special secret pickle for those who know the special pickle passphrase.

Bon appetit!
author: Dejana B.

description: The "style chicken salad", which I ordered with no beans, appears to be nachos with beans. $15 in the trash. How does food this wrong and disgusting get 4 stars? Moral of the story is not to trust these folks.
author: Mike D.

description:
Hot Sandwich - Corned Beef with cabbage, Russian dressing and Swiss cheese - 9.00
This sandwich tastes great. 
The bread is crunchy, not too hard, and buttery.
The corned beef is juicy, savory, and a little sweet.
I'm not a fan of cabbage, because it's one of those useless vegetables with nearly no nutritional value. I guess it has a little fiber, but here it adds some crunch and variation to the texture of the sandwich. 
I honestly do not know what Russian dressing is, but it all meshes together very well.

The portions are large. One order of this sandwich contains two of these large squares. By the time I thought to take a picture, I'd already consumed one of them. 
They also come with Andes mints!

The line gets kind of long around noon, but every place worth getting food from is busy around noon. Plus, I think they work pretty fast.

Downside: I think you need to spend at least $10 to use credit card. That's lame-o.
$9 to spend on a sandwich is pricey enough as it is, but I think it's okay to splurge on lunch once in a while especially if it tastes this good.
author: Joy W.

description:
If you are in downtown San Francisco, this is a great place to pick up lunch. They don't have a sitting area - such an inconvenience! But I still give the place five stars because the food is delicious and, if weather is nice, you can sit on the steps where Market, Post, and Montgomery streets meet, just a block away from the Cafe. The daily lunch menu is posted on the window a few minutes before the opening. 

I ordered the crab salad and pudding. The portion was just right, the food was full of delicate flavors. Loved it. I would definitely love to come back.
author: Zuma A.

description:
So good! If you see a long line, don't let it discourage you - it goes really fast. Their deviled egg sandwich is incredible and my longtime favorite.

What they DON'T advertise is their breakfast treats. They have, hands down, the BEST coffee cake I have ever had, and their oatmeal is amazing too. People at my work also rave about their breakfast burrito but I have yet to try it.
author: Jessica S.

description:
The corned beef sandwich is usually really delicious! I come here once every two weeks. The sandwich comes with a pickle and an Andes mint for $10.50. The beef is sliced at the right thickness and lean (I am not a huge meat eater and dislike the texture of fatty foods). The lines will get long during lunch hours but don't be deterred, it goes pretty quick!

This week, I had to take a late lunch and they were about to close. When I brought my sandwich back to the office, I was sorely disappointed! The buns, which are usually toasted just perfect, was oily and had lots of charring. It was bitter and literally left a bad taste in my mouth. I hope it was a one-off!
author: Cookie M.

description: I've heard great things about this place and received many recommendations to try it for lunch. I came here with a colleague on a Friday at roughly 12:30 pm. To our surprise, there was no line so we got to order right away. I ordered the roast beef (rare) sammie with smoked onions, frisee, and horseradish cream cheese.  My order came with 1 pickle in a plastic bag and 2 Andes mint chocolates (sweet!) and was all ready and packed literally within 1-2 minutes of me being rung up.  The description of the rare beef is no joke; the beef was super rare, but I'm not complaining because it was quite tasty! I'm usually very picky about the sandwiches I buy--some are too dry, while others are overly greasy or wet, but this sandwich was just right.  I'd definitely come here again as it is easy to get to from my workplace, and the prices are fair for what you get.  The reason I'm giving 4/5 stars is because despite it being tasty, fast, and affordable, I didn't really find anything too special about this place.  It's a standard sandwich shop, and you get what you pay for.
author: Christal C.

description:
I'm gonna go ahead and let my nerdflag fly for a hot sec here, so bear with me. If you're familiar with the X-Men at all, sandwiches probably aren't the first thing that pops into your head when you hear the word "Sentinel." Instead, maybe you think of Marvel universe's gigantic evil robots, hellbent on destroying mutantkind. Well, obviously, The Sentinel is not a purveyor of enormous purple robots that shoot laserbeams out of their hands, but having superpowers is an absolute necessity to take down one of their sandwiches.

These things are huge. Like, legitimately, terrifyingly, awesomely enormous. Two thick slices of delicious bread, with a mountain of roast beef and deliciousness inside? How could you go wrong?

Well, you can't. I loved every tasty bite of my Sentinel sandwich, which came with super rare, super thing sliced roast beef, a horseradish mayo-type sauce -- or at least, I loved every bite of it I could managed. Which was still less than half because these sammies will blow your mindhole. 

Looking for a sandwich the same width, height, and girth as your head? Look no further! The Sentinel specializes in exactly that: GINORMOUS sandwiches that will leave your wallet just as happy as your stomach. By a lucky mistake, my lunch group also walked away with one of their ooey, gooey, amazingly soft oversized cookies. I know it's pretty much asking the impossible, but you're gonna wanna leave room for a bite or two of one of those puppies.

Great deal, super fast service (it's a walk in, walk out kinda place), and deliciousness to boot? Sentinel, I'll be back, bub.
author: Gretchen F.

description:
They run this spot like a well oiled machine. Although there was a line, there was literally no wait. This is an order and go type lunch spot.

 I got the special: the spicy chicken salad. I wasn't a fan. It was 10-12 pieces of cubed chicken with siracha, seeds and mango over a bed of butter lettuce. It was a real weird combo and frankly just not good. 

Never had a sammy here, but I guess best to stick with those.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: The line is long so it's gotta be good! Right? Sure. Almost every time I'm in San Francisco someone seems to suggest this place for lunch. I mean literally everybody I know seems to love themselves some Sentinel, but to me it's just alright. Sure the sandwiches are super fresh, generously sized and pretty unique but the overall taste leaves much to my tastebuds' imagination. I will say that given the crowd and the fact this place is just a tiny little food stand, they have amazingly super speedy customer service!
author: Helina G.

description:
The Sentinel works well as a fancier lunch sandwich. I haven't been blown away by the vegetarian options, but it's good enough to keep me coming back (usually when I'm grabbing lunch with a meat-eater.)
They only have a few sandwiches to choose from each day and there are usually one or two that are vegetarian. I haven't found one that is "oh my gosh super awesome." There is the BLTA, which has basil instead of bacon. The egg salad is usually my go to, but it's messy, so grab a fork.
Even though the line might be long, it goes quickly. It's really impressive how fast they get sandwiches made, though they have messed up one of my orders before.
The place is really tiny with no seating and hardly any room to hang out in, so expect to wait in line and for your food outside.
author: Jessica S.

description:
I had 90 minutes to eat lunch, and was standing against my will in the line up wiht 100 others to dine at Sushirrito when suddenly I remembered "I don't really like this place" (see my review). My wonderful Austin BFF had a similar revelation and we quickly escaped the line up and jogged up the street to The Sentinal for a stellar sammie (or two).

Entering from the side entrance the menu is printed on paper and posted outside so you can make snap decisions when you get to the counter. I was torn between the Reuben and the Lamb and feta meatball sandwich.... just kidding, easiest decision EVER!!!

3-4 large light meatballs sit within a freshly baked brioche bun (almost a croissant in texture and buttery flavour - FML), a little sauce, A LOT of cheese and some basil leaves - HOT DAMN!!!

For the girth and density of this sandwich it was actually quite light. The meatballs were delicous... nay, scrumptious.... nay... I'm going to make up a word right now to describe the flavour.... right off the top of my head, SCRUM-TRU-LESCENT!

Yes. Simply Scrumtrulescent. Done!

Eat here. Don't be weird. Just eat here. They give you free pickles and Werthers Original candy with every order!
author: Kris U.

description:
It had been a few years, and I came back to grab another sammich when I was in need of a quick lunch. There's always a line, but if all businesses were as efficient as this one, we'd have cured all diseases years ago. If governments were run by The Sentinel, we would have achieved world peace a few centuries back. They're efficient, is what I'm saying.

The menu is pretty limited, but that's what you want. You come here for a sandwich, you pick one out of the list of the few they're serving that day (arrive early for the best selection) and you walk through, get your sandwich, pay, and get on your way. 

Second time around and it didn't disappoint. It was a Cuban torta-esque sandwich this time, served hot, and in my belly fast once I got back to the hotel room. I do wish there was seating (do they do any business when it rains?) but that's not their jam. It's quick, to-go sandwiches for under $10.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: Oh no. I used to really like this sandwich spot. However, my experience with The Sentinel today was incredibly disappointing. My coworker and I stopped by to grab some spicy pork sandwiches for lunch this afternoon. We both paid for spicy pork sandwiches, received our orders, and walked back to work. When I got to the office, I eagerly ripped off the white paper encasing my sandwich only to find - to my absolute horror - not a spicy pork sandwich but a sad, limp turkey sandwich... I took a deep breath and said to myself, "Hey! It's okay! The spicy pork is only $1 more expensive than the turkey. It's not a big deal. Let's give The Sentinel the benefit of the doubt. Perhaps today is the day I find a new favorite sandwich!" Then, I took a bite only to find - to my absolute horror - that the turkey sandwich tasted just as sad as it looked. The sandwich was pretty much 75% bread with 2 pieces of cold turkey deli meat slapped between a chunk of cheese and a sliver of butter lettuce (not unlike the kind of lettuce you'd find in a McChicken at McDonalds). Now I'm not a chef, but I sincerely believe my 13 year old nephew could've made this turkey sandwich that the Sentinel sold for $10 (technically $11 since I thought I was getting spicy pork) whole dollars. Luckily, they got my coworker's order right. Unluckily, she was not impressed with her spicy pork sandwich. The Sentinel is just not how I remember it.
author: Katherine C.

description: Awesome place.  Literally ran in here on a rush back to my hotel and the whole transaction took probably 1 whole minute, including paying and getting my sandwich.  Staff were incredibly friendly and the corned beef that I got was delicious.  I'll be back!
author: Chris L.

description:
FIVE STARS FOR THE MUFFINS! I recommend you come at 7:30 AM when they open and the muffins are still warm. My absolute favorite is the Apple Cranberry. The apple sweetens the muffin dough while the cranberries add this very subtle burst of tart. These muffins are magical. Before you read this review and get your hopes up you should know the Apple Cranberry muffins were evidently discontinued a few weeks ago. Considering how much everyone I know loves these, I'm shocked at the discontinuation, but I am also hoping this is just a temporary menu change?  PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE BRING THEM BACK.

The blueberry and the strawberry muffins are also delicious. These gigantic muffins have generous portions of fruit in them. The tops are ever so slightly crunchy, and somehow even a little sweeter than what you would expect. I honestly can never decide which part I enjoy more, the cake at the bottom or the tops; And I have never been one to differentiate the two. I walk 10 minutes there and 10 minutes back twice a week just to get one. I would likely walk there more often if the Apple Cranberry muffins were still available  :) 

I should add the butternut squash muffins are much like a pumpkin muffin with commitment issues. If you like the taste of pumpkin bread but feel it is a little too much pumpkin for you, then these muffins are for you. I personally prefer the bold taste of pumpkin bread over these, and will more than happily stick to the other muffin options. 

The chocolate brioche is really just airy bread with some melted chocolate inside, and a sprinkling of powdered sugar on top. Not bad, but not anything amazing either. There are just too many good pastries to be had in the city; I would have to give these only two stars. 

The sandwiches... I have only had one sandwich - the Vietnamese Pork Shoulder. Again. It was ok, but nothing to rave about. If you like a ton of meet, they are not by any means shy about their meat portions! Although a ton of meat is not my thing, I do appreciate that they do not skimp on their ingredients. I guess worst case you take some out. Overall, still just an okay sandwich for me and I would also give it two stars.

Yes, the muffins are that great to merit the four star rating, despite my thoughts on some of their other options.
author: Caroll M.

description: Don't know what the hype is all about. I had the hot corned beef for $12 plus tax and tip. Definitely not worth the price. I actually got the sandwich and it had 1 small edge piece of corned beef on each side and that was it so I went back and showed them.. They added more corned beef to the sandwich but wtf? Definitely won't be back.
author: Kyle P.

description:
This place was so amazing. Can I please give this place 6 stars?? 

They bake their bread fresh on-site every day.  I had the rare roast beef sandwich with horseradish sauce.  It came with a pickle and a mint. It was so good.  It was well worth the $9.50. 

They usually run out of this sandwich early in the day, so it's best to get there when they open (11:30am). Plus the line can get really long during the lunch hour, which is another good reason the get there when they open. 

Best sandwich place in SF!!!
author: Rose Z.

description:
Setting: There is no seating, just a counter where you place your order, so you have to find seating elsewhere. Fortunately, there are lots of seats just a couple streets down. There is a line during lunch time but they make the sandwiches quickly so the wait isn't bad. There's just a little bit of interaction with the employees (one who quickly takes your order and one who hands you the sandwich) but they were nice and friendly. 

Food: I ordered the lamb and eggplant sandwich because I love both of those ingredients. It was combined with lots of chickpeas, which I thought overwhelmed the lamb and eggplant. It didn't help that the lamb and eggplant were cut into tiny bits (like grinded up?). It was still delicious but I would have personally preferred big pieces of both. Oh, and they give you a pickle and Andes mint chocolate! 

Gave this a 3 for the lack of seating and my sandwich was just good, not anything particularly special.
author: Vio C.

description:
The menu is pretty limited, so you're definitely not standing there reading down a long list for forever and a day. But there were some winning items to choose from. I went with the roast beef and horseradish sandwich. While it was good, I was kinda thinking the roast beef was either rare or really fatty. It just had that fatty consistency and taste to it. I love roast beef, so I was a little taken aback by it's "freshness"?? But it wasn't bad by any means. And you get a pickle (although could you make them bigger??). 

I tried all three cookies... yes I did! Started with the sugar cookie, which wasn't as soft as I would have hoped. Just mediocre in my mind. The chocolate chip cookie was really ooey gooey good. Could have been sliiiiightly more chewy, but that's just being nit-picky. The oatmeal cookie was BOMB though! So soft and delicious! With no raisins, which I appreciate, as I'm not really a fan.

Even if you don't need lunch, you definitely need an oatmeal cookie from here!
author: Rachel C.

description:
5-star reviews can be notoriously difficult to pen. However, this one is as simple as Sentinel's delicious premise, which is anchored by a well-edited menu of only 10 flawless sandwiches. 

Good god these sandwiches are great!

The key to Sentinel's sandwich wizardry? Their mysteriously sweet, soft-as-a-pillow bread. It certainly doesn't hurt that they pile their sandwiches high with layer after layer of choice meats, cheeses, and housemade spreads but I stand by my assertion that a sandwich's bread is what separates the good from the great. And if a sandwich can be served cold and the formula still wows without interference from seductively melty cheese (for instance), then you know you have a solid sandwich.

I usually bounce between the turkey and the egg salad sandwiches, but I'm praying for the safe return of the chicken salad. I'm patiently waiting over here... anyone hear me?

Please don't be put off by the lines. I've never waited more than 5 minutes and I'm always on my way back to the office - clutching my beloved sandwich - within 10 minutes max.
author: Jelena Z.

description:
One of Fidi's Must-Have lunchspot is Sentinel for its famous corned beef sandwich & lamb eggplant sandwich!!

About the place -
1. A small corner shop , easy to miss. Else spot by its long line at lunchtime.

2. At lunchtime there is a long waiting, but line moves very fast. Many a times due to high popularity they sell out of their popular sandwiches. So best to get there early around 11.45 am to avoid the crowd.

3. Service - Very fast & efficient.

4. This is only a take-out place and No seating! So find yourself a place somewhere in the outdoors of high rises around or the Yerba Buena garden a few blocks away. 

5. They have sandwiches, hot & cold, priced approx $9. Each order comes with complimentary  pickle & a mint chocolate, what a treat. The portions are huge and very filling.

6. MUST-HAVE - Their corned beef sandwich & lamb eggplant sandwiches!!Utterly delicious. On 7x7's Must Eat List!
author: Payal B.

description:
I finally had the chance to visit this SOMA sandwich spot. My co-workers have been raving about this place for a while.

We came here today during the peak of lunch hour. Fortunately, the line wasn't too long. They made our sandwiches and had on our merry way in less than 5 minutes. Pretty impressive.

I guess they rotate their menu daily, so you don't come expecting to have a basic turkey/swiss on sourdough roll. You have two choices - take it or leave it. And I'm totally cool with that. I'm a Libra - so we have a tough enough time making decisions anyway. 

Today's menu included a roast beef sandwich (with arugula, tomato, onions, and horseradish cream cheese on a roll), and the pork and figs sandwich (with escarole and manchego on wheat). There were some other choices, but these were the two carnivore options that appealed most to me and my co-worker.

I'll be honest. My roast beef sandwich was good but not great. While i enjoyed all the ingredients, I felt like the horseradish could've used more kick. And the bread, while fresh, was a bit large and heavy. I wound up tearing off one half of the bread and making my lunch more of an open-faced sandwich. 
Like I said, the sandwich was fine, and I'd definitely go back to try another option. But for $9, I guess I was expecting a little more from The Sentinel.
author: Kevin B.

description:
This use to be a regular lunch spot for me and my coworkers (as was Golden West). But the recent price hike was too much, too quickly and we no longer go there. Would love to re-evaluate if the prices settle down a notch.

This place was on the edge of $, but now its well into $$
author: David P.

description:
If I wasn't worried about my waistline and wallet, I would be by this place every morning for one of their fresh baked muffins and every afternoon for a sandwich. 

Everything rotates, but they tend to have a few standards that are there every day. 

The salad offering is usually something that I don't think about when I go there, but the one time I got it, everyone at the office lunchtable was like "woah, where did you get that, looks amazing!" So, you might want to try that to mix things up. 

The sandwiches are plenty big and the bread they use is some of the tastiest sandwich bread I've had outside of fresh dutch crunch. My only warning is that sometimes I want to take a nap after enjoying one of their amazing meals. 

Did I mention the muffins!?!?! ;-)
author: Brian B.

description: I found my new lunch/sandwich shop!!! I did not realize how close this place was from my work. Waited after the noon rush to grab a bite here. Thinking it was a big spot, I was surprised to see it was literally a corner of a building. Ordered the Deviled Egg Sandwich and man did it not disappoint! They made it so fast I was surprised. When I got back to my work and opened the bag up, the sandwich is huge! Oh man....not sure how I can function after eating it (food coma to the MAX). So.....gooooood. I shall be back Sentinel....I shall be back for more. Two thumbs up from me. Also, good little surprise with a Andes mint in the bag! Woooooo! *my favorite type of candy*
author: A o S.

description:
Okay, this is what you gotta do...

Tilt your head.
Pout your lips.
Pull out your best peace sign.
...then tap your heart twice with your peace sign and kiss it!

Yes, that's how I feel about Sentinel's corn beef sandwich.

MUCH LOVE!!

One of the best sandwiches you'll ever sink your big fat teeth into in the FiDi!

Freshly made corn beef on a warm focaccia bun.  Served with a delicious home made pickle.  And definitely order ahead of time to avoid the long lunch wait.  They tend to sell out, so, there will be days that will disappoint you.

PEACE!!
author: Jenny T.

description: Every time I come to downtown SF from LA I gotta grab the corned beef sandwich. It's a personal highlight of mine. I recommend everyone in my family that visits SF to grab a sammich here. So good!
author: Vincent Y.

description: Wow - the spicy pork is delicious.  I could eat this everyday.  it is a bit pricey, but it is super tasty.
author: Erich B.

description:
Being a long time vegetarian sandwich places typically don't provide me too many options. The BALT was one of two vegetarian options on the menu and saying I was pleasantly surprised would be a understatement.

Avocado is great on any sandwich but I think the real selling point of this sandwich is the goat cheese. The melted cheese acted as more of a spread rather than a cheese. Personally I feel like it's hard to find good sandwich places for vegetarians. This is one of the few exceptions!
author: Ashwin M.

description:
Bread was good. 
Sandwich held together.
Tasted fresh... 
(the line was shorter by 12:45p, but they did run out of a few as everyone has mentioned)

Had the lamb... minced, it is. Not so "lamby" at all really. :(

Taste of sauce was alright. Nothing to blow you away, but definitely satisfies. I'd encourage the chef to explore more. 

PS the pesto had traces of cilantro I think... don't like cilantro.
author: Ralph M.

description: What more can I say about the corned beef sandwich that hasn't already been said?! The corned beef was chock full of flavor and I loved that they used foccacia since I like bread that have more substance to it.  The russian dressing and cabbage added a nice balance.  So why not 5 stars? I saw that they offered the corned beef sandwich with cheese in several yelp reviews, so I was hoping it would come with cheese when I stopped by.  I think that would have added a nice ooey-gooey- ness to the sando.  :)
author: Elena N.

description: The line can be pretty darn long, therefore, come early. I ordered the lamb and eggplant sandwich and boy was it packed with flavor. I truly enjoy the blend and the bread was pretty good. It gets a little soggy, grab lots of napkins :)
author: Nhung T.

description: I'm lucky to work a 5 minute walk from these guys.  This place is amazing.  The Spicy Pork Sandwich is fantastic.  So much flavor in every bite.  The lady at the counter is really nice and friendly.  Love it.
author: Praneeth W.

description:
I hate cabbage. But I went for the Corned Beef due to the cashier's recommendation. Every part of the sandwich was phenomenal. The beef was thin and savory. The perfect amount of delicious Russian dressing. Delicious, crusty, golden-brown, and dense bread. And cabbage that worked flawlessly with the rest of the meal. 

This place is very unassuming and is only open during lunch. Friendly servers. This place has so many more hot sandwich items that I want to try out: the barbecue pork, the lamb. I will definitely be back.
author: Vaibhav V.

description: Mouth watering! The best sandwich in SOMA is the Roast Beef from The Sentinel. I've tried a few of their most popular options and this one is by far the best. I will say that one time the Roast Beef seemed to be undercooked (made it very chewy) so I would just take a look before you walk away from the counter. So yummy though!
author: Amanda S.

description: The corned beef sandwich is the best! I have tried their Swedish meatball with gravy, too much mustard for my taste. Great lunch place for grab n go, there is no sitting area. If you want to try their daily special, be sure to get there early.
author: Kai Y.

description:
Make sure to get here early or after the lunch rush as there will be a line forming for this delicious place around 11ish.

Luckily my office is super close by so I tend to get here around 11:30 and there's only a few people ahead of me at this time. They post their daily offerings on their website as well as on their door where the line starts. They are known for their corned beef sandwich which is hearty and super delicious. As great as the sandwiches are, I really love their salad options. I've had their spicy chicken salad with mangos and most recently had their daily special which was a crab louie salad with cucumbers and dill and it came with a piece of bread and vanilla flan.

Overall this is a great grab and to go lunch spot when you are working in the area. Everything is delicious!
author: Christine W.

description:
First thing you need to know Dennis Leary != Denis Leary. While some may find this obvious, I am clearly an idiot or at the very least can't read too well. But I also trust Denis Leary and he'd probably like this place too so it all works out in the end. 

Get a hot sandwich here. Not because the cold sandwiches aren't great, but because the hot sandwiches are so goddamn good. Get the ground lamb and chickpeas if you want to pretend to be healthy. Beautifully spiced with some middle eastern flavors, this sandwich is stuffed to the point of overflowing. The portions are generous and delectable. 

If you are a realist and want to accelerate the inevitable shuffling of this temporary mortal coil in blissful joy, order the corned beef. I feel like that last line probably explains the depths of my feelings on the corned beef, but if it doesn't I will tell you that this sandwich is near perfection. A big flaw in a lot of reuben look alikes is they just jam the sandwich with cheese and russian dressing and that's a majority of a flavor. Not this sandwich, oh no sir. It's all about that corned beef and it delivers til the last bite. 

Not a place to be missed, but be aware there is always a line by noon. For good reason, I suppose.
author: Jake B.

description:
Well, after two spectacular visits, two years apart, it's about time I finally pen a review that I started in 2012.

The Sentinel is kind of a must-try for all Yelp CMs; not only is it super close to HQ, but it's totally delicious. Both times I opted for the deviled egg sandwich (basically a mouthwatering version of egg salad). It's slightly spicy, and perfectly piled high between soft and fluffy bread - wheat, in my case. It's the perfect mid-day meal (and might even be good for a hangover... or so I've heard). It comes with a pickle, too, which always puts a smile on my face.

And if a substantially sized sammie isn't enough for you, go for a cookie, too. They taste freshly baked and the chocolate chip is drool-worthy. Promise.
author: Jamie D.

description:
Yesterday I had a Reuben which called itself a Reuben and looked like a Reuben but was essentially not a Reuben. http://www.yelp.com/biz/fentons-oakland-2#hrid:sKJFM5JIV4oMqkpHMjzD_Q Today I had a Reuben which did not call itself a Reuben and did not look like a Reuben but was essentially a Reuben. Yeah.

REUBEN (listed as "CORNED BEEF with cabbage, Russian dressing and Swiss cheese") $9.00 tax included: I didn't mind Russian in place of Thousand Island, but I still prefer rye and Oxford commas. The price prevents me from rating any higher.

It's almost absurd how little time there was between placing my order and the sandwich box being in my hand.

Check out their (no parking on the) dance floor wax:
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Zn-JtWP90z6vGgIw11SgIA&userid=WALNtcSZlONK4Yj-o3pzKA
http://youtu.be/gomCkCbKHA4?t=35s
author: Dan B.

description:
Delicious, quick sandwiches. The line generally moves fast (like Chipotle fast), but they will run out of certain items as the day goes on. Hot corned beef sandwich is pretty large, I usually eat it for two smaller meals. Comes with a pickle and an Andes mint.

They also have really good coffee cake in the mornings. Be forewarned that the oatmeal comes with a lot of fruits and nuts mixed in, which is not to my taste.
author: Hayley C.

description: Got to know from a friend, great place for sandwiches, consistently good in taste.  Chickpeas eggplant and lamb is my fav. one.
author: Ajay E.

description:
Breakfast review only:  This is still a place that I want to try their corned beef sandwich but instead I made it here on my usual morning walk to work.  The smell of fresh muffins greeted me as I walked up to the counter.  I decided to get a raspberry and blueberry muffin  for $2.50 each, $5 total.  They also had a coffee cake of some kind in a pan which I plan on trying on a later date and oatmeal which is way too healthy for me to derive satisfaction from going so far out of my way.  

The muffins were super tasty and warm as if they were right out of the oven.  If they can make a sandwich as good as this, then I totally believe that their sandwiches have to be just as good.  

Will update when I figure out a way to get here during lunch without taking the entire lunch hour!
author: Ben H L.

description:
I had their Lamb and Eggplant sandwich and it was good! I'm generally not a fan of chickpeas, but mix it in with lamb, eggplant and curry, I didn't even notice them. 

I'll definitely be back to try their spicy pork and corned beef sandwiches!
author: Peter L.

description: Love this place for lunch. The trout salad is very good. The bread is homemade and super tasty. They run out of stuff so we may not get your first choice for lunch if we go there around 1pm like I do.
author: Anne M.

description: awesome, fresh and huge sandwiches. I love the corned beef. menu is small, check it out online before you go, although it's posted outside where the line forms. it's better to know what you want because they might even take your order while you're in line. they post the daily special sandwich online too. no seating and no drinks, but potato chips and cookies. there's always a line at lunch but it moves quickly. I'm a regular.
author: Bob U.

description:
#63 in the list of Stuff White People Like is "expensive sandwiches". I hate to reinforce the stereotype, but I do love me some expensive sandwiches. The Sentinel is no exception (even if they are a few years behind the trend).

Their sandwiches are excellent. The ingredients are unique and high-quality, and I can't help but love the simplicity of the menu.

I've had two sandwiches so far: 
1. Lamb/eggplant/chickpea, which was just okay (probably 3 stars)
2. Pork, which was much better (5 stars)

The prices are high, but I guess that's just life in the Financial District. On to #64... Recycling. How did they know?!?
author: Andrew M.

description: The Roasted Cauliflower Sandwich is a rich and buttery delight. As good as I'm going to get for veggie lunch eating. Beware though: it's very tall and a mess for eating without a fork, so you may want to pick something else for that lunch date.
author: Geoff D.

description:
I'd heard rave reviews about the sandwiches and was keen to give it a whirl - relying on Alex S's judgement I had the corned beef which is $9 and comes with a large pickle in its own bag and a Werther's. 

As I started eating, I was pretty underwhelmed. It was fine, but nothing memorable and I felt like I was missing something exciting. The bread was fine, the meat was fine and I liked the combination of flavours, but I definitely wasn't all that excited by it. Maybe it's just me as my workmate really liked hers. 

I did enjoy the ordering process though - super efficient and fast. The line might seem pretty long but we only waited 5 minutes, tops before getting our food.
author: Briony C.

description: WHAT IS THIS DELICIOUSNESS. Just a bit of this corn beef sandwich blasted my tastebuds into heaven! The foccacia bread is warm, soft, crispy, while the meat is perfectly seasoned, the cabbage is slighly picked and the russian sauce just blends all the magic together. The sandwich is gigantic and the price is reasonable. $9. Did I mention that the pickle is BOMB as well? Complimentary Andes mint chocolate too. SOLD.
author: Hoyan L.

description: I LOVE this place for breakfast! The oatmeal is so good!!! So much better than oatmeal from places like Jamba Juice or Starbuck, or even the Corner Bakery or Specialties. It's filled with seasonal fruit, nuts, and it's already a little sweet, but you can ask for a light sprinkling of brown sugar and it is perfect! They do tend to run out, so get there early. Also, pre-order lunch if you can!
author: Hannah P.

description:
Oh noes! I've only got 10 minutes left on my lunch break and the line for every eatery from here to the dogpatch is flowing out the door! Who will save me?!

The Sentinel honestly has the fastest service I've ever experienced. They almost knew my order before I did. I ordered the special (chorizo and egg frittata), which came out hot, delicious, and roughly 20 seconds after I'd paid for it. They assume everyone here is eating to-go, so everything is in a to-go box along with an Andes mint chocolate (if you don't like these, I'll gladly have yours for you).

The Sentinel saved my lunch break and allowed me to dash back in the office in time. My heroes.
author: Andy Q.

description:
The hype is real.   Even though the line looks really, really long, it goes by really fast.   I had the corned beef and it was fantastic.      

Also this place really knows how to focus on the what they do best, sandwiches.    Drinks are non-existent along with sides but I don't care.   I can get that someplace else.
author: Albert W.

description:
I tried the corn beef sandwich and was really sad/disappointed at it. It was not only 9 bucks plus some change but it just wasn't that good. I only had half sadly and the other half went into the trash. I mean, don't get me wrong, it wasn't a BAD sandwich per say, it just wasn't an amazing sandwich as all the others around my reviews have probably stated. 

Even though it is a "$" dollar sign, it's a pricey enough for me not to go again or recommend anyone else there. Oh and there's nowhere to sit and you have to get the sandwiches to go.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I don't get the hype! I ordered the corned beef (per Yelp reviews) and it wasn't really great at all. It came with foccacia bread which I love but it was toasted in a way that made it too hard to eat. The sauce tastes like a sweetened thousand island, which semi-cheapens the sandwich. For $9, I would rather go to a better sandwich shop like Working's girl. Though, I was recommended other sandwiches so perhaps I would just recommend to stay away from the corned beef. 

Also, it's a small shop so be prepared to wait in a line (they're speedy though).
author: Brandon P.

description:
I've heard so many good things about Chef Dennis Leary and I have been wanting to try Canteen but haven't had a chance yet. When I heard that he had a sandwich shop, I was really looking forward to it. I really wanted to like this place but nothing I had tasted good.

I hate wasting food but the chicken mole special ($11) was so bad that I had to throw it out. The flavors just didn't work for me.

I've also tried the coppa sandwich ($9) and corned beef sandwich ($9). They were not as bad as the chicken mole but it's not something I would order again.

It just didn't work for me.
author: Andy W.

description:
Was not impressed. The bread that they use is sort of reminiscent of a hamburger bun or maybe a kaiser roll? But it's way too soft and gets soggy really quickly. Got the pork and fig burger. It's filling for sure, but most places will do the job with that. The flavors were just okay, didn't taste particularly fresh or amazing. They do make some good pickles though. 

With every sandwich, you always get a pickle and a little Andes mint, which is nice. 

And, they've changed their credit card minimum down to $8.
author: Annie S.

description: I got the corned beef based on yelp reviews, which I didn't even realize I liked but it was AMAZING.  Will definitely return
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
For those that crave a solid sandwich in the area, the Sentinel's a pretty good option. They've got reasonable prices for the Financial District and menu options, all of which sound good. More importantly, the line moves pretty fast. 

However, if you hear corn beef sandwich and think of New York City and those thick juicy chunks of corn beef, dripping with deliciousness, you're flat outta luck. 

It's thin slices here, man. 

Bummer.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Pure laziness is the only reason I can think of for avoiding Dennis Leary's upscale sammie stand for the past two years. The limited hours haven't helped either since I would need to make a point of trekking to New Montgomery to find it. Then something happened last week. Sushirrito. The line started to form in front of the au courant place a few doors down, and the Sentinel suddenly became so five minutes ago. I was actually at Macworld thinking I would give Sushirrito a try. I saw the line, sneered at the prospect of waiting, and made my way to this corner closet of a shop.

Leary is the head chef of Canteen, and he seems to be going the way of Tom Colicchio who branched himself out to the 'wichcraft chain from his Craft flagship restaurant in New York. The key difference is that Leary personally makes the creations to be found here. You can tell. Not sure if he made mine, but the $9 Corned Beef on Flatbread is a standout. Slathered with Russian dressing, covered with melted Swiss and layered with shredded cabbage, the heated sandwich was the right lunch-time portion and satisfying with every bite (see photo).

The other sammies, the sweets and the lunch specials have my attention now, so a return visit is inevitable to this former cigar shop. There appears to be about ten sandwiches to choose from on a daily basis from Egg Salad to Veal and Ricotta Meatballs, all between $8-$9. I will gladly bypass the waiting throngs at Sushirrito to get one, so I can spend more of my lunch hour actually eating rather than checking my Blackberry every twenty seconds.

FOOD - 4 stars...glam-hearty sammies that are tasty, too
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...just a place to order, finding a place to sit is your challenge to deal with
SERVICE - 4 stars...pretty fast given how crafty the sammies are
TOTAL - 4 stars...Dennis Leary's fancy sandwiches are worth an extra buck or two here...well, go to Lee's if you're that cheap
author: Ed U.

description:
Not a whole lot of hot sandwiches to choose from so I ended up getting the corned beef sandwich. The flavor was there, but there was just wayyy too much bread. If I removed the top layer of bread, that probably would've been the right meat to bread ratio. If I'm paying $10 for a sandwich, there better be some meat to it, that's all I'm sayin.

Also, the line is really long.
author: Betty W.

description: Corned beef hash sandwich was amazing! I loved every minute of it along with a crunchy pickle.
author: Paige C.

description:
Oh my.  I'm not a breakfast person, but I will be for The Sentinel.  I've now stopped by their little stand on New Montgomery twice for breakfast, and absolutely LOVE it.  The first thing I've ordered there was their oatmeal.  You can request it without sugar, but it comes fully loaded with fruits like apple, blueberries, and bananas, and is topped with nuts.  I'm not sure what makes it so tasty, but I absolutely love it (much better than whatever it is they serve at SBUX...).  The second thing I've tried there is their blueberry muffin.  This muffin is TO DIE FOR!  I've had a sampling of their butternut squash muffin, and while you wouldn't think it was that good, the fluffy and delicate texture of the muffin makes you want more.  The butternut squash muffin tastes NOTHING like squash - it actually lines pretty close with cornbread!  So amazing! 

Just as an FYI, the muffins and oatmeal are on a first come, first serve basis, so if they're gone, they are gone.  Not only that, but it's hit or miss on what's available.  Also, they are cash only, so please come ready!  Their coffees are great too, which makes for a complete breakfast.  Enjoy!
author: Lisa I.

description:
Like many others, I'm a fan of this little sandwich shop (also a fan of chef Leary's Canteen restaurant). Love the old time cigar shop decor. But unlike other reviewers, it's my opinion that the famed corned beef sandwich (as praised by 7x7 Magazine's list) is just okay. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-sentinel-san-francisco?select=gtv6L2qCpifd0NsVygtW-A#9qZna9_PwC-Sh_dNKH1kDQ Too soft and mushy for my taste. Also too much mayo. I prefer the traditional version from Miller's East Coast deli much better.

Many new customer are easily disappointed, because they expect every food item to be awesome. I like this place for the chef's creativity, so sometimes u get winners and some not as good. I only come here if something new sounds interesting to me (daily menu posted online). One good example was the yellowtail ceviche sandwich, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-sentinel-san-francisco?select=q1apU6nG-8vyS7LafBenmQ#q1apU6nG-8vyS7LafBenmQ which was delicious. Another good one was a pork tenderloin sandwich. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-sentinel-san-francisco?select=koL2mhTO_-tewWK6gDyi4g#koL2mhTO_-tewWK6gDyi4g But not every new gourmet sandwich creation is successful. For example, one time a curry egg salad sando was a mess and didn't taste as good. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-sentinel-san-francisco?select=0bz5otBa6BScg7SipY01Zw#0bz5otBa6BScg7SipY01Zw

Soups are my favorite comfort food. And this shop makes very tasty creamy soups, like pumpkin soup http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-sentinel-san-francisco?select=t306Q_4WN_6nl-Dd52jnNw#t306Q_4WN_6nl-Dd52jnNw and celery root soup. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-sentinel-san-francisco?select=59tFnWYCMJDT9RJC-YeopQ#59tFnWYCMJDT9RJC-YeopQ And many others. For example, I still remember the delicious cucumber soup from their first week open in 2008. My only complaint is that soup portions are very modest (only 2/3 full) for the $6 price.

Most lunch menu items are priced around $8-9, only the daily special plate is over $10. In my opinion, usually the specials are less successful than the sandwiches. For example, one time a scallop ceviche with cucumbers was too watery, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-sentinel-san-francisco?select=L6FMNdLDPuFP-EgpV-aRZA#L6FMNdLDPuFP-EgpV-aRZA and a pear crisp dessert was unmemorable. Other flops include a chocolate flan dessert that didn't set properly. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-sentinel-san-francisco?select=5LHaQbZcK7MnwQ6LTV49VA#5LHaQbZcK7MnwQ6LTV49VA

Hours: M-F 7:30am-2:30pm
author: Luis C.

description:
Ohhhh baby! This place is dangerous. I had a fresh strawberry muffin and was like a little piece of heaven in my mouth. I didn't even know people make strawberry muffins! That was a delicious surprise!! I usually don't get full off breakfast muffins but this one hit the spot! The lady working there was super sweet. 

Only downside is that I can't eat here every day. I'm trying not to gain 20 lbs from eating breakfast muffins every day. Buuutttt.... It might be worth the 20 lbs lol
author: Lark J.

description:
Meatballs!! The rest of my lunch crew went for sammys, but me, I ordered myself the special... meatballs. They came in this gigantic container all filled with sauce and cheese and things. And it was fast coming out too! Geez louise, was I ever full by the time I licked the last remaining saucy bits from the container sides, holy toledo, yelpman!

If it's a nice day, place your order and find a nearby park. If it's a crappy day, place your order and find a spot indoors to eat. Either way, there's no stickin' around to bury your face between the wheats here. It's a walk up counter and its small. But oh so worth a visit!
author: Wendy P.

description: Sentinel is a small kiosk across from the Palace Hotel and near an Academy of Art sign--it was so inconspicuous, I walked right past it.  I'm glad I turned back.  The corned beef sandwich was great.  (Note: I substituted lettuce for cabbage.)  At nine dollars, it seems pricey for a sandwich and a pickle, but it's worth it.
author: Matt R.

description: i know i'm in the minority to say that i wasn't overly impressed. it's not bad, but it's worthy of 2ish-stars cause i have indeed experienced better. i just felt like i was paying for a lot of bread and semi-dry meat. would i go back? possibly.
author: Mike C.

description:
When you think of the Sentinel, you probably think of Sentinel's from the X-Men right?  They were those villainous robots that were hunting any mutant they could get their mighty robotic hands on.  Turns out, one has nothing to do with the other... weird.

The Sentinel in Soma, as it may be, focuses more on sandwiches than mutant abomination.  I, on the other hand, am more focused on the abomination of said delicious sandwiches... using my face.

By the time I got to the menu posted on the wall outside, I didn't have much time.  I needed to think quickly and decided it was time to enter my Cyclopes mode to scour the menu.  Which one do I choose?  The Egg Salad, The Corned Beef with Cabbage... time was running out.  I made a decision on the fly and went with the Pulled Pork Sandwich with Mustard Cabbage.  I tore open the packaging to find a stacked pork sandwich.  I Wolverine'd my way through it leaving no morsels behind.

One of my other cohorts picked up an order of the Meatballs with Polenta to share.  I used my Magneto force to bring that container my way and proceeded to feast.  It tasted as though Storm was in my mouth brewing up a flavor monsoon.

Needless to say, I thoroughly enjoyed my lunch from the Sentinel and will be sure to bring my X-men team back for more.
author: Scotty C.

description: The rare roast beef sandwich is one my reasons to live. I eat at Sentinel once a week, but can barely ever get the roast beef because it's so popular; it sells out at noon. I still love the corned beef, though :-)
author: Justin P.

description: Simple location, solid sandwiches for which there is a limited selection each day.  Always guarantees they're fresh. Both the bread and the meat are top notch and they don't use the same bread on everything.
author: S M.

description:
After seeing all the mouthwatering pictures of the famous corned beef sandwich, I've been dreaming of trying the Sentinel. The sandwich was fabulous! Perfectly grilled bread, thinly sliced corned beef with crisp cabbage and reuben sauce - talk about a "sandgasm" ;) lol! 

The line was fast and staff was friendly.  Plus I'm a big fan of the owner (Denis Leary)!
author: Kaila Y.

description: This is the perfect place to get a quick bite to eat during lunch time. The menu is small and things can run out, so be early if you want something specific. I had the  fresh mozzarella sandwich which was simple yet very fresh indeed. Would definitely go back and try more sandwiches!
author: Naomi Y.

description: The service was super fast and food was ok. Got the lamb and eggplant sandwich, which wasn't as good as I hoped it would be, but ok nevertheless.
author: Drini C.

description:
I went to The Sentinel on Mon 1/17/11 cuz I had the Holiday MLK JR Day off.  I got there late, but the line wasn't long.  It's across the street from the Palace Hotel on New Montgomery.  I tried Golden West, but think The Sentinel is better!

I got the hot corned beef w/ swiss cheese sandwich $8.75 & and chocolate chip cookie with nuts $2.50.  

Corned beef sandwich wasn't very hot by the time I walked to Cocker Galleria to eat it, they have tables & even a few heat lamps at that small mall.  Comes with a small pickle & an Andes mint.  Meat was fine, cabbage boring on focaccia bread.

Cookie I got was huge & soft, just ok for me.  You can charge it if u spend over $10.  My total was $11.25.

I might try a lunch special next time.

No bathrooms for the public I could see, & no seating, just a take-out place.
author: Ann L.

description:
YUMMMM!!! I was craving a warm sandwich for lunch and for the first time, Yelp did not disappoint. I got to Sentinel at 11:15 (they don't start serving until 11:30 am) and placed an order for the lamb sandwich. Instantly, you can smell the freshly baked bread....uummazzing! I placed my order and they were so incredible - they made my sandwich before 11:30.

Does this sandwich hit the spot or what?? Fresh baked roll, warm lamb and garbanzo bean filling, and a pickle. I'm in a happy place right now! OUTSTANDING!!! 

Thank you for doing it right!
author: LAIKA K.

description: By far the best coffee I've had in the financial district! I get coffee here about 3 days a week and so do my coworkers. Their food is amazing too! The muffins are so sweet and perfectly moist, blueberry is my favorite :) if you have a really big sweet tooth, try their cinnamon rolls or coffee cake. I have yet to try their different sandwiches for lunch but my coworker swears by them. And the best part of all is their amazing customer service! The people that work here are always kind to their customers and get your food or coffee ready pretty fast. I would highly recommend this place
author: Gabriela S.

description: this place roq! better be hungry, tho. sandwiches are pretty big...ingredients are always fresh, bread is baked daily, and pickles are made by the company.
author: Gary O.

description: One of the best burgers I have had. Coming from NYC i am very choosy about my burgers, and I had literally a mouth-watery experience here. Would recommend this place for lunch!
author: Vipul S.

description: So far I've gotten two sandwiches from the Sentinel - cold roast beef and hot corned beef - and both were excellent! Definitely going back!
author: Mitch P.

description: After hearing about this place I told myself I had to check it out. It definitely does not disappoint. I got the Roast Beef Sandwich since I'm not the biggest fan of horseradish but decided to opt out. If you're in for a quick, delicious lunch I highly recommend this place. Also did I mention the Service was AMAZING!!
author: Diego S.

description:
This place truly is a hole in the wall joint. There is no seating and occupies the same amount of space as would a drive-by coffee joint. The service was relatively friendly as everyone on yelp has suggested. A great combination of smiles and efficiency. 

However, the food wasn't as spectacular as everyone has been saying. I ordered the Spicy Pork Sandwich. The one perk was that the sandwich definitely had a lot of meat. But, for a sandwich that is labeled "warm," I honestly couldn't tell. After a 5 - minute walk from my office, the sandwich was lukewarm which could also label how much I enjoyed it. 

There wasn't very much flavor in the sandwich even though it was dripping with "red juices". I will say the plastic wrapped pickle was a nice compliment to the sandwich and the Andes Mint helped scrub the non-existent sandwich flavor from my mouth.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
Friday around 1:15PM. About a 5 minute wait. Couple things off the menu were crossed off while I was waiting in line. 

Corned beef sandwich was scrumptious. That focaccia bread... I would definitely order this again. Portion was perfect for satiety.

The spicy ham (Tasso) was good. Not all that spicy. The pumpkin seed pesto tasted mustardy. I wouldn't opt for this again. 

I was tempted to get the daily special: yellowtail ceviche with cucumbers celery cilantro and green tomatoes.....but I wasn't feeling a salad style sandwich.
author: Anna S.

description: The corned beef and pulled pork sandwiches are both really delicious. In my opinion, it is a bit greasy, but other than that, it's the perfect amount of flavor, good fresh bread, delicious, gooey sandwich. Yum. I wouldn't go back unless I was craving it, but my experience was good.
author: Jessica L.

description: Great...no, seriously.  When is the last time you had a sandwich made with a bun that was actually good? Also, I admittedly got there early (11:30am), but I had my sandwich in about a minute and a half.  In summary: worth the carbs.
author: Matlock J.

description:
Wow this place is fast! They serve your food quicker than you can check in on Yelp, which is always a massive plus for me when picking somewhere to grab lunch.

The sandwiches are incredible, dripping and overflowing with meaty goodness. My girlfriend once got the salad which looked ok but not as good as the sandwiches. Not a huge menu all round but I don't mind that. By the way, if you ask for substitutions then you mess up their whole system and it takes maybe like 3 minutes instead of 1 :)

I think it's a little on the pricey side but then so is everything else in the area - and you at least get $10 worth of sandwich!
author: George B.

description:
No soup for you! This is totally that kind of place. No substitutions, tiny, long line wrapped around the block. 

I'm kind of obsessed with Egg Salad...when it's good it's devine...when it's not good..throw up in my mouth. The ES quest keeps me coming back to certain places again and again, like Prontos in Carlsbad, Ca...and now this place in SF! 

I feel like anytime I'm in town from now on you'll find me in SOMA at 11:35 (to beat the rush) in line at this joint. The bread is soft and sweet, but stands up to the Egg Salad without a problem. The cookies are delish too! Beware of the 10$ minimum card restriction and bring your cash!
author: Trish S.

description:
The Sentinel belongs is a certain tier of tourist trap - one whose regional legacy ensures that when you, oh lovely native to the SF Bay, host out-of-town guests and you're clamoring for lunch in SOMA, you inevitably show your local know-how by exclaiming proudly, if not matter-of-factly:

"We're going to The Sentinel."

And it proves to be exactly what that sentiment conveys: a hole-in-the-wall with a line a mile long, factory feeding suits to shorts and all clothing betwixt.

8-9 sandwich options on seasonal/monthly/weekly/daily rotation (they do what they want), at least one soup, some sweet baked good and a hand-shaken lemonade on tap. The proteins are a no fail - the spicy pork, smoked turkey and corned beef on a Reuben (that's three different sands, folks) have de-shoed me with tenderness and flavor. And at under $10 including a pickle, these sandwiches will be ate regularly.

Service lasts approximately 13 seconds, so there's nothing to be said for that. I will note the slightly off-putting comment on The Sentinel's website, requesting feedback in emails "an effective way of communication, as opposed to anonymous comments on Yelp." Because nothing breaches the guise of anonymity like poignant input from WhipYaHairBackNForth@hotmail.com.

You're a four-star biz that's beloved by all but 50 of the near 900 Yelpers that have taken the time to share their thoughts; show some couth.
author: Damien S.

description:
The Sentinel is a great lunch spot!

Walk-up counter for to-go only so grab your sandwich and take it to yerba buena. Quick and satisfying hot sandwich, so far I've always gotten the spicy pork because it's so good. The sauce isn't all that spicy but it has a hint of buffalo sauce flavor which goes well with the juicy pork. 

Be warned though, it can be _really_ messy so don't forget to grab napkins from the side of the counter (since they don't put them in your bag!).

The fresh pickle spear is also a nice touch, next time I need to rip myself away from the spicy pork and try some of there other delicious looking options.
author: Ely L.

description: Wow, wonderful sandwiches and quick service. Perfect stop to grab lunch in the area. And their daily specials are incredible ... I just had a great duck paté sandwich, which was unexpectedly delightful.
author: Evan S.

description: It's... Okay. I got the corned beef sandwich which came fast and was piping hot. The flavor was good but nothing to write home about. It was a bit on the expensive side for what you get which probably knocked down the rating for me. All in all a good experience.
author: Joseph S.

description:
It was a dark and stormy afternoon, gusts of wind upheaving umbrellas, rain pouring down as I made my way into the ravenous crowd filling the financial district's streets... Drenched and starving, I lifted my umbrella as an unworldly scent of sandwich filled my nose. The Sentinel stood before me.

Oh gods of deli meat and deliciousness I praise you for blessing Dennis Leary with with his mastery to serve us mere mortals. I would wade through the most violent tempest to taste his corned beef creation again. He had me the second my lips touched that heavenly panini. I will forever thank him for touching my stomach and my soul.
author: Lady F.

description:
Hm, a little confused by all these amazing reviews for The Sentinel. I've been meaning to try it for a while because of all the lines during lunch hour but I wasn't impressed at all. 

The lines are long but the food comes out super fast, which is good for lunch crowd. I got their famous corned beef, and it was fine, the meat was tender, and the slaw and bread was all fine, but I found myself disappointed by the lack of texture and flavors overall. Actually, I thought everything was too soft and bland. Maybe I'm spoiled by sandwiches like Darwin and Cheese Plus? Either way, I wouldn't go back or even recommend The Sentinel.
author: Kate M.

description:
I can't believe I never wrote a review for this place.  I went through a phase where I was eating this once or twice a week.  

The corned beef is popular, but I don't really like that sandwich.  I've had the egg salad sandwich and the yellow tail sandwich, but only when THE sandwich to get wasn't available: the salmon!

It's made of cold smoked salmon and cooked salmon... GENIUS.  A little goes a long way.  That between their fresh baked bread and it's a fish party.  

I usually call it in to avoid the lunch rush.  Their cream of anything soups aren't bad either; ditto on desserts... but can skip.  Eyes on the prize - fish party.
author: Erika C.

description:
When I went there was no line which made the whole thing definitely worth it. I'm not sure how long of a wait I would say is justified but with no line I'd go pretty often.

My corned beef tasted like more than the sum of it's parts. The beef, and sauce were good but not transcendent, while the bread was incredible and carried the sandwich. Overall it works quite well, though maybe a tad expensive for the size.
author: Misha T.

description:
What I ordered:
+ The Balt (B-)

While the Sentinel doesn't make my top list, it was good enough that I know someone else will feel strongly different than I do. I will say they've got a good system going, total time from standing at the back of the line until the sandwich was in my hand was a good 7 minutes during the lunch rush. 

The bread on my sammy just wasn't working for me. Soft but almost too doughy, it was overwhelming the filling. I had Caprese in my mind when biting into the Balt, not a good idea. Overall flavor combination was fine but not quite as refreshing as I'd hoped. 

I'm the type of eater that if you tell me something is the best sandwich ever, I tend to think otherwise and vice versa. After hearing so many people rave about the Sentinel, I had very high expectations that were not met. Psychological? Possibly.

So if me and you share the same philosophy let me tell you the Sentinel is just OK and maybe you'll have a better experience than I did.
author: Jason O.

description: This is the kinda spot that actually kinda stresses me out from having too many different things that sound good even though the menu is small. It's impossible to feel confident on you decision.  I ended up with the tukey meatloaf, i loved the bread and the butter lettuce and the meatloaf was flavorful and yummy.  My only qualms were since the meatloaf was soft I would have liked toasted bread.  The pickle on the side is super good, tastes homemade.  I was kinda burpy later from the meatloaf so I wouldnt have it again for a lunch hour meal, but still a solid sandwich.
author: Emma H.

description: I'm spoiled rotten with this place less than 10 minutes from my work. All their savory lunches are heavenly. And their pastries! Don't even get me started on those butternut squash muffins.
author: Grace C.

description:
'09-'10 7x7 Big Eat List: #74 corned beef gruyere sandwich

Tried calling in my order, but missed the cut off time. When I got to the shop, the line was out the door, around the corner and into the alley. Luckily because of all the people working the lunch rush, I was able to order and leave with sandwich in hand all under 10 minutes. Yipee!

I never bothered to see how the sandwich looks like online. And so when I finally opened the box, I was highly disappointed by the small flat sandwich sitting inside. Soft focaccia bread with surprisingly pink corned beef layered between barely-melted gruyere and thin slab of cabbage and dressing. 

First bite, I only tasted the chewiness of the corned beef. The combination of dressing and cabbage was overwhelming and masked the flavors of the corned beef. It wasn't disgusting. But overall, the sandwich felt dainty and bland. I suppose for those who enjoy gourmet sandwiches would like it. But for me, not $8.75 worthy.
author: Marti L.

description: I hear this place is great and I feel bad for only three stars because the sandwiches did look good.  The line was out the door by the time I got my food but it's a really small place and they moved really quickly so I don't think that should deter anyone.  I ordered a spicy chicken salad which sounded really good but there was soooooo much pepper on it, I could barely eat half.  It was disappointing.  But I will go back to try their sandwiches.  The corned beef one everyone was getting looked delicious.  Also prices are reasonable.
author: Amanda K.

description:
1. Stand in line for a little while.
2. Get delicious sandwich. The later in the day you go, the more limited your options, as they have a small menu to begin with and they can def run out of more popular items. (Items = sandwiches, always. Maybe a soup or two.)
3. Move through the line. Pay, then take whatever "it" is with you.
4. Devour at your desk, in a chair, at your home, or anywhere.
5. Be happy, because it's likely a kick ass sandwich. Also, sandwiches are one of the most perfect foods known to humankind.
author: Rachel F.

description:
It seems like $10 will get you several different, really good sandwiches in the area.

The Sentinel is where you go to get a couple of them. While there's normally a long line out the door, if you go after 1 o'clock, you're in the clear.

The lamb and eggplant is like a gourmet, Middle Eastern sloppy joe with mint spread and chickpeas. It comes on a whole new species of soft bread. I don't even know what kind it is, but it's remarkable. Everything's a bit on the heavy side, but you're not getting an oversized portion. This is a quality over quantity kind of place. Although, they do put an Andes mint and pickle in your brown paper sandwich bag to make you feel like someone's mom packed your lunch.

Different gourmet-like sandwiches with brilliantly curated ingredients rotate on the regular here. The Sentinel is a really good spot to grab a late lunch.
author: K M.

description:
Would give this place a 5-Star rating but have only had one sandwich so far, which was awesome, but need to taste another before changing this to 5-Star :)  First off, a friend who knows that I love sandwiches sent me the following article, http://www.thebolditalic.com/articles/5901-read-this-if-youre-obsessed-with-sfs-sandwiches.  Figured that while I had tried several spots here, there were lots that I had not, and since one was near my office, today was as good of day as any to make a dent in the list.

Because of my New York heritage, I'm pretty finicky about roast beef, so when the summary of The Sentinel mentioned how good there's was, the only concern left was whether the rest of the ingredients would ruin the roast beef or complement it.  Not being such a huge fan of much more than mayo and tomatoes on a roast beef sammy, can make one skittish at the site of other intangible elements, especially the advertised, "smoked onions, frisee and horseradish cream cheese".  Well, I stand here today a HUGE fan of that combo, which I'll attribute to the combined flavors unleashed by the smoked onions and horseradish cream cheese.  Just music to my tastebuds.  The place is a tiny hole in the wall where you can only grab a sammy to go, but it's TOTALLY worth it!
author: P W.

description:
I've only tried their hot sandwiches here.   
One great thing is all the sandwiches comes warm and made to order.

Corned Beef - Tasty but i like corned beef sandwiches ridiculously packed with meat like from a jewish deli.

Eggplant Lamb - Tasted pretty good.  I'd get it again.


Note: Line is long for lunch, but they are quick and efficient so don't be afraid to get in line.
author: Steven F.

description:
This highly lauded lunch stop with a consistent long line (which moves totally fast) probably doesn't need another rave review, but imma hit y'all with it anyway. 

You know when a menu only lists 5-7 items yet you still can't decide what to order for yourself, then it must be doing something right. I'm consistently torn between the egg salad, chicken salad, and whatever they have on special. Most recently, it was a pork, fig, and manchego sammie - definitely needs to be a regular menu item. So savory. So sweet. And perfectly squished between their cloud-like bread. 

I rarely grab a drink or cookie here, but love enjoying the pickle on the way back to the office. Don't plan on hanging around here, no room for that.
author: Gloria C.

description:
First time here and my coworkers and I tried the corned beef and the roast beef sammies.

Corned beef was really juicy and savory but the downside is that they toasted our bread too long. Felt like my teeth were in peril of being chipped for a second. The roast beef  was cooked medium rare as stated on the menu and the mustard brought a bold pop of flavor that lingered.

My peeps and I liked it. Can't wait to try the specials next time.
author: Julie L.

description:
Came here for lunch today after reading the positive Yelp reviews.  Knowing that they get busy quickly I showed up at 11:20, and found out that they do not begin taking lunch orders until 11:30.  There were only 4 people in front of me, and waiting 10 minutes wasn't a problem, but it's good to know when they open for lunch.   My order was taken promptly at 11:30, I was on the fence about getting the eggplant and lamb or the corned beef, the employee at the counter recommended the corned beef so I went with that.  My sandwich was ready 5 minutes later, and I walked back to my office to enjoy it.  (this is strictly a take out place)
   Let me say first this is a solid sandwich weighing in at least a pound.  I had never had a corned beef sandwich on focaccia bread and so was curious as to how it would taste.  As others have said the Sentinel has some amazing bread. The focaccia was perfectly toasted and delicious, in the middle was flavorful, tender corned beef, cabbage, Russian dressing, and melted swiss cheese.   They could really label this a reuben sandwich, and it's a great one.  Alongside came a small slice of pickle (bigger please!) and an andes dinner mint.  A solid value for $10

If you want a cheap sandwich go to subway.  If you're looking for quality ingredients and amazing fresh bread, the Sentinel is a great option.  

I look forward to coming back to try the egg salad, eggplant and lamb and other options.
author: Nick G.

description: There sandwich menu isn't anywhere near extensive as they regularly just serve 3-4, but their corned beef is consistently a good choice for the FiDi folks. Not too expensive and good portion size. Focaccia bread works well with the corned beef and dressing. The wait for the sandwich is really quick, a lot faster than in the past. Makes me wonder if it's not made to order since the last one I had was not that warm.
author: Rick T.

description:
So I'm in SF for training the whole week and what does that mean?  I get to do the 7x7 Big Eat 2010 Scavenger Hunt (http://www.7x7.com/bigeat2010_scavenger_hunt/) or at least get started.  Since I heard that it might rain most of the week, I opted to go to the further food place and I wanted the Scottish Egg on Wednesday or Friday due to Lenten Observances.  

Well as I was jamming my tunes on my iPod (at the moment it was Muse's Starlight), I arrived at The Sentinel.  The line was out the door.  I was hoping it wouldn't take too long since I only had 45 minutes left for lunch.  I was surprised.  I think from when I got there to leaving it was about 5 or less minutes.  They had a system down and I guess the corned beef was the popular item so they must have these ready to go.  The place is small and is basically a order and go place.  No place to sit, but man the service was speedy.  The sandwich was $8.75 total.  You need at least $10 to pay with card so ensure you bring cash or just go skip a few steps to the Bank of America right next door.

The sandwich comes with a pickle and an Andes mint (cute).  The smell is intoxicating.  I'm still smelling it now since I couldn't finish it all.  The corned beef melts in your mouth.   The gruyere was all ooey-gooey.  It was the perfect lunch for a Monday cold afternoon.  The bread was well toasted.  Probably one of the best corned beef sandwiches I've had.  

I will definitely be back for this sandwich.  Many thanks to 7x7 for this list!  I can't wait for my next meal!
author: Carolen M.

description:
Again, I wish I could give The Sentinel 3.5 stars.  
Tried the Vietnamese pulled pork (shoulder) sandwich. 
Quality of ingredients were very good and all the ingredients worked well together.  Agree with the other Yelpers that the bread added to the goodness of the sandwich. It is a large sandwich, and unless you are a big eater, this should more than be enough for lunch. 4 stars for the food. 

Price 3 stars. While $11 is not that unusual for downtown SF places that are not chains, I feel that it is still at its heart, a sandwich shop. 
Since offerings are seasonal, I might go back later and try another sandwich and revise my review 

And be sure to ask for the pickle. It is not the usual salt and vinegar bombs found in supermarkets and other delis.
author: Nolan K.

description: Wanted to come here for lunch and the manager was a major dick!! Not to me or my friend, but to the employee who was working there.... We wanted to go back and tell him that we chose not to go there because of his unprofessional and awkwardness creating actions. Here's a tip: Don't yell at people in front of your potential customers... it's weird and will lose more business than if your employee doesn't immediately say "Hi, welcome"
author: Sam W.
