description: Spicy pork was good.  Could've used a wee bit more spice and more pork though.  A lady was taking orders down the line so it was pretty efficient; the wait wasn't too bad especially during lunch hours.
author: Linda N.

description:
I'm almost never in the Fidi for lunch, so I had to make a special trip here. I didn't have any excuse not to go, since:

A) I had the day off
B) I had to do it because I'm obssesed with my Big Eat SF list 
C) I had the day off. 

Reading the Yelp reviews prior to coming here, I was prepared to wait. We arrived at noon and found no lines.

I bolted right in to make sure nobody sneaks in front of me and ordered: 

#74 on my list: Corned beef hash sandwich with Gruyere at the Sentinel

I grew up eating corned beef.  From the can.  The Sentinel uses none of that crap. We're talking thin slices of beautiful (and lean!) corned beef, melted Gruyere cheese, sliced cooked cabbage and Russian dressing in a soft glorious bread. Hello, it's St. Patty's day in a sammy!  What a concept AND it tastes delicious! I'm hardly ever satisfied by a sandwich, but this one surely did it. You also get a half of a pickle and Andes chocolate mint. 

When I got home, I looked for the canned corned beef in my pantry. I was scanning the components and feeling really disgusted about the fact that I put all that sodium, saturated fats and preservatives in my body growing up. I almost chucked that thing into the garbage can, but decided to keep it.

After all, I'm almost never in the Fidi for lunch.  

Wait....when is my next day off again?!?
author: Janice C.

description: I'm not a beef or pork eater so I can't frequent this spot as much as I'd like, but the one time I had turkey meatballs there I was DELIGHTED. The chicken salad sando is also pretty tasty. Check their website for the daily special!
author: Nikki M.

description:
My manager grabbed me a sandwich from the Sentinel today. Since the corned beef sandwich seems to be the popular one, decided to try! I definitely wasn't disappointed. The bread was good and the corned beef with cabbage and cheese was warm and tasty. I asked for light Russian dressing which I'm glad I did since I wanted to taste more of the flavor from the meat. 
Overall, happy with my choice and would definitely want to return here to try some other choices! I'm not actually a huge corned beef fan but the sandwich was just right for what I was craving for lunch. Prices are not bad also but a good tasting sandwich. Also like the complimentary Andes candy with it!
author: Miss H K.

description:
It was such a nice day and I didn't have work, so i had to drive up to SF and finally try The Sentinel.  

It was my first time here and the girl behind the counter suggested the Spicy Pork.  The bread is so good, you could probably eat it by itself.  So warm, buttery and sweet.  The sandwich wasn't as spicy as I expected, but the slaw and pork mix was perfect.  

There are no seats, but close to eating area at the corner of New Montgomery and Market.  They also don't accept credit card for less than $10.
author: Richard T.

description: I'm usually a salad kind of gal for lunch but when I'm feeling a little adventureous, The Sentinel is definitely a rotation of mine. Love the Vietnamese pork sandwich on wheat but lately I've been on a veggie kick and it sure doesn't disappoint. My favorite is the deviled egg filled with chunks of whole eggs... honestly, any sandwich is going to make your tummy smile after. It does not disappoint!
author: Nho C.

description:
As far as SF food goes, Sentinel isn't that expensive, and the price you pay is definitely worth it! I'm a warm sandwiches person, and they only have two on the menu (both of which are absolutely delicious). But the other day, I finally tried their roast beef sandwhich, which is cold-cut, and it was almost just as delicious as the warm sandwiches! That said, my favorite is still the warm corned beef sandwich.

The line can get a bit long during lunch hours (12-1pm), but the wait isn't long. An employee will walk along the line and take orders in advance, so they're always on top of orders. I'd say the longest I've had to wait is 10-15 minutes, which isn't bad at all by SF standards.

The location is also great (a couple blocks off Market, on New Montgomery St.), so it's very accessible.
author: Andrew C.

description: I found out about this place through the "20 Epic Sandwiches to eat in SF Before you Die." The sandwich they recommended: the corned beef on focaccia with cabbage, Swiss, and Russian dressing. Truthfully, I wasn't a big fan so I decided to try this place out again to see if any of their other sandwiches made the cut. After coming here two more times, I have to say that I am not an ecstatic fan. Personally, I feel like this is one of those places that puts a bunch of ingredients, which are delicious on their own, together and thinks it will turn out to be an amazing product. For example, the sweetness of the Russian dressing did not go well with the corned beed and focaccia. If it was mustard or a more spicy sauce, I probably would have loved the sandwich. The other sandwich I got was the Roast Beef with onions, frisee and horseradish cream cheese. If it were a more tangier cheese that went well with the horseradish such as feta, I might have enjoyed this sandwich a little more also, but the cream cheese did not blend well and I also barely tasted any horseradish. The Tazzo was the one sandwich, which I somewhat enjoyed although still have some criticism. For example, the egg and the ham (and also the avocado that I added per recommendation of another reviewer) went very well although there was barely any ham! There were just two pieces and the rest of the sandwich was loaded with egg. Had there have been more ham, this definitely would be one of the better sandwiches I have eaten and I would be back. Sadly, I fail to see what the long line is about unless I worked in the area and there were no other options. Hopefully with the changing menu, there might be better options in the future...
author: Kunal N.

description:
super duper sandwiches! this is definitely one of my to-go lunch spots of 1) i had a ridiculously good run in the morning, 2) is starving my butt off, and 3) if there are no major afternoon meetings... if the stars align in such a way, then i treat myself to the corned beef sandwich with cabbage and russian dressing and foccacia. sometimes i eat this with a knife and fork, but really, it's more delicious when you pick up the monster and just go at it.. it makes all your coworkers jealous as well :P

they also give you a pickle and an andes mint - how thoughtful!
author: Christina L.

description:
I tried the Corned Beef sandwich.  Service was fast.  Just walk in, order on menu, and wait for order.  This is not a sit-in establishment.  You have to take it to-go.

Corned Beef Sandwich was underwhelming.  I appreciate the fact that I could taste the quality in the ingredients, soft focaccia bread, meaty and succulent corned beef, fresh crisp cabbage, oozy melted Swiss cheese, but for some reason I didn't really like the taste.  There was no boom or pop!  Please put more punch to the flavor! I paid like $10 bucks for this gourmet looking sandwich and but didn't deliver with the seasonings.  Sigh!
author: Judy Z.

description: Got the corned beef hot sandwich due to all the reviews on here and it was quite good. Got it to share with a friend and it was definitely enough for the both of us. $10 for a sandwich is quite expensive but if you think about it, $5 for a meal? It's alright. It was really good and I love how quick it was.
author: Polly L.

description:
This place was hiding right in front of my nose this whole time. I work right across the street and always saw the long lines during lunch hour and never put two and two together: long lines equals good if not great food. 

Of all the years working at my current job, It never occurred to me to venture across the street until recently due to necessity. I'll just simply state that due an incident after the labor disruptions we experienced several weeks ago, I was hungry after seeing there was no food in our cafeteria. My mind was set and I was going to grab a sandwich at Subway on 2nd Street. 

Along the way, I got a whiff of the aroma emanating from this place and instantly changed my mind and stopped to look at their menu. They all looked very simple but my mouth was suddenly salivating over the aroma. I decided to have the Corned Beef with Cabbage, Swiss and Russian Dressing. 

One word: WOW!!! 

Yes, it was that good and made my worries go away....for about an hour. Heck, even if I decide to change careers, I'll still return here to grab me some good sandwich.
author: John G.

description:
Good corned beef sandwich!

Was in San Fran for the day and took the chance to find out what all the hype was all about. 

Had the corned beef sandwich with cabbage, Swiss cheese, and Russian dressing. The sandwich was good particularly the way the flavors of the beef and lettuce marry with the Russian dressing. The sandwich also comes with a side of pickles to add another dimension of flavor and texture. The bread is hearty and held the generous portions well.

Overall, I thought it was a good lunch option but thought it a bit pricey at $9 but I suppose that's normal for San Francisco.
author: Roehl A.

description:
These sandwiches are so good. The lines around the corner kind of signal what you'd expect. 

I almost always get the corned beef though every now and then have tried the lam. Simply delicious. Not a lot of pomp and circumstance about the place which if anything adds to its charm.

Don't be scared away by the lines and definitely give this place a shot!
author: Milan T.

description:
Yum! I ordered online and it was ready as soon as I got there. Little hole in the wall so no where to sit but great for pick up.

Got the Corned Beef Sandwich and it was quite tasty. Several people stopped by my office and stopped to stare at the sandwich and said OMG that looks good where did you get it...no exaggeration! 

Minus 1 star for the odd pickle and would have liked more cheese and/or complexity. I'd go again though!
author: Rose R.

description:
I owe this place a long overdue review. Two years ago, I stopped by in the morning to buy 1/2 a dozen muffins for a meeting. The blonde woman with short hair who waited on me was one of the rudest servers I have ever had. I don't know if she was having a bad morning because she thought that she had a b****y resting face, but it turns out she's just a b****.

I can only assume I had deeply offended her with my opening smile & a "hello," because it was all downhill from there. She acted like she was doing me a grand favor by waiting on me with loud sighs, eye rolling, and cutting me off before I could finish a sentence.  She was so openly hostile that I have never set foot in this place again.

I emailed the owner and never received a reply, which tells me exactly how much they value customer service here. The food and prices aren't worth the attitude.
author: Jorge M.

description:
Made the mistake of coming here with high hopes.

A lot of the sandwich options sound like they would taste good theoretically but many didn't actually come through on taste for me. They definitely are unique but I can't say that I will be back here soon for lunch (they have limited hours!)

Also keep in mind that this place is basically an indoor food stand. No seating so be prepared to take food to-go or grab a bench a block or two down near Sushirrito.
author: Junes S.

description:
Wham Bam Thank you Ma'am!  This place is pretty quick.

FiDi has many mediocre sandwich spots and I blame it on everyone being in a rush. The Sentinel deserves a 3.75 rating since it's above decent and quick. It's not a 4 Star rating however since there are many other amazing sandwich spots in the City such as Darwin Cafe, DeliBoard etc.

The BEST item on the Menu:  Corned Beef - Fresh Focaccia, Gruyere, cabbage...only gripe; its thick slices and not fine paper thin slices. So if you bite into it, most of the meat will fall out. Sentinel, take notes on how Darwin Cafe or DeliBoard slice their meat and your ratings will go up . Rating 3.75 out of 5

Roast beef - Decent sandwich but needs more meat and more horseradish. Taste somewhat bland. Rating 3 out of 5

Lamb and eggplant - sounded promising but taste like a sloppy joe with way too much bread. Had way more bread than meat. Rating 2 out of 5

Spicy Pork - Simple Pulled Pork type of Sandwich. Pretty Decent but way too much bread. Rating 3 out of 5

Considering the competition in FiDi, this is one of the more decent sandwich spots in the immediate area.
author: David N.

description: WOW. Talk about fast & fresh food! I came here because I heard about their corned beef sandwich ($10) which is sooo good. They have their ordering system DOWN to a science to accommodate a huge flow of traffic, especially around lunchtime. Very impressive. The corned beef sandwich comes with small piece of pickle (half the size you would normally get at any other deli) and an Andes mint. Bonus points for the Andes mint! Good place for a tasty grab-n-go meal.
author: Stefanie C.

description: Had Cauliflower Curry, was good. Egg plant sandwich didn't like too much!
author: Vipul K.

description:
Whether you are an Atheist, Christian, Muslim, or believe in any higher being...

You will believe there is a Heaven after you've gone here.  I've been going here for 3 years and the breakfast AND lunch items are all top notch.

Breakfast - 
known for their steel cut oatmeal w/fixings AND their baked goods.
Peach muffin = best I've ever had. Gave it to my gf who doesn't like muffins and ... now she craves muffins.
Coffee cake = The word, yummy, sounds like a simple and elementary word to describe this but ... it describes the cake perfectly.
Banana or zucchini bread = very good too.

Lunch - 
known for their BALT and Corned Beef sandwiches
No need to get your sandwich fix at the other sandwich joints in the area. Patiently wait in the line and you'll get a delicious sandwich and a pickle WITH an Andes chocolate mint.


Not to poke fun at anyone who's given bad reviews but "the blonde woman" as Jorge M. stated is one of the sweetest girl's. She's always so welcoming and positive whenever I see her.  Jorge is your typical complainer as you can see from his reviews (more negative vs positive...maybe he has that b*** resting face... shall we say, a b**** resting attitude)
author: Sean Y.

description:
While my sandwich was just decent today (I'm not sure if I was the biggest fan of the sauce on my chicken sandwich - yes I ate chicken today), the wheat roll was divine and almost buttery sweet. 

The highlight of the meal today though -  was breaking off parts of my co-workers hot fresh cherry cake from The Sentinel. Moist, rich, and full of fresh cherry bits.

To die for.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I've had two lunches there now: a meatloaf sandwhich and a spicy chicken salad. Both excellent.

The place has a tucked-away feel to it. You enter from a side door, order, pay, and then wait on the open side on New Montgomery for your food. Makes you feel like you are in on some sort of secret. The secret? Good food!
author: Brent D.

description:
Yum, Smoked Turkey with pear chutney and cheddar cheese. Did not know it came with mayo or I would have asked for it without but I just scrapped it off. It was still delicious. The roll was so perfect and the chutney really made everything mesh together. It was a tastebud treat. 

Yes, there is a line but wow are these guys efficient and quick. They have the daily menu outside during lunch hours so you are ready to order, they make your 

$10 minimum card charge.
Sammie comes with a pickle. 
Walk up only, plan to take it to go.
author: Colleen B.

description:
I agree with many of the reviews here that describe the Sentinel's sandwiches as bland. I had the salmon sandwich (fresh and smoked salmon, dill) and my boyfriend had the curried cauliflower sandwich (curried cauliflower, raisins, goat cheese). I tried both and was highly underwhelmed. 

Heavy handed use of mayonnaise/goat cheese didn't help the already too-subtle flavors pop; rather, everything was a kind of muted mush. The rolls are actually pretty good, but they're quite thick and pillowy, so all that bread just adds to the bland. 

With all these reviews mentioning the lack of flavor, this place could stand to up the salt and acid. Good concept, fast service, mediocre execution.
author: Emily P.

description:
Super great hole in the wall.  Cash only.  Have your order ready, these folks move fast!  

Perfect treat for a sunny SF weekday.
author: Andy T.

description: Holy Moly..I never knew eating a sandwich could be such a religious experience. I made so much noise as I devoured it. Soft buttery bread, well balanced, full of filling and flavor. Definitely the best option in the area.
author: Howe L.

description:
This place had some seriously good grubs, and you'd think their sandwiches are made with pure magic. The experience is multiplied by the little pickle and mint chocolate that comes with the sandwich - always a delight!

They are also super fast and the line is usually pretty short.

Tip: try the muffin! It's amazing!
author: Don L.

description:
Had to stop by before my Big sur road trip to grab the famous Corned beef sandwich!

Portion was huge so I shared it with my sister. If you love corned beef and cheese you must try this. Although it wasn't the best corned beef sandwich I've ever had, it was definitively tasty enough and I loved the pickle on the side! 

This is a great grab and go sandwich place! Will be back to try their other sandwiches / special salad / lunch set. Appreciate the efficient service too!
author: Amber S.

description:
Not a bad corned beef sandwich, but for about $10 I expected more meat -- both quality and quantity. I'm a bit of a harsh critic when it comes to corned beef. I've been fortunate enough to try both Katz's in NY and Langer's in LA -- the gold standards of corned beef in my book

The Sentinel's corned beef sandwich is definitely a change of pace from the usual. With the first bite, the buttery foccacia bread definitely steals the show. Call me a purist, but I'm just not a big proponent of using foccacia bread as the vehicle for a corned beef sandwich. Focaccia bread excels on its own.

Instead, the bread takes away from the true star of the sandwich, which should be the corned beef. Here, the corned beef seemed to lack flavor. Or, it could be that it didn't even stand up to the rich and buttery foccacia bread. The Russian dressing and sauerkraut were there, but all I could think about was how disappointed I was in the corned beef.

If I lived or worked in the area, I could see myself slowly but surely trying everything on the menu. It would have to be an occasional splurge or treat, that's for sure. This smaller than a hole-in-wall spot is good for a quick sandwich run back up to the office. But if there's a long line? Count me out.
author: Dru C.

description:
I should have stuck to my guns and ordered the corned beef sandwich because I liked it so much when I tried a bite of my friend's sandwich. Of course, I could not resist the combination of lamb and eggplant, two of my favorite ingredients, so I decided to be adventurous and try something new. 

I was somewhat expected slices of lamb and eggplant, but instead, the filling was more of a sloppy joe like sauce with diced eggplants, ground lamb and chickpeas. It was quite spicy too, which I did not mind. I did, however, object to the level of acidity in the sandwich. Maybe it was because I was really hungry and kind of stressed out, but the sourness gave me acid reflex for the rest of the afternoon. If you're into very sour food, then this will definitely be your cup of tea, but since I'm more of a savory and sweet person, not so much. Next time, I will definitely keep to the safe option, the corned beef sandwich.

I also got a chocolate chip cookie and it was a great way to sooth the sourness of the lamb sando. It's big, chewy and crunchy on the edges, everything that a chocolate chip cookie should be. Definitely pick up a cookie with your sandwich, it's worth the calories!
author: Alice W.

description:
Went around 12:35 and it wasn't busy which is great. The food ordering was simple and I got the food really quick. I ordered the spicy pork. Now I am a little biased on this review because I'm not a huge fan of coleslaw but I figured I'd try it. There isn't seating so either eat and work or eat on market by the station. 

The sandwich was not very spicy at all. The coleslaw was flowing out of the sandwich. Each bite I took was a confetti of coleslaw exploding out. It really isn't something to write home about but if you're looking for a large sandwich for decent cost and not wait long, this is the place. I probably wouldn't suggest the pork unless you LOVE coleslaw. The corn beef might be a better recommendation.
author: Bobby K.

description:
Having the new office a block away makes it fairly difficult to resist this tiny treasure lost inside the financial district. They have a small menu and an even smaller store front, so keep you gps dialed in or you might just pass right by the Sentinel.

I've had the corned beef pretty much the last three times I've been there. It's a sturdy sandwich at a stiff price. It's not the first sandwich in SF that has thinned my wallet as much as it has loosened my belt buckle, but probably one that I can get a few times a month without complaining.

Head over early if you don't want to wait outside for too long, the place has a line out the door at lunch time and occasionally you might end up waiting for the better part of your lunch break.

So if you're in the mood for a greasy lunch time masterpiece and have the dime to spend, head on over to the Sentinel and get yourself something nice, you deserve it.
author: Jasper S.

description:
After several years, I still don't know what I feel about the Sentinel. 

The service: decent at times and horrible the others. It is never exceptional unless you're a regular. If you are a regular, you get the perks of having your sandwiches made when they see you jaywalk across the street, you get to cut in line to pay, and you get smiles from the cashiers. If you only frequent them from time to time like I do, you get to wait.  Also, if you get there at 11, when they "open" be prepared to wait and be ignored. And ignored. And ignored until you ask if they're open to which they respond with "no, you have to wait." And if so happens another regular jay walks across the street at 11:07, they are finally open and you are ignored.  Other times the service is what it is. 

The food: not the best. They are unique and tasty, but extremely messy. I just don't think it's yummy enough for me to deal with it. I normally would attack hard-to-eat sandwiches with a million napkins, you only get one :( 

For these reasons, I only get sandwiches at the Sentinel if I'm craving it --which is now only a small handful times a year.
author: Lisa L.

description:
A long, yet quick-moving line greeted our lunch group at The Sentinal last week. An employee jotted down orders outside and by the time we got inside, all that was left to do was pay the tab and wait a few minutes for the sandwiches. 

Back at the office, I unwrapped a monster of a tasso ham and mozzarella sammie, with a roasted peppers salad spread. The roll was a soft, buttery, doughy masterpiece. Easily a million calories by itself. I expected soft slices of fresh mozz, but the cheese was more like deli sliced. The ham was tasty but not as spicy as I expected, plus there were a lot of fatty pieces that I had to pull off. My favorite tasso ham sandwich resides in Philadelphia, but this version wasn't bad at all. 

I'd personally try to avoid these gut-bustingly large sandwiches for a mid-week lunch, but I would definitely recommend them to anyone looking to cure their hangover or put on five pounds in one meal!
author: Michelle C.

description: Great sandwich for take-out lunch. They know how to make good sandwich. The bread matches perfectly with the meat and vegetables. Highly recommend to try it out if you're looking for a quick lunch.
author: Teng-Yuan C.

description:
I decided to splurge today and had their lunch special.

MEATLOAF WITH MASHED POTATOES, BBQ SAUCE AND CABBAGE SLAW AND BUTTERMILK PIE WITH STRAWBERRIES FOR DESSERT- 11.65

It's totally worth it! Well portioned, not heavy and perfectly seasoned.

Their corn beef with cabbage is also a good go-to sandwich item.  Get there early as it can get sold out at times.  Their doors open at 11:30 a.m. from the Stevenson side.
author: Anne S.

description:
Extremely confused by The Sentinel's 4 star rating. I have now given it two tries, and both times, have left disappointed.

I tried the meatloaf cranberry sandwich and while the meatloaf was pretty good, there was nothing stellar about this sandwich. As other reviewers note, the bread is overly soft. While clearly freshly baked, it lacks flavor and crunch, instead acting as soft flavorless canvas for the meat. For $10, I expected much more depth.

I also have tried their chicken, mango salad and was less than impressed. The chicken was gross and the salad itself was sparse - mainly a bed of soggy lettuce leaves. 

If you're looking for a great FiDi sandwich, I would highly recommend Cafe Algiers- much better sandwiches and only $6.
author: Rachel L.

description: My favorite egg salad sandwich place! They don't skimp on their egg salad, and you get a HUGE sandwich you can easily split over two meals for about $8. There are usually lines on week days so order ahead online or on the phone and just pick it up when you arrive. I've tried both the sourdough and the wheat and recommend the wheat - it's fluffy and pairs amazingly with the egg salad.
author: Anu P.

description:
turkey sandwich with pear chutney very good 

SMOKED TROUT SALAD with apple, fennel, and raisins - 8.75 - sort of tasteless and on a greasy buttery roll 

line moves fast & they are efficient
author: Sonya Z.

description:
Delicious + Good Service + Interesting Sandwiches + They Do It Right = 4 very solid stars for the Sentinel!

My foodmate and I got here around 12:45pm, and from reading some reviews, I was expecting a line, but it was surprisingly FAST - thumbs up for speedy service!  It probably only took us about 5 minutes to get our food!  Maybe less! 

I ordered the B.A.L.T. (basil, avocado, lettuce, tomato, goat cheese) sandwich on wheat, and my friend got the corned beef one along with the carrot-ginger soup. 

I unwrapped my B.A.L.T. sandwich, took a bite, and was like DAAAAMN this HELLA GOOD.  The basil adds some punch to it!  Very strong flavor, and I love anything with basil in it.  The avocado and whatever sauce they used in it added a nice, creamy touch to the whole thing.  The butter lettuce was crisp and scrumptious too.  The bread was solid.  It was a melody of great flavors and textures, very well-put-together and tasty sandwich.  HIGHLY recommended.

I tried my friend's corned beef sandwich too, and it was also fantastic.  That's saying a lot too because I totally dislike corned beef, so to be able to almost convert me is very impressive.  The carrot ginger soup was tasty - packed with ginger flavor, which I feel like you'll either love or hate.  

And, as an added bonus, they gave me a PICKLE and a CHOCOLATE MINT along with the sandwich!  Now, I don't especially like pickles or mints (especially chocolate ones), but I do like free add-ons, so I happily took both and made cringy faces while eating the sour.  And I guess one of the cool things about eating pickles, for me, is that I feel like they're a nice, clean, crisp finish to a meal.  

I'd give this place 5 stars, but there's two things that deter me:

1.) $8 SANDWICH = normal for FiDi/SOMA, but still much teh expensives to me!  It's so totally stuffwhitepeoplelike = oh god, I'm turning pasty.

2.) I had a very strange interaction with one of the employees there; I'll call her E for employee:

V:  I'm trying to decide between the BALT and the pork loin.  What would you recommend?
E:  One is vegetarian, and the other one has meat.
V: . . .(*thinks: yes, I'm not stupid*)
V: Um. . .okay.  Well, between the BALT and the pork loin one, what would you recommend?
E:  I like the veal sandwich.
V: Um. . .okay.  I'll have the BALT then.  

Yeah, I don't know what happened there.

Anyway, one more tip: for places to eat nearby, since there's no seating here (it's a hole in the wall), walk to nearby Yerba Buena Gardens for a nice outdoor lunch with a friend or with a book.

But yeah, Sentinel sandwiches.  Sure to please!
author: Vivian C.

description:
I used to love this place until I found a hair in my polenta with pork shoulder and salsa. I was devastated to be so grossed out.

I loved the creative lunch specials and chocolate chip cookies. :,|
author: Jacquee P.

description: 5 stars for the corned beef. Yummy in my tummy. Couldn't finish it, nice big portion.
author: Lena S.

description:
Went today for Lunch ($9.50 including tax).  I got the curry lamb with chic peas and cilantro pesto. It was one of those sandwiches that gets better as you keep eating it.

Dennis Leary himself was right there managing and making orders (I LOVE how he is sooo hands on - what does he have now like 4 restaurants?, yet there he still is making sandwiches - gotta appreciate that dedication)

No one mentioned that you have to choose between white and wheat rolls for many orders - so be prepared to make that snap decision.

Oh and BONUS - each sammy comes with a GREAT pickle and an Andes mint chocolate.

go Dennis - you rock.
author: Amy W.

description:
#73 on the 2011 7x7 List: Corned-beef sandwich with Gruyère
#74 on the 2009 7x7 List: Corned-beef sandwich with Gruyère

-Tasty?  Yes - I couldn't wait and took one of the two square halves and devoured both on my merry way back to the office.  There's also a pickle and a Werthers at the bottom?  What a nice surprise!

-Service:  Friendly and efficient.  I was able to get my sandwich within a few minutes

-Ambiance:  Take-out place with line coming in one corner and the waiting area in the other 

-Worth the trip/try?   If you're in SOMA/FiDi, stop by and say hi to Dennis Leary (the chef, not the actor haha)
author: Winnie L.

description:
I see the appeal of this place. It's small, convenient location, decent prices. 

BUT FOR F**K's sake....PUT UP A MORE READABLE MENU!!! There's a menu board inside that doesn't have the menu posted. I don't want to have to look through a line of people to see what's offered that day on a piece of 8.5" x 11" paper with a small font.

Also, today seemed to be an off day for everyone there. The guy in charge (assuming here) kept getting bad order info and screwing things up for people. He was a bit harsh in verbally disciplining his staff. Not a good thing in front of all your customers. 


Menu items are usually fairly good. I like the spicy pork sandwich..but it has way too much mayo in the sauce. 

I like that they take the time and thought to put candy in the bag. But what gives with not putting a napkin and utensil in the bag? They take the time to wrap a napkin around a folk and put a rubber band around it. But not actually putting one in the bag? 


Needs more forethought and finesse.
author: Leo V.

description:
Slightly more expensive than the other sandwich shops in the financial district but well worth it if you're looking for something more interesting than the usual cold turkey on wheat bread. 

The rotating menu consistently offers a mix of new items and long time favorites. The corned beef and the spicy pork sandwiches are my two personal favorites. Not a place for dieters or people with "gluten allergies." Bottom line - great sandwiches (and cookies too), but at a price.
author: David B.

description:
One of the best & unique hole-in-the-wall sandwich shops I've been to in SF! My coworker suggested this place that happened to be around the corner, and we decided to give it a shot -- and BOY am I GLAD I did!

There was about a 5-10 minute wait in line and it is take-out only. It was funny at times bc the workers would often come out and cross out certain sandwiches that are "out of stock" for the day, while everyone gasps in anticipation that it is not the sandwich they will be ordering. :)

I tried the LAMB AND EGGPLANT with chickpea, curry, and herb pesto; and the SPICY PORK with celery root and carrot coleslaw . The best thing about the sandwich aside from its scrumptious fresh ingredients is its SOFT warm bread. Each bite is fulfilling and thorough. Loved it! In terms of drinks, the Strawberry Lemonade or plain Lemonade are fresh and thirst-quenching (and perfect balance of sweet and sourness). And what else can get better than that? The little Andes chocolate mint candy they put into the bag for a sweet finishing touch!

Last little tidbit is that they only take credit cards for purchases of $10 or more, so a sandwich plus drink will satisfy that minimum perfectly.

Can't wait to try this place again!
author: Jasmine G.

description:
Pros
- Corned Beef Sandwich
- Little Mints
- Quick

Cons
- No place to sit/purely take-out spot

Great lunch spot. I always get the corned beef sandwich. The meat is great and I love the slaw and Russian dressing. The past few times I've been here, the line has been considerable shorter, with the average waiting time being less than 10 minutes. The line moves pretty quickly and the people taking your order are always super nice.
author: Andrew S.

description:
From breakfast to lunch I'm in love with this place!

They make delish in house muffins and coffee cake that you can grab and go on the way to work.

For lunch you have to get in line for their corned beef sandwich.  It's just big enough to share if you don't eat too large of a meal.
author: Jessica D.

description: If you make a business based on meat sandwiches, then, for f*cks sake, do the meats right.  I went there and ordered the spicy pork with slaw.  The pork in the sandwich was abhorrent: overcooked, and ridiculously dry.  The only thing going for it was a decent sauce (they claimed slaw, but I didn't see it).  The bread was an underwhelming  "meh" of a roll.  I don't get it: if all anyone in this area wants is severely overcooked meats smoothered in "meh" toppings, then maybe we should all be vegetarians.
author: Alex Y.

description:
You had one job. No mayo. 

This is an amazing -- if pricey -- sandwich place, but they put mayo on my sandwich even after two people who worked there confirmed that my sandwich would have "no mayo." I can't abide mayo in any form or fashion. When I order a sandwich from anywhere and they make it and hand it to me, I always look them in the eye, deep into their soul and say, "No mayo, right?"

"Right. No mayo." 

Wrong. Mayo. Unacceptable.
author: Casey C.

description:
There is no seating (it's pretty much a counter in the wall), limited menu (maybe 10 sandwiches total), lines can get long during lunch hours (though not as long as some places near by).

Having said that, the sandwiches are delicious, so it gets a lot of credit for that, especially since that's what you're really going there for in the first place.
author: Andrew E.

description:
There's literally no space in the restaurant, so the line is always out the door. For good reason. They serve a selection of hot and cold sandwiches at lunch. Most are incredible & on fantastic bread (an often overlooked, but essential part of the lunch-sandwich). Everyone recommends the corned beef, for good reason. You really can't go wrong with the spicy pork or roast beef sandwiches either. Almost everything I've had from them is carefully constructed and incredibly delicious.

That said, at $10+ for just the sandwiches, It's not cheap, and their minimum credit card amount is just above the sandwich, so you need to tack on a (tasty) cookie or drink to meet it. 

Also worth noting, they have a sister restaurant with a similar but slightly different menu across market, The Golden West.
author: Toby W.

description:
I'm going to say it....not amazing.

Had the corned beef sandwich and it was fine. Not the big taste parade everyone says it is. Def not wait-in-line worthy.

Sorry ya'll.
author: Jay H.

description: Decent but not as amazing as I expected. Coworker and I shared a shredded pork and lamb sandwich- both supposedly hot but barely lukeworm when we sat down to eat 5 min later. A lot of bread. Service was nice.
author: Leily P.

description:
After finding out about The Sentinel on an episode of Unique Eats and seeing the overwhelming rave reviews on Yelp for their sandwiches, this was a definite must try. We were in the downtown area and early for our lunch reservation at Cotogna when I said "Let's go try The Sentinel". This decision may cause our empty stomaches to be filled before our anticipated lunch but I didn't care. I had to have their sandwich.

Fortunately, there wasn't a line and I asked the girl taking our order what she recommended. The infamous corned beef sandwich ($9) is what she said was the most popular. Decision made. One to-go please. 

Several minutes later, we dove into our respective sandwich halves. I thought it was a solid sandwich. The zing of the Russian dressing, the crunch of the cabbage, and the tender corned beef. It was enjoyable but didn't blow my mind. I'll have to come back some other time to try their other sandwiches but nice start so far.
author: Randy T.

description: The sandwiches, while creative, are 3-stars for me. It's the warm, fresh muffins that keep me coming back every few weeks for breakfast. They're light and airy, full of fresh fruit, and nicely browned on top. I'm now questioning my go-to muffin recipe because, frankly, it seems inadequate.
author: Wing Y.

description:
The sandwiches here are AMAZING. Yes, that caps lock was necessary. Because the food is really that good. I've tried almost every sandwich on the menu here and have yet to be disappointed. If I'm going to be getting food from The Sentinel I'll usually order in advance via phone around 11:30 to pick up at noon. Although service in the store is extremely quick and efficient they do run out of their best sellers usually before 1:00pm

Bonus points - the sandwiches come with a pickle and an Andes chocolate, what's not to love about that?
author: Caroline G.

description:
I had the lamb with chick pea and eggplant at lunch time.

VERY delicious and economical. Good price for what I got.

The line was pretty long, but very efficient and I was in and out pretty quick.
author: Rico M.

description:
Great sandwich shop. Expect a line (8-10 minutes) but expect food to normally only take a few minutes to pump out.

I got the corned beef sandwich without cheese. Removing the cheese added 5 minutes to my wait time (I guess they had cheese set up on the meat). It was delicious though doesn't stack up to best of New York delis.
author: Victor W.

description:
Fantastic sandwiches. And not just a "slightly better than usual" sandwich, these were really tasty. We tried the (not so) spicy pork, and the (actually spicy) lamb and eggplant. Lamb and eggplant was a definite favorite (as another reviewer put it - spicy and sloppy-Joe-ish). It was surprisingly also that the lamb was ground (thus the Mediterranean-inspired sloppy-Joe) but it all worked well. 

Price is reasonable given the big size and quality ($9/sammy), pickles were delicious, and we can't wait to come back and try some more! Call ahead and skip the line.

Note: We consider 2 stars as average, so 4 is a very solid review.
author: Amy D.

description: The thing to get here is the corned beef sandwich. I came here some during my lunch breaks, but not frequently because I was turned off by the line for expensive sandwiches. Still, there is no denying that delicious sandwich and nowadays, the lines aren't that bad anymore. It's relatively quick and I like that it's really just to go. No use in hanging around. The sandwich itself is on a salty focaccia and wtih some shredded boiled cabbage in between with the meat. It's filling for sure. Call ahead to order and pick up. Free candy too. $10 minimum for card.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Can't get enough of their corned-beef sandwich. Everything as a whole is great; from their choice of focaccia bread, dressing, & swiss cheese. Everything works together. I like the accompaniment of the little mint Andes chocolate and pickle too.

Downside is that it's only open on the weekdays and with a limited hours. It's really hard for me to try another sandwich since I always want the corned-beef when I go on my rare visits. It's even harder to try their breakfast muffins (which people tell me are delicious) as my office isn't close.

Overall thoughts: Wished they opened longer and/or on Saturdays so I can have more sandwiches.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
For me, Sentinel was a victim of its own success. Let me start by saying I had the Corned Beef sandwich. And, it was very good-just the right amount of dressing, bread was nice, and it was clearly high quality meat. 

But, it wasn't the kind of sandwich that I would stare daggers at you if you asked for a bite. It wasn't the kind of lunch spot that I would abuse on a 2-3 times a week basis. I see five stars and I think of food that I'm going to be thinking of for hours. It's been six hours and the corned beef isn't on my mind. Though, the wait isn't nearly as bad as I always think it will be. You are in and out of there in no time at all. 

A very good sandwich (some say expensive, but in SF you could do so much worse). But not an AMAZING sandwich. Also, I had the special once, but it wasn't as good as the corned beef.
author: Dustin M.

description:
If you're obsessed with sandwiches...than this is your type of place.  It's a corner store front on new montgomery that just deals with sandos...  No tables or eating space, just a line, register and some solid sandwiches.

I've tried items from both the hot and cold sandwich menus, and I have to say that my favorites are the corned beef with cabbage, Russian dressing and Swiss cheese and the lamb and the rare roast beef - mainly because of my obsession with horseradish.

Decent sized sandos, comes with some pickles.  The corned beef can feel a little greasy - but in that good way that you love.  Not THE most amazing sandwiches I've ever had - but a solid lunch option.
author: Arthur Y.

description:
Love their sandwiches. The line is kinda obnoxious, but it's less bad than sushirito and moves quick. The service is so fast, so the line won't last.  

Note: you're just getting your lunch here--you're not eating it here! Take your sandwich to one of the nice public parks near by like Yerba Buena! 

The sandwiches are so good and so big. They're creative and delicious. I do wish they had more good veg options...
author: Katy M.

description: Great sandwiches, prices are a bit steep but totally worth it. Make sure to bring cash as they don't accept credit for anything under $10.
author: James H.

description:
It's an interesting sandwich place, what can I say?

They pride themselves in being the non-conventional conventional sandwich, all the gourmet fixings and breads, plus non-standard meats like turkey meatballs and corned beef when it isn't St. Patrick's Day season. It's pretty impressive how quickly they churn out their eight or nine sandwiches to appease the sizable lunch crowd.

I'm a sucker for a warm, toasty sandwich with good flavor and meaty ingredients just like the rest of them, so it is unsurprising that the spicy pork and coleslaw (almost like a pork chop sandwich), the crunchy-focaccia-corned-beef combo and the vegetarian special have all come through in that lunchtime hour. The shop's close proximity to Yerba Buena Gardens makes it a lovely stop on the way to the park on a nice summer day.

Couple of places where I have "beef" with this restaurant - no tomatoes on the sandwiches (egregious in my opinion) and the price point is a little high. I think they can get away with it because they are located in the downtown SF area, but I'm not that old and I can say "I remember the day when sandwiches used to be $6." (That day was yesterday, somewhere a little further away!)

Hint: don't order the pasta special. It seems appealing and like it might be something they do specially, but it really isn't.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
I had the lamb and eggplant, and I don't know. I was really ready to like this but I just....didn't. It kind of tasted like a sloppy joe on a  fancy hamburger bun. Maybe I'm having a stroke.
Service there was amazingly quick and efficient though, so I don't want to crap on it too much. And everyone else seems to really like it. 
The pickle was great, though. Keep it up with the pickles.
author: Jessica M.

description:
first off let me say that i have been in Chicago in January and New York city in December. snowing and cold as he**.
so 45-50 in SF is nothing compared to those places, but it sure seemed chilly today.
i had to meet a friend for lunch at the Sentinel, an awesome sandwich place. but the lunch special today was chorizo and white bean stew. it sounded interesting. and tasted IN-CRED-BLE!
OMG, OMG, OMG.
texture, taste, and temperature were completely nailed.
tons of flavor
a little bit of spiciness from the chorizo but not overwhelming.
lots of meaty goodness.
it was in a word -WONDERFUL!
HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
too bad i cannot eat here daily.
I am a fan!
author: Jeff W.

description: Hot corned beef sandwich was terrific. Sentinel sign is covered up by construction. It is on the corner and a great find. No seating but a great grab and go restaurant.
author: Mypinions N.

description:
The Sentinel's comically small location offers few distractions from what repeat customers come back for: great sandwiches. My friend and coworker turned me on to this place during my recent visit to the big city. 

I had first come here weeks before, but gave up on waiting in the freezing weather in a long line that stretched halfway down a side alley. This time, upon my friend's suggestion, we ordered our food ahead of time and then walked right in 15 minutes later. What a great idea! Our sandwiches were warm and waiting!

I had the chicken salad sandwich with roasted peppers and artichoke hearts. It exceeded my already high expectations. Each bite was a cornucopia of flavor. It was a bit on the spicy side: let's just say I was feeling that red pepper long after my meal ended. 

I know I'll be coming back here again on my next visit!
author: Alex L.

description:
I don't get excited about lunch that often but when I do, I get excited about The Sentinel. This past week: Trout salad sandwich with fennel apple and dill on that seeded bun roll they use that makes me feel like I am The Most Interesting Man In The World. 

Post Script: After reading this review out loud to a gal pal, I found out I was completely lying when I wrote I don't get excited about lunch often & that I get -- quote -- "unreasonably excited," so let's attribute this call of I FUCKING LOVE LUNCH to the love that comes between the buns at The Sentinel.
author: Jon A.

description:
Looking for a solid lunch spot in the financial district?  The Sentinel has your back.  This tiny sandwich shop may be small, but they know how to serve mighty good sandwiches at a reasonable price.

A couple if friends and I stopped by for lunch and almost all of us grabbed a pork sandwich that turned out to be very solid.  The sauce was just the right amount of tangy, the slaw provided a great crunch, and the bread was a great compliment to the rest of the sandwich.

I also grabbed one of their cookies and found it to be relatively meh, but that didn't distract from the overall solid experience I had at The Sentinel.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Dear Chef Leary-
 
I have a problem.  His name is Eric.  
 
Eric is my co-worker.  He used to be friendly, well mannered and well liked in our office.  That is, until he discovered your sandwich shop.
 
Now it's all "The Sentinel" this, "The Sentinel" that.  He has been to "The Sentinel" EVERY DAY THIS WEEK.  He starts twitching around 11:30 am which of course is when your shop opens.    
 
And just the other day, he scarfed down his Reuben, Chocolate Chip Hazelnut Cookie, and Orange Gingerade then started eyeing my Turkey Salad Sandwich and Butter Cake with Roasted Figs.  But for my quick reflexes (i.e. kicked him in the groin) and speed (i.e. sprinted down the hall), I would have been lunchless that day. 
 
You are responsible for creating this hostile work environment.  FIX IT.  
 
Cordially,
Amy C.
author: Amy C.

description:
Came for work lunch pickup. Got the mango sandwich which sucked because the mangos were hard as hell. Maybe don't serve it if the ingredients aren't close to ripe? 
Coworkers liked their sandwiches though.
author: Tommy W.

description:
(See pic)

Trekked along Montgomery, as usual, on a nice day before treating the sacred body to something fresh.

Dennis Leary's fresh ingredients and simple elegant (sophisticated to conceptualize and produce) Californian technique have re-programmed one's appetite.

My colleague and I came down to pick up a couple sandwiches. I can't stop praising about the fresh bread-- foccacia had its crunchiness while the brioche bun was sweet and soft.

The corn beef was very flavourful while the lamb with eggplant, chickpeas and curry sandwiches was God send with a hint of spiciness. It raises the bar of take-out spots to a whole new gourmet level.

There was also this crazy crunchy one-half pickle that just redefined a pickle because it actually tasted fresh and not too vinegary, how oxymoron!

The peanut butter cookie was not your usual suspect, it was divine with soft and chewy peanut butter being sandwiched in the middle of the cookie.

The hot sandwich menu changes daily while the shop keeps most of the signature cold sandwiches. The list is long and I am amazed how a small shop can carry all these varied choices.
author: T L.

description:
5 stars because a bunch of other places downtown think they have amazing sandwiches and well they don't. So that's just for holding their ground.

No I didn't get the reuben because duh I'm not a clone. Eat the spicy pork. It was amazing. The spicy was spicy the crispy was crispy and the bread was saturated with some sort of meat juice that came from the french side of a pig.

5 more points for not having a sign that identifies the building, and 7 stars for having a bunch of hard to place accented attractive but friendly people taking the orders. 

Don't be an idiot just get a meaty sandwich and shut up. 

3 more stars for the pickle, but I make my own pickles so that was a long shot for them.

That's 20 stars. - 1 star to Yelp for not allowing 20 stars.
author: Patrick S.

description: Fantastic hidden gem in soma. Corn beef is amazing and the service is quick and nice. Get here early as the line can be long and they run out of specials quickly. Also try the roast beef.
author: Marc R.

description:
Best sandwiches downtown. Tons of variety; always fresh and hearty. The breakfast fare is totally delicious too. 

Great, friendly, speedy service from nice familiar folks who remember your name. 

Love the Sentinel!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
With such high marks on Yelp, you can't NOT have high expectations for a place like this.

Here's the deal: I'm an Ike's girl--through and through. I think he has some of the best sammiches in town. And yeah, I consider myself a sammich kinda gal. So I was stoked to see such a highly rated sammich place a few steps from my workplace.

I called in the order, walked over, and picked it up. I got the roast beef--which comes rare--with horseradish sauce and smoked onions.
 
Was it any good? Yeah. Yeah, it was. And it was Rare with a capital R; like, the paper it was wrapped in was spotted with bloody marks.

Was it worth the $9.50 price tag? Ehh... not really.

Also, they don't accept credit cards for anything less than $10; so you'll just have to eat the 0.50 cents. (Probably not as tasty as the sammich, though. Har, har.)
author: Adena B.

description:
So the Sentinel is a joint that people walk be every day and I am sure they do not even notice it exists. It is literally the size of a corridor and they are serving up delicious lunch fare sandwiches both hot and cold. The signs above the store state "cigar" and all this other good jazz and it is right across the street from the Palace. A team I am working with have been traveling to SF all year and staying at the palace but had never noticed or been to this spot so I decided to take them here for lunch one day. 

I would definitely recommend showing up to this spot before 12 because the line will literally stretch around the corner and down the block. They take credit cards but it is only after you spend a certain dollar amount. I think the most noticeable sandwich and one which receives a lot of praise is the Corned Beef sandwich and for good reasons. This sandwich has corned beef, cabbage, and Russian dressing in between two large slabs of focaccia. This thing is an awesome lunch selection but definitely get ready to fall into the afternoon nap mode after 2 PM. For those looking for a lighter fare the Turkey sandwich is a nice option which was interesting because I did not think cranberry and chipotle mayo would work but it does for this sandwich. I have had a few other sandwiches here and all have been solid. This is definitely a joint that I am a fan of and somewhere I always try to hit up whenever I am in town.
author: Dan M.

description: The pickle that came with the sandwich wasn't so great (it was kind of bitter), but I was really impressed with the BALT sandwich (basil, avocado, lettuce, tomato, goat cheese) and the quick service.
author: Michelle G.

description: Walked in around 2pm, no line at all and very fast and friendly service. Walked out a few minutes later with the best corn beef sandwich I have ever had in my life!
author: Scott C.

description:
This is exactly how a small business should operate. 

It's pretty wild that my three minute exchange chatting with the lovely ladies who work behind The Sentinel counter has become a part of my day that I look forward to. They are so sweet and friendly. 

The baked goods are always warm and savory, my favorites are the peach muffins, banana bread and the small steel-cut oatmeal with fruit and nuts (no brown sugar sugar needed here, believe dat). I've been here for lunch and it's equally awesome (minus line around the block).

Prices are reasonable but it's cash only. There have been a few times when I forget cash and they let me pay them back later. 

Props to you, Sentinel. I have a crush on your food, staff and business model. You do SOMA, SF proud.
author: Alison D.

description: I always get a corned beef sandwich whenever I go here for lunch. Not a long waiting time either. I'm in and out in under 5-10 minutes.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
The open air environment of The Sentinel lets you smell your future goodness before you can even see inside.  I'm not sure how the ordering and receiving your food process was so fast, but it was.  As we walked up, there was a decent line outside the door.  Even with the line, I barely had enough time to look at the menu posted on the window before it was time to order.

I ordered the pulled pork sandwich.  Being from the south, I wanted to see how pulled pork was don in San Francisco.  My first shock came from the size of the sandwich.  It was conveniently cut into two pieces.  It quickly seemed obvious to me that the sandwich was probably intended for two people.  The pork was as tender as I've ever had.  I ended up favoring my taste buds rather than my full stomach, and finished the whole thing.

From this southerner, The Sentinel and its pork get a "bravo."
author: Will L.

description:
Messy, messy, messy! Being a 'shroom lover, I ordered the bbq mushroom sandwich. Delicious, but what an overflowing mess to eat during lunchtime! Grab a stack of napkins (I didn't and regretted it), because you WILL need them. Sauce gushes out of every which corner! Despite the hassle in eating this, the bun was moist and flavorful, the portabello juicy, and the accompanying sauce super tasty.

I'm definitely interested in checking out the BALT sandwich next time. They seem to have interesting specials of the day, as well, but those include dessert and are thus priced a bit higher. It's a small menu overall, but the few sandwiches they do have, they do well, and everything is put together quickly. 

P.S. This is a grab-and-go spot. No seating available. Also, $10 minimum order to use a credit card.
author: Mansi A.

description:
Was able to get in line just shortly after 11:45am with only 5 people in line! The line moves very quickly here and decided to go for the Lamb and Eggplant hot sandwich as it sound interesting. 

Yes, absolutely a instant hit for my sammie list. The sesame & poppy seed bun with lamb, eggplant, chickpea and curry herb pesto was heavenly. The ingredients combine works like magic in making this sandwich a excellent choice for a first timer.
author: Wolfy W.

description: Really solid sandwich spot - hole in the wall. Lamb was delicious.
author: Greg C.

description:
Yes, this truly deserves 5 stars. I got the corned beef sandwich and it was one of the best sandwiches of my life. Imagine a Reuben sandwich but replace sauerkraut with crunchy coleslaw and rye bread with foccacia. I'm a big fan of Reubens but this was taking my love to a whole new level. Get there early because they do run out. The lines moves pretty quickly and they are efficient. Can't wait to go back and try the chicken mole and coppa sandwiches. 

$10 min on credit cards. Definitely a winner on the 7X7 100 things to eat before you die. I will be going back.
author: Jackie T.

description: This place is just killing it! Never disappointed and always try the specials! They are special for a reason :)!!!!! Keep up he good work!
author: Mark M.

description: The Sentinel is a tiny kitchen on an unassuming corner in the FiDi. On a Thurs around noon, the line was not long and my three friends and I quickly zipped in one doorway and out the other to order our meals. I got the lamb and eggplant sandwich, which came out faster than my friend's corned beef. I imagined strips of lamb meat when I ordered it, but actually the sandwich filling is composed primarily of ground meat mixed with garbanzo beans in a red sauce. Basically, a gourmet sloppy joe. I can say that the overall flavor of the meal was that of spaghetti, which is not bad but odd. I liked the soft, heated wheat bun that I opted for over white (you get a choice if you don't order the corned beef, I think). The sandwiches come with a pickle and an Andes mint, which always make me happy.
author: Amy G.

description:
I hadn't been here in over two years until last week.  

Two years! That was before Bdizzle was elected, before John Locke died, before Lady Gaga's bubble dress.  A lot can happen in two years.

What happened at the Sentinel is that it got a little more tastier, and what happened to me is that I am more likely to spend the extra few buxx on an amazing sandwich.

I had the spicy tuna with fennel, it was incredibly delicious.  It was the right texture, sort of like a ceviche sandwich. And the bread stood up to the challenge this time.

The homemade strawberry lemonade was full of chunky chunks of strawberry.  Sitting in Yerba Buena in the sun, this was one of the most idyllic lunches in a long time.
author: Joanna M.

description: Nice place to have a quick sandwich. I had the muffatella, it was somewhat healthy I think, and it tasted like any other sandwich - nothing special there. The girl was very nice, she gave me a free cookie because they were out of stock to make beef sandwiches. The price is a bit high for what the serve. I'll go back there if I'm on a hurry for the lunch.
author: Patrick D.

description:
Someone told me that The Sentinel rivals Ike's...which got me really excited, and made me question why I haven't tried The Sentinel before. The line was long but surprisingly quick and I couldn't wait to dig into my lamb and eggplant sando. 

Long story short- I was not impressed. The bread was OK. The sandwich filling was a little mushy and  not as flavorful as I would have liked. I'm surprised whenever I pass by for lunch, that the line is always so long. Maybe I picked the wrong sandwich and the others are better- but for ~$9 for a sandwich, I'll probably go somewhere else next time.
author: Christine A.

description:
The only thing, ONLY THING that bothers me about this spot is the prices. It's a bit pricey for me which is a shame because if it wasn't, I would go here weekly. Their sandwiches are great! $9 sandwiches - probably driven by quality, because the quality is high, but I'm a poor girl.

Sandwiches I've tried:

Lamb & Eggplant: Uniquely yummy. Good choice if you want something warm and comforting.

Smoked Trout: Probably my least favorite sandwich I've tried. I couldn't taste enough trout. It was a lot of veggies and a little disappointing.

Corned Beef: My favorite so far! Meat-filled goodness. Just the right size and just the right portions of meat to bread to everything else!

Service is quick and easy. The line out the door may be intimidating, but it goes by fast!
author: Junel S.

description: I'm not a big sandwich fan, but these are not your everyday sandwiches. Delicious and filling!
author: Goumada S.

description:
I tried the corned beef w/cabbage, swiss, Russian dressing... Good portion of meat on sandwich, cabbage was fresh, swiss was good melted, Russian dressing was mildly tangy and the bread was delicious. I'm not sure the name of the bread but it looked like focaccia.

Overall it was a good, tasty sandwich.
author: Wallace A.

description: This place is a life saver for downtown SF. Quality sandwiches from top to bottom of the menu, and the bread tops it off. I love the salmon, deviled egg, and eggplant sandwiches, and Teresa and her staff are super friendly. Prices are reasonable and this lunch keeps me full til' dinner time!
author: Marcel M.

description:
I have a confession to make: I have a serious aversion to lunch lines. This is partly because I am often in a rush but mostly because by the time 12pm rolls around I tend to be a little hangry. Having worked around the corner from The Sentinel for 9 months and gazing wistfully at their consistently long lunch line, I finally cracked one day and decided it was time to check this place out. Oh boy, I am glad I did. 

The Sentinel has a relatively small daily menu but every item sounds mouth-wateringly delicious.  On the day I decided to go I just couldn't go past the BBQ'd mushrooms and goats cheese sandwich. The meaty shrooms were thickly cut and oozing juices over the creamy goats cheese and buttery bun. It is probably too messy for a first date, but worth it for the delectability. My only qualm was one lonely piece of iceberg lettuce, which the mushroom rendered limp and rather slimy. 

Oh and as for the aforementioned line, we arrived just before 12pm and it was not an issue... in and out in under 10 minutes. Success!
author: Alex D.

description:
Their corned beef was amazing, and I don't even like corned beef. I also sampled some chickpea based thing which was just meh.  I went way past lunch time so there wasn't much wait, but I can see how this little shop gets a lot of traffic.  It's also located at the corner of the block and a little discrete so I had to keep an eye out to find it.  

Muffins were just ok, nothing to rave about.
author: Katie C.

description:
Good lunch sandwiches! Definitely a notch up from the usual sandwich joints because of the better ingredients. I had the corned beef sandwich (with swiss and cabbage. They don't have the gruyere, sadly), and it was excellent. The bread was more like a ciabatta and was very crispy on the outside, while the corned beef was complemented well by the cabbage.

If you can get there early, consider getting the daily special, since it seems to sell out quickly. I've looked at their online menu a couple times now and they look mouthwatering good. If I worked nearby I'd go to this place all the time!
author: Alice C.

description:
Heard great things about this place from a few fellow yelpers and was finally able to try it the other day as I was out looking for a place to eat.

Walked up to the place and it looks like a regular newspaper stand...with no newspapers or magazines on sale.  Saw a sign that directs customers to enter the side door on Stevenson St.  Their menus are posted on that wall as well.

Hmmm....heard this place serves good corn beef sandwich....so I gave that a go.  As soon as I gave them my cash...the sandwich was already in my hands.  Wow...that was super fast....and it was warm.

Uh oh...there's no place to sit since it's a very small deli at the corner of the Fidi....and the sandwich is warm.  Which means I have to get back to the office ASAP or else the bread will be all soggy when I take my first bite.

Got back to the office within 5 minutes and took a bite out of it.

I declare this the BEST corn-beef sandwich I ever had thanks to its sweet-marinated cabbage and the toasty, crunchy bread.  Served with a side of dill pickle and an Andes mint...all for less than $10.

I will definitely come back here again during lunch and go down their list of sandwiches.

I'm so giddly that I found a new joint to eat in the Fidi!
author: Dave L.

description: Had the TERRIFIC lamb and chickpea sandwich. It's so flavorful, and a really big portion (read: good value) and the bread is delicious. I called ahead when they opened at 11:30 and placed my order. When I arrived my sandwich wasn't ready because they had no bread yet ... that was weird and I had to wait around for like 15 minutes, which was a little frustrating, but the sandwich was so good that it was worth the wait :).
author: Anna S.

description:
I came back to the Sentinel and, yup, that corned beef sandwich was
still as good as I remembered, maybe even better.  I'm glad Mr. Leary is not messin with a good thing.  Such a light, fresh taste - nowhere near salty, nowhere near bland.  And the bread was fantastic.  I'm happy to see that not much has changed.  If anything, they've changed for the better.  

For some strange reason, there was no line at noon, plus they seem to be much friendlier and even more efficient now.  On the negative side, the sandwich was still on the small and pricey side.  Oh well, still a superior quality sandwich, so no problem for me, other than that I'm still a lil' hungry and I'm down 10 bucks already.
author: Angel S.

description:
Without the line outside, you probably wouldn't find this place. I came here with my friend to try their Corned Beef sandwich. We arrived around the lunch hour so the line was a bit long, but surprisingly they work fast so we didn't have a long wait.

I personally LOVE corned beef and when I got this sandwich it didn't quite come up to my expectations on what I thought it'd be but it still gave me a mouth full of flavor with each bite. What I'd like to point out is how interesting the bread was. It looked like roasted pork or garlic bread and definitely tasted odd, but in a good way.

I would love to try out the rest of their menu when I get the chance to knowing I won't have to wait very long and this place would have had five stars if this was my first time eating corned beef.
author: Richard C.

description:
If you're looking to grab some fancy sandwiches, this is the place.
There may be a short line at lunch but it goes fast. I would recommend getting the pulled pork sandwich which was awesome. They don't have a giant menu but I think it changes every couple weeks or something.
author: XiaoChuan Y.

description:
I had the corned beef sandwich: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kEhq0qT_JFxgeh-pCS4lPA?select=H0yZX2bx5N5jSddngp9htA
It was OK, not great, and it did not live up to the hype.
author: Scott F.

description:
Love the sandwiches here. Don't be turned off by the line because, even if it wraps around the corner, you will be through it in 10min, sandwich in hand. I'm not kidding. They are so incredibly efficient, it's great. There is one person who takes your order, one to ring you up, a ton in the back making the sandwich, and then one person to actually give you the sandwich. Like clockwork. 

And the sandwiches are huge and tasty. They will give you a happy belly.
author: Mariko F.

description:
I decided that last Friday was gonna be corned-beef D-Man day.
After yelping, I decided to try The Sentinel.
Long line, but it wasn't chaotic and it moves fast.

The neighborhood has changed over the years, and it's nice to see the mass development and money pouring in for property and business.

Onto my sandwich...I ordered up their corned beef sammie.
It was just okay. Good delicious flavors as one would expect from a Reuben.

The sandwich breading was collasping under the meat juices and dressing.
Luckily, I had grabbed a plastic fork and attacked the remaining meal like a salad.
Their menu listings are nice. Judging by the amount of people lining up, they have a cult following.

Add me to that list.
author: Derek N.

description: A little pricy, but good and tasty sandwiches. No place to sit in the small shop, but it's a block or two from Yerba Buena Gardens, which is a great place to eat your sandwich and watch people. I'll be back!
author: Steve F.

description:
The corned beef sandwich is supposedly the only menu item worth eating here. I haven't come even close to trying everything on the menu, but from the three different kinds of sandwiches that I have tried, the corned beef is definitely the best.

It's unfortunate that they close at 2:30 because that's not an unreasonable time to have a late lunch, but since it's take-out only you can just order whatever sandwich you want to eat and take it back to your workplace. Or, if you're out of work and homeless, order your sandwich and move a block down towards Mission and share with the other homeless people.
author: Andrew W.

description: Some of the best food I've ever eaten. It is a joy to experience a sandwich from The Sentinel. Busy place at lunchtime but you can order ahead on Yelp (or get there at 11:30 when they open.) I love supporting small business and they do a fantastic job of serving you a great meal at a reasonable price. I highly recommend the lamb eggplant sandwich. Even their pickles have a delicious unique taste! Open weekdays for lunch only.
author: Joe B.

description:
3 1/2 stars. 

The crab with corn sandwhich is pretty good. Very refreshing, but way to much bread. It's so hard to eat.

The corn beef is good. 

I waited awhile for my food, so they gave me 2 cookies on the house, which was very nice of them. 

Service is good, but I think the sandwiches have to much bread.
author: Karen H.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while and I finally made it today. It's a small spot on New Montgomery Street. Menu is not huge, but had some tasty sounding sandwiches on there. I ordered the Turkey sandwich, it came with your choice of wheat or white bread, turkey breast, cheese, spicy mayo, lettuce and cranberry sauce. Oh and they throw in a pickle and andes candy! I didn't have to wait long for my sandwich, the workers are friendly and efficient. 
I will try the corned beef sandwich next time since everyone has recommended it. I will definitely come back and will bring a friend.
author: Jeanie Ann D.

description: I tried there lamb sandwich, it was Gud, this place is really crowded all the tym. The bread was so delicious and it didn't took much tym to prepare the order super fast loved there service!!!
author: Shyam N.

description: Yup, it's true. These sandwiches are where it's at. Particularly the roast beef -- dang. That is one good sandwich. I also kinda appreciate that you can get your dose of the East Coast on Market and Montgomery. No frills service, and out the door you go.
author: Mel G.

description:
For some unknown reason I've stayed away from The Sentinel for over a year.  I can't say why, I just never craved their sandwiches.  Well, last week I decided to give 'em another go.  Guess what?  I ate there twice within 24 hours.

I like how their menu is kept small, probably so it's easier to get those large lunchtime crowds moving along.  They have about 10 sandwiches on the menu as well as a special of the day, which comes with dessert.  So far I've tried the corned beef (Reuben...I'm kind of obsessed), spicy pork (no, not pulled pork, sliced pork loin in a nice spicy sriracha-like sauce), & egg salad (pleasantly spicy!).  I have yet to be disappointed with a sandwich from The Sentinel.  The folks that work there are very nice & they make sure that your wait is as short as possible.

Great, quality food, served up fast, a block from work...yep I'm a fan.
author: Erin S.

description: Don't let the line scare you away. They are super fast.  I've only had the corned beef so far, but it was great.  Lots of meat and just enough sauce so that the bread did not get soggy, even after Barting back to the east bay.
author: Michelle R.

description:
The employees here work more efficiently and quickly than at most fast food restaurants.  They certainly cater to the fast paced life of many who work in the FiDi.  I waited in a short line out the door during the bustling weekday lunch hour and within less than five minutes I ordered, payed and got the corned beef sandwich I've been dying to sink my teeth into for the past year or so.

I'm a pretty big fan of corned beef and cabbage and this combo of tender strips of corned beef  with cabbage, Russian dressing and melted Swiss on focaccia was a winner.  Not the best corned beef I've had in my day and the sandwich was a bit on the smaller side, leaving me still a little hungry, but I would certainly grab another one should the opportunity present itself.
author: Erich D.

description:
It's been a while but now that working in Union Square area of course I had to return to the Sentinel.  The sandwiches are just as good as before but now they seem to have more filling in them so I'm happy to have them as my go to fancy sandwich place.  In fact, my entire office goes there all the time for lunch.  

So far my favorite sandwich is the corned beef.

***Tip: call ahead and skip the line.  You can call as soon as they open and let them know when you plan on coming by.  Then you just have to go up and pay.  However, if you come during crunch time 12-1 then you might find yourself in line to pay behind walk up customers and other call aheads.  Try to pickup either before noon or late lunch.
author: Jean K.

description:
Their muffins are still warm and the perfect addition to a rainy commute to the office.

But wait, I finally braved their lunch rush and inhaled "The Lonza": a ham, mustard and spicy slaw sandwich that was gone in under five minutes. The best.
author: Angelina C.

description: Best bread!  Their sister restaurant golden west is just as good. I would go every week if i could!
author: Noelle B.

description:
Such simple ingredients, yet oh so good.
Had the roast beef with blue cheese, smoked onions and butter lettuce. 
The beef is prepared rare and rare it is. 
And how the hell did they get their blue cheese to be so creamy and flavorful?!
author: Donna M.

description:
The Dish: I got the Corned Beef Sandwich. It was okay - nothing spectacular. I hate giving 3 stars, but this place really IS just A-ok. I didn't feel like "wow, this is so good and I'm coming back" but I also didn't think that it was the worst sandwich ever. It's really messy so be sure to bring wet wipes or hand sanitizer. And random tip, don't leave the mint sitting in the sun...gets all over your bag... 

Ambiance: It's a street-side cafe. Cute and fast!
author: Gina T.

description:
The Sentinel's muffins are the bee's on my knees. They're massive, bagged up still warm, and come in delicious flavors like strawberry, sour cherry, and butternut squash. Equally awesome are the coffee cake (best ever), banana bread (full of bananas), lemon pound cake, and the oatmeal. The oatmeal! It's hearty and thick and packed with fruit. 

I'd also add the staff there is always chipper and lovely and oh so kind.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Hot damn -- this place serves up a tasty pork sandwich.  Definitely in the Ike's Place category of gigantic, ridiculously-unhealthy-but-delicious sandwiches with long lines and high sandwich throughput.  I received about a half a pound of saucy, saucy pig.  A co-worker got a roast beef sandwich that was stacked a mile high.

One star off -- a sandwich is ~ $8.00.  That's a lot of dollars, even for a delicious sandwich.
author: Bill H.

description:
What the Sentinel lacks in size it more than makes up for in flavor: I happened in on a recent sunny day for some fare to takeaway to the lunch in the park. The word's long been out on this place, which I have yet to see without the requisite winding line making its way first in one entrance, then out the other side and into the street. 

It's a pretty simple arrangement when you get right down to it, and they're working with a rather skeleton crew: when I popped in, one guy barked out the orders while another toiled away in the kitchen. What you end up with is a street food experience that seems much less like street food than your eyes would lead you to believe: I chose the pork sandwich, which arrived on what seemed to be a sort of grilled baguette, piled high with pork and its accompanying sauce. It's a pretty hearty offering for the bucks. I'm not in the city all that often these days, but next time I am, there's a fair chance I'll be back.
author: Kevin N.

description:
A changing menu of delicious sandwichs. Great bread that always paired appropriately with the inside ingredients. The sandwiches don't weigh me down, but don't leave me hungry. 
The tuna is awesome, not too creamy
Various chicken sandwiches are great
Veg sandwiches are filling and satisfying
author: kaizar C.

description:
I'm no expert of corned beef, nor an expert of sandwich, but I came here for the corned beef sandwich. When I think of a corned beef sandwich, I think of dead saltiness in between two breads with some hint of meatiness from a canned beef stew. Surprisingly, The Sentinel's corned beef sandwich, is the total opposite of my imaginative description. In between two fluff and satisfying pieces of focaccia was layers and layers of corned beef topped with Russian Dressing which was tangy and sweet, balancing out with the savoriness of the corned beef, which is surprisingly not too overpowering, the marinated cabbage on the top adds a great soft crunch and a mustard-y bitterness to the whole sandwich, and the swiss cheese is just perfectly sharp enough to linger through the flavor of the corned beef. It was like nothing I have ever had before, it hit my every taste bud comfortably.
