If you're like me, who believe deeply in the recommendations on yelp, with the corned beef sandwich here reviewed 350 times plus being featured on Unique Eats, YOU know YOU GOTTA HAVE IT even if the sentinel is on top of the Mount Everest.
author: David H.

description:
The Sentinel just made it's way into my regular lunch schedule after my last visit. 

The line looks long, BUT DON'T BE INTIMIDATED, it goes very fast as they have staff coming outside to take orders in line in order to expedite the process.

I had the spicy pork on wheat, and it was incredible. The pork was perfectly cooked, well seasoned and they don't skimp on the sandwich meat! If you are looking for a satisfying sandwich with innovative flavors, this is a great place to try out.

Put this into your lunch rotation... DO IT!
author: Justin O.

description: OMG the corned beef sandwich. I'm quite the corned beef sandwich aficionado and am very particular about the taste, but this was hands down my favorite in San Francisco. My favorite is still Canter's deli in Los Angeles, and it does come close, but still for San Francisco its fantastic. I work nearby so will definitely be back.
author: Cody M.

description:
I had the corned beef Reuben thing, it was stellar!

otherwise it's an odd place - tiny, no seating, long line, few options - you go in and pick up your amazing sandwich and get out.
author: Matt M.

description: Very mediocre eggplant bbq sandwich. Eggplant wasn't cooked enough, bbq was flavorless, cheese was disgusting, bread was too think, tasteless, and unheated. I paid $10 for this crap sandwich. Never going back there.
author: Alicia E.

description:
I was a bit disappointed since I went here hoping to see what all the hype was about with the corn beef & gruyere sandwich only to find out they aren't serving it w/ gruyere anymore and have replaced it with swiss cheese. NO GRUYERE!!??! That changes the entire sandwich! Since they didn't the right combination for my 1st choice, I was going to get a fish sandwich, but there were none on the menu yesterday. So I ultimately decided on the spicy pork sandwich on a wheat bun. If it hadn't been for the sauce on the coleslaw in the sandwich, it would have been overly dry just from the bread alone. It wasn't terrible, but it definitely didn't leave me wanting more.

TIP: they don't always have Andes candy as a bonus, i got a sugar free werthers candy ...another big disappointment :(
author: Kristen C.

description:
My 4 star rating is largely for the breakfast at Sentinel. In fact, I would probably give the breakfast 5 stars, because it's that fantastic! They have fresh muffins (my favorite is the sour cherry, followed closely by the butternut squash muffin) as well as banana bread and lemon pound cake and the like. These are always warm when I get them and taste absolutely fantastic! They also have steel-cut oatmeal with fruit, which is absolutely delicious and something I've grown to crave! If you want a delicious and filling breakfast, I would absolutely give The Sentinel a shot!

However, when it comes to lunch, I've been rather underwhelmed. I've had the smoked trout salad sandwich here and the lamb and eggplant sandwich and I'm rather unimpressed and would give it maybe 2 stars. The bread, which is fairly tasty, overwhelms the flavor of any sandwich and make them fairly bland. 

A definite do for breakfast, but I'd skip the lunch rush. Also keep in mind they are pretty much cash only (for lunch I think they have a minimum of $10).
author: Maria G.

description:
Corned beef in a can? No way! Corned beef in sandwich form? Yep!! 

Location: Cool little sandwich shop in the SOMA district. Close to the Academy of Art & tons of businesses, so expect lots of students & professionals alike. 

Time: Only open M-F, from 7:30am-2:30pm. It tends to crowd up fast around lunch time. Better to come around 11:30am or call in your order for pick-up.  Otherwise, the line wraps around the corner. 

Food: The Corned Beef w/ Gruyere Sandwich is delicious! No wonder it's listed on the 7x7 list. The bread is thick, slightly buttered, and soft... has the right amount of crunch on the edges, too. The corned beef slices are tender and slightly sweet. No relation whatsoever to that cheap stuff in a can. Comes with shredded cabbage, melted cheese, and a little bit of mayo. It's gooooood! Nice to bite into that crunchy pickle and finish off your meal with a little Andes chocolate.

Service: Staff is as friendly as they can be, but since they are backed up their main concern is to get you w/ your meal and out the door.

Tip: no seating area available. However, you can sneak into the Palace Hotel across the street and go to the 2nd floor to enjoy the goods. Shhh!!
author: Joy A.

description:
Ohhh man the meatball and palenta dish may be my new favorite food. I had never had palenta before but I'm pretty sure theres was the best on earth. The sauce they used on the huge meatballs was- amazeballs. I also had a teeny bite of my friend's roast beef sando and that was pretty epic as well.

Definitely worth the price and small line. Only thing is that it's a minimum of $10 for cards (and my dish was $9...womp womp)
author: Cesie A.

description: Really delicious and quick. Minus one star because I found a big, fatty brown hair in my sandwich today. It can happen to anyone, but it's quite gross when it does.
author: Marlen K.

description:
Wow, this place is really good. This is the kind of place I am always looking for.  Place that serves unique food and is not too expensive or pretentious.  

I had the chicken dumpling sandwich which was yummy. I was surprised to find that they had pomegranate juice which was made there and good too. The oatmeal cookie was just OK.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Dear Sentinel,

I don't know if you guys read your reviews but if you see this update it's just to say how AWESOME you are. You know why (x4). 

Fondly, 
Phil
author: Phil D.

description:
Went here for a late lunch during the work week because of it's great Yelp! rating.

It's kind of a classic SF lunch place with an open door: you enter, order, and walk out. 

The menu changes most days, and they have several sandwich items and usually a salad and a few cookie options.

I order the cauliflower sandwich quite randomly, and while is was a totally odd and unusual flavor, I really enjoyed it.
author: Chloé M.

description:
I know I know you're supposed to get the corned beef when you come here but I don't like corned beef! Sooooo I ordered their roast beef ($9.50) without the blue cheese. Ugh so good. And MASSIVE. Onto the details...

Bread: Slightly sweet, topped with black & white sesame seeds (nice touch) and very soft. Maybe a bit too soft, I would've preferred to it have more of a crust to hold in the sandwich meat more. 

Meat: The roast beef was sooo tender. Thinly sliced, perfectly spiced and salted. It was nice and rare and a little bloody. Very very good but a bit scary looking I think after the blood got soaked into the soft bread.  

Side note: Overall the sandwich was big, filling and delicious. My only gripe is about the bread otherwise they would've gotten 5 stars. Cash only if your meal's under $10.
author: Beverly T.

description:
An exhilarating stroll from SoMA to Union Square today (my inner Bill Cunningham was most appreciative) .  On my return meander, I found myself on New Montgomery.  

Hmm, not much of a line at 1 pm, so I fell in at The Sentinel, which is still fabulously cheerful and efficient.  A truly excellent rare beef sandwich on wheat -- tender, generous, and oh, so, gorgeously red ! -- with the one perfect whole pickle and small chocolate apres.

I would have snapped my sandwich in the glorious SF sun, but alas, the sandwich had a more pressing role to play.
author: Mutant O.

description: That corned beef sandwich was so good! I was fortunate enough to have it delivered to me, but the size of the sandwich left my stomach hurting from eating it all in one sitting! Can't wait to get it myself! YUMS.
author: Diana L.

description:
Maybe I went on a bad day.

So I decided to get a sammy at around 1:30pm to beat the lunch rush and it was fairly empty.  The menu is on the side door and not above on the board behind the cash register so make sure you know what you want before you stand in line.

I got the Corned Beef with cabbage, Swiss, and Russian dressing... isn't this practically a Reuben?  After I received my sandwich, I walked quickly back to my office which took about 5 minutes... only to find that by then the bread was soggy!  So disappointing.  The flavor of the sandwich is very salad-like and the Swiss was quality but I really couldn't get over the bread.  I hoped maybe the pickled would be redeeming but it wasn't crisp like I like and believe me, it's not because it was overpickled either.

So for $8.75, I'll have to pass next time... unless perhaps it's a cold sandwich.
author: Shannon L.

description: Great lunch spot with delicious sandwiches. If you're in a hurry, don't go during peak lunchtime hours, though. The line can get a bit long.
author: Kyle K.

description:
I had the SPICY CHICKEN SALAD with mango, roasted red peppers, pumpkin seeds, and cilantro relish for $8.50. 

The dressing was a nice change from cream based dressing and vinagrettes with the heat from the spice in the dressing and the cilantro relish.  

The chicken itself is not spicy which was great.  The only reason this salad is not getting 5 stars is because it only comes with about three pieces of bib lettuce that isn't cut up.  It is a salad after all and could benefit from a few extra pieces of lettuce.  

However, it is really a nice change from typical chicken salads so I give it a four.  

Also, my colleagues rave about the TURKEY SANDWICH, although I've never tried it.  

When they have the SHRIMP SALAD on occasion, I enjoy that, 
too.  It is loaded with shrimp, a nice amount of dill, pepperoncini's and meshes well with all of these ingredients in a refreshing way.

The service is always great, and the ladies who head up the front are always quick to complete and get out the orders.  The gentleman who preps the food is fast and the place is well run.  Nice job.
author: Ana W.

description:
The boss is in town..and it was my turn to buy lunch today. Picked a BBQ sando for him..and the daily special for me--the daily special rocked!! Turkey Mole on basamati rice...and rich avocado salsa on butter lettuce..oh..yea..and the butterscotch flan...
Boss loved his sando..happy boss= happy me...
author: Mimi T.

description:
Help! I"m addicted to The Sentinel! I didn't get all the fuss at first, but now I can't seem to spend a day in SF without making my way over there for one of their heavenly sandwiches.

While most of their customers seem to be all about the corned beef, I get my sentinel crack in the form of the eggplant and goat cheese sandwich. SO delicious- and the homemade bread is especially divine. And of course I wash it all down with their watermelon lemonade. A must if you're eating here!

The lines are always long and the servers have a bit of 'tude, but last time they gave us extra cookies when we complained they forgot part of our order. I can handle a bit of 'tude for cookies and tasty food.
author: Andrea R.

description: Excellent place for an on-the-go lunch! The menu is short and concise and it took about 2 minutes for them to prepare a hot sandwich. I ordered a delicious lamb and eggplant sandwich. It was a soft bun stuffed with lamb, beans, eggplant and avocado - very filling. Bonus points for the way the sandwich is prepared because it's easy to eat it anywhere without making a mess.
author: Leon R.

description: I like that the muffins here are baked on-premises, and are often warm from the oven when you get them,  but when said muffin + a large coffee comes to $6.00, I can't help but feel that they're a bit overpriced (the same combo costs $4.25 at Peet's, $5.30 at Bread & Cocoa, $5.20 at Andersen Bakery). What makes The Sentinel so special to warrant such a markup? The muffin IS good (and fresh), but when everyone else costs less, I really can't justify it.
author: Eric H.

description:
I'm really not sure what the big deal about this place. I work right next to it and during lunch time there's a decent sized line so I assumed it will be good. 

Nothing at all was amazing. It was kind of just decent. I tried two sandwiches and none were memorable at all. Fidi doesn't have the best food, but I can easily find better in the area.
author: Justin C.

description:
Fall-apart Corned Beef, Weapons-Grade Chickpea and Eggplant and line run on pure military efficiency. Nestled into the shadow of The Palace Hotel is a beast of a sandwich shop. There is nothing about this place that isn't doesn't demand admiration and respect.

Do not underestimate The Sentinel, my friends. It will /bury you./
author: Ryan A.

description:
"Faithfully keeping hunger at bay" (why is a sandwich shop named after a guard?)

Smoked trout with fennel and apple. Delicious, filling, and interesting :)

Good food to go. Fast. Good Value. "Microbrewed" sodas by Thomas Kemper.
author: Oleg H.

description:
Drooling, just thinking about it. Corned Beef Sandwich - enough said. 

Well, probably not enough for the sake of this review, but OMG MOUTHWATERING.

As someone who isn't a huge fan of red meat, their corned beef with russian dressing sends me over the moon. The foccacia bread is perfectly toasted to be crisp on the outside, soft on the inside.

Yeah, the sandwich is $9, or $10 with tax (a bit more on the expensive side), but it's definitely large enough to feed me for two meals (And I can eat a lot for a girl!). Albeit, it's not as good for the second meal as when its freshly made for lunch, but I'm not complaining.

Perfect place to go to lunch if you're working in FiDi in the area. Line gets long pretty quickly and they definitely sell out of some sandwiches if you get there too late.

Cherry on top is definitely the complimentary Andes mint they give you :)

Oh yeah, just a note - WHY ARE ALL THE CUSTOMERS MEN?! WHERE ALL MY LADIES AT? You're missing out!!!
author: Connie Y.

description:
This place is very good, but I wouldn't even consider giving it a 5-star rating.  I'm OK with four stars but feel that that's a tad generous.

I went for the first time with a friend.  We had only a short time for lunch and I expected a long line (as depicted in one of the yelp photos).  Seeing that we arrived at 12:15, I was thinking that we might have to grab a sandwich elsewhere.  But, miracle of miracles, there were only one or two people ahead of us.  As has probably been described in other reviews, someone came out to take our orders before we were even near the cash register.  (This is a Starbucks technique.)  By the time we paid for our orders, my hot corned beef sandwich on flatbread was being slid into its box.

The positive: the sandwich was really good and the accompanying pomegranate juice was a welcome refreshment.

The negative: the sandwich wasn't *that* good.  It was a tad on the small side.  And the prices are pretty high here -- if I remember correctly, it was $11.75 for the reuben and the drink.

The comparison with Berkeley's Grégoire (made by a couple of previous reviews) is a very interesting one.  In Berkeley, the rents are surely a lot lower.  Customers get more for their money in the East Bay, but they have to wait around for their order to be cooked.  Here, the quick in-and-out was a plus for me.
author: Kenneth R.

description:
Located in a tiny corner shop, this place gets a long line during the lunch rush, but it goes by pretty quick.

Some of the items on 7x7's Must Eat List are not even worth it and way over hyped. The corned beef gruyere sandwich here is one of them. It was disappointing, but not bad. However, it's far from something I must eat before I die. I'm sure their other items are worth it, so I'll come back and try something else next time.

Corned Beef Gruyere Sandwich:
flavor was nothing amazing, the foccacia was soggy and cut in a 80/20 ratio with the 20 on the bottom so it didn't hold up the ingredients in between, sauce was globbed in 2 parts and the rest of the sandwich didn't have any, cole slaw and the meat was OK.
author: Linda C.

description: I really wanted to like this place, but I just don't enjoy their sandwiches. Take, for example, the Balt, which apparently stands for Basil, Avocado, Lettuce, and Tomato. While I do like tomatoes and avocados, I did not enjoy eating a sandwich that consisted solely of those ingredients, and I don't really consider that to be a sandwich. OK, so maybe vegetarian options aren't for me. I tried the Corned Beef once, and while the beef was acceptable, the slaw that sat on top of the beef didn't taste that great. While some may appreciate The Sentinel's slightly strange ingredient combinations, I don't. At least the line usually moves pretty quickly.
author: Daylen Y.

description:
Sadly underwhelming. Maybe I had my expectations up too high after having the place bookmarked for over a year, but none of the three sandwiches we tried really measured up.

Veal and ricotta meatballs with artichoke pesto - suffered from the classic meatball sandwich problem of uneven meat distribution. Why can't they be cut in half? Anyway, the whole thing was too creamy and fairly soaked in a rich gravy. It actually was fairly flavorful, I guess from the pesto, but this was nearly obscured by the creaminess. There also didn't seem to be any contrast among the ingredients.

Coppa with pumpkin seed pesto, fresh mozzerella, and mustard greens - I don't think i noticed the pesto here at all, sadly. I didn't feel like this came together well.

And finally, the classic corned beef with cabbage, russian dressing, and swiss - definitely not more than the sum of its parts for me. Too little meat, too much cabbage, cheese that doesn't integrate itself...I just don't see it.

The bread was the highlight for all the sandwiches, although it's somehow not even mentioned on the menu. We had the choice of "white" or "wheat" for the meatball and coppa sandwiches, but the names didn't really convey the richness of the bread.

I'm sure if I worked in the area I would consider having it again, but it wasn't worth the special trip downtown during business hours.

I was impressed at how fast and efficienctly they were moving people through, though.
author: Lisa K.

description:
I love food joints in tiny spaces because I know they mean business. There's no time to get fancy with seating or flower arrangements. There's only time for a counter and some great sandwiches. 

I went halfsies with a coworker because I wanted to try the corned beef sandwich and the egg salad sandwich. I preferred the corned beef, especially loving the crusty flatbread. The meat and cheese were perfectly melty and not dry at all.  I liked the fluffy wheat roll of the egg salad sandwich too but was a bit turned off by the high parsley population in the egg salad. 

To wash it all down I tried their famous watermelonade, and was not disappointed. 

I'm hoping that they're working on some more efficient strategies to get through their many lunchtime customers. When we went the people taking our order were using post-its and seemed to be a bit frazzled. I figured they knew what they were doing since the line was moving pretty quickly. The guy who seemed to be running the show had that grumpy hell's kitchen thing about him. I didn't really like the way he was talking to his staff, almost yelling at them at some points. Halfway down the block with our lunches, we realized we were missing one sandwich. I was scared to go back, but braved it with a coworker to let them know. There was no argument, and the sandwich was up in no time, along with a huge sack of cookies that must have weighed almost a pound each. Mistakes happen in fast-paced places like that, and I like how they handled it. I just hope no one got yelled at when we left!
author: Christina P.

description:
After giving the Sentinel a handful of extra chances, I'm upgrading my review to four stars.

One new thing I tried that I particularly liked was the B.A.L.T - the basil, avocado, lettuce, and tomato sandwich. Goat cheese too. The simplicity was refreshing and the bread is amazing. I could eat the bread all day, no joke.

I've also tried the spicy shrimp and crab stew. It was a very busy stew with all sorts of vegetables and spices though, so there was no dominating flavor, which was kind of disappointing. The bread was definitely the best part

And the desserts that come with the daily specials? That's where the going gets goooood. The apple cake? The banana bread? The blueberry cake? Simply amazing.
author: Viola L.

description: YUM! I hardly ever crave sandwiches, but I went here for the first time the other day and already want to go back. The pork shoulder sandwich was amazing; so many delicious flavors, the meat was tender, and the bread was fluffy and great.
author: Lindsey G.

description: As most of you already know, The Sentinel serves delicious sammies. But they also have a lunch special on Mondays that will rock your socks off, especially during these foggy summer SF days. Pork chili with garbanzo and kidney beans, a side of fresh baked bread and some sort of banana upside down cake for dessert. All for $12. That's less than what you pay down the street for a salad at Mixt Greens - and a lot more filling, too.
author: Abby S.

description:
Corned Beef Sandwich!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! The sandwich itself sounds pretty simple but it's oh so very delicious! I ordered and got my sandwich 2 minutes later. The fact that they slice your sandwich into manageable pieces and give you sliced pickles in a little baggy and an Andes mint just makes the lunch perfect. Personally I would have enjoyed it more if the pickles were more pickle-y instead of sweet.

I tried my friend's lamb and eggplant sandwich and it was good, but not as good as the corned beef sandwich. If this is your first time going, get the corned beef sandwich for sure. (It's also on the 7x7 list.)

The place is a whole in the wall so you normally line up outside but service is very fast. They have daily specials for $10 and they sell out quickly. The people there are very friendly too. I also like the decor inside and outside; they have cigar signs all over the place.
author: Lucy D.

description:
If you work in the financial district and are in need of a quick and delicious sandwich, this place is for you.

It's a small to-go only corner shop with a hefty line that can wrap around the block. The line goes super fast though so you won't be waiting more than 5-10 minutes.

Their sandwiches are the bomb. I recommend the corned beef hash (everyone raves about that here) and the lamb and eggplant. The sandwich comes in two foccacia square pieces and can be quite oily/messy, so grab your share of napkins. The meal also comes with a random pickle wraped in a small plastic bag.

Tip: Get the ginger or watermelon ale to get your meal total over $10 so you can use a credit card.
author: Nick A.

description:
I ate my corned beef sandwich so fast I didn't even take a picture of it. And I ALWAYS take pictures of my food. Enough said.

A little pricy at $9+ per sandwich but worth every penny. Not sure if it compares to sandwiches like Ikes or Roxies who are in a league of their own, but The Sentinel was delicious nonetheless.
author: Vivian D.

description:
Smoked Trout Salad. Get it.
Sounds a little risky for a hole-in-the-wall place, but given that they have about 10 things on the menu and this is one, I assumed it was good enough to give it a try. 
The roll it comes on is the most amazing bread I've ever had. Not to mention the Smoked Trout Salad was the most delicious blend of flavors, a combination of smoked trout, fennel, and apple (I think?). This is, without a doubt, one awesome sandwich. Definitely the best eats I had on a recent short trip to SF.
author: Shannon R.

description: Little gem on New Montgomery...get there early as the place gets busy. It's a tiny place, so there is no seating, but get your food to go and eat at a roof top or a park. The sandwiches are great and although there is usually a line, it moves pretty fast.
author: George M.

description:
I got my first Basil Avocado Lettuce and tomato sandwich there for my lunch and, man, I loved it!
I liked the fresh baked bread, the spicy pickle, the small chocolate mint and of course my super duper sandwich!
This place is fantastic!

Here is another fan, Sentinel!

$10 min on credit card.
author: Anelya S.

description:
"I would probably strangle a small child for a corned beef sandwich from the Sentinel," I thought to myself as I pondered what to eat for lunch here in Mountain View. 

Too bad you're so far away Sentinel or I would have you for lunch several times a week (except when it's rainy because the line is always out the door).
author: Trang H.

description:
I like this place. It has all the hallmarks of a little deli, with some San Francisco flava thrown in for good measure. Namely, that means a girl with short hair and attitude, a latino dude cooking, and some corporate suit types as regulars. Yay FiDi social milieu!

Rotating menu, going with the seasons, I like. Love the food, would be 5 stars if not for price. No seating, so take your food to go, whether you like it or not.
author: Wes T.

description:
Effing amazing sandwiches!  The roast beef was per-fec-tion, the bread freshly baked and the meat/bread ratio was reciprocal and generous.  Even the bloody pickle was delightful.

Perhaps the best facet of this place was how expeditious and friendly they manage to be.  The most efficient sandwich operation I've ever seen -- be not dejected by the line that invariably stretches down the alley way.

For dessert, my friend snatched the last chocolate chip cookie, so I thought I was settling on getting oatmeal, but DAMN!  The most genuine oatmeal experience I've ever had in a cookie.  Even if you HATE oatmeal cookies, you should be amazed.

So fresh and the meat so succulent!  And all be damned if I wasn't astonished by that oatmeal cookie.
author: David O.

description:
Roast beef sandwich with horseradish cream cheese. DELICIOUS. It's served at medium rare, a nice pink colored meat (PERFECT!). Whoever thought to pair horseradish with cream cheese is a genius. This tastes like...sliced prime rib in a sandwich (YUM). Best roast beef sandwich EVAR. But be forewarned, it can be just a tad bloody (YUM).

Mushroom soup. Good. Corned beef with cabbage, swiss, russian dressing. Not bad.

This little take away counter is a great place to pick up a quick, yummy bite to eat. A bit on the pricier side at $22 for two sandwiches and a soup, but it was enjoyable. Service was quick and efficient. If this place was a bit easier to get to (sooo crowded around there at lunch time), I'd likely come back more often.
author: Christine L.

description:
The Sentinel makes a mean sammie. I headed over here for lunch with Lizzie from London and was quite pleasantly surprised to see they offer a version of a BLAT that doesn't include bacon. The "B" stands for basil instead.

I know, I know. Most of you are thinking, "But, Tiffany, why would you ever be ordering a sandwich and be happy the "B" didn't stand for bacon?" It's true that I have been a big fan of bacon for my whole life. I even called myself a bacotarian previously. But, for the past two months I've been trying out the life of a pescatarian so the fact that I could have a BLAT seriously pumped me up.

Besides basil the sandwich also had tomato, lettuce and goat cheese. It was quite tasty and now I know why the lines at this shop can be so very long. Get yourself a sandwich and then take it to the park. On a sunny day not much is more delightful.
author: Tiffany N.

description: The pastrami sandwich is amazing! The line goes by fast so don't worry about that.  Definetly worth trying.
author: David B.

description:
Sometimes I get a craving for one of these $8-$9 sandwiches, and there is just no stopping me from jumping on a bus and getting lunch on the other side of the city.

My love affair is primarily with two offerings that have been on the menu at least since this summer -- the BBQ mushroom sandwich (with mustard coleslaw and goat cheese) and the lamb and eggplant sandwich (with chickpea, curry, and herb pesto). These are napkin-intensive lovelies that will keep the average person full well into the evening. I always consider trying something else, but the siren song of the oozy-saucy-goodness (be it BBQ + goat cheese or lamb/pesto/curry) has me forever chained. The only solution is to take my husband with me and bat my eyelashes so that he will let me have a bite of whatever he orders.

$10 minimum for credit cards, raspberry lemonade is a real treat, find a friend to eat your free pickle spear if you're not a fan.
author: Liz E.

description: Grabbed their roast beef with horse radish sauce. I was impressed with the size of the sandwich and the color of the meat, but I was disappointed with the lack of kick brought by the horse radish sauce. Also a very juicy meal, good but I had to wipe my hand and face almost every bit - kinda unprofessional in a business setting...
author: Russell K.

description:
Stop number 3 on the "Great Sammich Escapade of 2010" did not fail my partner in crime and I this week.

I showed up a little early as I heard the lines for this place were ridiculous. To my surprise, it wasn't too bad at 12:30. Rather than being wrapped around the entire block, it was more of halfway down the block situation. 

The impressive part  is the fact that the staff at the Sentinel knows their customers, and is able to not only put together a rockstar menu (they had as specials smoked salmon, roast beef, egg salad, asparagus,and  tofu sandwiches along with their usuals of corned beef and lamb meatballs), but also are efficient in helping to satiate their customers' hunger and constrained lunch hours by taking your order and name ahead of time. By the time you get to the front to pay, your sammich is wrapped and ready to go in your little hands. 

Sadly my sammich partner M was late. Which is cool, as I had come prepared with book in hand and a latte. It is pleasant standing across from The Sentinel in the sun, but beware the smokers who convene around lunch. Ew.

So I waited.
And waited.
Aaaaaand waited (over an hour).

It got to the point where the girls working the counter at The Sentinel probably thought I was being stood up by my lunch "date".
In FACT, one of them came out and asked me where my friend was, and then asked if I wanted a cookie. Of course I will have a cookie! So I followed her and was about to pay for my cookie when she said,

 "No worries. Do you want a refill on your coffee? It's cold outside"

Hahahaha...awesome. I love the fact that the staff at this place are so cool. And took pity on me :-)

When M finally showed up, we ordered the corned beef and the lamb feta meatball sammiches, and went halvsies like we always do. The result? Amazing flavors, from two sammiches that couldn't be more different. The corned beef was flavorful without being greasy. The lamb meatballs were a little spicy and on a flavorful brioche bun. 
I wanted to try out their lunch specials which is like a mini 3 course meal, but they were sold out! The lesson seems to be to go early if you can to get their special meal for the day. I saw lots of disappointed faces when they realized they had missed their opportunity.

Although the start to our adventure was a little harrowing, the end result was a lovely lunch sitting in the sun, surrounded by bike messengers and Market Street traffic. 

A perfect way to start the weekend.
author: Kathy K.

description:
Holy huge sandwich, Batman. 

Our timing was apparently perfect as there was no line to order at this tiny corner spot, so we had time to peruse the menu. I had hoped that the BALT would be on the menu as I'm trying to keep it veg, but unfortunately the only vegetarian option was egg salad, which is not my friend. So I opted for the chicken salad which came with green goddess dressing, which I seriously love. 

Sandwiches came out in a flash, service was kind of obsolete-- these ladies know how to work a line efficiently, even if it's not in the friendliest of ways. We made our way back to the office and dove in: these suckers were gigantic, mostly bread. The chicken salad was definitely green: absolutely covered in the dressing so that was pretty much all I tasted. It was good, but not fantastic. But damn, the place smelled so good-- I'm sure it puts out a killer product. Just blame my own poor ordering.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
The Sentinel completely messed up my dinner plans... and I had it for lunch!  I ordered a delicious corned beef sandwich this afternoon which was absolutely outstanding!!  The bread was homemade and the sauerkraut was just right.  The corned beef itself was succulent and really some of the best I have ever tasted.  I have absolutely no complaints, however it was big as all get out and since I ate the entire thing, here I sit now, at dinner time, stuffed!!  I had to cancel my dinner plans because I am so full still.  I had that sandwich a full six hours ago?!  

Thus, be forewarned if you stop in here.  Perhaps come in on Easter Sunday after 40 days of fasting or binge after a crazy diet.  Whatever you do, don't come here for lunch when you are going out for dinner too because, chances are, you won't go at all.

Quick tips: Come hungry and be ready to stand in line.  It can be long, but it's worth the wait.  Also - CHECK YOUR ORDER.  They are known for missing things (sandwiches, cookies, etc.) and nothing sucks more than getting a to-go order (there's no seating here at all) and then getting back to the office and noticing what you ordered isn't there!
author: Elsa M.

description: good but expensive for a sandwich and it was more a dish inside bread than really appropriate for a sandwich. messy.
author: Paul L.

description:
So I wanted to try something different
Eating the turkey and goat cheese meatball sandwich ($8.00)
Nastiness
The bread was super soggy
It wasn't hot at all and was a mess to eat
Not going to try anything new anymore
Eat only the CORNED BEEF SANDWICH please!
Learned my lesson for the day

The watermelonade was okay. It was more of a watermelon juice than lemonade and watermelon. I also wasn't super happy with my turkey and goat cheese meatball sandwich. Even the meat felt a bit dry. It was suppose to be a hot sandwich, but it tasted like it was premade and sat in the kitchen for awhile. The bread roll was super soggy and just a horrible mess to eat. =\ I was almost going to go back and order a corned beef instead. haha :P
author: CeCe C.

description: I work near this place and I always see a huge line outside. Never tried it before today. I got there a little late, so most of the menu was already sold out, but I got the last "hot sandwich" option, lamb and eggplant. It was amazing! Like a middle-eastern lamb sloppy joe. Also it was big enough to last 2 meals.
author: Gina T.

description:
I've had many of their sandwiches, but the corned beef sandwich cannot be beat; it's SOOO tasty and so diff from all the other sandwiches. 
The spicy pork and lamb with eggplant are yummy too, but the bread totally makes the corned beef sandwich. The should consider using the same bread for ALL their sandwiches. YUM
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
For once, I realized I could bypass the long line since it was almost 1:30PM and I needed to grab a quick lunch before a meeting.  So, off to the famous Sentinel for a bite.

I took a peek at the menu, leaning towards the pork, but decided on the BBQ beef.  Ordering process sounds like this:
Hipster girl: Yes?
Me: BBQ beef please and cantelopeade.
Hipster girl: We have lemonade.  is that OK?
Me: Yes.
Hipster girl: Name?
Me: Dan

Paid at the register, got my lemonade, then stepped to the side and waited.  Gagged on the lemonade realizing there's no sugar in it.  Added 3 sugar cubes.

About 3 minutes later...

Burly counter guy: DAN
Me: Thanks.

So service kinda sucks.  Pretty efficient, it seems, but it wouldn't kill you to smile and greet your customers, maybe even say thanks?

Was the sandwich good?  Yes.  Not the most amazing I've ever had, but solid.  I've had the bbq beef at the Golden Gate Meat Co in the Ferry building, and it's almost as good, and larger too.

It's certainly not worth $8 (almost $13 once you add in the lemonade).
So 4 star food, 3 star prices, 2 star service - averages out to a perfect 3 in my book.
author: dan s.

description: A friend of mine delivered a corned beef sandwich to me at work and it was so delicious! The toasted focaccia bread with juicy corned beef slices with cabbage and special sauce was fabulous. Would definitely get another.
author: Mimi V.

description:
Sweet mother of Jesus!

This place MEANS BUSINESS!  So I often stay at the Palace across the street when visiting and I always wondered why there were people lined up at this place that had no posted menu.  So I was delighted to find out exactly why this morning.    THOSE MUFFINS!  Are you freaking kidding me?  I don't eat many muffins to try to keep those pounds off.  I'm grateful that my trips to SF are not daily or I would need a seatbelt extension on every flight.  This was the most beautiful, moist, delicious muffin I have EVER had.  And the latte - Wow! 
And the smiling service by the wonderful gal who looked like a young Madonna - she was so sweet.  I LOVED the experience and can't wait to go back.  I feel like I discovered something secret.
author: Scott H.

description:
I am posting this review here since I emailed "Mike Fig" per the web site and received no response. :-(

I work around the corner and grab lunch here frequently. The sandwiches are typically very good. HOWEVER, earlier this week I arrived at 11:30 to find the spicy pork sandwich wasn't available and the meatball sandwich was sold out. So, rather than settling for another sandwich, I opted for the daily special of Spicy Shrimp Stew. After walking back to my office and digging into the bag, I discovered that the "stew" was nothing more than a stock with small bay-sized shrimp and nearly raw red onions, peppers, celery, and canned artichoke hearts.  In my book, it's a far cry from a stew and a poor attempt at a soup.  The soup looks like it was thrown together literally in minutes.  After consuming about half of it, I gave up as it was not very satisfying. The dessert of Almond Cake with Strawberries even lacked strawberries or fruit of any kind.

This is the second time I have ordered the daily special and have been disappointed both times.

In the future, I will NEVER order the daily special. The Sentinal definitely needs to stick to what they do best - their sandwiches.
author: David V.

description:
Great spot for a to-go lunch.  I went after my outta town bro said he wanted to give it a try.  It is a break from the normal sandwich grind, and the Lamb Eggplant had great spices, a little kick but not over the top.  I enjoyed it, but I'll likely try other delicious looking options on my next visit.  The line moved quickly, as they really turn-style you in an out.  

Cheers!
author: Charlie Y.

description:
Living in SF and working down south, I don't know how many times at work I've daydreamt about weekday lunch in the city...but I'm good at multitasking so it's a victimless crime.  Needless to say, every time I'm on vacation I jump at the chance to act all important and "do lunch" at FiDi places like the Sentinel.

Anyways, I don't think the Sentinel's sandwiches can hang with Ike's or Darby Dan's but they're still tasty 'wiches.  We tried the BBQ Mushroom and the Smoked Trout and weren't disappointed - the bread was very fresh and tasty (some sort of a poppy seed roll) and I liked the flavor of the BBQ mushrooms.  There's no seating at the Sentinel, so I suggest heading across Market street to a spot of sun on the stone benches in front of the fountain or to the rooftop garden on the Crocker Galleria.  

All in all a decent sandwich place but I wouldn't go out of my way to go here.  One star for the great bread, a two more for some tasty BBQ mushrooms but minus one star for very limited vegetarian options (about three that I saw) and minus a second star for being a bad value ($9 for a standard-sized sandwich w/ no chips).
author: Rosers M.

description:
If you're into regular sandwiches, just stay away.  Sentinel is about innovation, and mixing flavors that you thought would never really go together.

This time we had the yellowtail and the corned beef sandwich.  I'm not a fan of corned beef, but it was the best corned beef sandwich I have ever tasted, hands down.

People who like regular sandwiches may beg to dinner.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Tip: ORDER THROUGH THE PHONE. Then go in the store and pick it up - saves you from having to line up during lunch hours.

I didn't even know that I liked corned beef....but the sandwich was SO GOOD! Possibly because I really love ketchup, and the Russian sauce that's inside tastes like ketchup. The cabbage was also well seasoned. I wish the sandwich was $6-7 instead of $9 though.... can't afford to eat here everyday even though it's 1 block away from my office.
author: Sophia L.

description:
It was sammich time again in good ol' SOMA, and Team Awesome (Katy H, Jon A, Alexis M and little ol' me) headed over to the Sentinel to get ourselves some bread with stuff in between. I'd heard great things and had high expectations, and the line snaking out of this place's door spoke volumes. No wonder all the local office bods have smiles on their faces when they can grab some lunch here!

The Sentinel was so good I ended up there twice. During my debut I scarfed the barbecue mushroom with mustard coleslaw, oh my goodness how delish, and the second outing with Jenny L was all about the smoked trout salad - fresh, light and tasty. Both times I was blessed with really great bread, seeded on top and sweetly doughy, and both times I got a pickle. A proper pickle, individually wrapped and everything! Aces.

They also do great homemade sodas; the cherry option Katy recommended the first time was delightful. Oh and I can also thank the Sentinel for acquainting me with sugar-free cinnamon Werther's Originals. They exist, somewhere. I just need to order a vat of them to ship over to Mancland...
author: Emma Louise M.

description:
Legitimately disappointed. Nothing went wrong; everyone was nice; line wasn't long.  But, I just didn't like how it tasted.   The flavors were below average.   I ordered the lamb and eggplant sandwich...the lamb was ground up which I wasn't expecting.  I want to see my meat, know it's there.  The meat in this sandwich looked like mush interspersed with chunks of eggplant.  Also, the sandwich had a hint of sour-ness -- not sure if it was the curry? the pesto? or something else, but I was not a fan.

Plus sides, the bread was as good as everyone said, the sandwich came with two Andes mints (delicious), and a pickle.

I had been wanting to come here for a long time and I'm disappointed by how much I didn't enjoy it.  I plan on coming back and maybe trying a cold sandwich. My hopes were too high to let them fizzle out all because of one bad experience... here's to hoping for a better sandwich on round two.
author: Kimya P.

description:
My coworkers introduced me to this secret corner of deliciousness. Their sandwiches are very unique and hearty. Fresh, quick, real good food, they give you a pickle and an Andes mint in the bag too. Even if there's a line, wait in it because it goes super fast. Totally worth the money. I love the BALT sandwich, it's amazing. 

BTW, bring cash!
author: Martina M.

description: Just came here for my first time the other day.  One of the best roast beef sandwiches I've ever had.  Amazing horseradish sauce, bread, and roast beef!
author: Yoichi N.

description:
You can't beat these sandwiches. Sure the line is long but it moves rather fast. Don't let the long line discourage you from coming. They streamline orders quite nicely.

The menu isn't that long, but you really get a lot of love put into whatever you order. I always get the coppa sandwich. It's so awesome, they give it to you and the bun is still warm from the oven.

You can always get a good dutch crunch sandwich from Roxie or a dirty sauce hoagie with mozzarella sticks, fried jalapenos and halal chicken at Ike's Place. But The Sentinel is probably one of the best kept secrets downtown. Best quality and taste in sandwiches you can find in the city hands down.
author: Ryan E.

description:
I really enjoyed having my lunch at The Sentinel today.  S.B. and I walked over, ordered the pork shoulder special, the corned beef sandwich, and a ginger ale to share.  Both meals were extremely delicious, they tasted home cooked.

S.B. was skeptical about the corned beef, he said he didn't want to order it because he thought it would be too salty, and it definitely wasn't.  It was tender, beefy and perfectly seasoned, the bread was fresh, the sauce slightly sweet, and the cabbage was not overpowering.  The pork special was also very fresh and delish.  It came with chocolate flan, which got a little melty at the end, but it was super chocolatey and not too sweet.

A good solid lunch, we'll definitely frequent The Sentinel often.
author: Burrito M.

description:
One of the best sandwich places, period.

Some background: I have an unresolved relationship with pork.  I love me some Chipotle carnitas, but would probably never have a pork chop for dinner.  After having spent a day in meetings in San Francisco, absolutely ravenous, I was thus a little dismayed to find the only carnivorous option on the Sentinel's menu a pulled pork-based special.

The Yelp reviews pointed me here, though, and I had to have faith.  Faith was rewarded with one of the best sandwiches I have ever eaten.  Go here, if you haven't.  You cannot go wrong with the food.  

But, be warned -- I started this review giving only 4 stars because this is a take out joint, in the truest sense of the word.  It is, essentially, a deli counter placed between two doorways.  So, 5 stars for the food.  5 plus.  Minus 1-2 phantom stars for being so small, and thus not being a true oasis from the world.
author: Patrick M.

description:
3.5 stars

My friend and I went here for lunch today, excited at how good the sandwiches would be because of all the high reviews. He got the Tasso and I got the famous Corned Beef. 

My sandwich was probably about 6 inches long, so it definitely filled me up. The sauce was really interesting - kind of tomato-y but better? The bread was really oily so eating it was kind of messy, but I definitely really liked it because it was crispy on top. The beef was also really really good. 

However, (maybe because I'm not super big on sandwiches) I don't think it was worth $9. It was also...thinner? than I'd imagined. 

Notes:
- No outdoor seating
- $10 minimum for credit cards
- Calling and ordering beforehand is super convenient! It makes service a lot quicker, even though the line wasn't too long when we were there at 1pm on a weekday.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Out of all sandwiches except 2 by 2pm.

GR.
author: Jess C.

description:
I went today for lunch and got the corned beef. It was pretty good and the half-pickle they added with it definitely was icing on the cake. However I didn't think this sandwich was good enough to be getting all these rave reviews. I felt that it was maybe slightly better than a mediocre deli at best. Also I am not a fan of the bread they used at all.

Definitely a place to grab a quick bite for lunch as the line moves pretty fast, but if you want a GREAT sandwich you may have to look somewhere else.
author: Dennis R.

description:
Now that I have been here five times in the past month, it is high time I write a review. Short opinion: great customer service;  food is VERY hit or miss.

Corned beef sandwich:  I found this pretty gross (though I realize I am in the minority on this). But hear me out! This was one of the heaviest sandwiches I have ever had, despite it being rather skimpy on meat. Other ingredients included cheese, slaw, tons of mayo, and oily ciabatta bread. The first bite was decent, but at bite 4 my body was like "stop feeding me oil." Maybe I just really like the classic corned beef and rye combination. Anyway, verdict: 2/5

Lamb, chick pea, curry, and herb pesto sandwich: This was great! The lamb is ground which took me by surprise and made the sandwich messy, but I would definitely order it again. They slathered mayo on the bread which I could definitely have done without, but next time I'll special order it. Verdict: 4.5/5

Pork sandwich: This was seriously gross. I believe the chipotle-fig was left off my sandwich (see below under customer service for more on this) so all that was on my sandwich was slimy (from the cheese) slabs of flavorless pork and of course a quarter inch of mayo. I couldn't even bear to eat the second half. Verdict: 1/5

Rare roast beef sandwich: This sells out every day, so I wanted to see what all the fuss was about. Honestly, I think it's just one step above being "just ok." The meat is good - nice and rare as promised. Aside from that, there is a horseradish mayo (as you can see, my distaste for excess mayo may be coloring my opinion of this place), smoked onions, and lettuce. Sort of basic. Still, I'd probably order this again if the lamb were ever sold out. Verdict: 3.5/10

Daily special shrimp and tofu curry: Ehhh this dish bordered on a soup. Some rice was pre-mixed into the sauce but not nearly enough to absorb the sauce. Sauce was not terribly flavorful (for a green curry). Also, this was served with a side of seeded bread and a pickle spear! I love this practice with sandwiches, but with a green curry it felt odd. Would not order again. Verdict: 2.5/5

Peach and blueberry crisp: So good. This came with my lunch special and I am still thinking about it a week later. Perfectly cooked fruit and crispy top. Yum! Verdict: 5/5

Chocolate chip cookies: TO DIE FOR! Maybe this is what keeps me coming back  Plus, they get you over the credit card minimum when you buy a sandwich. Verdict: 5/5!

Customer service: This is what really sets this place apart; I cannot say enough good things about them! Service is very efficient, so that even if the line is long I have never had to wait more than 8 minutes total from the time I get in line until my food is ready. I also LOVE that they give you a pickle spear and an Andes mint with every lunch purchase. While certainly not the best pickle I've ever had, it shows such an effort to please customers. Finally, their responsiveness to customer concerns is wonderful. After my pork sandwich was missing ingredients (described above), I contacted the owner who apologized and said I could get my next sandwich on the house. I thought there might be a hassle when I actually attempted to take him up on that, but I showed the cashiers the email and there was no problem at all. Again, really shows a commitment to pleasing customers.

Ideally I would give the Sentinel a 3.5, but because they really seem like they're trying I'll give them the bump to 4/5. If you go, be sure to get a dessert!
author: Rachel G.

description:
I can't speak about the lunch because I haven't had it.... BUT the muffins that I grab there in the morning are the most delicious, fresh, and warm piece of wonderful goodness. I love the muffins. So far I have tried the apple, blueberry, cherry (my favorite), and pear. All of them are so good with chuncks of real fruit that just bursts with flavor in your mouth.

Do try the muffins! But becareful because they run out so fast... there were a couple of times where I was dissapointed because all of the muffins were sold out. :(
author: Mariya L.

description:
First of all, this place is a fast lunch take-out joint. No frills. You come, check out their menu of 10-15 items, order, and go back to your office.  Usually comes paired with a delicious pickle and an Andes chocomint piece.

The sandwiches. If you go later than 12p (close to 1pm), you might miss out on pork and fig sandwiches or other fancy specials of the day. Their menu changes for certain things but they obviously got usual suspects. I've had their corned beef, their roast beef, their pork+fig deliciousness, their deviled egg, and another pork sammich. My go-to is their corned beef.  All sandwiches are stuffed silly with meats. The bread is soft and delicious and can be eaten on its own. The flavour + amount of food you get is well worth the sub-$10 price tag.

The bread. Soft, delicious, highly addictive. It's not high in sugar content, like most standard sandwich bread. If you're expecting cheap crumbly dry bread, this is not the place for you.

What makes this a 5 star vs a 4 star? Let me tell you the 'wow' factor. I don't frequent the place often, because the bread's too much gluten for me personally and I get into a food coma. Ergo, I go here maybe 1x every 4-6 weeks. One of the gals there remembers my name. Every. Time. And when people serve so many people and can still remember your name? That's feel-good service. So now I am a loyal customer.
author: R B.

description:
When the Yelp Community Managers come to town every few months, we usually have one day when we "get to know a few other Yelp employees."  So today was that fun day here at Yelp HQ, and my new friends suggested we pick up grub from The Sentinel.  Not knowing SF very well, I went with it, despite the limited menu I perused online... and I trusted the hundreds of reviews that came before mine.

When we arrived, I was disappointed to find that the White Beans Soup with Chili paste and cinnamon was no longer available... I guess that's why they clearly say "all items subject to change without notice" on their website.  Instead, I went with a spicy egg salad sandwich and a cauliflower soup.  While the soup was a tad on the watery side, the sandwich was quite tasty and extremely filling.  The perfect weather enhanced the experience... we at at Yerba Buena Park!

The four of us ate for less than $40 - not horrible, but not cheap either.  The rest of my group all had the corned beef and seemed to enjoy it as well. I did learn that the pickles are homemade, and picklicious... mmmm! 

As long as you're fine with a very limited menu, you'll enjoy The Sentinel.
author: Gabi M.

description:
Spicy pork sando, uber-rare roast beef. Do I have your attention.

The Sentinel has a tenaciously tasty menu that "changes daily" as advertised. Which basically means they have fresh ingredients, so don't hate me if either of the aforementioned items are not there upon arrival.

The only con I've been able to find is they require a $10-minimum on cards and all their sandwiches float around $8. I also think the pickles that come with could use some work.
author: Jason M.

description:
Thanksgiving came a month early!. Turkey Meatloaf Sandwich this time. awsum!.  They put this one in Cold Sandwich section, but still warm enough. 

This place may very well be one of the best sandwiches I have tried so far. both sandwiches I have tried so far, 

- outstanding, 
- worth paying for, 
- unique in its own way, yet delicious!

Lets see if we get 3 strikes!.
author: Rajesh S.

description: Real solid sammy. The meatballs were tasty! The sauce was yummy. The bread was fresh. No long line. No nonsense.
author: Andrew K.

description:
On the 7x7 Top 100 must eat list, the Corned Beef Sandwich at The Sentinel justifiably lives up to its reputation.  The sandwich is really really goood.  The beef is tender, the cabbage adds a good crunch, and the Russian dressing gives that slightly sweet cherry on top taste to the sandwich.  The bread is also really good.

The egg salad sandwich is a different story.  I didn't find it all that great to be honest.  The egg salad lacked any real taste and could definitely use a little extra dose of vinegar.  Very plain jane.

With the hype from 7x7, Sentinel's lines do get long and their sandwiches do sell out.  Try to get there earlier rather than later.  I'm a late lunch eater, and I've always wanted to venture out from the Corned Beef, but they always sell out of everything.

All the sandwiches comes with pickle spears and the mints with the green wrappers (the name escapes me at the moment).  The pickles in my opinion taste a little funny.  I think they need to revisit their pickling process.

Also, there is a credit card minimum that happens to be just slightly more than the cost of a sandwich, so be prepared to either buy a drink or something extra if you want to use your card, else bring some cash.

The corned beef on its own though, makes Sentinel a worthwhile trip.
author: Kyle W.

description:
Get the corned beef hash.

Done.

Kelly and I pre-ordered. I got the corned beef hash, and she got the lamb and eggplant.

We went halfsies. I wish we hadn't.
author: Vince H.

description:
I don't get it.

People line up forever for their sandwiches.  And while it wasn't bad by any means, I've had better deli sandwiches, and for a cheaper price too.  I was underwhelmed and really didn't see anything special about it.  I wouldn't refuse to go if someone HAD to come back here, but I'll never suggest it as a place to grab some grub.  Just not worth it in my opinion, as unpopular as it is :)
author: Jen K.

description:
A corner sandwich shop with a line out the door, wrapped around the sidewalk, is a very good sign in my book. I've been meaning to check out The Sentinel for quite a while now. They're quite famous for their roast beef and corned beef sandwiches. 

The line went by speedy gonzales fast. They basically just start making sandwiches and put them into boxes so they're ready to go for the next customer in line who wants it. I ordered a corned beef sandwich when I got to the front of the line and had it in my hands within about 2 seconds. Paid $9 and was out of there in a jiffy.

This little corner shop isn't a place to sit and eat. In fact, they don't have anywhere inside to sit and eat. Does that matter? No. Because Yerba Buena Gardens is just a block or 2 down the street. And what better way to enjoy a 
sunny afternoon than to sit in a beautiful park, absorbing the sunshine, and eating one of the most delicious sandwiches ever? I guess winning the lottery might be better, but not much else.

My first bite of this sandwich was one of those moments where your life changes a little bit for the better. The bread was buttery and soft, but still held up extremely well. The corned beef was absolutely delicious, but what really made this sandwich was the sauce they put on it. I have no idea what it was, but it was so flavorful and mouth watering-ly good.

My friend who was with me let me try a little bit of his oatmeal cookie he got as well. Whoa. I never really think to get a dessert at places for lunch, but this cookie alone is worth coming back for. Might be one of my favorite oatmeal cookies I've had in a long, long time.

If you're in the SOMA area during the week at any point, I would really suggest checking out this little gem.
author: Ashley D.

description: I was in town for the weekend wondering around, went on Yelp, saw a picture of the lamb and eggplant sandwich...had to have it. It doesn't necessarily tastes like lamb or eggplant, more like a really awesome sloppy joe with their incredible curry but 100% worth the trip. They're homemade ginger drink is great too.
author: Ian P.

description:
One word= WINNING! 

Thank you Charlie Sheen for a great phrase, and thank you Sentinel for kick ass sandwich.
author: Thao L.

description:
Since moving to city, this place has been to my go to spot for sandwiches. I've tried the infamous corned beef sandwich. Don't get me wrong, it's good but it was a little hyped (IMO). The bread was super greasy. 

If you want something light, the trout sandwich is a must try. I believe it comes with slices of apples in it. At first I was a little skeptical but it worked.

The sesame chicken sandwich is also another favorite of mine. It's just different, definitely worth a try.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Finally got around to trying this place.  I ordered the yellowtail sandwich with fennel and it was simply delicious.  I also had the watermelonade, which is really just watermelon juice the way my mom used to make it.

I would give this place an easy 5 stars if it weren't for the hefty price tag.  The sandwich was $8.50 and the watermelonade was $3, which made a takeout only, fast FiDi workday lunch more expensive than I would like.  

Great ingredients though, so it's totally worth the occasional splurge. 

Still have to go back and try #74 on the 7x7 List: Corned-beef sandwich with Gruyère one day.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Great egg salad sandwich w/ light fluffy sweet bread. 
A little pricey, but worth it.
I called ahead around 1pm and was able to walk up and grab the sandwich within 5 minutes.

Can't wait to try the other ones on the menu.
author: Kate S.

description: Fast lines during lunch hour and a great portion of food. Spicy pork could have been spicier, though. I'll be back for sure.
author: Ricardo P.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said before about this place?
These sandwiches are serious.

1 star for Bread (so good)
1 star for Quality Ingredients
1 star for Deliciousness
1 star for Speed (the line moves fast)

I am knocking off one star, I kid you not, for too much meat. Yes, too much.  The past couple times I've eaten here the meat overwhelmed other ingredients.  An extra piece of lettuce would be nice.
author: Cliff C.

description:
I think the quality here is going downhill. The last few times I've been here the food has been nothing special for the price.

 I'd also suggest more clearly marking the menu for vegetarian vs. non-vegetarian items. Folks in both camps would likely be very appreciative.

I just ordered the $8.50 BALT; normally that stands for bacon, avocado, lettuce, tomato, but here apparently it's basil. Don't get me wrong, I like a good veggie sandwich once in awhile but I almost cried when I saw there wasn't bacon on this sandwich--I even double checked the menu online because I was ready to call them back! 

Even more inexcusable was the quality of tomatoes which should star in any veggie or non-veggie version of a BLT. It's still tomato season here in CA so a subpar tomato is just sad. The whole reason to get a BLT or BALT at this time of year is for the quality of the produce.

And, the sandwich was pretty small in comparison to others I've had there.

So the sandwich left me sad, hungry, and out $8.50. Meh.
author: J Y.

description:
I'll be the first to admit that I have questionable taste...in everything...sushi, food, clothing style, men; but I *KNOW* I am not crazy for disliking their corned beef sammich.

Let me break it down:
You don't get to choose your bread; it comes with foccacia which tasted slightly stale on the outside & soggy on the inside from being weighed down by cabbage & Russian dressing. The corned beef was mostly lean (which is a plus) but the texture was chewy instead of tender. As for the gruyere, it was neither melted nor solid. Judging from all the five star ratings, people seem to like their sandwiches prepared this way but I'm steering clear of this corner sandwich counter next time.

Bottom line: Not a well-integrated sandwich; ingredients did not compliment one another & instead was layer upon layer of over-hyped disappointment. $8.75 each. Brownie points for smiling, friendly staff.
author: Fancypants X.

description: This review is only for the vegetarian sandwich because that is the only one they had left when I showed up around 1:00 p.m.  It is just OK.  I am sure the other sandwiches are great because they were sold out.  Maybe I will get out of the office a little earlier so I can give them another shot!
author: K T.

description:
Probably the best sandwich place within walking distance to my office.

For a vegetarian, this place is not bad... they have only 1 or 2 options, but they are usually pretty good.

Had the BALT (Basil, Avocado, Lettuce, Tomato, Goat Cheese), their only veggie sandwich for today, today! That was a lottt of avocado for a single sandwich.. yummy!!
author: Aditya M.

description:
I finally, finally tried the muffins here this morning -- thought I would treat myself for making it to Friday. ;)

I got the blueberry, and as someone who LOVES blueberries but usually hates blueberry baked goods, I have to say: I am a convert. It was warm and delicious, with just the right amount of crunch on top. I wish I could treat myself every day, because I don't think it would ever get old.
author: Sara J.

description:
4 stars for the spicy tuna salad and ceviche daily special I sampled, spicy pork sandwich only gets 2.5 stars.

Spicy Tuna Salad Sandwich ($8.75): 4 stars. Dude, whoever thought to put artichoke hearts, potatoes, and spice up tuna salad is a GENIUS. The bread is definitely under-rated. I don't know if they make it themselves or get it from a local bakery but it is damn good.

Spicy Pork Sandwich ($8.50): 2.5 stars. To sum it up in three words: too much mayonnaise. Similar to above, the bread was delicious. I just couldn't get past the nasty white stuff.

Daily Ceviche Special(~$12): 4 stars. I just sampled but it was DIVINE. Avocado, just the right amount of citrus, and the fish was done wonderfully. I would order it again.

We came on a Wednesday at 11:45 and waited behind TWO people. Are you kidding me?! It was wonderful. Especially when we walked down the street and saw about 29308529 people waiting in line at Sushirrito. Our food came out super fast too.

Highly recommend if you work downtown!
author: Nicole W.

description:
Whenever I'm short on time and need a delicious sandwich or just need a delicious sandwich, this is where I go to. Efficiency in place is off the charts. Even if there is 15 people in line, you'll be in and out in under 10 minutes. They're cranking out like 4 sandwiches every minute. 

The roast beef sandwich they have is BLOODY DELICIOUS and I do mean bloody. The roast beef they serve is so rare that blood is dripping off of it. It is tender and delicious, but definitely not for those who feign at the sight of blood. This sandwich comes with caramelized onions, a piece of lettuce, and blue cheese.

Their cookies are very good also.  I have tried all three cookies: oatmeal, chocolate chip, and molasses. The outside is crunchy yet the inside is soft and chewy. Perfection!

There's a rotating lunch special that changes every day.

Sandwiches are around ~$9 and there's still a min charge of $10 for credit.
author: Steven B.

description:
Let me start with this I have minimums to use credit cards it really annoys me. Redemption when my corned beef sammy cost 9.01 and i pay with a 10 i get one back. I know its a little thing but to me that matters a lot. 
About the food... AWESOME. First it an interesting take on the classic with the choice of bread and extra sauces, but the variation pays off this is pretty much the best coned beef sam i've had i a while. So good on you. I'm excited to go back and try more! Cheers
author: Sean MC E.

description:
So here's what you pay for:
$1 - speed of sandwich.  Like lightening.
$1 - great foccacia on the corned beef sandwich
$1 - fillings.  All collectively worth about a buck.
$1 - complimentary little Andes Mint with sando purchase
$5 - hype.

So yeah.  I would love this place if I wasn't paying the extra $5 for the reputation.  Didn't come with fries, salad, chips, drink, nothin.  Lower prices would bump up the rating significantly, because although the sando was good, it wasn't great.  Next time, I'll have a Coppa with goat cheese, hold the hype.
author: Mari C.

description: While the Lamb and Eggplant sandwich was pretty tasty, I'm hard pressed to find any identifiable meat mass. Maybe it's just eggplant with some lamb drippings? Pretty pricey for this sandwich and how little you get. I guess you're mostly paying for their sky high rent in the financial district and little of that money makes it to the food you're eating.
author: John H.

description:
I've been hearing about this place all the time.  I just decided to try it out this morning and was able to grab one.  I tried the cranberry muffin and I have to say.  wow. 

That's the best cranberry muffin I've ever had.  

I'll stop by another time for more things but probably only twice a week can't make this a habit. LOL.
author: Homer S.

description:
My boss treated me to The Sentinel one sunny spring day. I never knew this place existed since it's in a corner, and a bit tucked away next to an alley. I was very thrilled to try it out after reading overly positive Yelp reviews and knowing the chef-owner Dennis Leary also owns Canteen, which is one of my favorite brunch spots in SF. 

We went at 12pm and the line was around the block. Surprisingly, the line moved pretty fast, only waiting 5min. Everyone selects what they want pretty quickly since the menu is small. There is no where to sit, so you have the option of sitting down at the nearby plaza's, which usually have live music. I tried the Spicy Pork with celery root and carrot coleslaw - 8.50. It came in a croissant bread, with an amazing sauce. So soo good. Also comes with a little chocolate mint, nice touch.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Lines are usually out the door and the menu doesn't have the largest variety of options, but the food is great. I highly recommend the lamb sandwich. There is no sitting area, but there are spots to eat at if you walk a bit down Market.
author: Arif H.

description:
The sandwiches are just amazing. Had the rare roast beef with blue cheese, and it was incredible both times. I don't know what they put in that bread, but it is just delectable. Plus sometimes gourmet sandwich shops somewhat skimp on the good stuff, but this was more than enough food, and I eat a lot.

Only gets 4 stars because both times I went my order was wrong, and had to go back and pick up the rest. The service is a bit touchy, but otherwise so worth the wait in line, even in lousy weather. You can see why people line up literally down the block just to get a taste.

The trick would be to send someone from the office, and make them get food for everyone. Avoid the line, and get the deliciousness delivered directly to you. INTERN!! GET OVER HERE!!!
author: Collin S.

description:
Line is long even at 12:40 pm.  The corn beef sandwich is very hearty.  I got a chocolate chip cookie for afternoon snack.  That cookie goes very well with a cup of cappuccino.  

Note:  You can only pay with credit card when your total is above $10.
author: Steven M.

description:
This place smells DELICIOUS. I was standing outside, trying to decide what to get for lunch, and the smell made up my mind for me. I ordered the cranberry chipotle turkey meatloaf sandwich, because that's what I thought I was smelling. As usual, I was wrong.

My turkey meatloaf sandwich was quite good. The meat was juicy and flavorful, it was slathered in chipotle mayo and the cranberry was a nice touch. However, I was a bit disappointed because it didn't match the aroma that brought me to the Sentinel.

I'm so glad it was $8 even. Is this a San Francisco thing? I love that. Because if I had gotten some change, I probably would have given it to one of the numerous panhandlers in the area. And I'm not sure they deserve it, what with the belligerent way they had been acting and all. 

Allow me to explain:

The night before I saw two panhandlers sitting outside the 7-11 on Market St., and another guy stumbled out and plopped down on the ground a couple yards away from them, holding a cup. 

One of the original guys says, "Oh HELL NO, you're not cutting us off," thinking the guy was taking over their territory. They go over and accost the new guy. 

This poor man is obviously intoxicated, and doing his best to fight them off with one hand while holding his cup in the other. Finally, he exclaims, "B*tch, I'm just eating NOODLES!" 

It's true. The cup was filled with instant ramen. This indigent individual was innocently eating his dinner, and he was attacked. 

*Cue War's 'Why Can't We Be Friends'*

Anyway, I'm thinking the smell was probably the corned beef; I'll have to get back here someday and give that a shot.
author: Peter D.

description: Quick quick quick. By the time you order and finally bring out your phone to start checking your email your sandwich is already ready. They run a tight ship here. Don't mess up their mojo by not knowing what you want when you get up there.
author: John B.

description:
I am not a fan of The Sentinel.

Let me explain that more, as that statement might seem to be a stark contradiction to the five star rating. I do not like The Sentinel in the same vein that I do not like the band Pavement or Impressionism.

All of the aforementioned things are revolutionary for what they did, be it using little dots to make a painting or sounding like Wilco ten years before Wilco sounded like Wilco. I just cannot get into it. It is not my thing.

The Sentinel is a top notch lunch spot if you like real(1) good food(2).

I consider The Sentinel to be the Blue Bottle of sandwiches; they have a deep commitment to the art that is sandwich making and it shows in everything - from the bread to the completed sandwich.

This is usually where I would list my favorite items from a particular restaurant but I do not have any favorite items. I mean, I tried an Egg Salad Sammy once but there was excessive amounts of mayo or something. Huge fan of this place but I do not think I could eat another one of their sandwiches... 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) When I say "real," of course, I mean in a non-preserved fresh sense.
2) I guess this means I don't like real good food?
author: Jeff M.

description:
The Sentinel simply has the best muffins I have ever eaten.

I spent a week trying different muffins around the area, and the classic blueberry muffin here was the best muffin I have ever tasted. It has a nice crust and sprinkling of sugar on the top, and the inside was fluffy and warm with whole blueberries. 

I also ordered a regular coffee, which was self-serve and pretty standard fare. I was just too impressed with the muffin to pay much attention. I have since tried the strawberry muffins, with the same happy results. Perfectly cooked, fresh fruit, not too sweet.

I will be back to try the sandwiches and for more flavors of muffin!
author: Elena H.

description:
What do you know about the best corned beef sandwich around? 


You wouldn't unless you've had The Sentinel's corned beef sandwich. 

'nuff said.
author: Cindy W.

description:
I guess I was expecting more, what with some 200+ reviews in under a year and an average 4.5 stars...   All sandwiches 8 bucks, rave reviews... I figured they gotta be making some seriously gourmet sandwiches, right?

Well, errr.... no.   I finally tried The Sentinel today and while the Spicy pork sandwich I had was good, it was certainly not great and certainly not gourmet.  In fact, it's no match whatsoever to Specialty's Bakery sandwiches just a block away...

I ordered a $3 Watermelonade which, while way pricey, actually warranted the price since it basically tasted like a 12 oz cup of watermelon juice.   That, my friends, totally hit the spot in this 90+ degree weather.

I may try 'em again... It certainly wasn't bad, but it certainly wasn't great either... Just A-OK.
author: David O.

description:
OMG. I just had the most amazing sandwich, and I found it in the most unlikely of places -- an old cigar shop across from the Palace Hotel. I felt so Euro lining up at the old vintage cash register to put in my order. With only three people working there, it felt like a true mom and pop shop.

On the menu so far? A cold pea mint soup, a salmon on brioche sandwich with horseradish, a chicken salad sandwich with endives and a chocolate mousse. Aside from those lovely little items, they had some espresso drinks from Four Barrel Coffee on the chalk board.

I ordered the salmon on brioche. The brioche was absolutely melt-in-your-mouth heaven with a flaky buttery crust. The salmon was fresh and light, and with green tomatoes and light horseradish sauce smathered on top, I was in heaven.

It turns out that this cute little establishment just opened 3 days ago by the owner of Canteen. It's just a take-out joint for now, but expect big things in the future! Something's telling me this place is going to get busy.
author: Nicole G.

description:
I just had a fantastical corned beef sandwich.  Really. Delish.  Worth walking through the torrential rain for a cozy, warm sandwich.

The hot sandwich selection is (I think) limited to 1 or 2 options, but whatever (just check the website before you go), the meatball sandwich looked pretty tempting.

Pluses: friendly service, lightning fast sandwich-to-customer turnaround.
Minus: $10 credit card minimum.
author: Priscilla T.

description:
I give this lunch spot maybe another week before there is a line around the block.

Denis of Canteen is out in force, sticking to his successful formula of an unusual space churning out truly remarkable food. Today for $11 I had tender pork shoulder on a bed of cabbage with a brioche on the side and some softened apricots. There were only three menu items (a stew, a salad, and the pork shoulder) all put together by the SF chef icon himself (literally he is serving up your food).

It's a foodie delight, so hurry up and go!
author: Jeremy S.

description: Spicy pork was tasty. Not so price effective as portion on smaller size but quality stuff. Really good employees kept busy lunch line moving
author: Anthony W.

description:
The Sentinel is definitely part of my weekly lineup. Despite walking past it dozens of times due to the massive line, I was blown away when I finally tried it -- both by the quality of the sandwich and the speed/simplicity of their service. 

I decided that my New Year's resolution -- yes I know it's October -- will be to try other sandwiches on the menu, but until then I will stick with the pork/havarti. I did try the chicken salad sandwich and though good, it didn't rock my world the way the pork does.

I'm getting hungry. Is it Monday yet??
author: Peter C.

description: The sandwiches are out of this world!!! I find lots of sandwich spots in the city that try to over complicate their meanie. The sentinel does it right they stick to what their good at! It shows because they sell out of sandwiches before the lunch hour is over. I highly recommend the corned beef. Not to mention all the dressings are phenomenal. This is a must try!
author: Jonathan A.

description: (Literally) Just finished the roast pork & fig sandwich from The Sentinel. The sandwich was good, but could have had more fig jam (there was more mayonnaise on it than jam). The service is pretty quick considering the long line (faster than Golden West, IMO) and they make it easy to grab a sandwich quickly on your lunch break. Sandwich + service with a smile = 4 stars.
author: McNeal M.

description:
The Sentinel's corned beef sandwich is poetry between two pieces of bread. It provides that cohesive sandwich experience of:
