- Every part of the sandwich is equally good (no sauce imbalance, no meat-bread size mismatch, etc.)
- Nothing of consequence falls out of it.
- It bites very easily and is not chewy or rubbery.

It's pretty expensive for a sandwich and soup.. so that's why I have to give 4 stars as it's not the holy grail of sandwich shops. The place is small and friendly and man, they are raking in the money.

If you want soup but are cheap, try and ask for a half soup with your order. It's not on the menu (at the time of writing) but they do it.
author: Josh K.

description:
A very solid sandwich place. Their sandwiches are around $8.00 but you get your money's worth. The sandwich ingredients are far higher quality than you would get at most places, and their sandwich styles are takes on classics. Today I had a corned beef and cabbage sandwich on ciabatta and it is great. I had previously also tried their egg salad, and while slightly expensive, was the largest and tastier than any other place's egg salad.

I also really like their system...your order is taken by one person, you pay another person, and a 3rd person is responsible for giving you your order. Despite long lines they are fast and efficient at getting you your lunch in a reasonable wait time.
author: Jordan C.

description:
BALT, I just can't get you outta my head. 

I've had this sandwich a dozen times since I've started working around the corner. My order has never been wrong and the wait never lengthy, even when the line is long. This sandwich shop does financial district lunch orders right - when the line starts to snake around the corner, someone comes 'round to take your order (the menu is small, the way it should be) and notes it on a series of colour-coded post-its depending what it is. Surprisingly, they take cards here. Because it's a walk-up shop and there are no seats, there's a list of suggested indoor public spaces where you can take your lunch. Also love the "Foul Weather Strategy" posted inside: if you place a phone order for at least five sandwiches when it's gnarly out, The Sentinel will buy lunch for your gopher! 

My standard order is the BALT ($8) and it goes exactly like this: basil (YUM), avocado, lettuce, tomato and (strangely omitted in the acronym) goat cheese. More delicious than you could ever imagine. And the lot is served up on a total manageable Swiss Triangle style challah, so it's soft, eggy and you don't have to snake jaw your way around it. Unspeakably delicious!

May I suggest the following improvised acronym for this majestic sandwich? BAT LEG: basil, avocado, tomato, lettuce, egg bread, goat cheese - we mustn't overlook that luscious bread and tangy cheese!
author: Kat F.

description: Fabulous, simple, and worth the short wait. Don't expect frills and you won't be disappointed. The reuben is as good as they come!
author: M J B.

description:
7x7 list - http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die 

# 74 - corned-beef sandwich with Gruyère at the Sentinel -- as good as the rave reviews b/c I was really surprised that it was not a super packed sandwich....it is the Russian dressing that makes it worth $8.

*also # 27 on yelp 2008 list - http://communityblog.yelp.com/2009/02/100-best-things-yelpers-ate-this-year-2008.html

The deviled pork loin with butter lettuce, cream cheese & walnuts was good with the spicy kick. I could pass on the chicken salad with sesame, lemon and chili next time. 

Thanks to Tony V., my personal delivery person, again!
author: Katie K.

description:
The turkey meatball sandwich had enough flavor to make me scream "Motherfucker" and punch myself in the face. 

The mushroom/goatcheese sandwich had even more flavor, and cause me to punch a motherfucker in the face and scream at myself. 

If youre a tourist and come here, dont bother. Youll only gum up the line, and piss me off, which as youve read above, will only serve to not benefit anyone but me if i eat in font of you. Im talking to YOU German family of 7 that wanted to know what the fuck was in everything. That said, if you must stay and aggravate me in line ordering food, get the corned beef.

All of the "OG Senties" will "pffffft" me for saying that, because apparently the corned beef isnt what it used to be, but you know what?

Neither is porn, muscle cars, metal or Beards...but you still enjoy the shit out of all of those things.
author: Mick F.

description:
Sandwiches are sandwiches are sandwiches. Except in the rare instance when you come across a place like The Sentinel. I've been here a few times for lunch, and have just loved it. The lamb and eggplant sandwich is spectacular...the spices and unique sloppy joe-ness of the sammy make for a delicious meal. The warm, soft bread is also key. Beware though - it's quite spicy! The Andes mints they throw in are an added treat...as is the opportunity to see Dennis Leary himself working behind the counter. 

Anyway, the next time you're looking to escape the rainbow sheen of the meat at Subway, make a stop at The Sentinel.
author: serena l.

description:
Was walking around looking for a quick bite to eat when I noticed this tremendous line circling both ends of the corner ... WTH is going on over there?  The closer I got to the line, the more heavenly the smell began to fill my senses.  Being the shy and nosey bee that I am, instead of asking what everyone was in line for ... I decided to just stand in it.

Since the line was moving quite quickly, I didn't really get a chance to see what the full menu had.  I heard someone ahead of me order the corned beef and cabbage ... SOLD.  The place is tiny, but they have this quick and effective way of taking orders by writing some kind of shorthand with your name on colored post-its.  Genius.

My name was called ... well, more like yelled ... and I was headed off with a warm bag and some napkins.  Found a spot on the grass in front of SFMOMA, opened the bag and I swear heavenly light particles started shining out.  The bread is amazing, the corned beef was right on par and the cabbage was a perfectly sweet compliment to the cured meat.

Don't ask any questions ... just look for it, stand in line, and enjoy.
author: candie s.

description:
There is a very delicious sandwich waiting for you at the other end of that daunting line... so don't let all those other people waiting for their delicious sandwich deter you from your course! Rest assured, even though there's 20 people hanging round the corner, the pros at Sentinel move along swiftly!

A lovely lady will take your order while you wait and if you have any sense at all, you'll select the spicy pork or the tofu sandwich. The glorious bits of porcine come stuffed between challah or brioche or heaven's clouds. 

Highly recommended to satisfy your midday munchies.
author: Monica S.

description:
OMG, I bit into the lamb and eggplant sandwich and went to heaven! It was an explosion of flavor! It was one of those messy sandwiches, with perfectly stewed lamb, eggplant and chickpea on top of soft bun with mint sauce and I believe a little bit of yogurt as well. I inhale the whole thing and licked my fingers clean before I could finish more thorough analysis of the ingredients. 

It is definitely one of the tastiest sandwiches I have tried in a long time! Highly recommend it. I can't wait to try to corn beef sandwich, which is the best selling sandwich.
author: Ally W.

description:
Awesome sandwiches, very fast service.

I've had the pork sandwich (the one with figs and cheese) and the corned beef (which is pretty much a reuben). Both were excellent. They usually throw in a pickle and some sort of small chocolate, which is a nice touch.

Credit card minimum is $10 and most of the sandwiches are just under that, so bring cash.
author: Sam K.

description: Tasty sandwiches at a convenient financial district location.  These folks are pleasant and provide delicious food with a smile.  Highly recommended.
author: John K.

description:
This was amazingly good.  I had no idea where the hell we were going, but I followed my coworkers blithely, and got in line, which is promising at any lunch spot, and it went quick.

I barely had time to see and pick off the menu before I stated "Salmon sandwich", which turned out to be a lovely wheat bun piled HIGH with salmon/fennel salad with strips of smoked salmon on top, and holy cow.


I'm pregnant.  I need the omega 3s and the protein.  This was amazing.  I could only eat half, it was so big.

First time I've had an 8 dollar sandwich that was actually worth 8 bucks, and possibly 9.

HIGHLY recommend. 

There is nowhere to sit, but it's close to lots of office buildings so I'm sure you can find a spot to eat.
author: Pippi L.

description:
The office chatter of an amazing sandwich place down the block and the suggestion from Shelby C. led me to The Sentinel one sunny summer day.

After doing some pre-Yelping, I knew I had to try the CORNED BEEF SANDWICH. I arrived around 12:30 and the line was only 3 deep. They promptly took my order and name and I was in and out of there in less than 5 minutes. The service is extremely fast and the people behind the counter operate efficiently.

Upon opening the box, I was greeted by a BIG 'EAT ME NOW' corned beef sandwich. The toasted bread was perfection. There was so much flavor and texture, I couldn't stop eating it. By the time I got 3/4 into the thing. I was feeling full; but nonetheless finished and licked the remnants on my fingertips.

Sentinel is a great place for delicious food and quick service. They also include pickles and an Andes mint as a topper. Parking can be difficult as this is in the FiDi.
author: Myron J.

description:
Since I work in Golden Gate Park, I can't get downtown M-F for a sandwich from The Sentinel. Lucky me that I had a meeting at 33 New Montgomery, and was able to jump in line before the lunch rush.  

I have complete confidence in Dennis Leary and his fine team of sandwich chefs, but I think I just ordered the wrong thing today. The BBQ mushroom with goat cheese sounded promising, but I did not like the sauce.  It looked and tasted like brown mud. 

Next time I'll try the corned beef, and give 5 stars. I promise!

Kudos to the very organized sandwich team. They really push you through the line!
author: Lisa R.

description:
I like The Sentinal. Its a good grab and go sandwich place with an amazing corned beef and hash sandwich. Served on a fresh baked bread, the bread is soft and they don't load too much meat in it so its the perfect balance for my lunch.

Its a $9 sandwich so the price is a bit steep, but in SF a $9 sandwich isn't unheard of. Especially when its delicious!
author: Analisa S.

description:
Get: Corned beef sandwich

Came here for lunch with work as one of my coworkers is a huge fan of The Sentinel (like came here every other day for lunch). Also wanted to knock another thing off my 7x7 checklist. The sandwich was good, but not the best I've had in the world. I guess I'm not really a giant corned beef fan but it was pretty tasty. 

Big portions...I could only eat half and took the other half home for dinner. Their pomegranate lemonade was also very tasty!

Tip: Come later if you want to avoid long lines (we got there around 2 something and there was nobody there) but watch out because many of the sandwiches were already sold out!
author: Vickie D.

description:
The crew ordered lunch from here today.  We phoned in our order so there wouldn't be a long wait when we got there.  Since their sandwiches are enormous, we decided to order 4 different sandwiches and split it amongst ourselves.  This way we'd get to try something different. Love the bread.

-(*)SPICY PORK with roasted pepper puree and carrot-celery root coleslaw - 8.50 
-ROAST BEEF (rare) with blue cheese, smoked onions and frisee - 9.00
-VEAL AND RICOTTA MEATBALLS with spinach - 9.00
-CORNED BEEF with cabbage, Russian dressing and Swiss cheese - 9.00

(*) = favorite

The group favorite was the corned beef, but I took a liking to the spicy pork (though I ordered the veal).
author: Stacey L.

description:
Was FINALLY able to try The Sentinel today and I was totally wowwwwwwwwed. 

I had the special of the day which was spicy pork and chorizo stew with potatoes and kale. Apple, Pear crisp for dessert. The stew was absolutely delicious! Flavorful, porky, smokey, with the perfect amount of potatoes, onions, carrots and big chunks of pork and chorizo. 

The dessert was a sweet way to end the meal. All for $10. 

They have gained another follower. Fo sho.
author: Jen D.

description: Used to love this place. In fact I started with the corned beef and worked my way thru the menu. Unfortunately, it never got better then that first sandwich. Today i had my worst experience yet. Probably won't go back.
author: Joel D.

description: Generally pretty good, but more expensive than it needs to be.  Avoid the roast beef.  It's very rare and gave me food poisoning once (12 hour flash bug, nothing major, but I won't be getting it again).  The cookies are fantastic.
author: Mike D.

description:
It's true, I've been to the Sentinel multiple times...but only dined once. There are a couple of menu items that stay the same and a few daily specials that rotate weekly or once every few weeks.

Sadly, I don't like mustard, capers or smoked salmon which automatically eliminates me from eating about 50% of the menu at the Sentinel. So, finally, on my 4th attempt, I found an item that was meaty and did not contain any of the previously stated ingredients - the corned beef sandwich.

Damn tasty. It is true, it is a pretty decadent, rich, delicious, corned beef sandwich with gruyere cheese and caramelized onions. It's also true that the friend who I dined with had crazy entree envy. It's a delicious sandwich and fully satisfying as many sandwiches are not.

The lines are relatively long (~20ish minutes, depending on when you get there) but at least they're orderly. The saddest part is that if you go too late in the lunch hour, they may run out of the menu item you're most interested in.

Knocking off one star for The Sentinel because the corned beef sandwich is typically the only appealing menu item for me. Sad. :(
author: Wendy L.

description:
Mid week lunch at noon with my bf and I had a craving for a sandwich. I had always heard that The Sentinel was one of the best spots in SoMa and when I saw a shorter than usual line (8 people long) I jumped in. 

I was going through a vegetarian experiment which lasted less than a week before I caved :) Anyhow, I ended up ordering the mushroom & goat cheese sandwich and the BF got the corned beef w/ swiss, cabbage and russian dressing. The staff was awesome and we got our sandwiches quickly. Because there is no sitting space at The Sentinel, we headed to the steps on Montgomery and Market. Its a great spot to go if picking up from food trucks or counter only places. 

My bf LOVED the corned beef- said the meat was cooked perfectly and the dressing is what makes the sandwich. I LOVED the mushroom and goat cheese and would totally get it again even though I am no longer on my veggie kick. The goat cheese was super soft and mixed well with the mushroom and soft bread. It was a bit messy but well worth it.
author: Seema M.

description:
Every morning, before I go to work, I make breakfast at home. That is until I heard that The Sentinel also serves breakfast. I decide to skip breakfast, and I partake in the most delicious Sour Cherry Steel Cut Oatmeal. The next morning, I wanted more... SOLD OUT. I've since decided to skip breakfast at home a couple more times just to get breakfast there. Herein, I lament over the portion of your oatmeal.

Dear ladies of The Sentinel: I go in, willingly skipping breakfast, just to indulge in your mouth-watering oatmeal. If I pay for oatmeal, please don't fill the container not even halfway. I've only gone there once and received a decent sized portion. If this trend continues, I'll just have to start eating breakfast at home again. 

4 stars for the quality of sandwiches, oatmeal, and muffins.
3 stars for skimping on my oatmeal.
author: DeLune Avec DeBussy B.

description:
Strengths:
  -Corned beef sandwich - I love that it does not contain sauerkraut. Perfectly saucy and the bread is perfectly toasty
  -Oatmeal cookie was awesome
  -In and out in less than 5 minutes even with a large line

Development Areas:
  -Give me some ice with the lemonade

How to get to 5 stars:
  -Offer the dessert a la carte
author: Jason L.

description:
Sandwiches or mobile meals as a friend calls them can be as simple and soul satisfying as any gourmet meal. Sentinel, may be the ultimate example of just how well it can be done. 

Even just walking up you have the feeling that this is going to be different, there is a line wrapping itself outside. A girl taking your order and using a snazzy, colorful Post It process that works brilliantly. You step up, pay, and maybe wait a few minutes before your name is called and you're off, lunch in hand. 

It's not the portions, not some other fancy trend or gimmick, it's just a damn good combination of toppings, protein, and bread. 

The cookies are also good (although, I'd stay away from the molasses cookies) and the lemonades are a deliciously sweet option. 

Grab Sentinel, hit one of the nearby picnics and enjoy!
author: Maria A.

description:
"I believe all everyone really wants in life is to sit in peace and eat a sandwich" - Liz Lemon. 

When she said that, she was talking about The Sentinel's sandwiches. You really don't need anything else (food, shelter, love etc) after one of those.

Don't be intimidated by the long line, it moves quickly and the staff is friendly.
author: Caro D.

description:
In general, pretty good -- if expensive -- sandwiches. I don't think they quite live up to the hype, but I'm generally willing to go here with a colleague who is in the mood.

For one, I don't love how they smear mayo on everything. Unfortunately I always forget to request they hold it because so many places in SF don't use it!

Also, I've found that their sandwiches have pretty interesting flavors but can be lacking in the texture department. A number of the sandwiches I've had have lots of gooey innards and then put on a really soft roll and it leaves something to be desired. But maybe I just haven't chosen wisely from the menu?

Sentinel is OK for the occasional lunch but not a place where I go out of my way to eat.
author: Sydney L.

description:
The spicy pork sandwich was unique and good.  Only complaint is that it was a little sloppy.  

Quick service.  Would go back.
author: Pat K.

description:
I think The Sentinel is definitely selling an experience more than it is selling sandwiches. Don't get me wrong, the sandwiches are tasty, but come on, they're not the most amazing sandwiches you've ever had.

The foccacia is good, if not a bit greasy and soggy. Especially the bottom piece, which has pretty much lost all crispiness and more closely resembles a sponge. Not sure if it's from sitting on a tray for too long or what.

I had the corned beef, and wasn't terribly impressed by the meat itself. It's edible, it's warm, there's a lot of it. That's about all I can say. For corned beef, it doesn't have much flavor.

But maybe that's because it's being masked by the Russian dressing. Which we all know is just a euphemism for ketchup and mayo. But if they added any spices like horseradish, I couldn't tell. It really just tasted like ketchup.

The sauerkraut was fine, I guess, but the dominant flavor in this sandwich is the Russian dressing, and the dominant texture is mushy.

Overall, I might try a different sandwich here, but I wouldn't get the corned beef again. I needed the sauerkraut to be crunchier, the bread to be crispier, and the beef to come out from behind the Russian dressing and be the star of the sandwich.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
I'm glad The Sentinel exists; the 'People who are busy and like good sandwiches' demographic has been ignored for way too long. 

It probably won't do much good to recommend specific sandwiches, since their menu rotates, but grab the ground lamb and eggplant sandwich if you see it - it's sort of like a sweet, herbal tasting sloppy joe - and I've enjoyed every incarnation of the roast beef sandwich I've tried.

The line can be long but it moves quickly; please contribute to it moving quickly by brining cash if possible (you'll need ten or so, a little more if you're having lemonade or a dessert) and studying the menu online or posted in the window before the server gets to you.
author: matthew r.

description: I go here all the time.  They are pretty on point.  From the oatmeal and muffins in the morning to the sandwiches and lunch specials its all very good.  Out of probably 50 visits I've only had one so-so sando.  I'd say that merits a 5/5.
author: Zack H.

description:
Finally! A sandwich! 

Corned Beef, Cabbage, Russian Dressing, and Swiss Cheese on a Focaccia with encrusted sea salt to add the perfect balance of salt to the sweetness of the dressing. The bread gives the sandwich a body and crunch that serves as a stage to let the melty, tender swiss corned beef mixture dissolve away in your mouth. 

The sandwich alone cost nearly 10 dollars but it hits the stomach like a rock. The perfect helping. Not too much and not too little. They should rename this delight to be called the "Content Corned Beef" because that was exactly what I was. (Cheesy I know)
author: Spencer C.

description: We stopped by this place during our visit to San Fran. The sandwiches are amazing! I had the veal and ricotta meatball sandwich while my fiancé had the corned beef sandwich. Both were freshly made and jam-packed with flavor! There isn't anywhere to sit and eat but Union Square wasn't too far of a walk so we went there. Hoping to visit this place again when I'm back in SF!
author: Sarath P.

description:
Roast beef no blue cheese!

I must have ordered the wrong item on the menu,. but my sandwich was crap.  I paid $9 for roast beef and lettuce,. roast beef that was REALLY raw!! Never have I eaten roast beef that raw before.  My co - workers were telling me that it should be toasted and kind of warm?! My sandwich was cold!!

The only good thing about the sandwich was the bread. I couldn't stand the taste of the roast beef in my mouth.  I only ate the smaller half and tossed the rest.  

Should have known better when they said they didn't have bacon and avocado to add.  Should have walked away,... 

Heard the corn beef sandwich was the best seller,. but I had a really bad experience,. don't think I will be back! 

YUCK
author: Chanel L.

description: Not too many options for vegetarians. There is only 1 option generally which is the Roasted Cauliflower cold sandwich. The sandwich was good but i have better sandwiches elsewhere.
author: Ashok L.

description: What?! they just made cauliflower delicious, which means I lost a bet with the gf. thanks sentinel.
author: Eric G.

description: The corned -beef was nothing special. I was not the best fan of the sauce, but in all it was okay.
author: Charles Z.

description: Now that is a sandwich.  Has a great menu and variety.  Not your typical sandwich either, so great if you want to try something different and switch things up.  I recommend the Tasso, it is AMAZING.  I also like their strawberry lemonade and cookies.
author: Annette E.

description:
Dennis Leary is one of the best chefs in the city. I'm loving the fact that when I get a little tired of Golden West I can always come to the Sentinel for something different and just as good. Between the two locations I'm set for 80% of my lunches for the week.

Rare roast beef +10
Corned beef +10
Ground lamb +10
Mushroom and eggplant +12
Pastry +15

Money well spent on real quality.
author: Steve S.

description:
$9 for Corned Beef sandwich.  Delicious!  As the most popular on yelp, I gave this a try and was not disappointed.  Its huge, came in a big box, by the time I finished my 15minute walk back to work, the bottom of the bread was not as toasty.  Still very good since the bread is thick.  LOADS of corned beef, excellent portion of cabbage and sauce & moz cheese - blended well and great flavor.

Comes with a lengthy slice of pickle and Andes mint (with every order).
author: Ju D.

description:
The Sentinel is a great idea: high end chef working away right in front of your face, presumably striving to make us believe that lunch out of a coat closet-sized kitchen has a rightful place alongside the white table cloth affair that we all enjoy when we go to fancy-pants restaurants.

Well, I'm a believer.  At the end though, I wonder if I really do need a chef of Mr. Leary's caliber to make me a corned beef sandwich.  It was good -- damned good, but it wasn't heads and tails above a corned beef sandwich I might find elsewhere.  The turkey salad sandwich didn't quite fare as well (a little dry, a little underseasoned?), but still was enjoyable and filling.

It's hard to knock The Sentinel, and the truth is that I'm probably not scrutinizing my other corned beef sandwiches the way I scrutinized this one.  That's my bad, not Chef Leary's.  So do I recommend The Sentinel?  Absolutely, it's a fun experience.  But I'm still trying to figure out whether I really had a great lunch or just a fun dining experience...
author: Laurence W.

description:
One of the best sandwich spots in the area.  Not the most healthy, but sometimes you gotta throw all caution to the wind and eat things like spicy pork, or roast beef with horseradish cream cheese.  (2 of my favorites on the menu).

The lines are sometimes long, but they're good about getting your order in line so that the wait is minimal...
author: DJ P.

description:
I showed up at 2pm on a Thursday and there was only one sandwich left (evidently they sell out pretty quickly).  For $9 I tried the Coppa, which has fresh mozzarella, prosciutto, greens, pumpkin seeds, and mustard.  It was probably the best sandwich I've had in san francisco and, considering it was the last pick by Sentinel patrons, Im eager to try the other sandwiches.  Plus you get two pickles and some of those Andes mints.

The place has no seating, but there are plenty of plazas around the area where you can sit down with your sandwich.
author: Chris M.

description:
I believe I have a calling.  It's to find those good simple sandwiches that simply leave you breathing out "wow."  And no its not because of the dressing or extra garlicky sauce, its the quality of the simple things: the meat, the bread, and the light aroma of flavor that marries them together.

The sentinel surely holds a place in that category.  With a nice squeezed lemonade, the corned beef gruyere sandwich was an amazing flavor with perfect seasoning and consistency with the bread.  And pickles!?  yes thank you
author: Vincent K.

description:
The Sentinel is my go-to sandwich spot, despite the fact that it's a 12-minute walk from my office (and I walk by 5-6 other sandwich shops).  It warrants the time commitment and I go here once to twice a week.

From the outside, it doesn't seem particularly special: a long line and no seating.  But they have their work down to a science and you can get through there really quickly (and they still manage to be friendly!).

As to the food, it's simply delicious.  Their veal and pork meatball sandwich is my favorite, followed closely by the lamb and eggplant.  Both of those meals tend to have the effect of making all lunch conversation cease: you just sit there concentrating on the flavors.

It's delightful.  Try it.
author: Jon B.

description:
got the corned beef...it was actually very good.  i like the slaw and the corned beef wasnt extremely fatty and greasy.  the bread they used was unique..crunchy yet light. will def try again

they also serve breakfast..coffee and muffins
author: Linda T.

description:
Meal: Lunch
Date: March 3, 2009

This place is small but not impossible to find. They've got food but no place to sit and eat. The menu is sparse but I knew what I wanted before I got there: the corned beef. It was delicious and well worth the $8.50 it cost me. They must sell a lot of them because I got mine in less than two minutes. I loved the combination of tastes: corned beef, Russian dressing, cabbage, Gruyere. I was a bit skeptical about the medium it was served on, flat bread, but it went well with the other ingredients. It came with a pickle and a butterscotch hard candy. It was a filling meal and no pricier than I would expect from a deli in the downtown area of a major metropolitan city.
author: Dave L.

description: I had the Smoked Trout Salad with with fennel, apple and curry mayo -- now silly me missed the word "salad" in that so I was pretty surprised when I got back and realized I had a mayo monster on my hand. While this is a huge dietary no-no (I even ate the bread) the sandwich was delicious. It definitely had an interesting blend to it which kind of amazed me (really). I'm not sure if my dietary guidelines will allow frequent visits but it definitely seems like a good place to go for a nice (calories laden) treat.
author: Shauna S.

description:
Oh man, I was working over at 33 Montgomery today for something, and we had our lunch provided for.  I had this chicken parmesean thingy that someone else had as well and to use her words tasted like leather.  Threw it out, went outside to grab something from the sentinel.  I asked the girl who was taking the orders what her favorite is, she said the roast beef is the bomb, but she said it takes like 10 minutes to make.  Too bad, I didn't have that much time.  She said the spicy pork is the bomb too, so I tried that.  2 minutes later, I was in elevator on my way back to my work thing.  The sandwich was the bomb, had this peppery sauce that was kinda sweet but kinda not.  Not very spicy for spicy pork but full-flavored, not dry at all.  And this pickle was quite a surprise - tons of flavor, but no bite like some pickles have.  

Definitely coming back.  Thanks for saving the day.
author: Dong T.

description: I got the lamb sandwich. It's basically ground/mushed lamb with Indian spices and chickpea, like an Indian sloppy joe. I was quite disappointed and was seriously concerned that the lady had given me a vegetarian burger because I could not taste/find any lamb. it's really heavy on the carb with the mushiness from the bun and the chickpea.  For 9 bucks I expected better. They've also got a $8 credit card limit. Given the restrictions, price tag and disappointing lamb sandwich, I probably won't go back even it is just right across from my office.
author: Q Y.

description:
SMALL PORTIONS! I just paid $11 for a very small appetizer: a couple cucumber circles, two strawberries and a very small scoop of pulled pork.

I'm sorry, but I can't believe how much I paid for for so very little food. Plus I waited in line forever.

Tasted fine, but not for that price. Holy Crap! I'm starving now, it only made me hungrier.
author: Cory D.

description: Omfg. Delicious and fast! Get your grub and get out of there, if you have a short lunch and see a long line, despair not! You'll be at the front super quick! I got the polenta and meatballs. Holy cow! This was great! I donno that I've ever eaten something so good out of a travel container. Marinara tastes super fresh. Eating leftovers as we speak. So good! Careful, sometimes they only take cash, which can be inconvenient.
author: Jessica W.

description:
I've yet to eat a sandwich here that I didn't like; yet to eat anything here that I didn't like. Always a long line from 12 -1 but it does move fast. The more popular sandwiches sell out every day. Breakfast is getting busier now too - though I haven't seen a line yet.

Breakfast - I'll take any one of their amazing muffins but in a pinch, I always choose the coffee cake. It's as good or better than any coffee cake I've ever eaten - and coffee cake is a tradition in my family. Top quality espresso drinks too.

Lunch - I've had the special many times but it's generally more than I want to eat in one sitting. I had the newest incarnation of the Chicken Chipotle (with Avo and tortilla chips) and I don't think I'll ever order anything else so long as it's on the menu. That said, the BALT is great for a warm day. The Copa with the pesto - amazing. The meatballs are great (if messy) for a warm sando. 

Suggestion** If you're not a big mayo person, ask them to go light - or leave it off altogether. I don't think it's too much mayo but it is probably more than I'd put on a sando I made at home.

Cookies - I'm a choco person and the chocolate chip here is solid but the peanut butter is awesome. The molasses (with raisins!) is xlnt too - if you like molasses.

Cantalope-lemonade, strawberry-lemonade, pomegranate-lemonade: enough said.
author: Robert B.

description:
I would eat here a whole lot more often if it were just slightly cheaper. It has some great sandwiches which all come with a pickle and a little candy.

I have liked all the sandwiches that I have tried (most of the menu).

Some things you should know: 1. Do not get discouraged by a long line, this place moves quickly and they have a very fast system for getting people in and out as fast as possible. I have never spent more than 10 minutes from start to finish of the process. 2. They sell out of items each day, so if there is something special that you want, you should go early to be sure they still have it. 3. They are cash only!

Everyone in here is very friendly. They call you by your name and are very smiley. I think this is a really great pick-me-up in the middle of a tough work day.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
The best way to get a Russian person to eat a sandwich is to use a hearty dose of horseradish, and throw in a pickle on the side. Sold. 

I've only gotten the roast beef (with horseradish) here, and its damn good. The bread is a little too soft for my liking though..

TIP: They only start serving sandwiches after 11.
TIP: The roast beef sandwiches sell out quickly.
TIP: Cash only.

Will definitely be back.
author: Artem A.

description:
MEATBALL SANDWICH.

Bad day= meatball sandwich
Mean boss= meatball sandwich
Annoying coworker= meatball sandwich
Hungover= meatball sandwich
Angry at bf/gf/wife/husband/anyone/guy across street= meatball sandwich

It's so yummy.  It's a veal meatball, in a soft roll, yummy tomato sauce.  It's not your typical heavy meatball sandwich, but it's not light either.  It's just perfectly finessed.

Thinking about it now I am so happy, happy to be alive, to look forward to another day when I can eat this meatball sandwich.
author: YJ P.

description: Finally had the chance to try it.  Was observing the crazy line to Sushiritto and decided to get the corned beef.  Really really good sandwich.  Warm, crispy focaccia bread with a russian dressing, slaw and swiss cheese.  The slice of pickle is seasoned and very good to compliment the sandwich.  I went around 11:30 and there was no line at all.  May try a cold sandwich next time.
author: Josh L.

description:
I've never understood the hype about this place.  I admit that their muffins are outstanding, but the sandwiches are pretty hit or miss in my opinion - and they use way too much mayo.

I went with a coworker yesterday and got the meatball special.  It was pretty tasty but nothing to rave about.

He ordered the spicy chicken sandwich, and partway through it he found a piece of chicken that was raw.  RAW.  Completely and utterly raw.  

I'm never going back.

(Well, maybe for the muffins.)
author: Katherine B.

description:
Second time eating at The Sentinel and damn, they know how to make sandwiches. This time I had the lamb meatball sandwich to feed my baby belly and it was really good. Interesting flavors in the meatball combined with a sweet bun and some gooey white sauce (ricotta?) smeared all over it. Not the healthiest lunch, but one of the yummiest, I have to say. 

Last time I had the corned beef and you can't go wrong here. Plenty of meat, delicious cabbage and the right amount of dressing. Takes some will-power to not eat here every day. 

Next up, I'll try some of their cold sandwiches.
author: Chiaty S.

description: Hot damn these sammies are good! I went there twice. While the Palace Hotel across the street wasn't my cup of tea, this little sandwich place right outside its door sure was! I had a cappacola, mozzarella and pumpkin seed pesto sandwich one day and the spicy pork with carrot the other. Both rocked my world! I never ever crave sandwiches or get that excited about them, but these....wow!
author: Charlie B.

description: I like that the Sentinel changes their menu all the time. They always have a variety of sandwiches and then a couple specials like soup or stew. Everyone raves about the corned beef sandwich, but I actually think it's just okay. I find it overly salty and too heavy. I prefer the lamb and eggplant sandwich or the roast beef with horseradish. Prices are a little high for the portion size and they often run out of items. Definitely go early if you're planning on ordering one of the specials.
author: Alice J.

description: Great sandwiches. Fast service. But reminds me of the "soup nazi" a little bit when ordering. You have to know what you're ordering. You have to be ready. Don't ask too many questions.
author: Aya C.

description:
This is a review long due.

Know how for some reason you don't yelp the places that you frequent? So for me this is really an example for such a case: ever since I've started working in the area I've been visiting this slice of heaven of a lunch spot at least twice a week. 

Each time I fall in love with a different sandwich. Then the process is as follows: I remain completely faithful to it until some workmate lets me try a bite of his, at which point I switch partners. So far I've coupled with the Egg sandwich, the Spicy Tuna sandwich, the Lamb and Feta sandwich. Smoked Mozzarella and Ratatouille seems spectacular and if it weren't for the onions I would have probably been closer to that one too.

What can I say.. I even love their cookie and coffee cake. 

Well, today I realized that it is my duty to Yelp. Curiously, it was due to a tragic accident: somebody there put the wrong sandwich in my bag by some rare turn of events. unknowingly I walked back to the office only to be stuck at a meeting and having to miserably watch everybody else eat. 
I therefore went back an hour later with my sandwich. And what can I say... they made up for it handsomely.. didn't think I could appreciate this business more, but there... 

Anyway, I realize this review came out bordering on fan fiction - so for the sake of proving that I was writing it while maintaining the proper levels of objectivity as worthy of a critic, I'll just mention that I am not a big groupie of the (complimentary!) chocolate mint or the pickled cucumber. So there: godlike but not perfect. I suggest you come and queue behind me on Monday.
author: tal n.

description:
Line was pretty long, but they have a good efficient system going on.  I ordered the corned beef sandwich based on the yelp reviews.  Everything about it was good even the russian dressing and I don't even like mayo.  If you're like me, ask for light dressing.  The bread was so good.  

I just wish it wasn't $10, but I guess thats what you get in the FiDi.
author: Erika C.

description: I had heard nothing but good things about this Sandwich Shop and the Chef responsible for it. I do not work downtown so I only recently had an opportunity to try it. I admit I was somewhat concerned that it might have been over hyped; I am pleased to say I loved it!!
author: Edward S.

description: Nommy sandwich. I had the "BALT" (Basil, avocado, goat cheese and tomato). The combination was delicious and a nice departure from the "grossly cooked hunk of mushroom" sandwich that seems to be every other deli's veggie option. There's no seating, but take it to yerba buena or union square for a nice lunchtime picnic. Definitely on the pricey end of sandwiches (8.50 ish), but the bread smells so good I can't stop myself.
author: Claire G.

description: This is a new place i stopped to grab a quick lunch... The LAMB AND EGGPLANT with curry, and herb pesto was really awesome... This is a togo place where you can grab a quick bite... they are pretty quick and love the taste..  I will definitely try other things on their menu...
author: Sid G.

description:
yummy sandwich. I had the roast beef

pros: fast service, bread is fresh, lots of meat, flavorful
cons: a little pricey, not enough sides (ie fries) or drink options (only lemonade or orangina)

will go back to try the pork sandwich
author: grant l.

description:
This tiny downtown sandwich could be the set of a Food Network reality show.  The efficiency and energy level, and seriousness, are stunning.  Redheaded Chef Denis Leary, in full Bobby Flay mode, commands five cooks, two cashiers, an order-taker, some back-of-house runnders, all in a low voice, staring down his station with the intensity of a caged bobcat, all in an area the size of a suburban bathroom - no exaggeration, the interior here is about 250 square feet. If someone says boo here there may be bloodshed.

If you haven't been I highly recommend it.  Just watching Denis and his expanding lunchtime empire gives me local pride.  Success couldn't happen to a more sincere, hardworking chef.

Prices are high for sandwiches, but low for serious food.  Quality ingredients shine on things like the olive oil on the salad garnish.  Some items here would be worth twenty dollars a plate at a sit down fancy restaurant.  But there are misfires.  Home baked bread makes the place smell wonderful, but Acme is better.  Pulled pork has a wonderful natural flavor but is stringy and dry.  By contrast the corned beef is awesome, and homemade pickles are a step beyond.

Right now I'm at a bar counter watching an even more famous chef wander his kitchen purposefully but in a happy mood, he jokes with a staff in obvious awe, his kitchen turning out sublime small plates to some early evening locals.  You don't have to be gonzo to be great, I guess.  As much as I love the Sentinel, it's too edgy, Denis is going to give himself a heart attack and I think everyone there could use a good shoulder rub.
author: Gil S.

description: I'm going to restate what I said before--this is AMAZING and hands down one of the best sandwiches I have ever had. I'm not one to love sandwiches, but this is incredible...beyond words.
author: Chrissy H.

description:
Honestly the first photo here say it all!!! I was skeptical about this place at first, thinking that I have had a lot of good sandwiches but not usually near FiDi. This place put all my skepticism to rest. The corn beef sandwich was incredible. The extra pickle on the side and the little candy were also a nice touch. I think my favorite part of the whole experience was not how great the sandwich was but rather the fact that this little hole in the wall shop was able to break my friends $100 bill. You don't see places like this do that very often. 

There were really only two down sides in my opinion. First there is no seating any where really near there. It would be nice if it was located near an area with some benches or something...Guess that means I will just have to enjoy my food in front of my coworkers and make them jealous. The other downside was the price. Definitely a great sandwich worth the price but nonetheless the price is what will keep me from eating there more often. I just can't justify a $10 a few times a week.

All in all I was pleasantly surprised by this place. All I can recommend is that you give it a try!
author: Andrew M.

description:
I nominate the owner of Sentinel to start his own reality TV show:  Hell's Sandwich Shop.  He would be the perfect host.  Given the small size of this shop you get a front row seat to the verbal interplay that happens in most busy kitchens.  That means terse words and orders being exchanged with regularity.  It's good theatre while you wait for your sandwich.

For the most part, they deliver.  The bread is always fresh (as it is at Canteen, the sister restaurant) and soft, kind of a brioche.  Although I've had many sandwiches here, the one I love most is the pork with the spicy sauce.  The roast beef has been a mainstay too; it's bloody rare and rich.  They are known for their corned beef sandwich, too, although I found it too mild for my taste (mostly over-dressed).

The sandwiches are messy.  It's the necessary result of using soft bread, actually.  They also tend to get a bit soggy because the bread absorbs moisture and there isn't generally much fat (e.g. butter) to keep it out.  This is a problem, although if you're like me the sandwich will be gone before its moist doomsday arrives.

In all honesty Naked Lunch has supplanted this place as my favorite sandwich shop, so I rarely come here anymore since moving away from it.  It's no fault of the business, really, there's just nowhere to sit and eat if you don't work in an office nearby.  I could see going again if they had a sandwich that could be easily eaten while you carry it.  That would mean using a crustier, more moisture-resistant bread.  

Anyway, in the meantime I am waiting for that reality show ...
author: J W.

description: believe the hype: The corn Beef sandwich is the bomb. Wish I could eat this breakfast lunch and dinner but then I'd be irish. Honestly a must try if you need a quick lunch very delious.
author: Phil D.

description:
Go for the corned beef sando. Go back for the corned beef sando. Keep coming back for all the other items they have. This is my favorite sandwich spot downtown far and away. 

Take an early lunch and get there right when they open as the line can get insane.
author: Louis A.

description:
Holy crap the line is around the corner. This better be a damn good corned beef.

Not a bad sandwich (I did eat it) but disappointing. Not the traditional corned beef that you find in NYC. A traditional corned beef sandwich does not belong on foccacia bread with coleslaw. But then again, this is San Francisco.
author: Vanessa N.

description: First time today. It's so good that I cannot stop eating it. I ordered the corned beef, it was ready in less than 5 min - piping hot and YUM! I will definitely be back. Perhaps next time I'll try the lamb and eggplant mmmmm...
author: Noneya B.

description:
First time I went: Great! 
Second time: Disgusting. Roast beef that was not rare but RAW (barf) and more mayo than I've ever had in my life. I love rare roast beef and i LOVE mayo, but this was disgusting. Now I just heard from someone else that their meatballs were raw inside. 

And yet there is still a line. Perhaps it's a new raw food cult - raw meat.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Highly disappointed! I don't really see what the rave is about...I still think Ike's is much better for $10 sandwiches...I had the spicy pork and it was too soggy...not enough flavor, and some parts of the meat (that didnt get much of the sauce) was really dry...pork is one of the juiciest meats and this was dry...but they do give you a lot of meat...

I also tried the corned beef sandwich...ugh...tasted really "animal-y"...maybe coz I'm just not a corned beef fan though it could be tasty as a breakfast dish with other stuff mixed in...

Can't believe I took the day off so I can try their sandwiches...
author: Jenny C.

description:
The ladies manning the customer line manage to remember my name every time I go. Service with a smile. Just ordering a sandwich is really pleasant here.

Not to mention the sandwiches. I've tried almost all of them so far, and the great majority have been mindblowingly good. The BBQ mushroom, smoked trout, roast beef and spicy pork are especially good. This is far more than just a sandwich; these sandwiches are made with love and mad genius. Do not miss.
author: Dara K.

description: Yummy and veggie friendly.  2 veggie options!  I had the egg salad sandwich and it was simply delicious.  Fresh bread and super tasty ingredients.  Yaya!
author: Matt N.

description:
I eat their muffins four days a week. Why? They are good, have fast service (2x faster than the nearby Specialty's), friendly, and are situated between BART and work, or rather where I worked until we followed the excitement and headed West this last week. Some flavors are rare (lemon / poppy seed) and appear twice a year, while others are common everyday like blueberry.

I get the lunch sandwich once every few months. It's good but the ordering gets confusing, although the line is faster than it looks.  Also per square foot that has to be the most profitable lunch stand in the city
author: Lost S.

description:
Holy moley, this place is tasty!  I just had the **chicken mole sandwich** with pumpkin seeds and tortilla chips.  The chips were inside the sandwich, just like I like to do at home! :)  It was deliciously flavorful, with good quality chicken and fresh lettuce (though I have to admit, I did up the spiciness level by dousing it with sriracha sauce back at the office!).

At $8.75 for my sandwich, it's not the cheapest, but it's also not that much more than most other places in the FiDi, and there's all the hype around this place because it's darn good.  And fast!  The line was around the corner when I got there, but I was in and out in just about 6 minutes.
author: David W.

description: Great sandwiches. Amazing coffee cake. Nice staff. Little pricey.
author: Roger J.

description:
My friend and I have been itching to try this place and we were so glad we came today.  Somehow the lunch gods allowed our first time at Sentinel to be relatively quick..  I had heard that there's usually a long line but we did not encounter that on  our visit. 
Its been cold in SF so we opted to share one turkey meatball and a BALT (basil-avo-lett-tomato) Now here's the fun part.  I ate the BALT first because I love avocado.  My friend tried the Turkey meatball.  We both liked our first sandwich over our second.  I liked the BALT because it was light and fresh. My friend liked the TM because it had so much flavor and felt the BALT was lacking in that department. 

Next time we come we are def. going to try the tofu sandwich and pork with pumpkin seed pesto.  YUM!
author: Sarah C.

description:
The Sentinel = Solid 4 stars

The food items changes daily and usually has about 5 items to choose from.  The place is small, yet clean and efficient.  I love the quality of ingredients and the chef in plain sight.  We had the roast beef sandwich and the tuna salad sandwich yesterday.  The roast beef was very meaty and the horseradish cream cheese spread was very creative.  As for the tuna salad, it was perfection!  The tuna salad wasn't drenched in mayo and had a real nice crunchy slaw with it.  Both sandwiches came with a remarkably refreshing pickle and fantastic breads.  Loved it!

For about $8.00 you walk away with a delightful sandwich.  The stars of the show are Chef Dennis Leary and his AMAZING choice of breads!!!

P.S.  If you don't work around and only pass The Sentinel during your commute, grab their breakfast pastries and it won't disappoint!  It's all fabulous!
author: Lisa R.

description:
On an analyst's salary, this is the most I can spend on a lunch without cutting into my other expenses.  It is insane how efficient their system is -- from ordering to paying and finally, to pick up -- all in a literal hole in the wall counter!  It reminds me of Japan and ordering food from a vending machine (you order from the machine, present the ticket ot the cook, and then get your food).  Easy as 1 - 2 - 3!

I had their corn beef and it was absolutely heavenly (bonus points for the cheesy bread).  I wanted to order the roast beef but it was alraedy sold out by mid noon.  Please get there early, otherwise you'll miss out on their specials. =)
author: Alexander H.

description:
Clearly people love this place, and I suppose I'll give it another shot to try other items on the menu.  Some sounded quite tasty.  But as for the hot corned beef sandwich with cabbage and swiss, it left me cold.  

Focaccia bread is a strange choice to use with this kind of 'wich, and it was soggy on the bottom.  The "Russian Dressing" had a lot of tomato sauce and the sweetness just didn't work for me.  

7 x 7 Magazine named that sandwich one of the 100 things you should eat before you die.  But it was definately NOT worth going out of your way for.  If you pass it up, maybe you'll live longer...
author: Sean M.

description:
I began my love affair with The Sentinel a month or so ago, and I gotta say this relationship is progressing at a fast pace. 

Started slow with the mushroom/chard sandwich. Second base was the lamb and feta meatball, which like any good  made me want more. Had the egg salad sandwich today which was earth shattering. Seriously the best egg salad I've ever had. The Sentinel sure knows how to keep a girl happy.

I  need a cigarette. If only I smoked
author: Sarah W.

description:
The sentinel used to be the lunch spot to go, place to show co-workers, place to boast about. But sadly, yesterday when I went, it seems that the Sentinel has let itself slip. 

My corn beef sandwich is no longer the famed sandwich I used to daydream about during work. It is now ..sorta cold, kinda dry with very little sauce and no longer packed with corn beef. Needless to say, I was not proud to bring my new co-workers here, especially after boasting and hyping about its legendary deliciousness. 

Sentinel, I will give you one more chance but please don't disappoint me next time. I know you can do better.
author: Lily S.

description:
The muffins...oh the muffins!

They're baked fresh and full of wholesome goodness.  I can't believe they're healthy too.  Fresh fruit baked in!  They don't leave you with a weighted feeling afterwards because they're not oily.  They're so popular, you have to call ahead or come early.

The blue berry corn bread muffin is good and good for you. The raspberry is soft, supple, and slightly sweet.  The peach, well it's good but not my favorite...
author: MTBer I.

description: I really like the turkey sandwich here, although the length of the line often scares me away. I've tried coming early to beat the rush, but they won't serve lunch until 11:30, so I feel like they force me to wait in a long line, which is why I'm only giving 3 stars. Some people don't want to waste their lunch hour waiting in line for food!
author: Jamon B.

description:
So we already know I'm obsessed with The Sentinel for lunch but I stopped in for a freshly baked muffin upon suggestions from other Yelpers and you MUST get one if possible.

I had the blueberry the other morning which is to die for, and served warm out of the oven. At $3 a little expensive, but huge and filling.

Had the fresh peach one for breakfast this morning, and once again- it was delicious. I definitely suggest stopping in for a fresh muffin before work and you will be happy ALL DAY!~
author: Sarah A.

description:
Colleague was raving about this place so I finally made it out here during lunch time. Line wasn't crazy long and they go fast anyway. I ordered the corned beef sandwich and wasn't really blown away. I'm not a big fan of cabbage but I still eat it. 
Definitely wouldn't walk all the way here for lunch but if I am in the area, I would definitely like to try the meatball sandwich.
author: Anna P.

description: Maybe I'm just not a sandwich person, but I think this place is overrated. I mean, it's good, but not heavenly amazing - I can live without trying this place. The prices can be steep for a sandwich, but the portions are ginormous! I ended up only finishing half my sandwich. I ordered the Corned Beef & Cabbage Sandwich since I heard good things about it. I really enjoyed the bread, but the sandwich could definitely use more corned beef and less cabbage. I feel like I was just eating a cabbage sandwich instead of a corned beef sandwich. The cheeses went well with the sandwich, but it wasn't anything spectacular. It's just a regular sandwich to me... and I prefer those from Safeway actually...
author: Michelle L.

description:
I could easily eat here for lunch every day.  

Their sandwiches are awesome, but I usually go with the Daily Special which comes with entree, salad, and dessert.

The last one I got was Lamb Sheppard pie, with a cucumber salad, and really good apple pastry for dessert.
author: Chris Q.

description:
A friend at work introduced me to Sentinel and it's fast become a favorite for my lunchtime ventures! I am usually guilty of eating at my desk or running across the street to the nearest sandwich/salad joint, but Oh.My.Goodness.....Sentinel is worth the walk! AND it gets me outside :)  I would highly recommend calling in your order - you walk right up to the cashier and wait a whole minute or so while they pack up your order. I love it!  One thing to note though, credit card minimum is $10 so if you're like me and don't usually have cash, you might want to swing by the ATM on the way. 

I've tried their roast beef (delicious - they make it rare and it's exactly what I need to satisfy that occasional craving for beef), the corned beef sandwich that my friend kept raving about (I totally agree with her but I think I'll stick to my roast beef) and most recently their corn, bacon, and clam chowder. The soup was good (not creamy and very well seasoned) and it comes with a huge, honking piece of bread so it was more than enough for lunch by itself.  I have to admit though, I think I like their sandwiches more! 

I will definitely be coming back! It's almost a treat in itself to check their site on a day that I've decided to pick up lunch and to see what daily special is in store for me. :)
author: Dawn L.

description:
Yes the sandwiches are the best in this area.  Yes the specials are f'ng delicious.  Yes the people who work there are awesomely nice.  Today I am writing about the bearclaw I had there.  It f'ng ruled.  

I'd never imagine myself saying that about bearclaws but here I am doing it.  I've had their muffins (delicious) cookies (incredible) and now their bearclaw (the best).  I don't know if they bake their own pastries but if they do, jeezus, how could this place get any better?
author: Pouria Y.

description: The menu is short but the sandwiches are good.  I had the lamb & egg plant sandwich; I'd give it 4 stores.  Just so you know there's no seating but it's a nice place to get a quick lunch.
author: Thomas P.

description:
I majorly heart sandwiches, and The Sentinel falls somewhere in the "good" range of my personal scale.  The variety of sammies is pretty wide, although there's really only 1 vegetarian option (2 if you eat eggs).  I got the curried cauliflower and the bf got the chicken mole.  Mine was good - though realistically, it wasn't particularly unique and I could easily make the filling myself at home.  The soft, delicious bun was really the standout.  The chicken mole was interesting... the sauce was really nutty and not very chocolate-y, but the addition of tortilla chips is a good idea.  The pickle on the side pales in comparison to those at Deli Board.  Really, the #1 most memorable thing is the Andes mint they include with your order (loooove those).

Line moves fast, service is good, prices are a smidge too high (reasonable for the meaty, less so for cauliflower, srsly).  Will probably be back eventually, but won't make this one of my standard lunchtime haunts.
author: Allison B.

description: Hands down, best sammie in the Financial District. Actually may just be the best spot in SF! For under 10 bucks you can get a sandwich loaded with delicious tender meats either hot or cold depending on your pick! They also offer a seasonal salad if you are looking to go on the lighter side. Today I had the spicy pork with carrot and celery root slaw and my stomach is on cloud 9! Absolutely delicious. The ladies who work there are super friendly and always willing to put things on the side or add extra! An easy ordering process with quick delivery! Anytime you get a free pickle and little dessert treat is always a great time in my book! Go try it today!
author: Sheridan G.

description:
This is the San Francisco and sandwich version of the Soup Nazi.  Be there early because things sell out.  You stand in a line that is longer than you expect down an alley.  Someone takes your order just outside the door and writes it down with some kind of cryptic symbols.  When I got to the door, I found myself side stepping right up to it, they pushed my order into my hands, already wrapped and bagged, and I'm left there feeling around in my pockets and fumbling with my wallet, feeling bad because it seems like I'm breaking the flow of his highly efficient lunch creation machine.

Behind the register is a sign with a list of nearby public outdoor spaces (which are often a little more hidden in SF than they should be).  This is an awesome way to offset and acknowledge that this is a take out only place.

I'm not really a big fan of the pickles, I think they try to flavor infuse them or something.
author: Andy B.

description:
My 1st trip to the Sentinel was a success!  The Sentinel is a well-run establishment that serves delicious sandwiches.  

Don't be discouraged by the long line that straddles the corner of New Montgomery and Stevenson.  First, a long line is a good sign!  The line moves pretty quickly because Dennis Leary and his crew have thoughtfully created an efficient system of order taking, food preparation, and cashiering, given the space his team has to work with. 

The Sandwiches (I tried the chicken salad sandwich and the spicy pork sandwich):

Spicy Pork Sandwich: Don't expect flavors similar to that of a BBQ pulled-pork sandwich.  There are slices of pork tenderloin lightly smothered in a slightly spice pepper puree, which is topped with a carrot/celery root coleslaw that gives it a bit of the tangy flavor.  This is served on a freshly baked Challah bun, which provides sweetness to the sandwich.  It's a beautifully crafted sandwich that satisfy the belly.  The portions are quite generous and well worth the $8.50.

Chicken-Salad Sandwich:  Also served on a Challah bun. You won't get any of the "mayo" flavor that comes with regular chicken salad.  This chicken salad was dressed (I don't think it was mayo-based) with large chunks of chicken along with roasted peppers and artichokes (pleasant treat).  It also had a tangier taste with the artichoke hearts, blended with the sweetness of the Challah bun.

Other things I liked about the Sentinel:
1) Food pricing- Tax is included in the price (presumably) so there's no added time making change with pennies, nickels, and dimes.(except for quarters)
2) Menu- Smaller selection (maybe 10 choices of sandwiches) means food is prepared quickly.  But it still takes time to decide on your sandwich because they all sound really good!
3) Order taking- In peak times, someone will take your order while you are in line. When you reach the cashier to pay, your food is ready for you.  This means no waiting around, and no crowd hovering around for their food next to the register
4) Werther's candy and pickle.  Added treats in the bottom of your sandwich bag.

I definitely have my eye on the corned-beef sandwich and the Coppa sandwich the next time I go. And if the sandwiches are equally tasty, I will add more stars to the review.  

As I finish up my review on The Sentinel, my mouth is watering and sadly, the computer clock shows it's only  9:11 AM.
author: Brian K.

description:
what a freakin lame experience my bf and i had here. we happened to be in the area, and have been craving to try this famous corned beef sandwich. alas, they were out. they told him the options and the pork sounded good. he went for the coppa.
the coppa was so uninteresting and flavorless that i had one bite and stopped. the pork sandwich had gotten on my bad side today. it was tough, so overly soggy bread falling apart and just going everywhere (note: i'm not a messy eater), just unappetizing. two bites and i couldn't take it. and i paid almost $20 effing dollars for this!! what the heck! you can't make one amazing sandwich and let the rest be mediocre. you can, but you shouldn't, and you do. 
i will try the corned beef sandwich one day. but my taste buds will try no more.
author: Abigail W.

description:
Quick, tasty sandwiches a step away from Moscone Center where I was hanging out for a week during GDC. I tried the corned beef hash on focaccia and the tofu sandwiches, both came with a spicy pickle and an Andes mint chocolate! 

The corned beef sandwich could've easily been split for 2 meals, it was soooo rich and filling. The bread was especially good. The tofu sandwich came with crunchy carrots and peanuts smothered in some flavorful sauce. I'm really not a fan of tofu but this sandwich was great!
author: Tatyana K.

description:
Damn I love this place.  Who are these people?  They pretty much nail anything they put their mind to.  Take today's Thai style fish curry soup which is just phenomenal:

LUNCH SPECIAL: SPICY YELLOW TAIL CURRY WITH CHUNK POTATOES, CABBAGE, BOK CHOY
author: j s.

description:
I love a good sandwich. The rotating menu and Ike's-like line outside of The Sentinel has piqued my interest for a while now. However, working in Hayes Valley and trekking to New Montgomery never seemed like a good use of time, so The Sentinel was forever bookmarked but never tried. Until a recent Monday I found myself at the Palace Hotel for a half-day conference. After leaving the conference full of energy and ravished from all that learning, my colleague and I decided it was time to try a sandwich. 

Don't let the line around the corner scare you, the line moves swiftly with efficiency of the staff. The ordering process, paying and pick-up were so quick I barely had time to stuff my money back in my wallet by the time my spicy pork sandwich was ready. 

The pulled pork was tender, flavorful and had just the right spice. Topped with crusty bread and the right accoutrements, the sandwich was pretty darn perfect.

If only I worked nearby...
author: Lee H.

description:
After all the amazing reviews on Yelp about the corned beef sandwich, I finally decided to give it a go since I pass the place so often. Got there before the lunch crowd at 11:30am and got my order in right away. The staff there are very friendly and warm and seem to have an efficient process going. 

This was a 3.5 star experience for me - the corned beef sandwich was very good but not spectacular so was a solid 3. Definitely a generous serving of meat but I thought there could have been just a bit more russian dressing on it. I'd bump it up to 4 for the service and the mint chocolate you get (nice touch!).
author: Melissa S.

description:
gave me the sandwich i didn't order.  that's cool; it was busy.  Salmon sandwich isn't a huge step down from corned beef.  but wait, it turns out the salmon sandwich *IS* a big  step down.  the bread was stale, like it was week-old.  and there's like one tiny layer of lox and a huge layer of lettuce.  not very salmony.

like last time i got the corned beef.  it was good, but really shy on the meat.  if you're gonna charge $9 for a sandwich, at least put enough meat on so that there's meat in every bite.

prolly won't try it again.
author: Dann D.

description:
Do get - Spicy pork, corned beef, and ANY baked goods they have left from the morning - cookies, muffins, etc.

Prices are a bit pricey... $9+ tax for a sandwich.

I've heard great things about some of their special fish sandwiches that they do and i'm going to try it next time.
author: Noah P.

description:
Delicious sandwiches at this takeout-only spot. Get a sandwich. Eat it. Bask in the afterglow.

I've had a couple of meaty sandwiches here. A pastrami and maybe some kind of corned beef. Both were simple, flavorful and filling. I dream of them from time to time.

Super fast service, too. A+++++ WOULD BUY A SANDWICH FROM HERE AGAIN.
author: Grant S.

description:
Ventured here for the 7x7 famous Corn Beef Sandwich which was pretty good, but nothing mind blowing. The bread of this sandwich has a satisfying crunch to it (looks like a focaccia, tastes like a dutch crunch). However, overall, it really could've used more meat.

Relatively, the Veal Meatball sandwich my friend ordered was below par and a sad disappointment. We were both expecting a hearty, luscious, marinara slathered type sub-sammie (you would think so, right?!), but instead...it was composed of pale, sad-looking balls squeezed between a mushy bread roll. The spread (ricotta-esque - resembling alfredo sauce) just did not meet expectations. 

The tomato soup of the day, on the other hand, was very warming and satisfying. Could hit the spot on a cool day.

All in all -- too much bread, too little meat.
author: Gail N.

description: When in the area, this is definitely one of the better sandwich places to hit up, as their sandwiches are definitely good and will fill you up. For me, a sandwich has to be out of this world good like the ones you can get at Ike's, so when I saw that the corned beef sandwich with gruyere was on the 7x7 list, I knew I had to try it. While the corned beef was flavorful and the bread was perfect, I didn't get that amazing taste sensation that I expected to get from something off that list. I'll definitely still be coming back here for their sandwiches since it's one of the best places around that area. =)
author: Gajan K.

description:
Great corned beef sandwich!  This place would totally get a 5-star rating had the sandwiches not been so expensive.  $8.50 is real steep for a sandwich, but considering that the place has a line down the corner at lunchtime I don't blame them.  The coleslaw and sauce that they put in it is great.  Just check out the pictures on Yelp and based on them alone I'm sure you'll be convinced.  Nice folks who work there and they move the line real fast.  Definitely going back. 

Updated 5/23/11: Had the veal meatball sandwich.  It was good.  Veal meatballs tasted very similar to regular meatballs.  I'd recommend the corned beef for first-timers of the Sentinel
author: Brian G.

description: Let this "yelp" serve as public record that The Sentinel's Veal and Pork Meatball sandwich is the best of its kind. The meat's juicy and tender, but it's the spicy tomato saucy and (strangely) the cabbage that make the whole messy thing work. Yes, it's $9, but I could be convinced to pay even more.
author: Nish N.

description:
According to numbers of positive reviews and recommended by 7x7 as one of the 100 must eats, I was expecting a five star sandwich.  Not that I'm not satisfied with their Corned Beef Sandwich, I'm just not as overwhelmed as my first experience at Ike's and Snack Depot.  Plus, the price could be lower for the size of the sandwich.

Meal: Lemonade + Corned Beef Sandwich = $11.75

After a couple bites of the sandwich, I was not impressed by the meat.  It was some thinly sliced beef but they didn't put enough in there for me to really taste it.  However, I was really surprised by the flat bread, the cheese, the cabbage, and it's sauce.

I am a sucker for bread that are toasted to a crispy yet not hardened and soft interior.  This flatbread has the perfect texture.  The cheese was nice and soft which further enhances the bread.  Their sauce and cabbage is a unique take on sandwiches instead of the regular lettuce and mayo.  Actually, I kept trying to taste what was in the sauce but I just gave up.

I'm going to give this three stars because of the price and lack of parking.  If you don't work nearby, you shouldn't go out of your way just to eat this sandwich.  But if you happen to be near and is trying to finish the 7x7 top 100 list, sure, why not?

In the end, I am confused as to what they were trying to sell me with this sandwich.  Was it the meat or was it the other components?  I don't really know.  The next time I want a sandwich nearby, I rather goto Snack Depot.
author: Ricky N.

description:
At 11:30am on a Wednesday, there was a line out the door (well, not many people fit inside, so a line out the door is pretty easy as far as feats go)...

Corned beef sandwich and spicy pork sandwich were equally good, I thought. I wouldn't call home about these, but they are a solid sandwich option for this area! 

Also went in one morning for their esteemed muffins - which you have to get early before they run out. I got a blueberry+strawberry muffin (blueberry-only muffins were available, too). Wonderfully crispy on top and soft, warm, and devour-able on bottom. Mmm.
author: Catherine H.

description: It's takeaway only, and the line stretches out the door since it's so small; but they are screamin' fast and efficient with orders. Also, the menus are posted outside, and offer a modest 7-8 options, so you can plot your order in advance. There were several that sounded good to me, including the vegetarian cauliflower sammie; but I ultimately opted for a sesame chicken with pumpkin seeds. It came served on a poppyseed roll that almost tasted like a croissant to me -- so delish. The chicken was prepared with a mayo(?) sauce that was a little sweet, a little spicy. I really liked it, though I think I may have enjoyed some of the other options even more... The meal came with a big pickle spear and an Andes mint, which is a cute touch. I also helped myself to a giant chocolate chip cookie -- good mix of chewy, crisp on the edges, but not a cant-live-without-it dessert experience.
author: Christina G.

description:
Their meatball sandwich was average, on the dry side, and because there's so much meat, will make you very very sleepy after eating.

Haven't gone back to try their other sandwiches, but it's hard to shell out nearly $10 for a sandwich!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Sentinel, I love you.

Your Corn Beef sandwich is amazing. I would willingly eat it everyday for a year.

I can't speak to anything else on the menu, but that Corn Beef is out of this world. If you like things that taste good, go and order that sandwich. You won't be disappointed.

One minor note: Credit Cards require a minimum order of $10.
author: Joshua G.

description: Stopped in for some sandwiches today. Yummy corned beef and cabbage. Would recommend it to anyone who is looking for a tasty bite to eat near Moscone or Market.
author: Jim K.

description:
Just went here for the first time today for lunch. I was pleasantly surprised to find that the line here moves quickly. There isn't a place to sit and eat, but it's a nice excuse to walk around to find somewhere fun to eat and people watch. 

I ordered the pork sandwich: very tasty! The ingredients were fresh and flavorful. NOTE: They do take cash or card here but know that if you will be charging they have a $10 minimum charge. They gave me a break on the minimum, so they might do the same again (maybe it was because they want to keep the line moving).
author: Jessica C.

description: The staff are friendly. $10 min on credit cards. I had the CORNED BEEF with cabbage, Russian dressing, and Swiss cheese - 9.00, the meat could have been a bit more tender. I like that the food is not over salty. Free pickle is a bonus.
author: Hidegrl A.

description: It should be illegal to default to including mayo on a meatball sub.  Shame.
author: Evan R.

description:
Another one of my Big Eat SF 7x7 food adventures. No time and space to eat there, so I took my sandwich to go and off to the Bart station I went (FYI, short walk from Montgomery station).  You would think that by the time I got back my sandwich was a soggy nasty mess, but that was not the case here. 

Hot corned-beef sandwich: corned beef w/cabbage, swiss, russian dressing on toasted bread. Listed as the item to try here on The Big Eat SF 7x7. I never liked corned beef, but this sandwich has probably converted me to think otherwise. Thinly sliced meat and flavorful bites accompanied with a side of pickle/peppercinis, I guess I'll let the fact that the top of my bread was on the verge of being burnt with blackened spots here and there slide. Picked it off and it was perfection. 

P.S. There is a minimum for credit card charges. Love the fact that they added an Andes mint in my to go order. Lovely touch and my favorite chocolate.
author: Tracy T.

description:
When I first walked by this place there were a ton of people standing around and I thought 1., they're giving away something for free or 2., someone just dropped-dead...it turned-out to be neither of those things - actually, people were waiting for their lunch orders to arrive out of this tiny little place.  With all the excitement I saw, I had to try it out and I'm glad I did - the sandwich I had was incredible!  I had a reuben, which included corned beef, Swiss cheese, sauerkraut and Russian dressing - all of this was grilled on buttered rye bread, and I was not disappointed.  To top it all off, you see Chef Dennis Leary making your meal right in front of you!

The menu changes all the time and they serve anything from about 5-7 different items including sandwiches, salads and soups.  It is a little pricey ($9 for a sandwich), so be prepared.  The staff is also friendly, which is a nice bonus.
author: Ken G.

description: I had my second Sentinel sandwich today and I am ready to start dragging friends and colleagues there to try it. People need to know about this well priced deliciousness in easy walking distance of Financial District/Union Square/SOMA. My first trip led to the lamb eggplant warm sandwich, which is such a unique experience on a bun. I tried to save half of it for later, and about 10 minutes later I was licking my fingers and wondering where the rest went. Today I had the spicy pork (note the menu consists of some staples with other options rotating daily). It was really good, but I was stuffed after half, which -these are fine for sharing or turning into leftovers. The line can appear long but it moves quickly, so wait. Its totally worth it.
author: Lesly S.

description:
Read all the good reviews on their corned beef & cabbage sandwich and had to try it for myself .  The line did go really fast so don't get scared when you see it snaking around the block.

It was tasty but not like holy moly out of this world.  I'm not a big corn beef fan so have to go back and try their other stuff.  A dude ordered the oatmeal cookie and it looked as big as my hand!  I'll get one of those next time too!
author: J B.

description:
All I gotta say is PLEASE BRING THE B.A.L.T BACK!

I went here two weeks ago, and it just wasn't the same without it.  For people that are not familiar, B.A.L.T stands for Basil, Avocado, Lettuce and Tomato.  And it taste more delicious than it sounds.  Their bread is amazing, so is their watermelon lemonade.
author: Anoo L.

description:
These guys have it (mostly) dialed. You should just go check it out. If you're in the 'hood, looking for a sandwich, you don't have too many other choices, so the opportunity cost is low.

I like the egg salad sandwich a lot. A friend recently got the roast beef and it actually had too much meat. They're super efficient and the prices, while a bit high, aren't outrageous. 

What do you have to lose? I wouldn't make any sort of pilgrimage to come here but if it's less than 4 blocks out of your way for your normal lunch fix, definitely give it a whirl.
author: Mike B.

description:
