Get there early or you won't have a very large selection of sandwiches to choose from.

The place has a small counter where you could stand and eat but you're better of just taking your sandwich to go.

I arrived there at 2pm, 30 minutes before they closed and the only thing that looked appealing to me was the corned beef and cabbage sandwich.  I was really excited about my sandwich because I heard very good reviews on this place.

That sandwich was tasty!  It was prepared like a Rueben.  It was expecting a lot more sandwich for a $9 price tag at a to-go sandwich shop.  It was filling none the less.

They had the right amount of thousand island dressing per slab of corned beef.
author: Eleanor L.

description:
They have some good standard sandwiches, the roast beef is good. But sometimes their special is the best thing on the menu. The price is a bit pricy for sandwich but these are high quality sandwiches. The feel like good sandwiches and taste even better. 

Don't worry about the line, they have a good system and they'll take your oder and by the time you reach the door and you'll get your food. They give a cool little mint and a pickle with your sandwich.
author: Rohan D.

description:
Just pure deliciousness in sandwich form. This is one of those places that you don't want to tell people how good it is cause the line will only get longer.

 "Nobody goes there any more cause it's to crowded" 

Amazing sandwiches up and down the menu, vegi options. Fresh baked everything including amazing muffins in the morning! The lunch special are delicious too. Some sandwiches are main stays on the menu and some are either daily or seasonal, but they don't make a bad sandwich.
author: Andrew W.

description:
OK there was so much hype about this place and it made it on the big eats 7x7. So i had to come try it. I came here today with my friend for lunch and we both order the corned beef sammy they were known for. 

First of all, when we got there, there was a long line and we though we would wait for a while but it was quick style, super fast. One of the waitress took our order and by the time we got to the counter and paid(less than 3 minutes), our slammies were done. BAM!!

The sandwich is decent size, not huge and  pretty good, but not good enough to worth 9 dollars though. It was simple with corned beef, Swiss cheese and lettuce. What surprised me was the kind of bread they used, it was this toast, crunchy, garlic bread like texture, it was pretty good. 

Wouldn't mind coming here again to try their other sandwiches. Quick services and good sandwiches. The only bad thing is they are kind of overpriced. I would pay like 6-7 dollars for their sandwiches but not 9. Then again, its Downtown, everything is overpriced!!!!
author: Daniel L.

description: This is a good lunch spot, but the line can get somewhat lengthy during prime time. Sandwiches are unique, but taste-wise are not mind blowing. I would say Ike's ranks higher on the deliciousness scale.
author: Cathy L.

description: wow!! warm, moist coffee cake in the morning!  best ever!!
author: Armando A.

description: 4* for the corned beef sandwich. It was mighty tasty, and even after some time in the refrigerator, I popped it in the toaster oven and it tasted just as good fresh. It sucks about the limited hours though and the price could be a bit cheaper.
author: Miko L.

description:
I don't normally like corned beef... but I DO like Sentinel's Corned beef sandwich.  The bread here is amazing.  I have tried both the Corned Beef and the Coppa Mozz Sandwich....and both JUST AS GREAT!

I will be back for sure...

Oh and b/c there is no seating area at Sentinel, you should just walk on over to 2nd and Mission (Look for the glass building on the corner attached to the Peet's) - plenty of tables and chairs there in the atrium for you to enjoy your sandwich!
author: Jennie L.

description:
There are sandwiches, and then there's the corned beef hash sandwich at The Sentinel.

A delicious bite South of Market, the proof is in the line that will easily wrap down the block. The Sentinel dishes out gourmet sandwiches in neat lunch boxes that will definitely bring you back.

While the space is small, the woman at the counter works quickly and is an absolute joy to interact with. 

The slaw draws out the sweet taste of the corned beef, and the warm buttery bread makes each bite a decadent plus.

As I continue my SOMA lunch adventures, I can confidently say that this premier spot is firmly on my hot list.
author: Mike K.

description:
Had passed by this place a few times and finally tried it out yesterday.  Got the hot lamb sandwich with chickpeas and spices.  It was kinda like a sloppy Joe.  They have a great way of using spices, etc. to pull it altogether...very yummy.  Very filling and interesting.  Oh, and I also had a lemonade to meet the $10 minimum credit card charge (!@%!)...good but probably wouldn't bother with it next time.

Don't think this would be a favorite go-to place...I'm more into slightly lighter sandwiches, although probably should try their veggie options.
author: Lynn H.

description:
Based on the rave reviews, I had the corned beef sandwich from The Sentinel earlier today. It was a perfectly good sandwich, but I don't really understand what the hype is about -- the corned beef was a little bland, as was the dressing. The bread (focaccia) was a nice touch.

I'll probably visit again and try a different sandwich, but at least on the basis of the corned beef, I thought this place was overhyped.
author: Neil C.

description:
I'm a humongous fan of this place.  It's not far from work and their sandwiches are HUGE!  I only eat a half at a time, so I get two lunches out of it.

Everything on their menu is awesome.  The rare roast beef is my favorite, though I've tried the spicy pork (not spicy, but still tasty), the coppa, and the cauliflower curry.  I recommend going with a few people and then splitting a bunch of different sandwiches.
author: Samantha B.

description:
I have to say I was disappointed.  First, there are very few vegetarian options, and really no vegan.  I got the curried cauliflower sandwich.  I mean, really?  I could make this at home for $3.  Creativity  - poor, and taste -  mediocre.

No sandwich for you!  Next!
author: Sameer D.

description:
Small little shop, I was recommended this place by a friend for a quick sandwich.  It's off the main path and by the time I had arrived, 3 of the 6 or so menu items were already sold out (good sign!).

I ordered the corned beef because it's quite a standard sandwich.  I really don't have any complaints about it.  The corned beef was flavorful, the russian dressing was typical, the bread was pretty yummy focaccia and from the whole meal this was the second most notable item.  The first was the spicy pickle.  I love a pickle with my sandwich and when I got this big sucker with my order I was happy.  On top of getting a good size pickle, it's also not your mom's pickle at all - this thing packs a little zing of heat and made me dream of more.

Service was friendly, helpful, and quick. 

Even though i'm giving it 3 stars, I will definitely go back and try one of the more non-traditional sandwiches which all sound amazing.
author: Shaun T.

description:
Ginormous, tasty sandwiches. 

You can smell the bread as soon as you enter the store. I had the roast beef sandwich which was super rare and super tasty. Oh and HUGE.  If you like leftovers, you can have half your sandwich for lunch and the other half for dinner. 

Its a $9 sandwich which is slightly expensive for my taste but its worth it every once in a while.
author: Rohith S.

description: None of my coworkers knew about this place but it's a great sandwich shop.  I loved my sandwich and will definitely be back.  Line started getting to 8 deep right as they were opening but they moved us through quickly.
author: Joseph G.

description:
Corned beef hash sandwich was OFF THE HOOK! I loved every minute of it along with a crunchy pickle. We came around 12:45pm and the line went by quick. 

Beware if you are planning on paying with a card, there was a $10 or $12 minimum. Sandwiches were around $9.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Corned beef sandwich: The corned beef sandwich was good, but too hyped up. My bread was slightly soggy and the whole thing kept falling apart. There was a slight strange taste, like mustard, in it. The pickle was really good. I also liked the piece of Andes chocolate that came with it. Also, the lady didn't give me back my change, but I just let it slide. Still...

I want to try their other sandwiches
author: Vera W.

description:
Ladies and gentlemen, I'm not going to give you any breaking news here.  Nor does the Sentinel probably need my rave review, I'm sure they're doing fine.  I just like it so much that I can't reasonably keep my gushing off of the internet any longer.  I've had a love-hate relationship with the sandwich.  Sure, it's a good idea in concept, but what if the bread is dry?  What if it's mushy?  What if it's just a slab of meat on a bun?  (Sorry, Carnegie Deli.)  What if it's not filling?  What if a quarter of it will end up giving me a coronary?  (Someday, when I've lived a full life, I'll have an Elvis.)

What if nothing.  The Sentinel serves up fresh ingredients in interesting flavor combinations faster than you can say "Gee, I hope they don't take too long to make my sandwich, I'm awfully hungry."  That tiny ex-cigar shop houses a well-oiled machine comprised of People Who Do Not Mess Around, and they want nothing more than to stuff your face with a culinary wonder that would make a particular deceased British nobleman smile down from whatever edible heaven he's in.

I could tell you what to get, but it doesn't matter.  Whatever sounds good, is good.  The sandwiches I have tried and find particularly delectable are the tofu sandwich (a staple in summer), the BALT (that's basil, avocado, lettuce, tomato, and some goat cheese for good measure), and my most recent discovery: the smoked trout salad.  They are respectively: texturally firm and a little spicy, extra creamy and adequately tangy, and crispy, just fishy enough (but I sure hope you like mayo).  I would attempt to describe to you the immense quantity of the flavor in each of them, but the drool on my keyboard is making that difficult.  They are all served on light, fluffy, buttery rolls.

Yes, there's a line.  Yes, they run out of ingredients.  But they encourage you to call your order in, and if they run out of ingredients after you've called in, I believe they're in the habit of offering you your order for free.  So do that.  Your tastebuds are in your mouth right now wondering if they're even alive anymore.  Save them.  Please.
author: Becca S.

description:
I don't know what was holding me back in my last review.  Yeah, the sandwiches can be a little heavy on the cream and sauces (just ask for them to go light on the sauce), but man oh man, this place is the bomb. 

That lamb and feta meatball sandwich? I don't even like lamb, but i thought it was fantastic. 

The corned beef sandwich can be a little heavy, but it is SO. GOOD. 

Really, though, one of the main reasons that I had to come back and up my review a star is because the people here are so amazingly nice.  I don't even know how they manage to find a perfect balance between being amazingly efficient at dealing with an insanely long lunch line and showing a genuine interest in you, but they do.  

Don't go changing, Sentinel. I have yet to be disappointed by you and I don't think I ever will.

Okay, fine. I still don't like the pickles, but nobody's perfect.
author: Alea G.

description:
This is tough ... the food was AMAAAAZING but the service was a little bit disorganized. I would suggest that this place isn't good for groups bigger than 4 or 5 people. We were a group of 8-10 and it was just a mess! Orders were mixed up a little but - BUT they got resolved and everything eventually worked itself out.

What's more important though is that the food was great! I heard through the grapevine that the corned beef was a good sandwich. OH YES! It was delicious. The bread was good, the meat was plentiful and the general portion size was great. Almost too much to handle!

Don't forget to try their lemonades though - perhaps one of the best things about this place is their lemonade. I tried the watermelon one and it was so good I sucked it down before walking back to my office 2 blocks away.

No seating here folks, take out only! Make sure you have a sunny park bench or cozy office chair to dine on because this place is not only crowded, they don't really have the space to allow people to eat inside.
author: Katy H.

description:
With all the great reviews here I think I will have to go back and try another sandwich...

I have to admit, I didn't care for the Corned Beef sandwich, it seriously tasted like cheap deli meat  and I hate to say this but smelled like dog food. I'm not sure what the red sauce was  but that had no flavor at all and the cole slaw was tasteless too. The foccia was yummy and I think my favorite part of my lunch was the spicy pickle that came with my sandwich... that was delish!  I also ordered the raspberry lemonade which I had to water down b/c it was way too sweet. I think the worst thing was when when the chef told one of his employees to do something and the employee wasn't moving quick enough so  he snapped at him and told to do it now but was an asshole about it, that was done in front of a 12:30 lunch crowd, I'm sorry but I can't stand people like that! Hopefully, next time I go the food will be better....
author: Nisi C.

description:
Feels SO WRONG to not have a reuben sandwich on rye but OOHHH it's SOOO GOOD on the focaccia bread!

Will have to go back to try out the rest of the sandwiches. They are SOO QUICK! I placed my order and a min later my order was ready!

The Andes candies and pickle is a nice touch too.
author: She R. A.

description:
Great food.  Prices are on par with other places in the city, ~$10-12 for a sandwich and a drink.

There's nowhere to eat at the restaurant, but just walk a couple of blocks to any of the outdoor spots in the city.
author: Juan R.

description:
Meat ball and feta cheese bap with lush tomato sauce, that oozed slowly through the entire sandwich. It was so, so good and a sublime choice for lunch.

The queue can get quite long during lunch hours, but the staff literally whizz through it. They serve quickly and efficiently. The short but tasty menu providing stunning snack style meals, that will tantalise anyone's taste buds.

I would recommend this place without hesitation.
author: Leon C.

description:
Most people don't relish business trips, but I love coming to San Francisco to visit the company mothership. No, not because of work, but because it's practically a paid vacation - I get to visit my cousin and sister, catch up with old friends, and check out a lot of local places. It's just too bad there are scheduled 8-hour bursts of work sandwiched between, but I guess it's a minor inconvenience to do what I'm paid to. 

Speaking of sandwiches, the Sentinel has become one of the things I look forward to when visiting the city. With no shortage of lunchable options within a few block radius, the Sentinel has risen above all the other quick-lunch spots. Yes, there might be a line, but it zips along fairly quickly, and yet, once you have food in hand (and in mouth and in belly) there's no indication that the preparation is rushed, nor that you've been short-changed a quality meal. 

While you almost can't go wrong with any of the menu staples, inlcuding the aforementioned sandwiches, I love trying out their daily lunch specials, because you never know if it'll appear on the menu again. Today's special was ground turkey with cabbage, mint, and sweet white corn kernels. It seemed to be lightly drizzled with a citrus vinaigrette, and I was surprised at how light of a meal it made. The tangy taste of the acid contrasted well with the sweet corn, and the turkey was meaty and yet not overly hearty. In addition the special came with a warm cranberry-apple crisp that was tart with the crumbles providing a nice crunchy texture. 

I just now finished my meal, not 5 minutes ago. I normally don't rush to write a review but I wanted to write about this experience because with the Sentinel's always rotating specials menu, I don't know if I'll ever have quite the same combination again.
author: Mike Q.

description: I didn't like my turkey sandwich. Seems like a good place but just not for me. The bread is fresh tho.
author: Cam S.

description: My sandwich was very, very good.  The only problem is that by the time I got there, 1:30-ish, most of the sandwiches were not available.  There were approximately 3-4 sandwiches to choose from and more than one that I was interested in eating, so this was not a huge deal.  Next time, I will try and arrive a little earlier.
author: Scott And Jim H.

description: I guess I can appreciate the artisanal quality behind the corned beef sandwich, but it just isn't my taste.  There's cabbage in it (as is tradition) with a sauce that has a bit of tang/vinegar to it.  The bread is fantastic.  For $9 comes with crunchy pickle and Andes chocolate mint :)
author: Alias A.

description:
The corned beef sandwich is SO good. I was so sad I couldn't finish all of it, because it really fills you up. Everyone in my office was talking about how good it smelled and how delicious it looked.

Service is great too. The people who work there are really friendly, and even though I didn't meet the minimum to use a card, they did it for me anyways. I LOVE GOOD SERVICE!!
author: Chrystal Z.

description:
The sandwiches and soups here are excellent. I normally go with the corned beef lathered with Russian dressing. If I want to be slightly healthier, I'd go for the salmon sandwich which incorporates the fish cooked and sashimi style. 

Tip: - Call ahead so you can pick it up right when you get there and avoid the lines.
author: James W.

description:
As a stereotypical white person who likes expensive sandwiches (see http://stuffwhitepeoplelike.com/2008/02/11/63-expensive-sandwiches/), The Sentinel is a great lunch spot. It's takeout-only, and there is always a line, but it moves fast.

I had the smoked-trout with fennel and apple sandwich. The amateur chef in me thought that those three ingredients sounded just about as random and disjointed as you could possibly get, but the even-more-amateur food critic in me found that they blended remarkably well.

The only downside is their rather limited menu. If you haven't been to The Sentinel before I suggest reading their online menu first to make sure something piques your interests and satisfies your dietary requirements.
author: Adam B.

description:
If you do not want to read the whole thing here is my quick synopsis:

The good
1. The bread was actually good.
2. The taste of the filling was good. (but not enough)
3. Nice staff

The bad
1. Too much bread to filling ratio
2. Not worth 9 bucks (You'd expect chips and a drink for this price)
3. The pickle was terrible.
4. Way over hyped.

I have been avoiding this place because, every time I go by there there is an extremely long line. So, finally after 3 years of my co-workers telling me how good it was, I passed by today and found only 4 people in line. I said what the hell let's give it a try. 

I liked the fact that there were only about 6 sandwiches on the menu, so it was easy to order. I almost got the Corned Beef Sandwich but wasn't in the mood for that typical sandwich. I was seeking some adventure. It was a toss up between the Corned Beef and the Lamb and Eggplant with Chickpea Curry. I got the Lamb. 

Upon first inspection I was impressed by the bread, I got the wheat bun. I opened it up and saw the curry mixture and I thought they had not given me any meat with the sandwich. All I could see were the chickpeas. I expected something like a shawarma style meat, I looked closer and the lamb was ground up. 
They really should call this sandwich "Chickpea and Eggplant with Ground Lamb". 

I took my first bite and all I really could taste was the bread, then the curry flavor then the chickpeas. I could not really decipher any meat in this mixture or the eggplant. It was all drowned down in bread, the chickpeas and curry flavor (which I liked). I almost felt like I was eating a Vegetarian sandwich.

The major complaint I had was the bread to filling ratio. There simply was not enough filling! 

My second complaint was that that sandwich was not worth 9 dollars.
If you're going to sell a 9 dollar sandwich I'd at least want it big enough to save and have that other half for a 3 o'clock snack. But that was not the case because after you eat the one half, because of lack of filling, you can eat the other half no problem. Or give us some chips and a drink I think you can afford to hand us some chips in that bag for 9 bucks a sandwich.

Oh last but not least the pickle tasted like it was "pickled" in the ocean. BLEH. It tasted like when I used to surf and I'd swallow ocean water.

Maybe next time I'll get the Corned Beef.
author: Mark S.

description:
So I have a theory. This theory is that Dennis Leary owns not only this restaurant, but he also owns a Corned Beef ranch. Yep, you heard it here first. He has those little doggies rolling along, gittin' along, just enjoying life being corned beef. A whole ranch of corned beef. He must because he sells so much corned beef sandwiches, it would be smart to be vertically integrated. Own a bakery for the bread, a mayonnaise and pickle farm and warehouse. I can see it now.

I love the sandwiches here, and (surprise) particularly the corned beef. With cabbage and the russian dressing, mmmmmm, very very good. I occasionally diverge into the realm of great soups especially when it is cold outside, but I lika mah corned beef.
author: Heather O.

description:
Today, I got the corned beef sandwich. The meat was very tender and the cabbage "slaw" was crispy. The bread was the best part: it was still crunchy (in all the right ways). 

Something about the russian dressing tasted weird to me, but I have a feeling it's supposed to taste like that. When I've gotten corned beef sandwiches in the paste, they've had thousand island dressing, which I personally prefer. 

I will definitely try another sandwich from The Sentinel in the future.
author: Anne M.

description: Absolutely love, love, love this joint. Two wonderful ladies greet me every morning and brew a tasty cappuccino that perks me right up. The pastries are sinful and I cannot resist. The apple cinnamon, blueberry, strawberry, peach muffins are all heavenly but the coffee cake is the best. Need a little Europe in your life, stop by and you might just get your fix.
author: Kelly C.

description:
This has become my go-to spot for lunch as of late. Despite always being a line during the lunch hour, the staff sifts through customers quickly and the food comes out moments after I place an order. But I never feel rushed - the staff is full of politeness and smiles.  

The sandwiches themselves are YUMMY. Everything always tastes so fresh, including the bread. I love how small there menu is - it's easy to make a decision. It changes seasonally, and they offer a daily special. Recently, I've been ordering the Smoked Trout and Apple, and I always finish every crumb. 

Sandwiches all come with a tasty dill pickle and an Andes mint!
author: Kori M.

description:
I really like their corn beef sandwich with russian dressing but it's a tad too salty and rich to finish the whole sandwich for me. I thought their pork sandwich was bland and boring.

I love that they have a changing daily menu to give us some interesting options with the limited SoMa eateries. Yay to the homemade pickle and the small dessert treat they give you.

So why the 3 stars? The price is a bit steep, they run out of menu items, and there's no place to sit.
author: Bemmy B.

description:
The egg salad sandwich is great - it has a little spice, which makes it a little more interesting than it sounds.

The chocolate chip cookies are not great - walk over to Specialty's nearby and get a couple of theirs and you'll be happier.

The rest of the food always looks good. I've had their meatball sandwich, and it was pretty tasty as well. The line moves fast, the staff is quick, and I haven't seen them make any mistakes. All good qualities for a quick lunch spot.
author: Ben B.

description:
Yup, yet another SF sandwich shop within swinging distance of my new company.  

Based on a recommendation (thanks Alex), the corned beef sandwich here is the best I've ever had.  While it may have been the only corned beef sandwich I've ever had, it is one to rival all the potential past and future corned beef sandwiches I will ever have.  

What was probably sauerkraut on their delightfully airy bread with amazingly tender corned beef and secret sauce (not to thick thousand island), it topped most sandwich experiences I've had.  It was tough to pass on the pork shoulder special they had, but I was not disappointed.

While somewhat pricey, especially after going to Algiers yesterday, it's worth it.
author: Jeff N.

description: What do they do to get the cookies so good here? I missed the apparently famous lunch sandwiches, but the cookie I had here was almost worth the trip on its own...
author: Sarah K.

description:
Sentinel and sister establishment Golden West are my two favorite lunch places in the Financial District.

Being vegetarian I'm usually stuck with a boring salad or some tasteless soup. Not here. Their menu is seasonal and and includes delectable dishes like curry cauliflower and chickpea sandwich with mint or to-die-for cream of mushroom soup. Their desserts are equally amazing such as cherry cake with sour cream frosting or butterscotch pudding, No one does dessert or bread like Sentinel.

If you're in the mood for truly gourmet at a reasonable price you don't won't to miss Sentinel or Golden West.
author: Jenny S.

description: Delicious sandwiches. Very bold flavors and ambitious sandwiches. I never know what to expect when I go here. I've had trout, pastrami, eggplant, zucchini, chicken, etc. I don't personally like the in house pickles that they make, but I do appreciate how they are unique. The only reason no 5 stars is the portion sizes seem a little small. I always seem to still be hungry after eating here
author: Daniel B.

description:
Yes, I've seen the muffin man.  He is alive and well and working at The Sentinel.

Getting here early in the morning for the fresh-baked muffins is a special treat.  These ambrosial muffins are rich, warm, moist and fluffy and almost never make it back to the office without being half-devoured along the way.  Its like someone finally managed to make an entire muffin that is as delicious as a muffin top.  The flavors change daily, and often sell out, so it pays to get here early to check out the selection.  The coffee at the The Sentinel is also pretty good.

Lunch selections at The Sentinel are also delicious.  The corned beef is a standout, and the daily specials have a tendency toward awesomeness.  Call in your order to avoid the line.

The Sentinel has no seating, its literally a (sizable) hole in a wall next to House of Shields, so plan on having a nearby place to sit and munch.
author: Aaron S.

description:
Honestly, the sandwiches look better than the one I had tasted. It was pretty simple. Basil, lettuce, tomato, and goat cheese (the BALT). An award winning combo, to be sure, but I had some issues with The Sentinel's version and let me tell you why:

1. With no option to add chicken or turkey cold cuts, I took them up on their suggestion to get it with the chicken salad inside- my need for protein in the afternoon is like a hooker's at 2am. It was excessively doused in mayo and lacked in any real added flavor or zing. I ended up dumping it all out in the end, and sort of wish they had meats other than roast or corned beef to add into their veggie options.

2. For a sandwich that was intended for vegetarians, it was really lacking in cheese. Cheese- or, "the 8th wonder of the world" as I call it- should be a dominant flavor in any sandwich, but ESPECIALLY in one that has only vegetables and no dressing (I don't do mayo and they don't seem to have any sort of house sauce). There was two bites of cheese in there. TWO. I counted....twice ;)

3. The bread is super soft and crumbles very easily. I should have taken a picture- left with a mountain of bread and chicken salad in the end. Not that it wasn't tasty, just messy. And it would be nice to have the option to toast it. If that is an option, I wasn't asked about it and regretted not having asked.

All said, the place smelled INCREDIBLE and my special sexy male friend loved his rare roast beef with horseradish. I might try it again when the menu changes, but being that its downtown and I work in SOMA, I can't say I'll go back too soon and I can't say that I have anything wrong with that.
author: Raquel C.

description: I came here on two glowing recommendations from different people and was not let down. The woman who helped me here gave exemplary customer service. I showed up right around closing time and they helped me anyway. She did not rush me at all, my food was delicious and ready in the blink of an eye. She gave me a free strawberry lemonade and muffin because it was the end of the day and she didn't want them to go to waste. Score! Seriously, y'all, do your mouths a favor and get their eggplant and lamb sandwhich.
author: Danielle W.

description:
I'm surprised there aren't more Lamb and Eggplant sandwich reviews here. My friend and I were visiting from the valley, and after walking around the city taking silly pictures, we were hungryyy. This place was nearby, and I must say, I'm so glad we stopped in. 

The Lamb and Eggplant sandwich was nice and herby. The bread was crunchy on the outside, yet soft enough that it flattened nicely to fit inside your mouth. Best of all was the flavor. The flavor of the curry and herb pesto created a symphony of spices in my mouth! 

The only cons I found was that it was a little pricey for the size of the sandwich, and that it was cash only.
author: Mary N.

description: So incredibly delicious! I ordered the trout salad sandwich and it was incredible. They were super quick too, and very friendly. Will definitely be back to try more!
author: Sara N.

description:
Best egg mayo sub eva! Seriously I have no idea how they do it but the bread is sweet, the filling creamy and the happiness level at maximum. 

I was taken here during a trip to SF with work and we bought some sarnies from here and then sat and ate them in the sunshine. It was the perfect break from the office and meant that i could get totally involved in the eating, while making a mess and not worry about getting egg everywhere - I was outside and the grass doesn't mind egg apparently.

Mmmmmm.... I love egg!
author: Lizzie S.

description: Well, I gave in to the urging of these reviews... got the roast beef sandwich and yes, when they say rare, it was really, really rare.  Great portion size, guess that's suppose to justify the price.  Will return to try another menu item, sorta odd that the "menu" is on a single sheet of paper taped to the door...but the place is definitely worth a visit...I am curious how much rent they're paying for that spot!
author: Steve M.

description:
*Fresh, warm, chewy-but-not doughy bread, with just enough of a crust.
*Mouthwatering corned beef that's actually not drenched in russian dressing.
*Pickles on the side.
*Speedy service.
*Topped off with an Andes mint!

It wasn't the lunch experience of a lifetime, but for a takeaway sandwich, it was damn tasty.
author: Emily P.

description:
Went there twice in 1 week.

Pros: 2 great sandwiches: Corned beef (most rec'd on this site), but forgotten by many is the spiced pork. I generally like corned beef more as a lunch meat, but the sauce and bun for the spiced pork was the winner for me. No frills (no seating)

Cons: No seating. Both times I went (January) it was cold (40s F), and it would have been nice to have a warm place to sit. I beat a line both times I went, but I can attest to it accumulating. But they turn customers fast.

Tip: Get your sammy and walk across the street to the Palace hotel, and pretend you are a guest!
author: Nathaniel K.

description:
*On our quest to try 52 places in 52 weeks*

Here's the thing- the hubs has a real problem with mayonnaise (wow- have you ever tried to type that word before?? very difficult). He HATES it. With a passion. If you try to snnnneak some mayonnaise in, he'll find it. Lo and behold, we come to The Sentinel, which shockingly we have never been to before (we used to go to law school around the corner), on my recommendation. And I am really talking this place up. Because everything I had heard, I'd liked: the varied ingredients, the freshness, the amazing bread, and the efficiency (which may be my favorite).  We wait no more than 2 mins and put in our orders. I order the pear chutney and cheddar cheese and the hubs orders the corned beef. He almost ordered the egg salad sandwich, but once he heard they still had some corned beef left, he jumped at it. They quickly come out and we go take a seat in my building. Two bites in....I see it. That dreaded face...of "there is mayonnaise in this." Shit. Although he eats one whole half of the sandwich (these sandwiches are BIG by the way and come with a pickle!) and SWEARS it's tasty, which I believe it is, he picks at the other half. Although there was also mayonnaise on mine, I think, I don't know, it was verryyyy good, but too big. PEOPLE- I am a small eater, why can't I just get half a sandwich?! We left saying we'd try it again and put in our requests next time. And I put my other half in the fridge, pretending I was going to eat it......
author: Melissa N.

description:
The roast beef sandwich on white bread is the best sandwich ive had, hands down.

While i havent strayed to much on the menu everything is served with great care and tastes great. Even if there is a line the service is fast.

Although get there before 1pm or so, thats when popular items start selling out.
author: Sean A.

description:
I love their morning muffins because they are always freshly baked and warm with fresh fruit. I have always wanted to try their lunch.

 I just had their lamb and feta meatball sandwich. It was so good I bit my own hand eating it!  Well seasoned, and sooooo yummy! The tomato sauce is not spicy, but its a perfect paring with the meatballs. Be warned that this sandwich is messy, but worth the mess and stains on your shirt!

Their sandwich creations are so unique. Their daily specials are usually good too! I also had a chocolate chip cookie that is super chocolatey and has a hint of hazelnut to it. Super delicious!

It all take out only, and there is a $10 minimum credit card charge.
author: Marlene D.

description:
I'm so lucky this place is down the street to my office because I wouldn't have noticed it if I didn't walk pass it everyday. 

I don't come here that often because I'm ballin' on a budget but the corned beef sandwich is hella good! I tried the other sandwiches and it wasn't bad--I'll stick to the corned beef. The staff is nice and they gave me a free cookie here a couple of times during lunch. 

The hot muffins in the morning are so delicious. My favorite is strawberry. Coffee is so-so but I come back because the muffins are huge and addictive.
author: Jerold R.

description:
FINALLY a decent lunch spot in the FiDi. I never thought I'd find a sandwich place as good as Bakesale Betty's or Genova's or Gregoire's. Ike's is pretty damn effing scrumptious but not convenient enough for a work day.

The Sentinel is what all of downtown is missing: creative, delicious, affordable. Seriously, the FiDi is a hell hole of roach-infested restaurants serving over cooked pasta in Chef Boyardee sauce, sushi rolls made with frozen fish, and all manner of things unhealthy, fried and OVERPRICED. I'd spend $8 at Sentinel any day over $7 somewhere else.
author: Rachael S.

description:
I FINALLY TRIED THE CORNED BEEF SANDWICH! 

I must say that......IT'S SO SCRUMPTIOUS! it took me a while to find it, because I got my streets mixed up, BUT nonetheless, worth the find. It's like right after you see NEW Montgomery and continue going straight...right by the corner.

The sandwich itself is so BIG and when you bite into it, the bread is like toasted to perfection. I usually DON'T like cabbage in my sandwiches, but the corned beef and cabbage with Russian dressing was so delish in one bite. It's was like such a good mix that I didn't even recognize the cabbage taste in the sandwich. I ate the sandwich withing 20 minutes, and even though I began to feel full, I finished it 'til the very end. That's how delicious it was. I would definitely want to go back. 

I think this sandwich is good for the 8.95 that I paid. They also give you pickles if you like that and an Andes mint. 

happy eating! :)
author: Liberty C.

description:
They were sold out of my first three choices by 12:57 PM.
Corned Beef sandwich was best non-famous deli version I've ever had, but that ain't saying much.
The brownie was crumbly, dry, dusty and filled will starchy, mealy, raw walnuts. I was hoping for a "brownie version" of the great gingerbread I had at Golden West. Ugh.
GET OUT OF MY BROWNIE STUPID WALNUTS!

PS Love the House of Shields.
author: Brian C.

description:
A line started forming around 11:15 (for 11:30 lunch opening).  The line itself moved along quickly and efficiently.
I followed the recommendation of previous reviewers and tried the corned beef sandwich, and would have to say that it was very tasty.  It will tend to get a bit soggy if you let it sit too long, but the bread holds up pretty well.  The accompanying pickle was good, but I prefer a slightly more sour deli pickle.  The Andes mint is a nice little finisher.
Thumbs up!
author: L T.

description:
If what the nutty right-wingers say about Prop 8 is true and gays getting hitched means the eventual destruction of the institution of marriage, and that people will be able to marry anything they want including their dog, then LEGALIZE IT ALREADY so I can finally make an honest sandwich of the corned beef with Gruyere. For real. I've got a ring picked out and everything.

The Sentinel is a small shop with a limited menu that is committed to only one thing: getting simple, glorious sandwiches into customers' hands.

The service is efficient: Don't come here if you want coddling and tummy rubs along with your lunch. The staff doesn't care about you; they care about food. That's the kind of priorities I like from the people who make my lunch.

And don't whine about the price, either -- you'll drop around $10 just like you would on any quick lunch in the Financial District, but you'll get a burly sandwich that's so good your coworkers will hound you about it as soon as they smell it.
author: Arlette T.

description: The Sentinel is a great place to show what SOMA is capable of for lunch.  With a few delicate, yet filling, sandwiches it is the sandwich shop to beat.  I have not found a better reuben in the area.  The sandwiches are all seasonal, so some of them may be removed from the menu by the time this review is read.  But I would encourage you to try some of the more "out there" sandwiches.  For example I had a spicy pork sandwich with carrot on it, and a lamb and eggplant sandwich that was very yummy.  The bread that they use for their sandwiches is great too.
author: Alex H.

description:
I had the portobello and chard sandwich. I was abnormally excited about checking this place out for some reason, and definitely it is a popular place. On the good side, despite the number of people hovering around, the guys move fast and your sandwich is finished quicker than you could shake a lamb's tail. 

As to the sandwich, it was a good sandwich - but I wouldn't say it was a legendary sandwich. It's a decent size and kudos for choosing to not overwhelm the main stars by adding lashings & lashings of toppings, but for those cash strapped amongst us, it is a slightly pricier sandwich than others. Would I say this is a decent place to go to? Yes.  Would I say it was amazing? Yeahhh--wellllll---nooooo....

I did like the surprise mint chocolate in the bag. That was really rather sweet.
author: Catriona C.

description: I am convinced that there is nothing here that is not good.  I finally got my hands on the Lamb Eggplant today!  At first, I was disappointed that the lamb was grounded rather than in strips.  But after my first bite, F strips of lamb when grounded lamb can taste this good.  And to my surprise, they smeared my favorite on the bread - cilantro mint chutney - which made the sandwich less heavy.  I usually can't finish sandwiches but screw this - I'm eating my dinner NOW!
author: Linh V.

description:
Their corned beef sandwich is the best of comfort food goodness jammed in between two slices of fresh bread (which I hear they bake themselves). 

I was in comfort food heaven for an hour--then I had to go back to work and put up with 1.5 hour mandatory HR sexual harassment training where they made us watch videos and taught us to keep our hands to ourselves.
author: Sue L.

description:
Order: (1) CORNED BEEF WITH CABBAGE, SWISS, RUSSIAN DRESSING - $8.00

This sandwich comes on Sentinel Flat-bread (whatever that is) which over powered the minute amount of meat served in this sandwich. After struggling to search for flavors there was the Russian dressing that was next found in my taste buds (still no meat could be tasted). The Cabbage, didn't even need to be there as it added no flavor, nor could it be deciphered since the bread over whelms the entire sandwich. If I hadn't had to go back to work I would have returned the sandwich if only for the lack of meat. Really, it was pathetic how little meat was in the sandwich. You get more meat in a 7 Eleven sandwich from the fridge.

The meal also comes with a pickle that was not finished being pickled as I could still taste it as a cucumber. I had 3 pickles in all, one looked old, one had a green mark on the back from either a marker or from it not finishing pickling and the last pickle I tossed because there really wasn't any point to eat it.

If any of you like good food, stay away, there are far far better sandwich shops then Sentinel. I'll take a "Specialty's" (that's how they spell it) sandwich over Sentinel any day.

$8 for what I got was highway robbery. If you have not tried it already, AK Subs on 8th and Harrison is much much much better. A little far from Sentinel, but you won't be disappointed. I must say though that I was not surprised with being disappointed as downtown San Francisco is full of horrible eats. It really is frustrating to know that these food stops think so poorly of us that they think they can get away with selling us crap.

I make a better sandwich at home with whole wheat fiber enhanced bread and a can of tuna.

For those of you who wrote a review here, I think you need to get out of downtown and go experience a real sandwich. Maybe even go to L.A. or New York, somewhere other then Downtown San Francisco.

This was my first ever review written on Yelp and I stand by my word. I hope whoever reads this knows what good food tastes like and isn't fooled like I was by poor Yelp reviews by people who don't know what "Tastes Good" means.
author: Mathew R.

description:
I really wish I had known about the Sentinel when I worked a street over for over a year.  Oh well.  While pricey, I do believe this is the single best place to get a quick bite to eat in the area.  And again, while pricey-it is pretty on par to what you'd get pretty much anywhere else in downtown.  But not every place tastes so fresh or so good! 

While my options are a bit limited because I am a vegetarian, I've had the BALT (Actually, it was a MALT because they used mint instead-it came out GREAT!) and the egg salad. Never had egg salad like that before.

When I went with a friend they gave him a free cookie because they made him wait a bit longer than myself.  It was quite good.

I normally bring a sack lunch, but is it worth splurging at the Sentinel?  I think so.

Oh yeah, and the bread-it's really good.
author: daniel m.

description:
Great sandwiches. Refreshing flavors, everything is light and balanced without being bland. Everyone is super-efficient so you get your food with a smile and without a long wait. Kudos for being a good service in addition to having good food! 

Took out 1 star because the sandwich I had, while tasty, lacked structural integrity and became a mess to eat. I ended up leaving the pidgeons with a lot of food when my sandwich collapsed. Clearly one to eat with plate and utensils, at least if you get the pulled pork ;)
author: Angel S.

description: lamb and eggplant . 9 dollars fine you want good food you gotta pay we get it but seriously where Is the lamb ? all I tasted was pesto and garbanzo beans and awesome bread to be fair , heard a lot about this place and was waiting to eat and leave  stars , will give it a try again , it must have bee an off day .
author: NAEL K.

description:
Though I'm still not a fan of their sandwiches, I've found something that they do better than most other places.  Sentinel makes excellent muffins, which they sell until lunch or when they run out.

Why are the muffins excellent?  They're freshly baked, the muffin tops (heh!) and the muffin bottoms are both crusty while the insides remain soft and moist.  Muffin varieties vary with the seasons.  As of July 2010, they're $2.50 and one will make a pretty good breakfast.
author: Suo L.

description:
I'm not a big corn beef fan, but got it for lunch after reading the Yelp reviews. It was juicy and tasty, definitely something I can rotate in as my lunch options in my work hood.  

Also took a bite of my coworker's albacore sandwich and loved it too. We got there around 1pm and 4-5 of the sandwiches were sold out at that point, so recommend getting there early in case you want options.
author: Karen L.

description:
I eat here about 4 out of 5 days a week.

There's not much more I can say that hasn't been echoed here before: awesome sandwiches, insanely efficient line, and friendly staff that seems to remember everyone.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Had a pork loin with fig, Havarti, and frisee sandwich and a honey dew-ade.

The sandwich was listed as cold but received it hot, which was a nice surprise.

Great sandwich (the bun it's served on is really, really good). Not among the best I've had but tasty.

I'll be returning to try the tuna/fennel/green bean and the corned beef sandwiches, at some point.
author: John C.

description:
I had no idea the Sentinel was steps away from the office. Great corner spot right across the way from the Palace Hotel. Very small and very busy. I tried the Corned Beef Sandwich. Deliciousness! The Basil Lettuce Tomato Avo was also a winner. 

The sandwiches are filling and there isn't an extensive menu. This is definitely something to get once in awhile since the sandwiches are somewhat pricy. 

The sandwich assembly team are on point and kudos for some butterscotch candies as a mini dessert.
author: Alyson C.

description: Heard this place gets a long line at the height of the lunch hour so I got there at 2:15 right before they closed. No line, got the Corned Beef, cabbage, Russian dressing & Swiss (gruyere) sandwich. It's a small corner shop, cash only, simple menu of favorites & specials (today's was a meatball sandwich) take away.  Sandwich was as I expected from the reviews I read, very tasty and makes you want to go back and try their other creations.
author: Stacey M.

description:
Came back again for the infamous corned beef sandwich and I was surprised to find that it's now more of a "meh, it's not how I remembered it to be." The sandwich tasted soggy and it wasn't too flavorful. I also got the pomegranate-ade for $3 and in the words of my fiance, it tasted like exactly like Lemon Tea Vitasoy that you can get ~$3 for a 6-pack from Chinatown. 

I almost chose not to eat here because it was so cold and gloomy and I didn't know where I could bring my sandwich. BUT, while I was standing there, I realized they tell you where you can find open public spaces to eat your sandwich: 55 Second St (I only saw some outdoor cafe tables - didn't seem like it was open to the public but I suppose if the cafe doesn't regulate, you can sit there), 101 Second (a big glass building with tables on the first floor as well as the second), 235 Second, and 1 Sansome.
author: Tina T.

description: Every sandwich that I've ordered from here has been amazing. I especially love the lamb eggplant and the corned beef! This spot is right next door to my gym, so basically, I cancel out my workout by having these sandwiches for lunch, but it's so worth it!
author: gina s.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmmm.  The Sentinel is my lunch hero, no pun intended.  (Well, maybe a little bit.)  

Here are all the things I love about it:

*  Delicious, creative, wonderful sandwiches with fresh quality ingredients
*  Standard menu means you can have favorites
*  Seasonal changes to the menu and daily specials means you can try new things and have even more favorites to stalk
*  Regular veggie option(s)
*  Fast, efficient service where you're treated as a valued individual
*  Menu posted online and usually updated promptly
*  YUM

The only changes I'd suggest would be: MORE!  
More veggie options! 
More cookies without nuts for the deathly allergic!  
More locations so I can get my big goopy sammich fix no matter to which g*d-forsaken corner of the city my work relocates!  More!  More!  More!
author: Andi T.

description:
There's something about those gourmet sandwiches that you can smell as you stand in the loooong queue and smell the deliciousness!

I am a Fan!
author: Sumit G.

description: Didn't get what the hype was all about but the sandwiches here were just okay. Nothing earth shattering.
author: Joy A.

description:
OK, this place made me a Dennis Leary believer. The Yellowtail with Avocado and Fennel Sandwich is out of this freaking world. Their rolls taste freshly baked, and are soft as room temperature butter.

It is on par with Ike's, which I think serves to satisfy the normal deli cravings I have. The Sentinel produces finer, much more highbrow delights.
author: May T.

description:
Believe it. This is why we're all spoiled to live in San Francisco. No one is in hotter pursuit of the insatiable sandwich connoisseur's approbation than the folks here. 

The Sentinel has been a roughly bi-monthly indulgence for me since the beginning of the summer, but the spicy eggplant with goat cheese sandwich and cinnamon butternut squash soup the other day reminded my that I am overdue to give the staff their twice earned kudos.
author: Alex B.

description: Great spot downtown. Everything is good including the cookies which are probably the best I've ever had. Sorry Grandma. I recommend the roast beef and corned beef sandwiches, but everything is good. Daily specials change everyday. My only complaint is that I've been going there for months and they don't know my name or seem very friendly towards me.
author: SF I.

description: Places like this make me happy, or at least make my stomach happy and then in turn, the rest of me is happy.  I couldn't choose a sandwich for the life at me. I was at a battle with myself. Do I get the corned beef, even though I am SUPER picky about my corned beef sandwiches? Or do I get the shrimp, which is the lighter, healthier choice.  Luckily for me I was with a co-worker who was extremely understanding with my indecisive nature and agreed to split both we me.  Although I am glad I tried both, I will never stray from the heaven, which is that corned beef sandwich again. EVER. It was awesome: homemade bread, warm, perfectly flavorful meat, a small spread of sauce and pickled cabbage. Plus they serve homemade cookies. Do yourself a favor and GET A COOKIE. Life changing cookie, no lies. I had the chocolate chip, which was the perfect combination of gooey, crunchy and sweet. UGH! I want a cookie right now!
author: Brittany F.

description:
Yum - just the right serving of squidgy, crunchy comfort foods on the form of a sandwich - served by perky gals in a pirate bandana - what more could you ask for?

Well - there could be more veggie options, but the chickpea-spread sammich was quite a delight and they did have a couple of other veggie specials, so i will be back for more.

(Spoiler alert!)

Oooohhh - and a bonus surprise chocolate in the bag too! For me? Ohhh! Thank you gals!
author: Kingpin X.

description:
These aren't regular old sandwiches. 

Today : marinated hamachi with the ripest avocado, marinated cucumbers, and the softest butter lettuce on a sunflower seed roll. Heaven.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: Do yourself a favor and find this place.  Total hole in the wall with some amazing cooks because this place makes a case to be considered one of the best sandwich shops, if not THE best, in San Francisco.  Try fellow 9-5er's
author: Daniel C.

description:
I've been to the Sentinel a few times and it definitely lives up to the hype! Their gourmet sandwiches are simply fantastic...made with fresh, unique ingredients and packed with incredible flavors. Definitely some of the tastiest sandwiches I've ever had!

I decided to phone in my order today to beat the lunchtime line and took several tries before I got through. I'm not sure if it was THE Dennis Leary who answered the phone but he was prompt to take down the sandwich I wanted, my name, and pick-up time. This is great since you get to cut the line, pay, and leave with brown baggie in hand within 5 min. =) Thank god they take credit cards too since their prices range from $8-$10 (including tax)...not too bad for FiDi and the quality of their food.

I've had the infamous corned beef, pork loin, and BBQ eggplant sandwiches before and ALL were uh-may-zing!!! They melt in your mouth (hot sandwiches) and are soooo delicious that you never want it to end. I would say they are all must-trys in my book. I was sad they didn't have the BBQ eggplant on their current Spring menu.

Today, I decided to go another route and tried the cold marinated yellowtail with fennel and avocado sandwich. The abundant yellowtail fish was marinated with something zesty and lemony plus fennel, topped with lettuce, cucumber slivers, and avocado (I think they skimped on mine though). The fish was seared on the outside, slightly raw on the inside and was very fresh!

The roll was covered in sesame and sunflower seeds so that added a nice crunch to offset the tenderness of the fish and softness of the bread. All the flavors just blended extremely well together and is something I will order again. I finished the entire thing, no problem whatsoever and my tummy was happy as well. 

I love how they change up the menu every so often too to provide some variety. I'm determined to eventually try all of their sandwiches!
author: Karen Y.

description:
I discovered this place completely by accident. The incredible fresh-bread smell wafting out of the big open doors forced me to stop.

The food is simple, fresh, high quality, delicious. There menu consists of five or six standards--a roast beef, a tofu, a tuna, etc.--plus three or four daily specials. The staff and fast and friendly. 

The line gets long but tends to go pretty quickly. If your lunch break is limited, I recommend calling in your order.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
Awesome yummy goodness!!! The Corned Beef Sandwich is a must have.  They're super efficient and oh so convenient. 

Do it, you won't regret it!!  

Btw, I believe they have a $10 min for card charges so bring cash if you're flying solo.
author: Nathan J.

description:
Bad:
Their coffee is no bueno, and prices are a little high.
Good:
i've only tried the peanut tofu sandwich, but it's awesome.
author: Tim R.

description: Great sandwiches and in my opinion not that much expensive for what it is. Depending on what time you go you may have to wait in the queue for some time but it's generally not that bad.
author: Baris M.

description: The best sandwhich in the FIDI.  A little pricey, but definitely worth it!
author: Yan L.

description:
What can I say that hasn't been said already? This place has solid food with a price tag.

The workers are friendly and efficient - you're in and out the door within 5 minutes usually.

The corned beef is delicious, albeit a bit saucy for my tastes. The roast beef is served medium rare, so be warned that you're more than likely going to have a bloody, messy sandwich on your hands by the time you sit down to devour it. (I mean that in a good way.)

People say the bread is baked fresh, and I would not be surprised if that is indeed the case. PIllowy soft, never too much of it.
author: Amy C.

description: The corned beef sandwich is what dreams are made of. The lines can be like waiting on Elm Street...a total nightmare.
author: Christina S.

description:
YUM. The other day I had their lamb & feta meatball sub. They have the BEST watermelon juice but it might only be a summer thing. Apparently April is not summer :(  The line might be long but you can order and get your sandwich in 5 minutes. Cash only if its under $10 I think but if you get a sandwich + drink or cookie it will be about that much. 
Definitely worth hitting up for lunch on occasion.
author: Sara P.

description:
Up until this fine morning I had only enjoyed their lunch offerings.  Now, I love me a sandwich, but there is nothing like a baked good to get my motor running....

Upon passing by their inviting doors this morning, I was ill-fated to the temptation of the aroma of sweet peachy awesomeness.  In all honesty, I couldn't wolf the thing down fast enough, while fighting all urges to slowly savor...  I proceeded to buy a dozen for my clients as well.

Most amazing muffin of my life.

And I have a girl-crush on ALL of the employees.

The end.

(Sigh...)
author: Valerie W.

description:
Zip!  Zap!  Zoom!

For some reason, I felt as though the workers behind the counter at The Sentinel were superheroes....they move with such confident speed, grace, and conviction! 

The Sentinel serves to all of my vices!!  With 5-7 sandwich choices, life becomes (semi) more simple for little Miss Indecisive.  Miss Impatient was appeased with the fast paced line and the 5 minute wait for sandwich!  And Miss Snooty Foodie fell in love with every element of her sandwich.

Mr. Deviled Pork Loin Sandwich laid upon my idea of PERFECT bread: seedy, crunchy, and soft on the inside.  The pork was fall-off-the...sandwich(?) tender, and sweet with just a hint of spicy kick.

Shared half of Corned Beef with Gruyere was sumptuously soft, warm, and overflowing with savory corned beef and adamantly crunchy cabbage.

$8 for all sandwiches in FiDi and in quick time is a penny-saver indeed!

Know Before You Go:
1. Need a place to sit?  Mosey on over to kitty corner Crocker Gallery - sit on outdoor top floor for some fresh SF air!
author: Jane L.

description:
I just had the lamb & feta meatball sandwich and it was DELISH! I'm not a huge lamb fan (at least I think), but this was juicy and flavorful to the MAX. The feta was melted in so it wasn't falling off the sandwich. They used a sunflower seed roll which was soft, but stood up well to the hefty meatballs. The sauce was a spicy tomato, not too spicy but offered a nice zing to the sandwich. 

I definitely recommend ordering ahead on the phone as it tends to get packed during the lunch rush. The service was quick and efficient. Portions were solid at the price points. Must try if you work downtown!
author: J S.

description: This place has the sticky icky stuff. The pork sandwich is incredible. Soft buttery bread, super tender pork, amazing fig glaze. I could go on, but it's making me sad that I didn't order seconds. You'll usually see a line out the door, but don't let it discourage you. It moves fast. I was in and out in less than five minutes. Top marks!
author: Julio A.

description:
I don't really take the time to write reviews. Only when you piss me off or I am super duper happy with your service. 

Well, this time is one of those good reviews I had to take the time and write about my experience at the Sentinel.

Yes, this place gets crowded but they are quick to take your order and you probably have to wait at least 5 minutes for your food. 

I have been here a few times and every time I order any kind of sandwich they have, I end up wanting more.   My all time favorite is the asparagus sandwich.  I never thought I would say this (a meat lover) but its better than any ham or steak sandwich out there. 
Their bread is to die for!!!  I would like to find out their recipes but I am sure they don't hand them out so this is the reason why I am addicted to this place.  I keep going back for more.

Keep up the good work!
author: Liza B.

description:
So after hearing and reading Julie F.'s reviews, I figured I could walk out of the building and check this place out.  Thank goodness it was sunny out and I didn't mind standing in line for 10 minutes for the Swiss Chard, Mushroom and Goat Cheese sandwich on Poppy and Sesame seed roll.

The service was kind of crap, if you ask me (2 stars).  The woman in front of me ordered, then the guy in back of me ordered...HELLO...what about ME!  I get up to the cashier and tell her what I wanted, she wrote my name on a post-it and rang me up.  I didn't know the different colored post-it's reflected a sandwich, so I commented that nobody took my order..and she said "I did" and proceeded to help the guy behind me who placed his order with someone behind her! UGH! It would be nice if they actually had a system where only one person does the order taking and one does the cashiering. Bleh!

Anyhow, the sandwich was good (4 stars), definitely not worth $8 - but considering where it's located, it's the going rate.  I liked how the sandwich wasn't too overwhelming in flavors and that the goat cheese was nice and creamy and complemented the chard.  I'll probably try the Corned Beef sandwich next time just to see what the rave is all about.
author: Christine C.

description: Had the eggplant and lamb sandwich. The description failed to mention the 1" layer of mayonnaise on the sandwich. Bread was weirdly thick and the sandwich was hard to eat. Seems like a very popular spot, but its not for me.
author: Thomas W.

description:
I had the pleasure of meat-ting the veal & ricotta meatball sandwich today. Delicious, sinfully delicious. It is veal after all but then again it doesn't matter if you're eating the baby or adult, you're still consuming an animal. The veal that I had must've been treated like a prince or a princess at the farm because it tasted so sweet and pure. I enjoyed it so much that now I feel like I need to repent or be punished for enjoying it so much. 

Now the actual sandwich was just ok. It was appropriately messy but not as saucy as I normally like. I'm not even sure if the ricotta was in there. The roll was good, I don't even know what it was called but it was similar to a kaiser roll.

I called my order in ahead of time but I probably didn't need to since I go to lunch rather late, at 2pm. The line wasn't long at all. I like the Soup Nazi kitchen feel of it, that is you better know how to order otherwise you'll piss off the staff and the regular customers. 

"You're on deck sister!" "Are you kissing in my line? THERE'S NO KISSING IN MY LINE!"
author: Tatiana D.

description:
Muffins: 5 STARS! Best muffins I've ever had, so hearty, down to earth, yet all the right texture that I was looking for. I tried the butternut squash muffin, and the BEST EVER pear muffin. The pear muffin has huge chunks of sweet juicy pears, they are so big that the muffin stays so moist. The squash one is unique in flavor, not too spicy, but you could definitely taste the sweetness of the squash. Both of them have the the BEST slightly crusty top, which is what I love about muffins. When I go to other places, i buy a couple muffins but eat only the top, then throw the rest away, just don't care for them. Here at Sentinel, I ate the entire thing, every single time.

Sandwiches: 3 STARS. After trying all the sandwiches, personally I like warm sandwiches over cold ones, so my favorite is the Lamb and feta meatball sammy. The corned beef one has a great bread with gruyere cheese, light in texture. Both lack in flavor in my opinion, the lambmeatball one needs a little more spiciness in the tomato sauce (even though it says spicy...), the corned beef one...needs something but I can't pinpoint what's missing. 

Great breakfast and sandwiches all at a great price, what's not to love this cute little place?
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Home for lunch to shit the dog. Sick of eating the same Soup Freaks and Toaster Oven sandwiches over and over (sometimes slumming it at Quiznos just to cleanse the palette). I decided to throw caution to the wind and just walk in the other direction to see what I could find. I didn't have to walk far before I noticed the Sentinel. Was this some House of Shield's cafe? A newsstand? As I got closer, my eyes read "Corned Beef" and I quickened my pace. 

Turns out this is the best sandwich place in SoMa YET! Just 1 block from my house. I've been on this block for over a year and didn't know it was there. I think it's one of those places that just looks like a wall when it's closed.

Anyway, my corned beef sandwich had the perfect amount of each ingredient and the bread was not too heavy. They didn't slather it with too much dressing. The meat was quality. You get what you pay for. I can't wait to go back to make sure it wasn't a fluke. It would be sweet if today's sandwich was a fluke in a bad way. Like they normally make it twice as good. That would be awesome.
author: Gabe M.

description:
This place rocks and is super delicious. 

I was just told this place is a "Stuff White People Like" type place, and since I am extremely white I like it too!

First off, it is small and tight, and looks artfully "mechanical" with a chunky clock on the wall. White Point!

Second, there is a limited, changing menu of sandwiches every day and they are all about 10$. If you don't like what they have to offer then just go elsewhere and spend less. White Point!

Third, the counter girls are cute and reticent, which makes me feel like I need to be on my best behavior to gain their sandwich approval. White Point!

Fourth, it is really quick. White Point.

Lastly, the sandwiches are delicious and pretend unfancy. Today I had a mole Chicken sandwich. White Point!

Anyway, since the food is so good, I guess other ethnicities might like this place too. Which makes me feel multi-cultural and worldly on my lunch break. Golly, another White Point!
author: Colin M.

description:
When my collegue took me out for lunch one day, we ended up at The Sentinel! I had the roast beef sandwich and oh my, it was sooo good!

This is a lunch spot and there is always  a line but it goes quick. It is a whole in the wall, literally! Nowhere to sit and eat your lunch but who cares, it is really good! I would def. go back.
I am hungry for it right now!=)
author: C A.

description:
The $8.50 corned beef sandwich was super.  However, for $0.50 less, you can have the other sandwiches, which seemed far less delicious.  Just to make sure my theory was correct, I ordered three sandwiches; The corned beef, the vegetarian Swiss chard, and the deviled ham.  

The Swiss chard was unique in that it was unlike anything I'd ever eaten before.  It came cold, with a wallop of chard and mushrooms, a huge smear of goat cheese, sun dried tomato mayonnaise, and curried raisins.  It was a taste sensation my mouth was not sophisticated enough to appreciate yet.  I'm purely a deli meats kind of gal, I suppose.

The deviled ham, although appearing to be minced with mayo, looked unappealing as soon as I opened the wrapper.  It was accompanied by butter lettuce, cream cheese and walnuts.  Not my favorite choice, but my husband loved the flavor, and said it tasted swell.   Then again, he'll eat anything meat.  He calls pigs "a magical animal." Yes, I'm married to Homer Simpson.

But I put my vote in for the corned beef.  It had Gruyere, caramelized onions, Russian dressing, and what I think was some sort of slaw.  It was the perfect combination of sweet and savory, and the beef was perfectly prepared.  The sandwich was served warm, unlike the other two, and it hit the spot on a cold San Francisco afternoon.  

So there you have it.  My Sentinel theory was correct.  Corned beef = crazy delicious.  Everything else = normal delicious.  

(I will be back for the muffins, however.  They could very possibly blow my theory out of the water.)
author: Kristina R.

description:
I certainly wish the hours at this place were a little more convenient!  I've been wanting to check it out for months and have never been able to swing it until Friday.

To make up for it, I ordered two sandwiches:  The Corned Beef and the Lamb Meatball.  I spent the next 30 minutes eating both and trying to figure out which one I liked more.  :)

Both sandwiches were quite good, and far better the average sandwich in the city.  The Meatball sandwich is bold and full of flavor.  The Corned Beef is milder in flavor, but offers greater complexity and balance.  I loved the Russian Dressing.  The Meatball sandwich, on the other hand, felt like it needed something -- it was a bit too one note.  But, even so, I couldn't put either down.

But, was either the best sandwich in the city (as some claim)?  I'm not so sure.  I think I like the Cubano at Ironside and the BBQ Pork at Saigon Sandwiches better.
author: Tony F.

description:
I've read alot about the Sentinel thanks to Yelp and you know what, all 258 reviews are right! I got the corned beef sandwich for my coworker and I. It was after the lunch rush so I was in and out in 5 min! Super fast! 

Brought back the sammies to work and was happy to see my nice corned beef flat bread sammie with the fixings. Only complaint was that my sammie was a light on the meat. I peeped my coworkers sammie and saw that hers was not light or heavy but just right. I was a little disappointed but I still would come back to try their other offerings.
author: Julie F.

description:
The Sentinel is a great place for a gourmet sandwich but it can cost you up to $8.50 for the just the sandwich. 

So far my favorite was the tuna sandwich, unfortunately, the tuna is no longer offered because the menu is seasonal and changes weekly. I like this but I do miss the tuna :).

I have also had the chicken mole and the egg salad sandwich. The chicken mole was wonderful! The first time I had the egg salad it was great but the second time I had it I think they scrambled the eggs because it was very runny and the texture of the eggs were of scrambled eggs. Also, the egg salad was a bit warm when it should be cold. After that experience I was kind of turned off from the egg salad.

Other than the one time experience with the egg salad I have very much enjoyed their food and will continue to try new sandwiches!
author: Amanda V.

description:
I am not a big sandwich eater.  They usually just don't wow me.

The trout salad sammie I just had at The Sentinel would be an exception to that rule!  Its unique and its good!  Smoked trout was good (aka not too fishy) and well complimented by apples, fennel and dill and just enough mayo to hold it together.  The bun it was on was soft but not too soft - it held together and nicely hugged the filling to keep everything in place.  

And they get extra points for including a pickle spear and Andes Mint (yum!) with the order - nice touch.
author: Jennifer G.

description: The best sandwiches in the FD as far as I'm concerned. They must bake their breads soaked in butter... Delicious, but not good for you. Highly recommend the spicy pork and the egg salad.
author: Evren O.

description: I tried the chicken salad on a sesame roll today. Wow, very delicious!  The food came out quick. Definitely give this place a try!
author: David T.

description:
The corned beef is seriously overrated. So is the chicken salad sandwich. 

I'd like to consider myself a sandwich aficionado. I've had a lot of corned beef sandwiches. Maybe because I've lived in NYC for almost 8 years now, I have high standards for what to consider "amazing" corned beef. It's better than mediocre here (meaning "good enough") but nothing worth a trip. 

I will say it was a good portion size, in terms of not overeating. One sandwich will satiate you and not get you stuffed, which I respect. But if I'm going to pay $8.50 for a sandwich, I better have leftovers. I can get a better, bigger gourmet/fresh (however you want to label it) sandwich in NYC for 25% less money. That's saying something. 

Considering the reviews, I'm sure it's one of the best sandwiches you can get in SF and encourage all SF sandwich eaters to eat more sandwiches when traveling. Maybe you'll see what I mean. 

However, the other sandwiches on the menu do intrigue me and if circumstances bring me here again, I will try another sandwich. That's my own fault, though, for not following my gut and ordering something different. Oh well. Canteen looks promising, too. Maybe I'll check that out instead.
author: Ingrid C.

description:
I ain't gonna lie. I'm ballin on a budget. But man cannot live by $5 dollar foot longs and $3 saigon sandwiches alone, not too mention trader joes frozen chicken vindaloo (don't get me f$^%n started).

The Sentinel fills the gap and provides what the suits call "accessible luxury." and they do it with gusto.

I used to get the corn beef with gruyere on the reg, never giving so much as a glance to the rest of the menu. 

Now that I'm on the healither "tip" I steered clear of the corn beef and hit up the salmon sando

A fragrant and scrumptious mix of smoked and fresh(!) salmon, on a brioche it really hit the spot. 

Now, having broken out of my corned beef routine, I'll be back to Sentinel often to explore the menu fully delight in this lunchtime luxury.
author: Gabe b.

description:
It simply doesn't get better than The Sentinel. Roast Beef with blue cheese, Corned Beef over cornbread, and a Veal and Ricotta Meatball. You can't go wrong. 

Call ahead for your order. There is nowhere to sit, the lines can be long and they often run out of the favorites. It's a little expensive but considering the quality of ingredients is worth the change.
author: Tucker T.

description:
Now THAT is what I call a sandwich!

Believe what everyone says about the long line moving QUICKLY. With only a handful of menu items, they seem to be actively making everything on the list, but with such a busy lunch rush, it's not like your reuben will be sitting there all forlorn and lonely while it waits for you to order it.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Wow, I REALLY like this place.  The line was kind of long, but it moved very quickly.  

I had the - CORNED BEEF WITH CABBAGE, RUSSIAN DRESSING AND SWISS - 8.75... and I must say, it was SUPER GOOD.  I definitely recommend it, and am actually craving one as I write this.

And along with your sandwich, be sure to get a cookie and some lemonade, which altogether make for a perfect lunch.

On the neg side, there is nowhere to sit, so be prepared.
author: Jaymar C.

description:
Amazing corned beef sandwich!  Comes on focaccia bread and is warm and delicious.  I don't work in SF, but worked from home the other day just so I could get a sandwich here.

Warning, they do have a rather long line, so don't expect to get your lunch in a huge hurry.  That being said, the line does move quickly, so don't be THAT intimidated.
author: Jessica J.

description:
Located across the street from The Palace Hotel, this busy little place serves fresh and tasty sandwiches. There isn't a seating area, but it's just a quick walk to Yerba Buena Park or one of the indoor areas that they recommend on 2nd Street.

I got to sample a couple of sandwiches, both delicious and interesting in their own way. One was yellowtail served on a soft seeded baguette with fennel and apple. Fresh, light and dressed in a bright vinaigrette, it was a refreshing combination. The other sandwich was their special of the day, the BBQ pork sandwich -- thin slices of pork covered with enough tangy sauce to keep it together between its soft roll.

Open on the weekdays for lunch, be sure to get there early if you want  to pick from their full menu. We got there after 1pm and many of the options were sold out.
author: Joel A.

description:
I walk 5+ blocks to get here. I love their selction and the tasty lunch sets are awesome. Bread's freshly baked--and the tastiest secret I've recently discovered--they have fresh baked goods in the AM. I had a cranberry muffin that tasted like heaven. and I have a pretty high expectation of what heaven should taste like. 

I like the small touches like an Andes mint or a bubble gum they tuck in. the staff is extremely friendly and efficient. their watermelon lemonade was a treat all summer.
author: Ms. Q.

description: The selection for vegetarian sandwiches is usually slim but all the ones I have tried I enjoyed. The service is incredibly quick, I don't know how but the time from your order being made to having your sandwich in your hand is at most 2 minutes.
author: Lori L.

description:
And the winner to the most overrated place on yelp goes to....... The Sentinel

I, like most white people like expensive sandwiches (http://stuffwhitepeoplelike.com/2008/02/11/63-expensive-sandwiches/), but this place just doesn't cut it for me.

I came here with some coworkers and we ordered a few sandwiches (Corn beef, turkey cranberry and pork with fig jam)  to share. Everything that we had tasted good but nothing that made us say wow, we need to come back. Also whats up with not having chips? Are chips not cool any more. If so, I am screwed. 

This place sounds good on paper with their unique menu but ultimately  falls shorts of a marque sandwich shop for me.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Excellent sandwiches. Gourmet, unique, tasty, large variety, not insanely expensive. A normal sandwich will run you $8-$9. If you feel like a 3 course meal, you can get the special (around $11) and get a salad, main course, and dessert. 

I had the lamb feta with mint meatball sandwich. The bread was AMAZING, as was the meat. They give you an Andes mint too.

It's take out only. There's usually a line, and the line is always outside, so be prepared if it's bad weather.
author: Grace Y.

description: I always make a weird face when I see the strange combinations that Sentinel comes up with...then I forget my fears, and order whatever is a vegetarian option. They ALWAYS have one. Thank you! Their sandwiches are basically works of art. It always comes with an andes mint, and a pickle. I'm never let down by their ever changing menu, and sometimes even sad to see the sandwiches go. The employees are hardworking too.
author: Cherish P.

description:
