One of my friend that use to work near here recommended this place. She told me that there always a line, the sandwiches are awesome, and the manager is nice, so while I was waiting for her to get off work I decided to give this place a try. 

OMGGGAHHH! The corn beef (recommended by my friend) was absolutely amazing. I would totally come here again and wait in that line just to eat the delicious sandwich again.
author: Tina T.

description: I ordered the eggplant and lamb sandwich and thought it was good but not what I expected. It wasn't slices of lamb and eggplant. It was chopped up eggplant with chickpeas and a bunch of other herbs and the lamb was grounded lamb made into a ragu with everything else. It was $9 including tax. The wheat bun that it came on was good, a lot of bun though if you are carb conscious.  Service was fast but I got my sandwich before a lot of others waiting. I guess everyone else ordered the corned beef which I will get next time to try. Credit cards accepted for $8+.
author: Bling L.

description:
The MUFFINS!! Sentinel has the best muffins I have ever tasted. Chunks of fresh fruit, piping hot, not too sugary. It's heaven. 

The blueberry, peach, and zucchini are GREAT. Bring $2.50 and start your day off to a perfect start with the Sentinel muffin. It's dangerous how good they are.
author: Jackie M.

description:
I've only had 2 sandwiches here, but they were both very good.  

Mind-blowing?  No, not really.  Just a real nice alternative to the kind of crap you wind up eating downtown for just a buck or 2 more.  Which, I think, is always worth it.

I've had the 2 hot sandwiches on the Summer Menu:  The veal meatball and the corned beef.  The stars of each were the meat, as I'd imagine they should have been.

The meatballs were flavored with nice fresh herbs that gave a loud garden-like spin, while maintaining a huge meat flavor.  The sauce had a nice taste, but was drenched all over the meatballs and both buns to the point where it could not be picked up dues to sogginess.  Meatballs and sauce on a bun;  that was it - no additional roughage or veggies.  Flavor-wise, it arguably doesn't need anything else, but texture-wise I'd say some contrast was missing.  Pretty messy, very heavy, but damn satisfying.

The corn beef itself wasn't too greasy at all.  More importantly, it didn't have that tough or rubbery texture you can expect at some of the cheaper spots nearby.  The lightly toasted (and quite greasy from butter) foccacia and cabbage offered a little more bite to this sandwich.  The Russian dressing was mild but nice.  Very filling, but required a good amount of napkins that weren't found in our take-away bag.  

I like this place.  I'm looking forward to seeing the fall menu.  Also, if these two sandwiches made their summer menu, what kind of heavy items can we expect come winter?
author: Dave H.

description:
Every morning I stop here for coffee.  It is usually a wordless transaction: the staff sees me, grabs an empty cup and hands it to me. I leave three bills on the counter, fill the cup, and go.

The other day I was given a slice of coffee cake.
author: Jorm ..

description:
Oh, I LOVE the Sentinel.  I love the busy-bodies working behind the counter oh-so serious in the creation of the perfect sandwich.  Yes, and I think they've accomplished near perfection.  I don't work in the financial district, but whenever I have a week day off (I'm a student) I make sure to find time to stop by.  Going down that way for lunch is a good reminder that we need to get more women in business, finance, whatever it is these "financial district" people do, but that's beside the point.

I've been to the Sentinel a handful of times now and most of the time I get the egg salad.  My only complaint is that I loved the first one I had the best, and since then they've changed it a bit.  The first one I had came on a wonderful crispy roll - just the right amount of crunch with a soft, buttery interior.  The egg salad had a great flavor - a little bit vinegar-y with some fresh herbs chopped in.  It also wasn't too heavy on the mayo.  I think this last time I had it, the vinegar flavor wasn't really there, and I missed that.

I've also tried the chopped chickpea salad.  My favorite part of the sandwich was the bread.  Probably the only time I'll eat white bread, and it's well worth it - tastes like it just came from the oven.  I had a white bean soup as well - it wasn't incredible, but had an interesting tangy flavor.

As I'm not a meat eater, I can't say much for the meat sandwiches except that my dad (who was visiting from Wisconsin) is still talking about his Reuben!  

I recommend going early - we went 1/2 hour before close once and they were out of all but one sandwich.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Sentinel Haiku

Long line, no seating
Who cares? the reason is clear.
Damn-tasty Sandwich
author: Shannon N.

description:
The Sentinel and I are officially best friends.  We do everything together.   Girlfriend in the city for a facial?  Take her to The Sentinel.   Taking an interview candidate out to lunch?  Take him to The Sentinel.  Any other day?  Take myself to The Sentinel.

Will you indulge me a minute while I gush some more?  

It all starts with the website.  Check the daily menu: if the special sounds appetizing, well, you better get it.  If not, then it's an excuse to treat yourself to the corned beef, eggplant, turkey meatloaf (my recent go-to), smoked salmon, or whichever other regular item you either haven't tried or can't wait to try again.  Call ahead if you want -- good weather brings out a long line, but recently it hasn't been necessary -- and walk on over.

The next step is my favorite.  Holly.  She is the world's greatest register girl.  She's cute, friendly, and remembers your name.  She has an awesome system of color-coded post-it notes for handing off the orders to the cooks.  She always makes a gesture of conversation, no matter how busy she is.  She's never messed up an order no matter how large.  If it's been more than a few days since you've been, she'll make you feel missed.  If you come alone, she takes care to ask where your friends are -- Tavi, buddy, she misses you!

You'd like to stay and chat with Holly forever, but it'd be rude to the customers behind you.  So you step back a little and patiently wait for your food.  And salivate.

Dennis calls your name; your food's ready.  He's left you a few extra treats, too: Andes mints and pickle slices.  Open up the package and take a peek, because god oh god does it look good.  Tell the crew thanks, and depart for heaven.
author: Jack S.

description:
Line out the door moved pretty quickly!  The whole experience was like a whirlwind.  No sooner had I walked in the door did I have my sandwich in my hand and I was walking out the other side.

Corned beef sandwich was tasty.  Apparently that's their signature item.  I also tried the pomegranate-ade, which was also good.  I'd definitely return.
author: Justin H.

description: OMG! I had never tried it since i dont usually carry cash. But now I will start carrying a $10 bill. Just got the tuna sandwich - unusual - but very, very good!
author: Saf A.

description:
After being a die hard Sentinel fan for at least a year, I am happy to report that Dennis's little "have a nice day" to me when handing me my soup and lunch box yesterday actually made my day.  I even called my husband to brag about it!  He must have been having a good day.  That one, he's so serious, but if that's what it takes to get me my damn good food in the middle of an otherwise dull work day, I'll take what I can get.  Besides, I get all kinds of smiles and friendliness from the girls at the register (Monika and Teresa, both of whom rock).

All the sandwiches are super bangup delish.  The daily lunch special is always such a surprise delight.  But the best thing on the menu is the soup.  I could kill for that soup.  Every day it's something different.  I think my favorites have been the mushroom, tomato parmesan, and sweet corn soups.  I think he may use a little bit of a cream and butter in those soups.  A touch.  Those lovely soup containers covered in foil with a slice of bread and pickle and an Andes mint (along with whatever sandwich or lunch special I happen to get that day) are really setting me back quite a bit for lunch, but I DON'T CARE.  I am blinded by the soup.

And, the daily rotating selection of muffins and oatmeal in the morning is incredible.  I think they might be made of cake batter, as that is what I feel like I am eating every time I sink my teeth into them.  God bless Dennis Leary.
author: Isabel M.

description:
cant say anything that hasnt already been said... TO.DIE.FOR.  sooooo delish.  the corned beef sandy = ahhhhmazing.  but the surprise juggernaut was the roast beef sammy.  OMG.  i died.  

alas, only four stars because i want to sit somewhere to eat.  like, a legit chair and table.  i know.. im so high maintenance.  my office is far.  so there.
author: Sammi C.

description:
I had the eggplant and goat cheese sandwich. The bread does help it to be a tasty sandwich. Bonus for being quick even with 15 people in line in front of me when I got there. They don't mess around.

Update: also had the egg salad. It's a winner. It's because of the bread, mostly... mostly.
author: Jamie F.

description:
My co-workers have been raving about this place for ages. I've walked past it, but always a bit too intimidated by its higher-end pricing. 

Until I gave in today. That $8.50 was totally worth it, I had somewhat of a religious experience in my mouth. 

The corned-beef sandwich is part of 7x7's San Francisco "100 things to eat& drink before you die" list. The bread was toasted just perfectly with a nice crisp without being overly hard. The corned-beef was sweet and delicious, and I would love to know how they managed to make lettuce taste so stupidly good. Plus a nice sized chill pickle to bring this simple yet superbly delicious ensemble to a whole new level. 

I. am. Addicted.

Buh-bye Madeleine's/Specialty's. Forever. PS to myself, need to drop by Canteen some time real soon.
author: Fiona S.

description: First time here. Out of corned beef, so I try the roast beef. Dry mealy whole wheat roll, bland despite horseradish. Hmm. Bad day?
author: Clifford B.

description:
My husband is kind of in love with this place.

About once a week, he checks The Sentinel's website, scans through the menu, and calls in his order so he doesn't have to wait in line.  (His one complaint: it sometimes takes a few tries to get through -- The Sentinel needs call waiting and/or a louder ring tone.)  He then walks to MUNI and rides a few stops down to the Montgomery Street station -- just to pick up an $8 sandwich and a pickle.  (And occasionally -- TOO occasionally for my preference -- pick one up for me to eat during my graveyard shift that night.)  Once the food's picked up, he sits on the benches outside the Art Academy and devours everything before riding MUNI back to work.

Favorites: The chard, mushroom & goat cheese sandwich (though they're messy to eat -- the mushrooms are diced small), the pork loin sandwich, and any special that involves steak and an apple crisp.

My husband used to ride MUNI every day to and from work when we lived in SF -- and he hated it.  But he now does it regularly for sandwiches from The Sentinel, which says a lot.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Warm pear muffin...you totally made my morning!  Oh what a yummy treat and great way to start the day.  Actually, deadly.  Must not make a habit of it.  But oh-so-good!  

My coworker declared that he had found the BEST muffin and so a group of us followed him to this little sandwich stand.  Little did I know what I was getting myself into.  What awaited me was melt-in-my-mouth goodness.  The "muffin" was actually much more like a cake, with a nice crumbly top and moist inside, especially where there were chunks of pear, almost like bread pudding.  At $2.50 for one, it was extremely filling.  

I'll  have to limit myself to one a week or else my new nickname might be muffin top.
author: nini t.

description:
Awesome rotating menu. Show up early and have your pick, show up late and some offerings may be sold out. The salmon sandwich and, if you haven't heard, the corned beef hash sandwich are both excellent and for under $10 it's unbeatable. 

No seats, but bring your boxed lunch to 106 Second, across from the Van Heusen store, cross street Mission, and there is a glass atrium area with about 50 seats & 25 tables which is a nice place to eat and read, chat, chill, or people watch.

Oh and the pickle and Andes Mint are a great touch to your lunch.
author: Kai F.

description:
I've walked past here many times before without giving The Sentinel a second thought other than the use of Helvetica on their awning.  Walking in is really underwhelming.  Natural lighting, no seating, and a staff of only three (one young female asian cashier and two hispanic cooks in the back).  It's about the size of a dorm room.  From experience I knew it had to be something good for this hole in the wall to survive.

The interior isn't anything upscale but it has it's charming touches such as the antique wooden cash register, big ass clock, and plainly stated menu board.  There is a counter for maybe two people to eat at, although this is primarily a take out spot for people on the run or living in the nearby hotel.

According to the website the menu changes seasonally.  They state that they have breakfast and soup yet no items are listed on the menu, only sandwiches are listed.  All the sandwiches sounded really tasty but the corned beef on flatbread with gruyere cheese sounded the best.  Plus there aren't that many places that serve up quality corned beef.

I was expecting a 'Soup Nazi' yet the cashier was really nice.  Even saying "por favor" to her hispanic comrades.  The sandwich comes in a recycled-paper box with a bagged pickle and butterscotch candy.  I really loved my sandwich.  Super tasty.  All the elements worked well together.  The corned beef sandwich had cabbage as well as some kind of pinkish-orange sauce that tasted like tomato.  At times it tasted like pizza.  Now I want to try putting corned beef on a pizza pie!  The quality of corned beef is worth noting.  Really moist, flavorful, and plentiful.

The sandwich is pricey at $8.25 but it really filled me up.  It looks kinda small but it definitely exceeded my expectations.  I would go back if I ran out of ideas or craved a sandwich.  Locals probably bring back lunch from here all the time.  I envy them.

I'll notch it up to 5 stars once I try more of the menu.
author: Michael H.

description: Line is fast, food is good, but they raised their prices. Really should now be two dollar signs. I'll be back though!
author: Kevin S.

description:
Like other Yelpers, I am loath to write up this review for fear of contributing to what I'm sure will soon be a very, very long line... because Denis Leary's food is very, very delicious.  But it's been a while since I've gotten excited about lunch downtown, so here we go!

There aren't many choices at this adorably teeny shop: two sandwiches, one entre-sized salad, one small soup.  But it helps that every choice is fantastic.  Today, the bf had:

Pastrami on rye with gruyere, grainy mustard, and red cabbage slaw - which must have had some serious aioli mixed in cause this one was RICH.  In a good way.  It was the perfect boy sandwich - ultra-meaty, savory, and intense.  

I had:

Smoked salmon with horseradish aioli, watercress, and fennel on a seeded roll: this was, appropriately, the female counterpart to the above: fresh, delicate, and subtle.  Every flavor was distinct and balanced.  And the roll: amazing.  It had to be housemade.

We shared:

Corn soup.  Essence of corn.  And well, cream.  Probably a lot of cream.  Hence the sharing.

Both sandwiches came with pickles, which, while bf-approved, disappointed me just a bit: I wanted something more interesting on the side - I'd heard rumors of fabulous-sounding mini-salads served earlier in the week.  I also tried to score an order of the strawberry shortcake that accompanied today's ahi tartare (which I would have ordered if not for the scary spicy tuna bowl I foolishly consumed last night at the Westfield food court - what was I thinking, raw tuna in a mall?!), but was rebuffed.  What do you mean, I can't have one of those?  The word "no" does not go over very well with me.

So, sigh.  Dessert will just have to wait til next time.  And you can bet there will be a next time.  Many of them.
author: Melissa B.

description:
I am 100% sold on The Sentinel!  I have been working my way down the menu before writing my review and after sampling over half the items I have to say they make the highest quality sandwiches in downtown SF.  The bread melts in your mouth and the ingredients are top notch.  So far my favorite has been the pork sandwich with Havarti and figs.  It's to die for.  

My biggest problem with the Sentinel is bringing myself to stray from the awesome sandwiches I know to try the awesome sandwiches I don't know (yet).  I have been bringing my coworkers here for the last few weeks and everyone has raved about their sandwich.  Even the tuna sandwich with the spice and green beans made me a believer.  It sounds crazy but I don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu.
author: Chuck N.

description:
Short version: The corned beef sandwich is phenomenal.

Long version....
The following is a breakdown of my lunches this week; I didn't even realize how much I liked this sandwich (but don't worry, I am vaguely aware of how neurotic I am):

Monday: I want. I want the Sentinel's sinfully satisfying corned beef sandwich, on fresh flatbread with melty gruyere cheese, tangy coleslaw and rich russian dressing so bad i can taste it... I think over the weekend, I dreamt of me and this sandwich, hand in -um, sandwich hand, frolicking through a flowery meadow, together forever. Suddenly, an Instant Message... what? I have lunch plans with some friends? No Sentinel? I promised? This is precisely why I have commitment anxiety.

Tuesday: At Sentinel. I can taste it. Me: "I'll have the corned beef sandwich, please." Girl behind the counter: "Oh I'm sorry, we're out today." Me: DAMMIT!

Wednesday: Today it will be mine... waaait, hunger is weakening me... getting sucked into the post-company-meeting lunch crew... How did I end up at Mehfil? *Sigh*

Thursday: Where did the time go!? 3 o' clock lunch, at least there will be no line at Sentinel... oh wait, it closed at 2:30.

Friday: If anyone is still reading at this point, know that a tragedy almost occured. So I'm at the register. My sandwich and tasty tangerine-aide are placed inches away from me. Where the f*ck is my ATM card? I almost lost it. Almost went straight wolfnuts for a second there. But where there's a will there's a way. I am tenacious. Today I was unstoppable... I got that sucker! What a rough lunch week. What an exhausting quest. I even canceled my Gold Club lunch plans. Worth it. Hot damn that sandwich was delicious.

And since I am ranting with reckless abandon, I'm gonna go ahead and throw this tidbit in: Dennis Leary is an absolutely dead-on older doppelganger for my friend Garret. It's freaky. Okay, that's all I'm gonna say, I'm done. I swear.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
I met a friend here for lunch yesterday who works nearby, and I was very impressed.  Firstly, the line moves FAST.  Secondly, the counter ladies are very nice and efficient. Also, when my friend said that he was buying my sammich because it was my birthday, the counter lady who was ringing us up said "Oh, it's your birthday? Here, have a free cookie." 
And that cookie was NOM. Oatmeal with chopped nuts. 
I had the Spicy Pork sammich with red bell pepper sauce & celeryroot, on a seeded roll.  It was very tasty, but not at all spicy.  Nice lean pork roast, thinly sliced and tender.  Two thumbs up.
author: Melissa L.

description:
I was introduced to this place on my first day of work at my current company. As an initiation ritual, I had to order food for everyone. Their service was quick, even when I accidentally messed up the phone order and needed an extra sandwich. 

Since then, I've been here several times and while their smoked trout salad is amazing, the others that I have tried have been okay but not spectacular. It's too bad the trout was a daily special or else I'd be going back all the time just to eat it over and over again.
author: Tiffany J.

description: Ive heard about this place for years and finally go to try it today.  I was super excited. Got the corned beef for $10. While it tasted good. There was at its thickest maybe 1/4" of meat. Out toward the corners of the bread...maybe 1/16"?? Like 2 thin slices.  Not what I expected. Not coming back for more.  Good taste. Not even close to enough corned beef for the price.
author: Mike N.

description:
Saw all the great reviews on here, so I thought I would give it a try.  Had the corned beef sandwich.  Not the sort of thing I'd usually order, but figured I would give it a shot.  Was a little disappointed there were only 2 warm sandwiches on the menu (I generally prefer my sandwiches warm).

Service was quick and friendly.  Nowhere to sit, but I was going back to Moscone anyways, so it wasn't a bit deal.  Not too much of a line around 11:15.

I thought the sandwich was just OK.  The quality of the ingredients was good, and the taste was alright, but it just didn't jump out and grab me.  Maybe I'm missing something here.  Might try again with a different sandwich later this week.
author: Ryan S.

description: Wow medium rare roast beef sandwich.  You aren't going to find that in a typical sandwich shop.  The cream cheese horse radish was somewhat potent, but great.  As popular as it is, I was surprised I only had to wait 10 minutes.  It must have been because it was late in the lunch hour.  The price is good compared to the surrounding areas.
author: Kent H.

description:
Get here early or prepare to wait a long time. We stopped in at 11:25am -- by car, even though the office is a block and a half away -- on our way back from an errand. The Sentinel is notorious for its massive line and limited supply, so we thought we'd beat the rush. Even though Jessica was second in line (they open at 11:30am), I waited in the getaway car for about 20 minutes for the order to come out. 20 minutes for two gourmet spicy peppered turkey on ciabatta sandwiches. In those 20 minutes, I saw the line grow from 2 to 20 people, with the line formed along Stevenson Street. This better be a damned good sandwich, I thought to myself.

Because I was posted out front inside the Yelpmobile, I didn't get to check out the selection of desserts. Which was just as well though, because the sandwich was huge. There was about 2" of turkey, and oh was it delicious!

I can't wait to come back to try out the daily changing selection of sammies and sweet treats. Chef Leary has himself a little gold mine in this corner shop.
author: Connie C.

description:
Lunch is yummy here. I have been happy with anything I've had so far. Sandwiches on delicious bread--quite tasty. So are the baked treats! I went to the gym one morning and then decided to offset my workout with an apple muffin--probably one of the best apple muffins I've ever had with more chunks of apple than anything else.

My one complaint--I wish they would give a little bit more in quantity because $8 seems like a lot for what you are getting. Get there early--things run out and the line gets long.
author: Kat H.

description:
Just got a super rare roast beef sandwich today.
best roast beef sandwich I've had in the whole city.
I get the feeling that every sandwich I get from here will fit in that same sentence:

best __________ sandwich in the whole city.

the rare beef was perfectly roasted, juicy (mmm bloody), and went perfectly with the horseradish cream cheese and freshly leafed romaine lettuce.  the foccacia bread was perfect with it.

I've heard stories about their corned beef reuben-like sandwich.... need to come back for it.  they change their menu often so you won't get stuck in any ruts here!  They go for about $8.50 ea (inc tax), so while they aren't cheap, they also aren't gonna break your bank.

their fresh juices are great too--I had their green melon juice and it's perfect... just fresh blended fruit.  ahhh

line's out the door (it's a small place), so try to come early to beat the lunch rush.  you place orders from the stevenson st side.
author: Fong L.

description:
BREAKFAST~~ They have the BEST SEASONAL FRUIT MUFFINS here!! I've had their strawberry, pear, and blueberry muffins so far. They've had fig and some other fruits as well. The fruit they add into their HOT and FRESH BAKED muffins all depend on the season and the word delicious doesn't do them justice. The service is friendly and as fast as 1 or 2 people behind the counter could be. There's always a line for their coffee, espresso, and/or muffins. If you want to know what kind of muffins they have the day  you're craving one, call ahead of time and have them save you one. You'll be happy you did! 

NOTE: I hear their sandwiches are to die for as well. Check out their website!!
author: Rie P.

description:
I got the turkey meatball sandwich to be eaten on the train later... By the time I got to it, the bottom of the bread was soaked but still delicious.  The turkey meatballs themselves were pretty darn good, and I think the sauce was the real winner.  They were actually kinda hard to eat and I ended up just using a fork and a knife and eating the bread separately.  Overall, it was a very delightful meal.  I even saved half to be eaten a few hours later (room temp) and it was STILL good!  :)

I called in my order but arrived earlier than I said I would... and they made my sandwich on the spot so I only waited a minute -- definitely the way to go!
author: Lisa T.

description: I am not downtown as much as I used to be, so I hadn't been to The Sentinel in a while.  That while is long enough that I hadn't been since Dennis opened his next restaurant.  So the sandwiches were good, but not as good as when Dennis was here every day.  I don't know how much time he is putting in, but he should stop by and see if the quality is everything he wants, and everything I want.
author: Spike S.

description:
It's been a while since I've been to Sentinel and I felt like giving it another shot today since I didn't have the greatest experience. 

Today I ordered the deviled pork loin sandwich and it was much better than the previous lunch I had there. The pork was very moist and flavorful, the lettuce and nuts added some nice texture and crunch and the cream cheese helped bind it all together. 

I would definitely order this sandwich again!
author: Jason B.

description:
In-fill sandwich shop on an anonymous corner in the FiDi... nice. 
If you don't work downtown or can't get to the FiDi during the week, you're out of luck. Otherwise, this place is a decent addition to anyone's lunch routine. My pulled pork sandwich was delicious and gave me that gourmet boost for $9. Granted its a rotating menu but on that day, it was the *ish. Sure it's pricey for just a sandwich but that's life right.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: Disagree with 7x7 on this one. Corned beef is fine and dandy, but it's ALL ABOUT the salmon apple sando on brioche.
author: Amanda F.

description:
I love having breakfast at Canteen (motions at my Canteen review, heh), so when I read in the San Francisco magazine that the same chef opened up a sandwich shop in the Financial District, I had to go give it a try!  
 Gourmet lunch indeed!  We had the Corned Beef with Cabbage, Swiss, and Russian dressing sandwich, the Veal and Ricotta Meatball with tomato sauce and herbs sandwich, and an order of their Mushroom soup.  All of it was so amazingly delicious!  If only I actually worked in the city, then I wouldn't have to play hookie to indulge in their lunches!
author: Crys L.

description:
A tiny little corner packed tight with a line out the door, a high end chef at the grill, and 3 items- OH, wait, nope they're erasing that.. Okay, 2 items on the menu..

Hrrmm.. 

I ordered the Roast Beef Salad. At $11, I dunno.. I was expecting a nice big leafy salad with lots of.. Oh, I dunno.. salad?

*EHHHNNNNT* WRONG!

I opened up my cardboard container upon retrieval from the counter and found what looked to be several small chunks of meat, potatoes, in a flesh colored sauce. Yeah, that doesn't look like salad.. but. Yeah, okay. 

There was also a little coleslaw number side, and what looked to be a chocolate blob for dessert.

I dug in.

...?!

Wow! It was surprisingly good! The roast beef and potatoes were flavorful and had hints of lemon in the sauce that made it really different. The coleslaw was coleslaw, and the chocolate mousse was so rich and thick that one spoonful was 'sensory overload'.

I'd definitely check out the Sentinel again. I'd love to see 3 choices on the menu, and at $11, it's a bit pricey, but the food was good and it was interesting enough that I'd love to see what else he's got up his sleeve.
author: Katie A.

description: Finally I made it to the Sentinel and tried the corned beef and all I can say is wow. I am not a big fan of corned beef but whatever sauce they use in combination with the cabbage makes one great combination of sweet and sour. I will definitely be back.
author: Olga B.

description:
Exceptional food and service!!

I had the Corned Beef sammie and it was delicious!  Flat bread, CB, cabbage (but not the obnoxious sauerkraut-ee stuff; blech), Russian Dressing, and a homemade pickle. Just enough of everything and I was satisfied. Also tried the Cranberry Lemonade. Cannot wait to go back.

The service was really fast and the owner of this place had everyone moving in perfect time.
author: Sparkely K.

description: Food pretty good. Long line during lunch. Service flawed, inefficient. Price Moderate-high. Hours inconvenient. Space tiny. Credit card minimum $10.
author: Chris M.

description:
My wonderful friend, Erin treated me to a gourmet lunch at Sentinel and it was delicious!!

She tells me, "Dennis Leary, the chef at Canteen, just opened this little sandwich shop" and you can tell he knows what makes the perfect sandwich.  

I had the pork sandwich with fig jam and it was the perfect mix of sweet and salty.  She had the corned beef with gruyere and wow!  Best in the city fo' sho!

I'm so glad she let me in on this little secret because now I have the perfect lunch spot!   Thanks, Erin!!
author: Lauren C.

description:
Well well well, wasn't that a tasty treat.  Just ate her with my gal Jack-off, and i must say , she finally picked a good lunch spot!  I had the Turkey goat cheese meatball samich with tomato sauce, and it was MONEY!!!  I would come back here in a san francisco minute, might have to try that corned beef they have, sounds like an orgasm for the taste-buds!

"fuck me like a porcupine! i look like a fucking porcupine! winner winner porcupine fucking dinner!"
-Guy Fieri
author: John B R.

description:
After trying The Sentinel on two separate occasions, I can safely say that I've experienced better.

"Blasphemy!" you may shout, or "Heresy!" you may scream, but I speak the truth. Sentinel did  not blow me away, and I have had much better sandwiches in my day.

It wasn't the customer service or speed, because both times I've gone have been after 1:30 when there was no line and I was in and out in about 3 minutes. The first time I got the smoked salmon sandwich, which was good and today I got their corned beef Reuben, which was nontraditional but still tasty. The bread was excellent, there was just the right amount of Gruyere, the Russian dressing added a nice sweetness and the slaw gave it a crunch without the sloppiness caused by sauerkraut (though I must admit, I love the flavor of kraut and will deal with the messiness any day)

It was all good, solid food. But for $8.25 I was not wowed by this sandwich (and I expect to be wowed for that lunch price). Overall, I think Gregoire in the east bay is a much better choice. Same type of small shop, same fresh ingredients, same lunch specialties of gourmet sandwiches (think duck confit, shirred egg and anchovy, pancetta and tomato, seared scallops, leg of lamb, etc on sandwiches on a menu that rotates every month).

It was good, don't get me wrong. But for the same price point, Gregoire in Berkeley and Oakland are much better...
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Every day at lunch time, there is a brief moment when the corned beef sandwich from the Sentinel pops into my head. "Hellooooo, LIz.  Wouldn't you like to have lunch with me?" I went there a couple of months ago, so that means that a lot of corned beef sandwiches have been doing a lot of popping in my head.    It was SO good, that no matter where I am, I can envision myself driving downtown in a daze, lead by the memory of the sight and smell and taste of that tender, tasty corned beef and delicious bread.  

The special Pork Sandwich that we tried was good too.  The tomato soup was eh.  Stick with the sandwiches, I think.

I love Dennis Leary for being so present in his businesses - it's great to see him at the stove at Canteen or slinging sandwiches at the Sentinel.  And seriously, in a town full of mediocre sandwiches, I give him a lot of credit for opening up a "real" sandwich place.  The lines out the door speak to the need for such a business.  

It doesn't even matter that there is nowhere to eat.  I picture people hovered over their keyboards in the surrounding office buildings, hunkered down with their sandwiches like animals, making grunting sounds and not even bothering to wipe their mouths.  I'd be perfectly happy to sit on the curb and watch the weird homeless guy who likes to charge the opposite direction in traffic like the Don Quixote of SOMA.

One of these days very soon, I will indulge my fantasy and get myself down there again for that corned beef sandwich.  Until then, it will pop into my head on cue, same time, same bat channel.
author: Liz S.

description:
My 2010 quest for eating is to try at minimum two new places around my work each month.  This is not hard to do, considering I work in SOMA and this past week alone I think I actually went to 5.  Haha!  Anyway on to the review!

I have walked by here many many times but did not know this place actually existed until coworkers settled on going here.  It's not a sit down place, and they have a menu that apparently changes every day (which you can view online, score!).  So we looked at the menu before leaving and walked right over.  

There was a line, but it was not very long - about 15 people tops.  It went by really really fast.  I don't know how these people do it, there were at least 5-6 employees for a crowded sandwich joint on the corner, working with speed and knocking out those orders like it was no ones business.  I ordered the Coppa sandwich which basically is ike a glorified salami sandwich with mozarella, tomato, lettuce, and - interestingly - pumpkin pesto.  We got our food and took it back to the office.  The sammich was awesome!  Especially the hint of the pumpkin in the sandwich, it wasn't overpowering or crazy (which is what I was afraid of).  Sandwiches are on the more expensive side but it was a good healthy portion and I was full for the rest of the afternoon.

Next time I come back here, I am going for the corned beef.
author: Sonya T.

description:
I'm on a quest to fill out 7x7's Big Eat SF - 100 things to try before you die http://7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die. The Sentinel's Corned Beef Sandwich is #74 on the list. Check. 

So today, I ordered Corned Beef sandwich and watermelon-ade. The sandwich was good, not really something I feel like I needed to try before my untimely death, but tastey nonetheless. The bread was nice and buttery, with a fair amount of corned beef and crispy cabbage. The pickle that comes on the side wasn't as salty as I expected - and that was very nice. 

Watermelon-ade = agua fresca. It was oddly refreshing and filling at the same time. Also nice touch with the starburst dessert that was included. 

I'm no dainty little-thing, so I don't really understand what the other reviewers were talking about when referring to small portions. The sandwich was hearty and the portion was enough to fill me up for the remainder of the work day. Although, I have to admit that it was tempting to grab a cookie at Specialty's about 30mins after my meal...but that's a different review.
author: Laura R.

description:
Creative, gourmet lunch from a fast, friendly take-out stand on an SF street corner. Innovative sandwiches like pork loin and fig or vegetarian BLT (the B is for basil) for around $8 and a daily special with a side and dessert for $12. Food is freshly prepared on the spot, with fresh and healthy ingredients. Staff is cheerful, professional and move like a well-oiled machine, which is good because there's always a line.

Had heard about this place from co-workers, so went for the first time today. Had the special: a fritatta with corn, chorizio, potato and red salsa; a side of sauteed eggplant with light garlic and a dessert of sliced strawberries and melon topped with fresh, homemade whipped cream. A good-sized portion of fritatta and appropriately sized portions of the side and dessert, so that I didn't feel guilty (or stuffed) eating it all and didn't waste any food. Food was hot and well prepared.

Only gave it four stars as I've only tried it once.
author: Vince S.

description:
So I found out that I tore my tendon in my foot and that I will be in a walking boot for 2 months. During this horrible news I was fortunate enough to be half a block from Sentinel.

So I decided to eat my feelings in the form of a crispy yet moist chocolate chip cookie. Thank you Chef Leary for allowing me to eat my sorrow.
author: Roger H.

description: Lamb and eggplant was yummy, extraordinarily yummy,  but I found myself coveting my friend's mushroom sandwich. It looked amazing. Keeping it to a 4 for now because that means I need to return several times to do more "research" for my reviews....
author: Keri B.

description:
Cute hole in the wall. Really easy to miss.

Morning breakfast: They serve coffee (small $2), oatmeal, and home made delicious fruit muffins made from scratch. Daily flavors include peach, strawberry, blueberry. Really moist inside and made with lots of fresh fruits. Their oatmeal is mediocre; sadly they are not made with steel cut oatmeal. Mixed with a few chunks of fresh peaches and blueberries. Brown sugar topping is optional. 2 sizes: 1) small 8 oz. cost $3.25 or 2)12/16 oz. 

Lunch: Sandwiches only. Haven't tried it yet. 

BEWARE: They DO NOT ACCEPT credit cards in the mornings. Lunch time, minimum charge of $10.

No place to sit/stand.
author: Keiko C.

description:
I always wonder about places with lines out the door, but this one was worth the wait. At this lunchtime hotspot, a pricier $9 will get you the best sandwich the FiDi/SoMa no-man's-land has to offer. It looks really simple at first, perhaps a little too simple, but my corned-beef brisket sandwich on ciabatta bread with cabbage, Russian dressing and gruyere was delicious.

Since I have little to no patience when it comes to food,, I got here at the perfect time - 2 p.m., which was way after the lunch crowd, half an hour before they closed and half an hour before my nearby meeting started. The gal who took my order was very nice, and included an Andes chocolate mint with my meal. No lines, no wait, no lost patience.

A once-in-a-while treat for sure. And good motivation for me to walk it out later on!
author: Tara R.

description:
My favorite corned beef sandwich in the city is Sentinel's: tasty corned beef with with cabbage, Russian dressing and Swiss on tasty focacia.  It's a lunch-to-go place so don't expect any tables and chairs.  A good tip (particularly if it's raining) is to take your sandwich top nearby Crocker Galleria that has public indoor tables -- with heaters, too!

Don' forget to order their chocolate chip cookie -- it's huge and TASTY!

http://blog.junbelen.com/2010/03/17/best-corned-beef-sandwich-in-the-city/
author: Jun B.

description:
500 reviews. I stalled at 497 for, what, a year? I guess I was waiting for Dennis to do something wonderful. Canteen was reviewed in my first week of Yelping and is still my favorite place to have dinner in San Francisco. Maybe anywhere.

The Sentinel is downtown kiosk coffee and sandwich place you've always wanted. House made baked things, house made chai, excellent coffee and nothing under plastic wrap and no hating yourself for buying a $2 blueberry muffin that was manufactured for Costco. 

Haven't been for lunch yet but I hear the lines are extreme. A good excuse to leave the office early.
author: patrick g.

description:
I gave Sentinel a wide berth at first, but I've learned to appreciate it.  Sentinel is full of very adult-like flavors: eggplant, gruyere, fennel, and lots of things that seem pickled.  BUT it is also resplendent with deliciousness and if you're not afraid of some of these things it can be very rewarding (except eggplant.  never, EVER lose your fear of eggplant.  srs.).  They make some great meals - the corned beef and the pork loin are tops - and they have delicious fresh juices which go a long way for me.  I'm a big juice guy.

Sentinel is a cool idea and they execute on it really well.  Stuff on the menu is always varying, not the least reason for which is that they're frequently out of popular items by the time I get there at 1:00 or 1:30.  Insider tip: lots of stuff comes /back on/ the menu after it initially sells out, so don't only go by what's crossed out on the taped-up menu in the window; make sure you query the cute register girl to see if your preference really is available.
author: Oliver N.

description: Solid lunch time sandwiches. I usually go for the shredded pork or roast beef. I wish there was more of a variety from week to week though.
author: Huy T.

description:
The Sentinel is a great place to pick up a soup, salad, or sandwich for lunch. I say "pick up" because there's nowhere to really sit in here.  

The corned beef sandwich may very well be the best thing on the menu. Corned beef, gruyere, cabbage (seems to be somewhat pickled) and russian dressing fill 2 slices of warm foccacia bread for $8.75. Yep, kinda steep for what it is, but unfortunately these are the prices you pay for lunch in the city. Though they change the menu with the seasons, you can expect this one to stay on throughout the year.

It's hard not to like this sandwich (since I love all of those ingredients separately), but make sure you eat it while it's hot. No one likes a cold corned beef sandwich without the gooey cheese. Also, if you're here during the summer, try the watermelonade - it's super refreshing and tastes like you just bit into an ice cold slice of watermelon - but better.

Also, the corned beef sandwich is on the 7x7 The Big Eat SF: 100 Things to Try Before You Die List.
author: Melissa P.

description:
Love the concept. Absolutely dig the food. 

The Sentinel is yet another reason why SF is a great city to live in. 

Since the menu changes daily, I'm not sure that this review will be of any help to anyone reading it for recommendations. But the shrimp salad I had a month ago was very, very good. Just enough seasoning to complement the tasty shellfish.

Before that I had a smoked salmon sandwich which was also very tasty.  

Now if I could only make it there in time for breakfast...
author: Stephanie I.

description:
First off, I go here about 3 x's a week.  They all pretty much know my name now  :) - but whatever,  I'll respond to anything just to get one of these damn good sandwiches.  The "specials" are always extremely unique and paired nicely.  On any given day you can get scallop ceviche or some huge sausage plate.  If you're new though, as everyone else recommends, I would go with one of the sandwiches.

I'm dreaming about the Pork/Fig sandwich now.  It's sloppy, it tastes crazy, and it is F'ing awesome.  The bbq beef is also sloppy goodness!   Everyone there is "kept it real" cool - especially the owner.  No nonsense, high quality food that's worth splurging on.  Screw you subway and your processed meats.  I would pay twice as much for half as much food when it comes to the Sentinel.
author: Danny C.

description:
It's not quite living up to the hype that it's getting.  

My sandwich was totally lacking and the service is a little "raw".  And for $12 I would expect more.  

Why 2 stars then?  When my coworker got a sandwich from here, he gave me a bite and his was WAY better.  Booooooo.
author: Bhumika K.

description:
Sandwiches i've tried since my last review:

- ground lamb w/ eggplant and raisins: really good. The lamb is a tad too game-y though. However still tender, served warm so it's all good. I like the sweetness of the golden raisins.

- egg salad: Nothing spectacular about it. Just your average egg salad sandwich. Still good though.

- spicy tuna w/ fennel and green beans: the tuna is really fresh and fennel with anything is good. It's a really light sandwich so after a couple of ours I found myself hungry again. It is not too spicy.

- fresh yellowtail w/ fennel: 2nd favorite after the fresh/smoked salmon sandwich. The yellowtail is slightly seared and the fennel just gives it the right amount of crunchiness. It's a messy sandwich though because it drips everywhere.

- roast beef: not my fav. It had blue cheese spread in it. I don't like blue cheese so this sandwich did not make it to the top of my list.
author: Terry D.

description: We got there about 2 minutes before 11AM.  When we tried to order lunch at the counter we were sternly instructed that they were open for lunch AT 11AM.  But that's ok; for the greatest corned beef sandwich in SF one can overlook a little quirkiness.  But the sandwich was only ok.  The corned beef and sauerkraut was too little; and the bread and russian dressing was too much.  Still looking for something SF closer to the  number 19 at Langers in LA.
author: Jim L.

description:
the sentinel is going to my new go-to place for breakfast on the way to work. i had the warm blueberry muffin today and it was so good! thanks holly for giving me a sample of the coffee cake too :) 

i can't wait when they add some egg dishes and house made granola with yogurt on the morning menu.

my only gripe is that they are not open on the weekends....
author: Helen Y.

description:
I'm sold.  Has been on my list to try for a while, not sure what the heck took me so long.  Finally made it this week.  Went Tuesday for lunch and was pretty blown away by how good the corned beef sandwich actually was.   Was trying to hold off on going back because, well, I'm cheap and I don't like to spend $8.50 on lunch p/day, especially since I won't have a job soon... BUT I couldn't, I was back by Thursday!!  Then my friend was telling me how awesome their muffins were... so today, where do I end up at 8am this morning?  Back at the Sentinel for a steaming hot cranberry muffin right out the oven.  MMMmmm, it was SOOO good, I could have easily eaten 3 muffins.  But beware, if you just were walking by, it would not be obvious that they even have breakfast stuffs.  They're not displayed, nor is there a menu.  Basically, you have to ask to find out what they have.  

p.s. I would highly recommend calling ahead to pre-order lunch if you're planning on going during the height of the lunch hour.
author: Yvette H.

description:
I always get this whenever I am on lunch because 1) it is close by 2) REALLY great sandwiches 3) love the complimentary Andes 

My favorites are the corned beef and smoked tuna. The menu changes which is great because it is a sign they use really good ingredients. I was not that fond with the lamb meatballs, but personal feelings because it was a little too much gameness in a sandwich and really saucy.
author: Tif L.

description:
Today's lunch special was a warm corned beef sandwich w/ gruyere, served on ciabatta and pressed.  Sounds yum, huh?  I'm sure it was...I ordered it, but when I got back to my office I had a cold Turkey sandwich instead :(  It was a cold day, so I was really excited for that corned beef sandwich...

That said, the Turkey sandwich was damn good!  The bread was really fresh and light, the turkey very fresh and it had a tasty spiced mayo that really topped it off nicely.

Bottom line, you know you have a great new lunch spot when you're really excited for your lunch, get the wrong order and are STILL really satisfied...I definitely be back...but will have to reserve that 5th star for my corned beef experience.
author: John R.

description: Believe the hype. This was one of the best sandwiches of my life, and I've had a few...If it's on the menu, order the smoked trout with fennel ,tarragon and apple. The roll was challah-ish and topped with the black seeds that we call charnishka. Delicious chocolate chip and nut cookie for dessert.  Now I'm determined to try every sandwich ( that doesn't involve pork or shellfish).
author: Bleep S.

description: Good stuff.  The corned beef as a whole was good.  The extra oil they throw on the bread is unnecessary imo.  The meat itself was delicious.  The pickle could use some improvement.  Overall a good spot to check out for lunch if you haven't all ready.
author: Ken B.

description:
Being a big Canteen fan, I have no excuse for it taking me so long to try Sentinel. Went down there for lunch today hoping for the famous Corned Beef sandwich but no go...all they had was a tuna tartare. I bit.

Now...a hot (very hot for SF) afternoon and tuna tartare. There are two ways to think about that. Tuna getting funky on a day in the high 90s or a crisp, fresh light lunch. The latter for sure. Dunno if it was the weather or not but this was one fantastic lunch. The tuna was super fresh and seasoned with just a bit of a kick to it. The best I've had? Probably not but close. Walking around SOMA with a cardboard carrier eating cool tartare. Great meal, great price, I'll be back. Like the  tiny size of the shop, aint much more to say so I'll keep it short. 

Check this place out for lunch if you're in the area and you can't go wrong.

5 stars
author: Gary C.

description:
OK on a good streak now.  Tried three new places in two days and everything has been really good.  Got the tip from Nadim on this place and decided to get lunch there just now.  Got the corned beef sammie as well as the butternut squash soup (can never resist that) and am stuffed now and sated!

The sandwich was huge and by itself would have been a good meal but adding the soup and only the late Andre the Giant would not be full.  Staff was super nice and if it was nicer outside it would have been a perfect lunch to eat outside, but I guess most folks going here are FiDi or maybe the art students down the road.

Good eats fo sho!
author: Gene X.

description:
I've been on a huge salmon kick after I found out that it's not only sustainably farmed and caught, but it's also high in anti-inflammatories and healthy stuff.

This means I eat a lot of Salmon.

Luckily, the smoked salmon sandwich is unbelievable at The Sentinel.  And that horseradish sauce and and roll that encase this nutritious morsel of protein is absolutely savory and sweet all at the same time.  Definitely my new favorite thing on the menu.
author: Audrey T.

description:
This is one high class deli/lunch stand.  The Sentinel occupies a tiny broom closet-sized space in a corner of the FiDi, but you'll see the line far out the door.  My co-workers love their pork loin.  The menu only has about 4 items each day, so I recommend checking out what's on it first if you're a vegetarian.  They usually have one veggie item per day and there's only a few I like.

I had an amazing sammy here the other day with grilled mushrooms, swiss chard, goat cheese, and raisins(!).  They always give you a pickle and a little chocolate too.  I recommend trying their pomegranate-ade as well.
author: Sid D.

description:
Where's the beef?

I absolutely HATE lines.  I wouldn't stand in line for anything, especially a sandwich.  (For our readers on the East Coast, I wouldn't stand ON line for anything).

So, we came here at 11:15 on Friday to avoid standing in line.  We did avoid the lines, in a way.  Apparently, they didn't serve lunch until 11:30.  Still, the friendly clerk at the counter took our order and our money and told us to come back at 11:30.  I showed up at 11:32, and had to wait 3-4 more minutes because our food wasn't ready yet.  No big deal, I can wait.

I kind of like the shop itself.  Sure, the name makes you think of a small-town newspaper (The Poughkeepsie Sentinel, for example).  However, the decor is reminiscent of an old New York deli.  It's a tiny place with a tiny kitchen and no place to sit.  The 1950s cash register encased in old mahogany - very stylish.  Unfortunately, the comparisons to New York delicatessen end here.

I ordered the corned beef sandwich ($8.25) and a cup of acorn squash soup ($5.50).  The soup was NOT a good value.  A cup, although pretty big, was only 3/4 full.  The soup, which was supposed to be a puree, had the consistency of water.  I wish they had given me a straw instead of a spoon.  The corned beef sandwich itself was very tasty: grilled panini with onions, cabbage, Gruyere cheese and Russian dressing.  What was missing, however, is corned beef.   Two measly slices?  Are you kidding me?  Carnegie Deli in NYC gives you more corned beef than you can shake a stick at.  

If they want to establish themselves as a "New York Deli," they should really consider not skimping on the meat.  Yes, it's a delicious sandwich, and a very popular one, might I add.  However, until they decide to add some meat, I probably won't rush back.

As my coworker said, "it was the best five-dollar sandwich I've ever had."  My Sentinel sentiments exactly.

I ask you again, Where's the beef?
author: Yan G.

description:
3.5 stars for overall experience - I know I know, how can I?  I really want to LOVE it but I didn't.  Maybe it was all the great reviews I've read (not just on Yelp) that really setup some serious expectation that is nearly impossible to meet.  Folks, I took a day off and drove all the way here to try the infamous sandwich - even got there way early, too early.  Got there at 10:15am and Dennis Leary was the only person at the little shop.  I didn't know they don't serve lunch until 11am but he said I can place my order and come back.  He was busy and preoccupied and not very friendly but then I guess he's a famous chef and taking order is not his daily task.

Decided to try the brisket sandwich and be back at 11am.   Drove around, no space and parked at the Mission garage.  It was still too early but it was a nice day.  There is now a staff in the small kitchen working and a cashier.  Decided to get the lemonade while debating on the soup and the special salad.  

At 11am sharp, the cashier called my name.  The lunch came with a small sweet treat - andes mint.  Walked to the closest shady spot and dug in - it was good, just wasn't a WOW.  It's definitely not a deli sandwich but a sandwich you will find in a fine restaurant.  The sandwich is on the smaller size, lean on meat,  plenty slaw, and a flavorful sauce.  The pickle was not good.

Won't go out of my way but will try again if in the neighborhood.  Will likely try the salmon sandwich.
author: Gloria H.

description:
The chicken chipotle sandwich is DELICIOUS.  Someone brought it in for lunch today so I haven't checked out the venue yet but having a taste of this sandwich has me hungry to try the others.  But from what I understand the venue doesn't really matter since you can't eat there.

Definitely try these sandwiches!
author: James G.

description:
Because I'm having a bit of a challenging day I decided to treat myself to lunch at Sentinel.  

I've been for lunch a couple times before and have always been pleased.  Pleased in that I can tell that the food is made with great care, and I don't make that comment lightly.

When I walked up today and saw the rare roast beef on rye on the menu board the food memory hit me square in the face.  

In my college years, I'd often walk into my grandma's living room to find her sitting on the floor, my grandfather in his favorite easy chair, both of them accompanied with sandwiches on paper plates.  
"We're having rare roast beef on rye, do you want some?" she'd chime hopefully.  
"No gram, I'm not eating meat" I'd say.  
"Well, I just don't know how you do that" she say disappointed, as if it was the first time she'd heard of such a thing.  
Our conversation moved swiftly on as she was a marvel of a woman who enjoyed so much in life and was always eager to hear what I had to say.  

I miss her tremendously but hopefully she saw me order and savor my rare roast beef with horseradish on rye today.  Here's to you gram.

Many thanks to Sentinel for triggering that memory.  On a side note, the strawberry rhubarb crisp was phenomenal.  Chef DL has a way with fruity buttery goodness.  Yup gram, it was even better than the Entemann's coffee cake you used to always keep in the freezer.
author: Kiki R.

description:
Who should check this place out for lunch: all people of all races and backgrounds who love peace, happiness, sex, puppies, happy babies, and most importantly good food.  This place is just so damn good.

People who should avoid this place: Evil, malicious, smelly people who live like trolls in dirty, stanky-ass caves and hate freedom, chocolate gold coins, love, and really tasty lunches.  

The menu is ever-changing, but a few highlights: scallop ceviche with cucumber and fresh dill, turkey pastrami sandwich, and the pork-shoulder with sweet corn sandwich.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Sandwich serenity. My roasted salmon on a seeded bun with horseradish mayo, watercress, and fennel felt like a heavenly indulgence. The seeded bun was toasted and the corners had a satisfying crunch while the inside was tender and moist. I ate at the counter in front of the tiny kitchen watching Chef owner Dennis Leary hustle to keep up with the line. An assistant and a cashier are the only other two people behind the counter. 

It's food made in small quantities with thoughtfulness behind the texture and flavor. The interior is spare but only to put attention on the food, which is prepared with passion.
author: Netty L.

description:
I'm sold. 

Breakfast - Gotta get the muffins. I've had their oatmeal, it was pretty good too. I like their coffee. I read a review that said they didn't like the coffee because it was plain. Well I don't know about you but in the morning most people like their coffee simple, saving that over-caloried sugar filled flavored heart attack in a cup of coffee for later when you need that extra kick of sugar to keep you going through your workday.

Lunch - If it's lunchtime right now you need to stop reading my review and go stand in line. I've never had a bad sandwich here, no pre-wrap crap. I love their regular sandwiches but you should check out their daily specials online, www.thesentinelsf.com. Prices are great (considering the area) and the portion is really big (not with soup). I would suggest that you CALL IN YOUR ORDER, that way you can go straight to the cashier. You could also avoid the lunch hour, before noon or a little after one. I would go earlier than later because they run out of ingredients. Check their doors to see what sandwiches are still left. Their soup is alright, not too much of a favorite. 

I think the service is also what makes the Sentinel, the Sentinel. They're so friendly and personal. Not too mention I love how the cashiers work that old school register.

**If it really is lunchtime and you made it to the bottom of my review, shame on you for wasting some precious Sentinel sandwich time. Now go get one!!**
author: Jamie Q.

description: A co-worker had recommended The Sentinel and after seeing the sandwich she got there I was really curious about checking it out.  It's a bit of a walk from my work but I met a friend as it was a midway point for us so it all worked out.  We didn't get there until a little later in the afternoon and a lot of sandwiches were already gone and the one I wanted (roast beef with sharp cheddar) was gone so I went with the often written and talked about corned beef.  I'm not a huge corned beef fan but I loved this sandwich.  Everything about it had tasty written all over it from the sauce to the bread to the actual meat.  Kudos Sentinel!
author: Blake B.

description:
Update: So, I decided to return a day later to try my luck again at the Sentinel, even after coworkers joked that I'd get my food spit in. Scary thought, but this isn't McDonald's. I'd return anywhere else if the food is good enough. A bad experience is unlikely to keep me away, so back I went.

I stood in line and Chef Sentinel took my order- and moved on to the next person. I wasn't done ordering. Understandable, as I'm sure most people are only ordering for themselves, or they call ahead for a larger order, and they need to be quick about it. 

I continued my order with Holly, who recognized my name right away from the Yelp review I posted yesterday. She immediately poured me the glass of lemonade I had ordered and apologized. As for the Nazi- Well, I won't apologize for my honesty yesterday. That's what Yelp is for- Real People, Real Reviews. And you got it. But maybe I was a little harsh-but he was not a Nazi today- and I could hear him just fine. I might have even seen a small smile! 

I don't know that I've been anywhere and had someone knowingly and willingly be so responsive to correct a downfall. +1 star, and thanks very much for that. My Corned Beef with Gruyere sandwich is fantastic, the lemonade is perfect, and I just received a "Yum! So Good!" email from my coworker about the eggplant sandwich. I will be back, and my coworkers will likely also be sure to follow.
author: Panda B.

description:
While training at Learn IT on New Montgomery, I had the pleasure of a sandwich from the Sentinel. I chose the corned beef sandwich on flat bread, with Gruyere cheese, caramelized onions and a bed of cole slaw. All this comes neatly packaged in a Earth friendly cardboard container with a proper sized pickle. Does it sound delicious and mind blowing? It should, because it was! 

The Sentinel is a corner side sandwich shop, there is no seating so everything is to go. No big deal for folks on the run, but in general I like a place to sit and enjoy my lunch with some lunchtime conversation with colleagues. 

I was pleased to see chef Dennis Leary working out at the counter with his team to put the final touches on the sandwiches before handing them off to the customers. His staff is very nice and accommodating, no doubt I'll be back. 

The Sentinel is right outside the entrance of 33 New Montgomery
author: Eric L.

description:
You'll notice that the people who complain about this place either a) don't get that the staff is trying to turn over orders quickly or b) are from NYC and like to complain that anything outside of NYC should never be considered real cuisine.  To them I say, you have to appreciate The Sentinel for what it is -- a superb sandwich stand (not deli, depite the corned beef) that's low on frills.

The pickles are the perfect compliment to any sandwich.  Of which my current favorites are the salmon and the chicken (sometimes turkey) salad.  Both selections are light yet filling.  The salmon has just enough smokeyness and dill to be flavorful without being overpowering or giving you fish breath.  The chicken salad packs a nice mini-punch with the lemon and chili, and isn't heavy on mayo.

Word to the wise -- go around 11:45am.  Know exactly what you want when you go.  You'll be in and out of there in about 6 minutes.  Note that Dennis will sometimes ask you what your order is before the girl at the counter can get to you (in which case, repeat order to her again to help that line move along).  

Enjoy...and if you don't, stop going so I don't have to wait as long next time.
author: Deidre B.

description:
The corned beef sandwich was the BEST corned beef sandwich I've ever had. I was completely wowed by not only the sandwich but by the utter awesomeness of the staff. 

Because I had been underwhelmed on my first visit, and then overwhelmed by how good that corned beef sandwich was, I've been back a couple times to try the smoked trout sandwich and the pulled pork sandwich. They were both okay, just like turkey sandwich I had on my first visit. Since the pulled pork sandwich was advertised to have figs in it, I expected figs. Instead, it was a figgy jam, so not what I expected. There was also too much pulled pork and not enough of the other ingredients. The smoked trout sandwich had too much mayo (like the pulled pork sandwich). 

I'll probably go back next time I have a hankering for corned beef.
author: Sahra H.

description:
I just ate here for lunch, and I wholeheartedly agree with Jack S.'s sentiments (http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-sentinel-san-francisco#hrid:WkE7zj1f43Fk77xe1f8UeQ). In fact, aside from his observation of the "Woohoo! As good as it gets!" text that I truly never noticed, everything he wrote also applies to me. So, let's just pretend that I wrote the very same thing. I feel so eloquent right now.

In addition to the tasty food, I noticed a power outlet under the front counter. Why is it there? What is its purpose? Could I recharge my phone while waiting for my food? Food for thought.
author: Tavi N.

description:
This place rocks!!  I am new to SF, but not so new to the culinary scene of New York and LA.  The portions are just right.  The food is incredibly fresh and well prepared.  The price is right, too.  $8.00 for a sandwich.  You do get what you pay for.  

If you are looking for bulk at a better price point, there is a Subway, like a block away for those on a budget or who prefer quantity over quality.

I'll go with Sentinel instead.
author: D M.

description: A bit hyped up. The options were intriguing, but the sandwich itself was just skimpy on fillings. There was not much meat, there was not much cole slaw, it was ok. Might stop by another time, might not. Im impartial.
author: Benjamin K.

description:
Really good sandwich place.  It gets busy at around 12:20 (lunch time). make sure you reach there at around 11:50 and you will get your sandwich faster :)

I got the roast beef sandwich and loved it. I am going here again for sure.
author: Rohit B.

description: Located on the corner of New Montgomery and Stevenson, this tiny sandwich shop is hardly noticeable upon first glance, but a snaking line of people emanating out of it during lunch time makes it hard to miss. So why do many people flock here? Well, there are four reasons: (a) the sandwiches are decent, (b) speed, (c) speed, (d) speed. Yes, they are super fast. Subway fast! Minus the generic frozen ingredients! The most I've waited for my sandwich after placing my order here was probably a minute or two. But alas, being a vegetarian, my choice of sandwiches is fairly limited. Ahem, in other words, there is only one sandwich I can go for. Now, the good thing is that they rotate their menu ever so often, so sometimes the veggie sandwiches are 'meh', while on other occasions they are awe-frikkin-delicious! My personal favorite was the Curry Cauliflower (please please please I want that back on the menu!), which they had on the menu some time last year. But since then the veggie sandwiches they've had haven't been much to my liking. In any case, if you're not a vegetarian, do check it out...`coz I heard from my meat eating friends that the sandwiches here taste good.
author: Srivatsan S.

description:
Fastest quality sandwich place I know of.

SANDWICH:
I had the trout sandwich, which had a nice amount of salad filling. It was juicy. The bits of apple were nice. Bread was soft.

"SMOKED TROUT salad with fennel, apples, and parsley - 8.75" (Menu)

The sandwich also came with a pickle slice and an Andes mint.


DESSERT:
I got the chocolate chip cookie for $2.50 - it was a good size, but there were nuts in the cookie. I wasn't a fan, as I prefer a softer, nut-free, intense chocolate-filled chocolate chip cookie.


AMBIENCE: Happening during lunchtime. Very much a grab and go place.

SERVICE: Fine. Tax is included in the listed prices. They were fast at churning out sandwiches.

VISIT DETAILS: Lunch with a couple co-workers. Recommended by a foodie friend.
author: C L.

description:
09/29/10 - I was craving the corned beef sandwich last week and couldn't wait to get my hands on it.  We grabbed our sandwiches, walked over to Crocker Galleria found a perfect table to sit at and finally I was able to unwrap my bountiful sandwich...NOT!  Where's the beef?  This sandwich used to have so much meat in it you would have to stop and think how or where do I bite this sandwich?  Now it's a bread and cabbage sandwich with a splash of corned beef and I was truly disappointed.  I hope I happened to go on a day where they were low in corned beef because it was definitely lacking in that department.





I decided to write a review on Sentinel because I'm craving for one of the corned beef sandwiches right now!  You have to get there early before they run out of their delicious sandwiches and they don't have seating so plan on going to crocker galleria or back to your own lunch to take a seat.  You want to be seated to enjoy this perfectly put together sandwich.  Salty corned beef and cabbage on warm focaccia bread...yumm!  I've yet to try their other sandwiches but I'm going back for corned beef right  now..
author: Michelle D.

description:
OK, someone told me that I needed to switch up my morning coffee and bran muffin routine and hit The Sentinel for a fresh cup of coffee and warm pastry, that they could not be beat. For the last year and a half I have been walking right by this place with no clue!! Love love love them. The last week my mornings have been brighter and much yummier than normal. A little stand, no real menu or anything priced-- you can walk right on by this place and not know it is as a phenomenal coffee shop. They are on the corner of a busy walk way and all you may see are people standing in line. No signs posted saying they are even there-- it's like a hidden local gem. The mocha is made just right, but the morning pastries are to die for. Sour Cherry muffins, cinnamon coffee cake and a French toast type of pastry... all still warm and smelling freshly baked like they are. Everything was mixed and baked the same day, not frozen and then baked the same day and shipped in like some corporate coffee places all over the city. I just found out that they have lunch and am looking forward to trying lunch there soon!
Kudos to this place, it is a true find!
author: Rachell M.

description:
Just got a late lunch of chicken salad- super tasty with pine nuts, golden rasins and a mustard dressing. Pretty light on the greens with fennel (but I'm hoping that has to do with the fact that it was one of the last chicken salads served.) Served with a caraway seed bread and a side of sweet roasted rhubarb that was an excellent way to end the meal.

Not sure if it was worth a $10 takeout but good nonetheless. I'll be back to try the other menu items since it's close to work.
author: Emily L.

description: So...Finally, a great, enjoyable lunch. I work around the soma, so getting lunch can be frustrating...due to the long lines and wait, but when I found this spot for lunch today, the wait was literally under 5 mins. I ordered the corned beed sandwich with swiss and it was A-M-A-Z-I-N-G. I'd give it 5 stars, but because they did not include any napkins, it was a bit messy. That was probably the only downside of this meal.. Other than that, it was bomb . com . The bread was yummy, and their russian sauce was scrumptious. Must come again!
author: Colette P.

description:
YUM....OMG....YUM!!  

the corned beef and smoked trout sandwiches are lip-smackin, finger-lickin, moan-with-your-mouth full oh so good!!  These hot little numbers must be devoured immediately!  I top it off with their freshly squeezed orange-ginger juice and I'm one satisfied woman!  I usually don't go for sandwiches during lunch but damn, I'm salivating just thinking about this tiny little place.

Call ahead if you don't want to stand in the long line but it moves pretty quickly so not a big deal.
author: Sara M.

description:
When the Sentinel didn't offer vegetarian options, I lived vicariously through my coworkers' stomachs.  Before I ordered something for myself, I almost thought this place was a joke -- everyone would hem and haw,  oooo and ahhhhh, as if their trout salad or spicy ceviche was actually going down on them, rather than in them. You dig?

I'm no skeptic; in fact, if I hear that something is evenly remotely decent, I'll be first one stuffing it in my mouth or putting it on my credit card or trying it on for size. However, the zealous and over-the-top emphasis put on the Sentinel food made me cock my head for a while.

AND THEN.  

They added a vegetarian option to their limited menu.  I am now a believer. 

Even if my BBQ eggplant sandwich with goat cheese has yet to chomp my box, I still understand the hype.
author: Chloe S.

description:
3 things to know:

Very creative
Taste great
Not a lot of meat
author: Marvin N.

description:
Man - it was really hard to decide whether to give this place four or five stars, but as a web developer I've got a soft spot for restaurants with well-designed web sites, and The Sentinel's is just beautiful, so there you have it.

Went here for lunch and was immediately torn between four different choices. Also, we spent the majority of our ten-minute line-wait trying to decide whether the bay shrimp salad was in sandwich form or salad form, which didn't do much to help me collect my thoughts. I wasn't alone in my indecision, though, and so, once we found out that the shrimp was indeed in sandwich form, we ended up splitting the veal-and-ricotta-meatball-sandwich and the bay-shrimp-salad-with-avocado-and-dill-sandwich.

We walked down to the park by the Metreon and ate our delicious bounty in the sun, and man oh man were those good sandwiches. In the red corner, the veal-and-ricotta meatballs were great, and the cheese really pulled the whole thing together. And in the blue corner, the shrimp-salad-in-sandwich-form was nothing short of rejuvenating. I felt distinctly better when I was finished eating it than I felt beforehand, which I can't say about many of my other favorite foods [*cough* nick's crispy tacos *cough*]. 

I'll definitely be coming back - I won't be able to rest until I've tried the pork-loin-and-apricot-and-muenster, not to mention the corned beef.
author: JR H.

description:
The Sentinel makes me wish I was a working girl, and I could stop by daily for lunch making googly eyes at the ginger-y Dennis Leary while munching counter-side in my power pumps. 
       Instead, I inhaled today's lunch special in the wind tunnel alley beside the restaurant, amongst the ambience of motorcycle parking and meandering panhandlers, fingers numbed from the 60 degree July day we call "summer."
       The suffering was worth it. Oh, how to be inventively superlative about the bockwurst with polenta and braised radicchio, not to mention the blueberry cake with sugary crumb topping. A perfect lunch on a miserable fog encased day: warm, comforting, fresh and delicious.
author: Lee T.

description:
4.75
Does anyone use the word gourmet anymore?  I think these are gourmet sandwiches, yeah i said gourmet, mmmmmmmm!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

And yes the srevice is super friendly, unfortunately you can only get these gourmet sanwiches to go.
author: Aaron I.

description: After 5 years of me working down the street, I was sad to discover this place the 2nd to last month I was still in SF.  I had passed by numerous times, but the long line out the door around the corner had always turned me off.   One day while passing by I had discovered that there were about 2 people in line.  That was a definite first, for lunch time, but it looks like everyone was at Sushiritto down the block.  I ordered the corned beef sandwhich, and that was definitely to die for.  The meat was perfect and the russian dressing made it that much more perfect.  Plus a pickle?  I was definitely in heaven.  On top of that the ladies behind the counter were friendly and attentive.  A definite must stop at least once a month SF lunch spot.
author: Ang H.

description:
I've been dying to eat here ever since I heard of its opening and I was beyond excited to visit early in the morning and get some breakfast.  Apparently, this is the best time of day to come because there is no line and you can watch the chef all you want (I tried not to stare too hard at him!).

In any case, Chef Leary makes an insanely good sour cherry muffin.  When its fresh out of the oven, warm, with a light dusting of powdered sugar,  its the most ridiculously tasty breakfast you can get.  Studded with whole cherries that burst with tart juices, the muffin was moist and light.  Along with a small coffee (really good by the way), it makes for a meal that just starts your day off right.

Unfortunately, I haven't had the chance to go for lunch, but you can be sure that next time I'm in the area, I'll be there in line like everyone else, waiting for a gourmet lunch.
author: Angela H.

description:
I'm reducing my rating to 3 stars to reflect how hit or miss Sentinel can be. Their muffins are still a must-have. Doesn't matter if you like what's in them, they are always ungodly good! With their muffins being so good, I wondered if I was missing out on their other breakfast items. Nope, nothing to miss there. I've tried the coffee cake and brioche and neither came in comparison to the muffins. 

As for the sandwiches, it pains to me say that I had an awful experience once with the turkey meatloaf sandwich. It was cold! I found it strange when the sandwich came out within seconds of me placing the order but I figured maybe they found a way to optimize the process. Nope - they just forgot to heat it up, or something. It was nast. I had another recent disappointing experience with their special lunch entree - braised veal breast with macaroni, mushroom salad, and chocolate something or other. The veal and macaroni were good but very light and not filling enough. Mushroom salad was fine. But the chocolate something or other, wtf. It was a blob of gritty, ultra thick chocolate frosting mixture. Completely inedible and a waste of $11.

Despite my inconsistent experiences, I'll still go to Sentinel. There's something about their cute little corner space and smiling faces that will always make me come back. Next up, I'm trying the salmon!
author: Susan L.

description:
This little take-out spot is the yummiest sandwich spot around the Financial District.
I come here at least once a week since I work around the corner. 

Recommendations: 
ANY breakfast muffin, they are so fresh, moist, and warm in the middle you swear you've been to heaven and back after eating one.

The Roast Beef sandwich which they only have in the summer I believe.
