The cookies are freshly made everyday, they are way better than Specialty's down the road.
author: Brenda I.

description:
Coming to the Sentinel for lunch is always an adventure as you never know what you're gonna get. They have about 6-7 sammy choices (there's always a veggie option), with usually some sort of pork/ham, chicken, or corned beef concoction. 

Although my sandwiches have always tasted pretty good, there was one sandwich that just freaked me out. I don't recommend the Deviled Ham sandwich unless you like eating hundreds of tiny squares of ham (I apparently don't). Still, I appreciate the chef's forays into culinary adventures.

Don't let the line out the door freak out you. It goes pretty fast!
author: Ava S.

description:
I usually fixate on a particular dish or restaurant until I've overdosed, but I think my addiction to The Sentinel is permanent. After several months of making two, maybe three trips a week to this hole-in-the-wall spot, the idea of getting a sandwich anywhere else still strikes me as ludicrous. 

People line up early, so shoot for noon if you want to avoid the crowds and ensure that you don't miss out on the more popular items (arrive at 2:00 and half the menu will be crossed out). The staff is awesome - I'm impressed (and mildly embarassed) that the cashier knows me by name, which she'll write on a color-coded post-it for orders - crazy system, but it seems to work. 

Lately I'm a fairly consistent hot pink post-it - the turkey meatloaf is ridiculous. I'd never consider myself a meatloaf kind of girl (I don't think I'd ever even tasted meatloaf before) but this sandwich comes with some crazy delicious chipotle spread and juicy cranberries. But the real superstar is the bread - fresh from the oven and definitely the key to The Sentinel's sucess. I can also recommend with the upmost confidence the bbq eggplant sandwich, the spicy chicken salad, and, if you don't mind a post-lunch food coma, the corned beef with gruyere. Eat your heart out.
author: A M.

description:
This review is only about the blue berry muffin.

My friends, there is a place where muffin tops and their base are treated as equals.  Where the tops are just a prelude to the festive soul of the base.   Where blueberries flow from the entire spectrum of muffin...top to bottom.   The warm slightly, chewy/crispy outer mushroom top is finished and completed by the soft and warm embrace of her foundation (the bottom).  I was once a cynic against all things that diluted the effects of my morning coffee, but atlas, I have found her,...the perfect blueberry muffin- by the Sentinel.

happy eating!
author: Sam K.

description: Decent sandwich, I'd go back.   Fast service despite the line.
author: Michael E.

description: The Sentinel experience is unique.  I walk over to pick up lunch at least once a week -- not because I think the food is that much better than the many good choices in this neighborhood  (sandwiches are  better, but the selection is limited and I don't like the salads the entrees come with dessert which I try to avoid).  I go to the The Sentinel because they have put a level of personality into the lunch pick-up experience that I have never seen.  Holly knows my name (finally I can remember hers, part of my reason for posting is so I don't forget it AGAIN).  My order is taken on a color-coded postit.  Dennis Leary is charming and focused.  As I said, unique.
author: Robin W.

description: I had the cornbeef sandwhich and it was fabulous. Make sure you get there before the line wraps around the block!!
author: Nii M.

description:
Just went there for lunch.  I liked the "creative" sandwich menu.  It's not *really* creative because I can make all this stuff at home on my own given the right ingredients.  But this is a bit better than Boudin.  

I ordered the B.A.L.T. (basil, avocado, lettuce, tomato) with goat cheese on white.  Eight dollars!!!  Pricey for a sandwich, in my opinion.  And because I didn't have any cash (they accept cards, cool), I had to buy something else (watermelon juice for $3) to hike the bill up to the $10 minimum for using a credit card.  Lame.  So my just-OK lunch was $11 total.

Aside from the hefty prices, I have to say this place is a very well-oiled machine.  From order time to sammich-receipt time, I waited maybe 2 minutes.

No seating (this is a to-go place) so I sat on some nearby steps, with street people and yuppies alike, and enjoyed my sandwich (with complimentary pickle rings and an Andes mint!) in the warm sun.
author: Caitlin B.

description:
My only experience with corned beef is eating it out of a $2 can - gross.

But I work right next to this place and wanted to see why there was always such a long line at lunch time!  If i could describe my corned beef sandwich in one word it be: succulent.  Very sweet and despite its size is very filling.  An explosion of flavor.

I don't think I've ever met a nicer staff.  Highly recommend.
author: Tyrone I.

description: I might give this place 4 stars in a different context, but the fact that it's in FiDi (and not a particularly good area of FiDi at that) allows it to exist in its own league, apart from the other mediocre entities that proliferate seemingly for the sole purpose of shoving their mediocre $9 sandwiches down the throats of harried financial professionals. Sentinel is in that price range, but their sandwiches are a solid bracket above Specialty's and their kin. I had the lamb and eggplant, which also had chickpeas. The filling was well seasoned and interestingly textured, and I love the bread they use. I've been told that it's not even the best sandwich they have, so I look forward to exploring further.
author: Angela X.

description: Had the corn beef sandwich, ungodly good. With little pickle slices. The only issue I had was with size. The quality was so high I'm going to let it go on this one.
author: Michael S.

description:
First and formost: FRIENDLY staff. LOVE that. OK.
It makes total sense to me why I love this place. Dennis Leary is a BOSTON native! Way to go...now I get it. This is a little bit of my hometown away from home!

Ingredients for a turkey sandwich= really, really good fatty bread...lotsa butter; 4 slices of turkey breast meat, Boston lettuce (aka butter lettuce), homemade mayonnaise with herbs, avocado. WOAH MUMMA- I am IN LOVE. It's 10:30PM. I ate this sandwich at 1:30PM TODAY and I am STILL thinking about it. Nice small garnish of cucumber with parsley and fresh cheese. WOW. Undoubtedly the BEST eight bucks I've spent on lunch ever.  Dennis Leary is a bona fide rock star chef. I got lucky today...no line...guess it's too cold for all of the frail San Franciscans! The Sentinel...is ...splendid. It gave me one more reason to smile today. Thanks!

Tried the BBQ Beef Sandwich recently...same A++ service...and same A++ out of this f'ng world food! I am soooo thrilled this is close to my office. Yay!
author: Sherie R.

description:
Before, I would have rated Sentinel a solid 4 stars. The sandwiches are fantastic and filling, but on the pricier side, and the soup can be hit or miss (try the mushroom; that one's delish). 

Then I discovered that Sentinel does breakfast! The muffins are fluffy clouds of carbohydrate goodness, generously scattered with fresh, juicy fruit -- the pear is ridiculous, and the apple cinnamon's pretty freakin' awesome as well. Did I mention that they're also ginormous -- you can easily sate yourself and save some for later.

It doesn't stop with the muffins. Sentinel's oatmeal is my new favorite way to start these too-chilly mornings. It's a little different each time: you might find walnuts, raisins, apples, etc. within the hearty, oat-y, gooey goodness. One thing that's never missing is the brown sugar.

Well done, Sentinel.
author: Marisa F.

description:
My office recently relocated from the Mission to downtown - and The Sentinel's yellowtail/avocado/fennel sandwich sandwich has been the highlight of my move. I'm sure the other sandwiches are great too, but every time I come, I can't bring myself to risk eating anything less delicious than the YT. Alas, I now eat it multiple times a week.

I don't know how often the menu rotates or changes, but if they ever remove this sandwich, I might have a nervous breakdown.

You'll see a line around the corner, but the place is pretty efficiently run (brilliant system of post-it notes to document orders, and what do you know...a yellow post-it signifies ordering the yellowtail!), so the line moves pretty quickly and you get your food pretty fast.

They also do take credit cards - a definite plus. All of these cash-only lunch places kill me...

No seating, so you'll have to bring it back to the office with you and make all of your coworkers jealous that your sandwich wins at life.
author: Rachel L.

description: I had the chicken salad sandwhich.  One word: Delish.  The bread is tooooo good.
author: David H.

description:
I work by here and go here religiously. To the point that they know my name. It's a place where I think you can't go wrong ordering anything and believe me I've tried. Don't be intimidated by the lines, they move fast and it's worth it. The highest compliment I can pay is that I completely trust Dennis Leary. I can't wait to get myself out to Canteen, cos this in my favorite place in SF. If and when I leave I will truly miss it.

Stand outs: Corned Beef, Egg Salad, and the Roast Beef.
author: Vic E.

description:
In a small corner shop on New Montgomery, The Sentinel takes sandwiches to a whole new level. The financial district houses a number of great sandwich shops, but none compare to The Sentinel. With fresh bread baked in house and quality meats and produce, you can't go wrong with any item on the menu. 

My personal favorite has to be the marinated yellowtail with fennel and avocado. The fresh bread was so soft and was balanced well as the seared yellowtail fillet offered a little heat that was offset by the coolness of the fennel and was topped off with tartar sauce. The tenderness of the fish with the crunch of the fennel made this sandwich, like all others, a culinary masterpiece. The meal was made complete with their homemade pickle and andes mint. 

Though this venue doesn't offer any indoor seating, taking your lunch to go should be no problem with all the great public spaces around the financial district.
author: Francis T.

description:
Maybe it's, because I'm Jewish, but I have always loved corned beef sandwiches. The Sentinel definitely did not let me down!

Awesome bread, corned beef (I've heard people complain about the amount of meat, but I thought it was perfect), sauerkraut & thousand island. It was perfect! It definitely sounds like your normal corned beef sandwich, but somehow it was much, much better. Maybe it was the Gruyere cheese that was on it, I don't know, but what I do know is that writing about it is making my mouth water.

The BBQ'd eggplant sandwich was good too, but I would order it with different bread next time and get it without the cheese (or cream cheese, I can't really remember).

I will definitely be going back to The Sentinel for a corned beef sandwich in the near future...good thing I work close by.
author: Elaine S.

description: Great high end sandwiches for that "Oh, I'm eating a gourmet lunch" feeling. I tried the short rib sandwich and it was super good. A tasty brioche crammed with rich pork, onion, and mayo. Maybe the gods were smiling on me but I didn't find any of the lines that other reviewers mentioned.
author: Ivan L.

description:
The. Best. Corned. Beef. Sandwich.
Period.

I think the soups are a bit iffy (had a cream of leek soup that was watery and thin and a friend has a similar experience with another soup), but the desserts are a good call.
Last dessert I had was a nice buttery cake with fruit.

I've had other sandwiches, but none compare to the corned beef--so I don't take the chance in being disappointed and get corned beef each time. I don't go there often enough to take the risk on anything else.
author: fi l.

description:
This place is fantastic. Their corned beef is one the most delicious sandwiches I've ever had in my life. Each order comes with a pickle and an Andes mint. The pickle is dill, but not normal dill- it's interesting. The Andes mint is a nice chocolatey way to end the meal.


CORNED BEEF with cabbage, Russian dressing and Swiss cheese
-Awesome. One time when I orderd this the bread wasn't ready so it took a little while... and they gave me a free cookie!
 
SMOKED TROUT with fennel and apples 
-meh. mostly mayo, not a lot of trout.
author: L B.

description:
Patience is a virtue. 

And the best part is that you don't have to wait as long as you think when you first get there. The line looks long, but it's not that bad. And the corned beef sandwich I waited for was, in a word, incredible. Highly highly recommended.
author: Michael E.

description: Sick ass sandwiches at this joint! Quality ingredients and the combination of  flavors make this place unique. Go early as this spot has a pretty nice size line at lunch time. The women there are very friendly and helpful if you have any questions. This is a must try if you're in the area, just wish the prices were a tad bit lower.
author: T L.

description:
Went there on opening day with some foodie co-workers. I have to love the premise -- just a few items on the menu (to be exact, 4), served fresh, etc. etc. Very today. 

The unfortunate problem with this premise is that like all things in simple food, each element has to be outstanding for the concept to work. The three of us shared an avocado gazpacho which we found too creamy and lacking spice (2 FAILs, 1 maybe); two braised pork with apricot entrees (no starch of any kind; pork less flavorful than expected -- 2 FAILs) and a corned beef sandwich (1 success). But, making a corned beef sandwich delicious is just about the easiest task in the wide world of lunchmeats.

We expected more.
author: David Y.

description: I am doomed. I love Deliboard so much that all other sandwiches don't really compare. But on those rare days when the wait for deliboard is over an hour and my stomach is growling so loud it's embarrassing, Sentinel is my first choice. All the adulations have surrounded the corn beef sandwich. But all my love goes to the roast beef and spicy pork sandwiches.
author: Sophia C.

description:
I outsmarted myself. I showed up around 1:30 to miss the lunch crowd because i'd heard how popular Denis Leary's lunch place is, but instead i missed the daily special. It was a scallop ceviche, composed salad and chocolate flan for less than $12. D'Oh!

The Sentinel is a cool-looking lunch counter decorated with old newstand cigar lithos just adjacent to House of Shields. Today they had the justifiably popular corned beef sandwich, a spicy pork with sweet peppers, roast beef with horseradish and a turkey meatball with goat cheese. Wow. 

Its amazing what you can accomplish with a limited menu, strict quality control and low prices. I'll be back and soon.
author: Todd B.

description: It seems like there is a lot of hype about this place for nothing.  It was expensive, they only had one non-meat option of the menu, and the corned beef sandwich had almost no meat on it.  I had the egg salad- it was fine, nothing I would go back for.  The split pea soup made me a little sick.  It had A LOT of dairy in it and was just too creamy.  This is not what split pea soup should taste like.
author: Jordan F.

description:
Very excited about this new lunch place near where I work. I love Canteen and would appreciate a high quality take out lunch given that I spend most of my work days typing away in between bites.

We ordered the chicken salad special. Being a girl from the midwest, I like a good chicken salad. The chunks of chicken were ample and fresh, and  I love the golden raisins, but the spices were off to me. The dish left an odd taste in my mouth. The few pieces of bread served along the salad were delicious - I was given two but could have used more. The endive salad was fresh but very bitter. I think that one of the challenges of serving food with this much personality is that people aren't eating it with a well chosen beverage - so intense flavors can overpower the meal entirely.

The special comes with a small dessert - genius. Today they served the chicken salad special with chocolate mousse. So good and just enough so I could enjoy it but don't feel guilty about eating.

I will definitely be back and I'm sure things will improve in the future 
(since they only opened two days ago).

UPDATE: I have gone back several times - such amazing food. Really a treat during the work day. Just arrive early - they sell out of things and if you eat late lunches then you might miss out. Also, the brioche is absolute heaven. I had it once 2 months ago and still can't stop thinking about it after traveling to Tokyo and NYC - both foodie towns but neither offered up anything as memorable as the brioche I had at Sentinel.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
$2.00 for a small cup of coffee...that I have to grab my own cup, pour my own coffee, and they don't even have soy milk for those who are lactose intolerant????  I don't think so.  They were making some dude a double latte and it was only $2.15.  Why so much for a plain coffee??????  Ridiculous!  Stupid.  And totally not worth it.  La Boulange coffee is organic and so much better...plus $.60 cheaper!  

Sandwiches are okay but I'm always starving after...and I'm a skinny girl!
author: Ayrn H.

description: This place has the best muffins ever! Lucky for me it's located between my daughter's preschool and my office, so I get to pick one up most mornings on my walk. I wonder if I will ever get tired of them-  but since they rotate between squash, strawberry, blueberry and apple, I doubt it. I love their lunch food as well, but sometimes the portions are way too big (and it's hard to have any self control because the food is that darn good!)
author: Kerry L.

description:
Come on! 
Finally a sando with some love.  They bake their own bread and rolls people!

This is the way a lunch counter / take out place should be.  Back in the day in NYC - like in the 20's, places opened early and sold "cakes" and coffee then served up meat sandwiches to hungry workers on the run.  Fast forward 90 years and switch coasts and you have The Sentinel.

mad props. MAD!
author: Sam S.

description: Their corned beef sandwich was pretty good but not all that it's hyped up to be . This place intrigues me so I will probably be back to try more of their sandwiches .
author: Eileen L.

description:
Although I resisted writing a review about Canteen for wanting to keep it a secret, this Dennis Leary creation deserves more attention.

My sandwich was so satisfying today, and I walked 5 blocks each way to get it.

Fresh ingredients, made to order, flavorful, and all for about the same prices as most lunch places around Financial District.  Opens from 7-2, M-F

Now I just have to find a closer public space to devour the take out.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
i love meatball sandwiches and the sentinel's veal & ricotta meatball sandwich was succulent...i have to be honest and say that i have to try really hard to not think about what veal entails. i am no vegetarian and might be okay with the idea of finding meat in desperate times, but it's just the thought.

anyway...the sandwich is good and the quality of the ingredients make it that much better! i hope to come back soon for a quality sandwich in the city!
author: Marjie T.

description:
Ok. Ok. WHAT. 

I've already reviewed this place. But it needs to be reiterated: This place is FRIGGIN awesome. 

You can check out the daily menu online? And order by phone? SWEET.

The lunch special today was out of this world crazy delicious! 

Roasted pork loin over a bed of figs and caramelized onions. So tender. Figs perfectly cooked. 

With a side of corn that was divinely inspired with basil chiffonade. Uh, huh. You heard me. It tastes EVEN BETTER than it sounds.

And it doesn't stop there.

The "dessert" that came with it was a sumptuous melt in your mouth cornbread cake paired with freshly sliced nectarines.

Holly. You're so sweet.

Dennis, you are out of this world crazy wicked genius.
author: Harrison M.

description:
A friend and I tried to calculate how much this place makes in an average week. Let's say they make 250-300 sandwiches on a good day at $8 a pop. With drinks and other breakfast items sold in the morning, they probably gross $3K or more depending how busy it stays throughout the day. I could see that in a solid year, this place might rake in over $1mm no problem.

What's all the hype about, you may ask?  They only make a few items, so they can focus on doing them right. It's like my Dad used to say, "If you are going to do something, do it right." The Sentinel seems to have taken this golden adage and produced a collection of sandwiches, soups and salads that are amazing. Fresh, seasonal fare that is worth the short walk from my office, and the line that can often develop down the alleyway.
author: Sam S.

description:
come on people, get a clue. this place is horrible. i'm so disappointed that anyone would eat their corned beef and be satisfied.

first of all, it's on foccacia bread. fluffy no crust full of air pockets and stale foccacia, which of course is immediately turned to a SOGGY mush when covered with wet meat and sauce. 

wait, no, actually, first of all...the sentinel website says they are "opposed to anonymous comments on yelp". 

of course they are. they want you to buy their food based on reputation alone, not the quality of content. perhaps they should move their restaurant to an oppressive top-down society where they can track everyone's identity and punish them for speaking out in opposition. 

it's like they don't understand the healthy benefits of logic, reason or the beauty of anonymous speech in a FREE republic. but i digress...

second, corned beef is supposed to be spiced and salty, let alone corned. it shouldn't be rubbery. ugh, i shudder when i think about biting into the rubber they use. i can't believe anyone actually gave this more than two stars.

i mean that already you're holding on to a soggy sponge of foccacia with cold rubbery slices of tasteless meat. shall i continue?

third, the cabbage is old and wilted. i can tell it's supposed to be fresh kraut but instead it ends up missing the crunch, the flavor...it just adds more mush.

then they drench it with mayo, cheese and ketchup. KETCHUP! wtf 

basically, this is a square peg of corned beef that someone is trying to pound into a tired old round hole

it's the post-1980s american recipe for a cheap hamburger. oh, but they used corned beef. wow. get in line

i feel like some 8-yr old came up with the recipe:

lunch meat on white bread with ketchup, mayo, cheese and wilted cabbage...brilliant!

i threw mine out after the first few bites. 

when i get a corned beef i want the bitterness and spice of salt and rye...if you know the history of corned beef, you know it was the food of the wealthy. it was a special meal.

now, sadly, this place has turned it into the corn syrupy sweetness equivalent of a costco burger on a sponge.

perhaps the best way to describe the flavor of this mess is like a soggy pile of sweetened aluminum foil, which is probably what it was wrapped in. 

i could go on, but let's face it. anyone who likes this place is in into the group-think of food. or maybe the people who like this are long-time lovers of the fast food flavors and don't have any idea what they are missing.

a billion served and long lines at a drive-through mean nothing to me. i still don't eat at mcdonalds. the fact that this place sometimes makes you wait on a line? whatevz. so does burger king.

you can get a far better sandwich for less money in a dozen places within a few blocks of the palace hotel. 

definitely the worst corned beef i've ever had...and i eat a lot of corned beef. even denny's does a better job. think of that before you spend your money here. you could get a better sandwich at denny's. 

and the soggy pale green luminescent pickle they put on top of the sandwich with a walmart mint? please, no. stop insulting my tastebuds. zero crunch. zero sourness. in a plastic bag that can't be recycled or composted. 

stay away if you care about food, flavor and freshness. go if you like to stand in line of posers and feel like you're part of something...some kind of weird yelp thing where bad food gets good ratings. check out the ratings where they say "it's a privilege" or "please tip". get a clue. i don't care who came up with the idea or what famous chef blah blah blah. the taste misses the target, the temperature is wrong, the texture is wrong...bad food is bad food no matter who makes it or serves it. period.

oh, and when i asked a bunch of people who work in an office nearby about it i heard no end of their crap about how this place hires illegal euro labor. i don't think about that as much as the food, but apparently it's an issue to consider when noonish rolls around.
author: Mulberry S.

description: Amazing as usual! Hot homemade corned beef-fresh slaw-melted Swiss-freshly baked focaccia bread-yum!!! Watermelon lemonade was refreshing!
author: emily b.

description:
The Sentinel serves sloppy sandwiches forged with love and cool efficiency. Just the right amount of food to feel fulfilled, not engorged.

Mine was an 8.50 sandwich and though it was pricey, they pulled out all the stops--yes, that's right--TWO pickle slices. The Bay Shrimp Salad sandwich made a great summertime picnic lunch and was a treat to my pescaterian tooth; next up is the chickpea sandwich. Wish the menu was a little larger, since the rest of the choices are meaty! 

The line around the corner may cause you to rethink your options, but as long as you've got the time, the patience pays off...
author: Alan F.

description:
This is the embodiment of #63 on the list of Stuff White People Like, Expensive Sandwiches.

Now, some sandwiches are worth boarding a plane for. Other sandwiches are good because they are available on the same block as you. Sentinel's sandwiches are good, but maybe not in the "I would walk 12 minutes to eat one" good category. Especially when $8 can buy me two pork banh mi and a soda somewhere else!
author: Ian G.

description:
So I found the place on yelp as I was looking for a great sandwich near my office.  Unfortunately, I found just an "ok" corned beef sandwich at The Sentinel.  The sandwich itself was acceptable, albeit a bit hodgepodge (focaccia bread for a corned beef sandwich?).  
But $9 for the thing? I understand san francisco isn't cheap, but come on, guys.  Three stars for the average sandwich,  minus 1 star in the value department.
author: Dan P.

description:
Finally know what all the fuss is about. For the longest time, felt like this was a club I could never be invited to, what with it only being open for lunch on weekdays, and my working in Marin. But, serendipity blessed me today, and the B.A.L.T was totally worth it. Look forward to making this sandwich myself - who knew this ingredient combination could taste so good? 
The line whiners are lying. Waiting time is quick and painless even if the line looks long.
author: Purnima M.

description:
This is pretty much the best sandwich place near my office.

The menu rotates often and there are only about 3 options per day.  It avoids indecisive brain freeze from looking at a menu with too many options.  Don't worry about not finding something you like, everything is so well done you can feel free to live a little and try something different.

It's a little pricey at $8+ for a sandwich but I have no issues paying that here from time to time.  It's that good.

There can be a bit of a line during the lunch rush, but it's not bad just before or after and they work hard to get things out quickly.
author: Jared W.

description:
I came here for the first time today, my enthusiasm tempered by the low reviews I read on here and the feeling that it cant be all its cracked up to be. 

The financial district of San Francisco has its share of sandwich joints. From AG Ferrari and Specialty's to Subway and Quizno's, working in the FiDi puts you in a veritable nirvana of stuff between bread. While all are pretty much variations on the same theme, there is the rare shop that breaks down stereotypes and gets truly innovative. The Sentinel, on New Montgomery and Stevenson Alley is one of those places. The menu changes every day and they only offer a few selections, but each one is crafted uniquely and promises at least innovation. 

On Tuesday, May 5th, the menu consisted of a vegan option, yellowtail, pork, roast beef and the hot corned beef sandwich. All of these priced between $8 and $8.5. I had the yellowtail. It was marinated with fennel in a lemon/dill marinade and lightly seared. It was in sandwiched inside a rustic egg roll and topped off with Avocado, butter lettuce and cucumber. From the first bite, the overwhelming flavor was muted perfectly by the avocado and soft roll. The cucumbers and lettuce provided crunch and the yellowtail and fennel danced delicately on the tastebuds to provide a complex combination of tart, savory and crisp flavors. This creative take on the tuna sandwich certainly had me hooked from the first bite and I had no problem finishing the entire sandwich. 

The service staff was efficient and prompt, while giving up quite a bit on the friendliness front to accomodate the long line of patrons. Personally, I cant wait to get back and try their other sandwiches.
author: Adam L.

description:
I looked at their menu online before going and was was nervous to try the roast beef or corned beef because of the potential amount of dressing/mayo that may have been on it, which I did not want. So, I went with the lamb & eggplant, chickpea curry, pesto one... it was good, but having it once was probably enough. I think next time I'll have to try the roast or corned beef, as it seems those are the specialty items. 

When looking at the menu online I saw you could call in your order so you don't have to wait... definitely suggest doing that. 

There is a $10 minimum, which you meet if you get a cookie. I got a cookie and it was decent, but hard to compete for great cookies when specialty's is only half a block away.
author: Caitlin B.

description:
I firmly believe this is one of the best sandwiches you can buy at $8 range, so I wonder why some ppl spend 5 dollars on dead bland meat at chain store.

Either Canteen or Sentinel, they earn my business.
author: Dennise d.

description: It's expensive, and I'm leery to come here because of the giant lines. But I just can't say no to a Sentinel sandwich. I've had a few, and the smoked salmon that the had last summer was pretty good, but the tops is the roast beef. It's a mound of meat large enough that you doubt you can fit your mouth around it, topped with onions and horseradish and in a delicious soft bun... Mmm. I think you'd probably have some kind of massive coronary event if you ate them more than a couple of times a month, but that sandwich really illustrates how awesome it is to be a carnivore. 5 stars for that sandwich alone!
author: James B.

description: BEST. SANDWICHES. EVER. I'm now officially addicted to this place. When I'm in SF on business, I eat here pretty much every day for lunch, and I'm never disappointed.  I actually own a cafe that serves sandwiches, and this place is both an inspiration and a beacon of hope for what my sandwiches might someday achieve...
author: Joe S.

description: This place rocks. The only bummer is that I am kind of getting tired of $10 sandwiches. Seriously, it's a sandwich, $10? Oh well. I'll still keep coming here. First time I got the roast beef. It was great, but keep in mind, when they say blue-cheese, they mean dressing, not crumbles. It was still really good, but I was a little surprised. Second time I had the corned beef. That's definitely my favorite of the two, but I work right next door so I'll be back to try more. $10 minimum for charges, so grab an awesome cookie with your sandwich if you want to use your card.
author: Alfredo A.

description:
Shhh...don't tell no one, but.....

Their salmon sandwich is amazing!

Great. Now this place is really going to BLOW UP!
author: Fil L.

description: I love you, beautiful sandwich! I had the coppa-with mozarella, pumpkin seed pesto, mustard greens. The whole wheat bun worked really well with it too. The line can get long, but if you come around 1, it's not so bad. Need to go here more often!
author: Alex Z.

description:
Good Quality Ingredients, friendly quick service, Flavorful food.

I had an opportunity to taste The Sentinel today, and I must say that their offerings are quite good.  had their corned beef sandwich, with a side of pickles and an Andes mint for $8.75, which is a tad pricy, but as soon as you sink your teeth into the soft, sweet meat of the corned beef, you instantly feel better about the price.  The cabbage and russian dressing definitely round out the flavor of the sandwich, and make the overall experience quite wonderful.

Their menu changes by season, and changes daily, so check online before heading over, and be ready to wait in line at least 5-10 minutes.  There is nowhere to sit and eat, but great for take-away if you are close.  I gave them 4 stars instead of 5, simply because the sandwich was not so amazingly good that it left me craving more.  I have tried many a corned beef and I would place a few higher on my tastiness chart.  While others may disagree, try the Corned Beef sammich at The Phoenix Pub in the Mission, as a comparison.  Both sandwiches have their individual pros and cons, but in the long run, I feel that the Phoenix has a better overall sammich.
author: Chris P.

description:
I really don't want to write about The Sentinel. I don't want the line to get too long. But I am just bursting to tell you about my amazing lunch!

I've been a fan of Canteen for a few years now. So when I heard that Dennis Leary was opening a breakfast/lunch spot, I had to check it out. The location is basically just a walk-up storefront with no seating. Everything is take away. Which is fine, given how close it is to the Yerba Buena Garden.

I decided to order the chicken salad. I didn't know what to expect when I opened up the eco friendly container. Inside was the most perfect little meal. Kind of like an urban/foodie version of a tv dinner. There was a very tender and delicious chicken salad with a light citrusy dressing with golden raisins and pine nuts. Beside the chicken was a lovely salad of thinly sliced fennel. The very best part was a warm fruit crisp topped with freshly whipped cream. Actually, the best part was the flaky dinner roll. (see my review of Canteen for my homage to these insane dinner rolls).

Needless to say, I'm going to Canteen for dinner tonight and then back to The Sentinel for lunch tomorrow. YUM!
author: melissa n.

description:
This place is a machine.  In a space about the size of a newstand they crank out delicious sandwiches, fast and friendly.  
I (vegitarian) had the swiss chard and goat cheese --amazing (it's served on a wheat round, which they don't tell you in the menu), though kinda messy, so be sure and grab an extra napkin and a place to wash your hands after.
My [ever so hot] lunch date had the corned beef, and loved every moment of it.
Butterscotch candies included in the bag sealed the deal.
The tiny space, combined with the line out and down the side of the building makes you feel like you're in the know on a big secret
Welcome to lunch time.
author: kerry a.

description:
A bit overrated, but still good. I like the variety of sandwiches they offer, and the service is so quick! 

I had the corned beef. NOT the best corned beef EVER, but at least now I know for myself what the buzz is all about. I'm interested in trying the other sandwich selections too...

For the service, location, price, and value--I'm a happy camper.
author: Ava C.

description:
so far i've tried: 

corned beef with cabbage, havarti, russian dressing: $8
pork loin with figs, frisee, havarti: $8.25
scallop ceviche with summer vegetables, toffee mousse:  $11.65
roast beef and polenta, small salad, chocolate custard: $11.65

i had the corned beef twice. the first one was probably the best corned beef i've ever had. the second one was excellent, but fattier than the first. still, with the cabbage and dressing it was excellent. their online menu says swiss cheese now, but i swear the two sandwiches i had came with gruyere. 

the pork loin with figs was also excellent. the frisee was nice as a bitter and sharp taste to offset all the sweet and richness of the meat, figs, and cheese. 

roast beef special: four slabs of roast beast, rich and savory polenta, two pieces of vinaigrette-sprinkled lettuce and a decent looking piece of tomato that was unfortunately wasted on me as a salad, and a chocolate custard. the custard was good, but a little watery. 

sea scallop ceviche special: melt-in-your-mouth goodness. nice, big chunks of sea scallops, yellow and green beans, pickled red peppers, some kind of root vegetable i couldn't identify, but was crispy and kraut-like, all of it in a citrus and fennel sauce; the bread-half was fresh and buttery; the toffee mousse was good, but a shocking contrast to the sharp and citrus of the ceviche. 

twice now i've witnessed deliveries of rising dough, so i know all the bread is fresh. 

HUGE KUDOS for having the most Amazing Pickles!!  the pork loin came with spicy bread-and-butter slices that a co-worker and i are still talking about a week later, and the regular sandwich spears were extremely fresh and, i think, lacto-fermented... at least it tasted like it to me... let me know if i'm wrong. anyway, they're awesome. 

it moves SO fast; don't let a line scare you. they have a color-coded system using post-it notes that helps speed things along. 

the counter people have always been nice and friendly. the guys in the back definitely don't want to deal with the public, and fair enough -- they're moving as fast as they can, crankin out the best lunch food in downtown.
author: ray m.

description:
Whenever work is in the early AM, the question of lunch will continue to cross my mind until it's happily situated in my hands. As any other day, I walked over to The Sentinel with my $15 tip money hoping to find a delicious alternative to the now closed Soup Freaks down the street. :(

Lunch specials change daily, today's special was the Baked Ziti with a Bolognese Sauce and an Almond Cake with Bananas. The baked ziti was meh, but the almond cake with bananas... H E A V E N L Y! The cake was dense, melted in your mouth and had the perfect hint of almond extract, the banana flavoring was lacking BUT regardless to say I'm still salivating from the thought of that slice of cake. A piece of cake fell out of my mouth and I nearly cried. On another occasion, the Lamb Shepard's Pie was absolutely delicious, but a bit on the cold side so there was a slight crust forming atop my mashed tatoes. Again, they nailed it with the dessert; an Apple cake: fluffy, dense, topped with powdered sugar, and chunks of apples stuffed into the airy pockets... absolutely amazing. My friend has had the tofu sandwich and called it a cop out for a veggie sandwich due to the lack of flavor on the grilled tofu slices, however she did note that the peanut sauce was tasty. And the corned beef sandwich lives up to everything my fellow Yelpers describe it to be: YUMMY.

The short, sweet and savory:
Quick, friendly service
Temperature of food could be better
$11.65 daily special = $4.35 to budget for lunch for the rest of the week :(
Desserts similar in texture and flavors with slight variation but DELISH
Food could pack more of a punch aka knock me out with flavor, please?
Corned beef, thumbs up
Will I continue buying lunch here? Probably, but only once a week. 
'Nuff said.
author: Maggie H.

description: I love this place!  I come here maybe 3-4 times a month and it hits the spot everytime!  I love their pork with fig sandwich and the meatball sandwich is awesome.  They also have daily specials that are always delicious.  You can also call in your order, but I've never found it necessary since the line moves very quickly.  I would highly recommend this place.
author: Dean L.

description:
"ooh baby i love your ways" 

the line was long, but with their efficient system, my friend Patty L and i were out of there within 10 minutes of lining up, and by the time we had finished paying, our food was ready! 

i got the corned beef, and she got the roast beef.  there was no shortage of meat, they  were both delicious, but i preferred the corned beef.  There was something about the way the sauce mixed in with the soft buttery bread 

You can't eat there, but a quick walk to union square to enjoy your sandwich is so relaxing, and eating there just adds to the delicious experience that is the sandwich.  

next time i'm in SF, i'm coming back! who's down?
author: Michele W.

description: Had Green Goddess for lunch last time, yummy! Fresh and green. Their breakfast muffins are pretty good too, crispy on the outside and moist inside with fruit chunks.
author: YY M.

description:
Mixed review.

MUFFINS: 5 stars. I don't care that they're $2.50. I've had two before: pear, and persimmon. Both have been piping hot, so fresh that they're still a little gooey (in a good way) in the middle, and absolutely delicious. And I appreciate that they were a little inventive with the flavors without going overboard and creating something nasty like a Pomegranate/Szechuan Peppercorn mess.

SANDWICHES: 1 star. I'm a vegetarian, and their veggie sandwich is pathetic. The roll is sweet, puffy, too soft and flavorless (I'm guessing they don't bake it). It's full of vegetables (ok), cream cheese (no), romaine lettuce (no) and not much else in terms of seasoning. Very disappointing, especially considering the price ($8). Not willing to subsidize the more exotic fare that omnivorous patrons enjoy, especially when AG Ferrari's Positano is delicious, 50 cents cheaper, and just around the corner on Mission St.
author: Jason M.

description:
4 stars.

This is a small little sandwich shop with no seating. I came here because it was on The Big Eat SF and got the corned beef with gruyere. I must say the sandwich was pretty delicious. It came with a pickle on the side and the cheese was melted just right. There was a line out the door when we got there, but service was much quicker than I expected. You also get an Andes mint with your meal. Too bad there was no place to sit, but my sandwich was still warm and delicious by the time I got back to the office.
author: Mei C.

description: Oh my what a sandwich! Too bad they're only open for lunch on weekdays, and I don't work in SF. I had the lamb, garbanzo beans, and eggplant sandwich. It was on some strange sort of bread that reminded me of Asian bun bread! I wolfed down the whole thing and so did my coworkers. They are very efficient here!
author: Ryan C.

description:
Soup is not that great.  Cookies are not that great.

But the sandwiches are delicious.  Or at least the roast beef sandwich is.  Best roast beef sandwich I've ever had.  I need to go back and try the corned beef sandwich now after all the hype about it.
author: Jen Z.

description:
yes, woo hoo! as good as it gets! this is the perfect lunchtime takeaway sando spot. dont be deterred by the line, it moves super fast. bring cash and an appetite. i have yet to try the desserts here but after having the corn beef sandwich (and i dont even like corned beef) I was hooked. I recommend trying the specials whenever possible, I have never been disappointed. 

Love this spot, and also love showing it off to my FiDi friends who havent heard of it yet.
author: LeeAnne T.

description:
OMG had lunch here the other day! SOOOOOOOOOOOO Good! Had the chicken mole sand which.  I wish I never came here because I feel like I might be hitting this place up all the time!!! :)

Wait and line is a bit much but TOTALLY worth it!
author: Gilhooly G.

description:
I had a terrible sandwich yesterday.  tough woody asparagus, hardly any mushroom, and a soggy pickle.

Why 5 stars then?  Because I wrote to Mike Fig to report my bad sandwich and he responded super fast and went into lots of detail about how he was going to fix things.

I can't imagine most of the rest of the sandwich joints downtown responding to one concerned customer so thoroughly and so quickly.  I was feeling the love.
author: Vince T.

description:
Yum! Yum! Yummy!

I love love love the corned beef sandwich. I'm not a corned beef girl, either. It's normally dry and sandy in my mouth. But wowie! The corned beef sandwich that the Sentinel makes is no joke, the best. And this isn't any fluke. It's not like today the sandwich rocks, and ooops, tomorrow it sucks. I've tried, er gobbled up, this sandwich to many times to count, and it never changes. Yum yum yummy!

There are others I love too - meatloaf sandwich, salmon with fennel sandwich, deviled ham, chicken salad. All good. 

A definite lunch time favorite.
author: Juls P.

description:
First time i had it:

Pros:
-Good size, decent amount of meet
-Cute workers =D
-Comes with a dill pickle

Cons:
-Long lines
-Taste was just okay
-Overpriced
-Bread wasn't toasted enough


Will give it another try some day...
author: Patrick M.

description:
Why does everyone love this place so much?

I got the smoked salmon sandiwich and my friend got the special of the day.  It tasted like a standard financial district sandwich to me.  

It's a bit far from the office, so I probably won't be going back.
author: Carol L.

description:
You can't go wrong with any of their sandwiches!

The standout is the corned beef sandwich.....recently mentioned in 7x7's "100 foods to try in SF" list......

They even remember your name if you're a regular......  :)

Cheers to Dennis,  Holly,  and the rest of the team at Sentinel!
author: Pete D.

description:
I stayed away from the Sentinel for a long time after it opened.  Partly I was turned off because I kinda liked the establishment that was here before (though I can't even remember their name anymore, so what does that tell you?) and partly because every time I thought of going here there was a long line for the small $8 sandwiches.

However, I finally got bored enough with everything else in the area to breakdown and try The Sentinel the other day, and I am glad I did.  The Corned Beef Sandwich was delicious.  I don't even like Corned Beef.  That's how good it was.
author: Jin D.

description:
I heard about the Sentinel while talking someone standing in line at the Real Food festival in Oakland.

I had high expectations and it was met at the Sentinel.

This lunch joint is located at New Montgomery and Stevenson alley a central location with easy access from the Financial District and SOMA.

I got there at 11:45am trying to beat the lunch crowd, but there was already a line out the door when I arrived. That was a good sign. The place was humming with order takers and food preparers frenetically outputting orders. It helped that Dennis Leary (the owner the Sentinel and Canteen) was also behind the counter. You knew lunch was going to be exceptional.

The menu that day:
Bean Soup
Pork and Fig Sandwich
Spicy Tuna and green bean Sandwich
Avocado and Tomato Sandwich
Corned Beef, Cabbage and Russian Dressing Sandwich
Special: Roast Beef, Fennel, Frisee, and Cheese Sandwich with Dessert

I ordered the Spicy Tuna sandwich ($8), a fresh baked chocolate chip cookie, and Watermelonade Drink. Each sandwich has a choice of bread white or wheat.

If you didn't know about the quality of the food you would think you were getting a run of the mill sandwich by the sound of the menu and the choices along with it. Far from it the Spicy Tuna was made with real fresh tuna (not canned) mixed some kind of saracha chili sauce (great heat not overly spicy). The bread was a fresh baked long roll topped with sunflower seeds. The sandwich had the right texture  (not to hard to chew through) and all the flavors from the tuna, green beans, and bread came through complimenting each other. It was easy to eat not overloaded and dripping on my hands.

Each sandwich comes with a house made spicy pickle. The only complaint I have is that for a sandwich that cost $8 it should have some kind of side salad.

I would recommend ordering a dessert item. My  fresh baked chocolate chip cookie ($3) was huge and very good. Although it is no the best chocolate chip cookie I have had. It needed more molasses and vanilla flavor. The "nade" drinks are good too. My Watermelonade ($2) tasted like a really good Agua Fresca.

The ordering process was very fast they keep things moving there. Service was efficient but not rude. While you wait in line you have plenty of time to scan the menu so you aren't standing there deciding while everyone is giving you the evil eye.

-- 4 stars I want try the other sandwiches. Menu changes daily.
author: Peter C.

description: Great sandwiches and think of the line as fun. I'm a huge fan of the pork options and will have to make myself try some of the others.
author: Eclectic E.

description:
This is a pre review, what i mean is that I love Dennis' food very much, I have followed him from his days at Rubicon to now this tiny spot and I think its so cool to have a talented chef behind the bar cooking up what you eat (when was the last time Michael Mina cooked your food).

Oh yeah, "pre" review because I think he is trying to figure out what works.  So look back for a more formal review when I have had a chance to taste his full menu.

I walked over for an early lunch to avoid the lines and there Dennis was, I asked whats good (I know lame question to ask a talented chef and he gave me that look too) so I ordered the corned beef with melted swiss and picked purple cabbage.

What can I say but I ate everything in my container and licked my fingers too.  I wish it was hardier of a meal (e.g., more beef) but I felt satisfied for lunch.  He needs an outdoor bar area where we can eat our food (Dennis apply for out door seating just a long narrow and tall communal table no seats).

Keep up the great work, but come back to Canteen too, its closer to work.  P.S. sell cigars if you have the look might as well have the real thing.
author: G R.

description:
Since discovering Sentinel a few months ago, it's become one of few places that I've added into the weekly rotation to have lunch.  This is not a sit down place so all orders are to go only.  

Their menu is very simple and offers maybe 5-7 lunch items per day.  They have a Smoked Salmon sandwich, Corned Beef and Cabage sandwich, and BALT (Basil, Avocado, Lettuce, and Tomato) sandwich which are all almost always served daily.  Then they'll have some daily specials which usually will be some sort of fish salad.  Everything  that I've ever eaten here were all very good.

Sentinel is a 4.5 lunch spot in my book.
author: Steve D.

description: I've eaten here six or seven times over the last few months. All of their sandwiches are both interesting and delicious. The menu changes fairly frequently and the range of hot/cold/veggie options means everyone can get something they like. The line moves quickly and the prices are pretty fair for FiDi lunch.
author: Andrew J.

description:
I went to the Sentinel earlier this week after a chef friend recommended it.   i hadn't read reviews before and wasn't sure which to get.  I went for the chicken sesame sandwich, which was good, but not quite as phenomenal as I was expecting.  Decently sized and on a buttery brioche type roll.  Does anything not taste good on that kind of bread? Mmm.  

They did let me taste the chicken beforehand so I knew I wouldn't be totally disappointed before laying down $9, but I'm still not sure I made the right decision (I was hungry and tired of reading menus at all of the overpriced lunch spots nearby).  I was less pleased about the lack of napkins accompanying it; I'm pretty confident that no matter which sandwich you pick, a napkin will come in handy. 

All in all, probably closer to a 3.5. Maybe I'll reassess if I try another sandwich.
author: Casey P.

description: Corn beef and gruyere - the bomb.  The line can be a pain, but hey!  this is SF and thats how we do.  Solid spot to have on your Fidi/Soma lunch circuit.
author: William B.

description: I had worst experience about this place recently, my co worker and me got a muffin the other day, it was delicious and almost half way through muffin i found bunch of hair, it was disgusting and i kept the part, went to that place tried to have conversation with the owner, he was working at the same time and really rude and did not even apologize just took the muffin from me said if I want my money back or free breakfast, i was not happy since i found a bunch of hair i would not go there again or even want sandwich or muffin, breakfast .... Checking out their kitchen for me it did not look clean at all, i don't know what to say ...people who work there is really rude  espically the owner  and place is tiny to service sandwich or even baking muffins.....i would not recommend this place to anyone that i know..
author: Jenny B.

description: These sandwiches are delicious!!! Just make sure to arrive early because they often sell-out of the best sandwiches.
author: Jenna Q.

description:
I've eyed this place many times but the line always turns me off. Finally today I caught things during a lull and ordered the roast pork loin with fig, frisee and havarti. The thin-sliced pork was tender and perfectly cooked, and came on a buttery, yeasty, slightly sweet soft roll. Very very nice.
I ordered a molasses cookie as well, and received a huge dark beast of a cookie that turned out to be the cocoa-walnut cookie instead. I can't say  I was complaining, though. That big soft crumbly hunk of a cookie nearly killed me, it was so good. I'm still saving the other half for later today.
I have to subtract for the lines, and it certainly isn't the cheapest option, but you will never, ever, get a Subway sandwich like this. Service was quick and polite, even if they did mix up my cookie order.
author: Sara G.

description:
Speedy, tasty, interesting sandwiches.

-1 Star b/c they recently instituted the "Minimum $10 on Credit Card", which is both a pain in the butt and a violation of the agreement with the card companies.
author: Rafi J.

description:
Had the turkey meatloaf sandwich.  Simply great.  If white people like expensive sandwiches, white people can't be all bad. :)

http://stuffwhitepeoplelike.com/2008/02/11/63-expensive-sandwiches/
author: Brendan L.

description:
MMMM... it was XCELLENT! 

*Freshly baked focaccia bread
*Tasty beef brisket (is this their own recipe?)...maybe a slice or two more would have made it exceptional! (don't bring a new yorker; might cough up a lung laughing at the mediocre pile)
*Contrasted well with the shredded sauerkraut\cabbage thingy & tangy dressing.. 
*Good crunchy pickle included - (saved for later, my 9 yr old pickle connoisseur daughter thought it rocked)

And.... double-plus good that my lunch was handed to me by the Star chef man himself and was piping hot to the bite, even after my 3 block trek back to the office! It was delicious!!
author: Meredith C.

description: Okay, I've been back many times since the first visit and it never gets old. The food is always good. So far, I've tried their corn-beef sandwich, their salmon sandwich, pork sandwich, and a bunch of other sandwiches. I've heard good stuff about their coffee cakes. I work nearby and can smell that they make the whole street hungry. There's a line usually for lunch but don't let that fool you, they seem to have the long lunch line efficiency down.
author: Vien T.

description: Four stars for not including napkins and utensils in our bags, however, the most amazing corned beef sandwich I've had. Sweetness from the cabbage, salty from the corned beef and YES greasy, delicious, chewy focaccia that got better a few hours later. Kudos for eco-friendly paper disposable containers. :)
author: Peter C.

description:
I tried the corned beef sandwich and it was pretty disappointing.  Very mushy and greasy, blah.   I couldn't even finish the whole sandwich because it was just too much to handle.

But the muffins!!!! OH they are pure heaven.  If you couldn't decide between the blueberry and the peach (both are equally delicious) the Sentinel has made the choice easier by making a muffin with blueberry AND peach!!  Not available every day though.  And some days they have raspberry muffins which, granted are just the same muffins with different fruit, but somehow dont' taste as good as the blueberry or peach ones.  When I have one of these babies for breakfast I pretty much can skip right through lunch, they are THAT filling.  A must try if it you happen to pass by it on your way to work.
author: Nancy J.

description: Yummy! For someone who isnt much of a sandwhich lover, I devoured this delish tuna sando. Quick, street-food for the financials in the Fi Di. It doesnt get more NYC than this in SF.
author: Betsy F.

description: We ordered 2 sandwiches, the corned beef, and the pork. Both were well made and very tasty. Good quality corned beef (nice and lean), on crispy panini bread.
author: David W.

description:
I just had the most delicious smoked salmon sandwich (with cucumber, horseradish cream cheese and some green leafy leaves) and will definitely hit up The Sentinel more often!

I was totes bummed that they ran out of the soup - it sounded so tasty (corn and parmesan) - but the pickle that came with the sandwich may have been the most flavorful one I've ever had.
author: Marcus C.

description:
I've been there twice. I've enjoyed it both times, although the staff could be sliiiightly nicer.

Last time I went, I went with two of my coworkers. They both seemed disappointed. One of them got the "TOFU WITH SWEET CHILI SAUCE, PEANUTS AND SESAME" and he seemed to dislike the tofu's consistency. My boss got the "ROAST BEEF WITH HORSERADISH" and the roast beef was totally rare. Like, blood rare. After a quick and hot session with the microwave it was edible, but he seemed to be irked about it.
author: Jan M.

description:
It's all about the ingredients...
And the chef right there making it and bagging it up.
Quality control!

I got the sandwich of smoked trout, apple, creamy horseradish, butter lettuce, awesome chewy bread.  I could use more spicy horseradish tho...
author: Melanie C.

description:
Decent sandwich, but I know it costs more just for the fact that it's in the FiDi.
Though there was a line, we quickly paid and got our corned beef & gruyere on foccacia and our smoked trout on the sweet bun. While we were waiting, I will admit to shamelessly sniffing and staring at the trays of sweet buns by the door..
Either way, the corned beef was tasty and tender, but I was disappointed by the thinness of the sandwich and the slices of meat. (I think I was spoiled by my previous visit to Katz's). 
The smoked trout was a little disappointing to me. While the sweet bun itself was fresh, chewy, and soft, it tasted SO much like chinese buns. I kept thinking I was eating a hot dog bun or cha siu bao, but I was getting the cold, salty lettuce and trout. The bun outshone the trout, which was sparse in the sandwich to begin with.
Love that they give Andes with each sandwich--it was a surprise waiting for me in the bag.
Good, but mostly if you're in the area. It's a bit expensive to trek out of the way for.
author: Jen T.

description:
Just had my first lunch there.  Would be 4 stars but the lentil curry soup was a watery consistency w/o much flavor.  On the other hand, I had the meatloaf sandwich with light chipotle mayo and it was delish!  Some of the other sandwiches looked pretty tasty too and I will have to try those, but no soup next time!

Also, service was fast, in and out in 5 mins.
author: Ab B.

description:
This place is great!  I came here for the Corned Beef but they had run out of everything at 2pm except the asparagus/mushroom sandwich.  I wasn't so interested and began walking away until the owner/cashier offered me the asparagus sandwich for free (and snuck in a cookie!).  While the sandwich was innovative, it wasn't amazing (served on house-made wheat bread!). I can't wait to go back to try the corned beef sandwich.

The cookie was delicious as well!
author: Jeff A.

description:
This really is the perfect place for a to-go lunch (if you're not vegetarian).

Corned Beef Sandwich: Just had this today and it was perfect.  The beef was tender, the dressing was just right, the cabbage still crisp, and the bread was a perfect balance between light and heavy.  The bottom slice just a tad soaked but it held the flavor nicely.

BBQ Beef Sandwich: Just enough BBQ sauce that you could taste it without it ending up all over your shirt.  The roll it was served on had a pleasant, buttery flavor.  The beef, oh the beef.  These guys really know how to cook beef, you can even see it in their sandwiches.

Portions: The sandwiches are just the right size.  Big enough to keep you full until supper but not so big that eating the whole thing immobilizes you. 

Service: These guys are super quick.  There were four people waiting ahead of me when I ordered my corned beef.  I got to the register, paid cash, and literally 5 seconds later they called out my name.  And the people there have been in a good mood every time I've been there, smiling and cheerful.

This is definitely becoming my Thursday ritual.  See you there.
author: Ryan W.

description: The muffins are brain blastingly blissful. If you call ahead they'll set one aside for you!
author: Jan O.

description:
Updated to add that everything in this place is just amazing.  So amazing that I'm motivated to try things here that I normally wouldn't like.

I don't like eggplant.  Their lamb and eggplant?  Amazing.  I've never been into corned beef or cole slaw.  Their corned beef sandwich with cole slaw inside?  Perfection.  I'm not a big fan of cherries, but the oatmeal with sour cherries and bananas the other day was to die for.  I don't like egg salad.  Their egg salad sandwich?  ...you get the point.

Their lemonades are the best I've ever had.  I also finally tried one of their lunch specials the other day for the first time.  Turkey chili with avocado salsa and strawberry cake for dessert.  Unbelievable.  So good.  These guys could make a sandwich out of dirt and sour milk and somehow they would make a fantastic sandwich out of it.

What an A+ of an establishment.
author: Jeff S.

description:
The Sentinel is a perfect quick-lunch spot for top-notch simple food. With a nod to California cuisine, they prepare a minimum of take-out dishes with with maximum quality.

I suggest a soup + sandwich (no half portions here) and turning the corner, hopping up on a ledge while taunting the line at Subway while you enjoy your delicious grub.
author: Kevin S.

description:
After a disappointing experience at Wichcraft, I stayed away from sandwiches for weeks until I came across some reviews for the Sentinel. Everyone seems to love it. It brought back my desire for sandwiches so I headed over and picked up a corned beef brisket and cabbage sandwich.

The price was reasonable but more importantly, it was GOOOOD. The bread was excellent and the meat was tasty. The sandwich was pretty big, too. The other two sandwiches (smoked salmon and vegetarian) don't sound too interesting to me but I might give in to trying them one of these days.
author: Barney M.

description:
Came here today because my friend really want to take me here to try their sandwiches.  This place is definitely one of the BEST places for a delicious sandwich.  Average price is about $7-9 a sandwich, but totally worth it.  Turns out they change their menus occasionally so today we shared a Roast Beef sandwich, Eggplant/Goat Cheese sandwich and Butternut Squash soup.

I have to say my biggest rave was the eggplant/goat cheese sandwich with eggplant, goat cheese, tomato, lettuce, basil.  My gosh such a good sandwich!  The bread they use is so fresh and crispy with a hint of something like warm melted brie cheese (not sure).  The basil and goat cheese brought such a sensational taste to my palette, perfect combo.  Everything was so fresh and made me appreciate a good sandwich again.

The butternut squash soup was creamy and flavorful, one of the best butternut squash soups I've had!

Be sure to go early though because we got there around 11:50am and there was a line already.  Also there is no seating, so be prepared to have a seating strategy after you get your sandwich.  i will definitely be back to check out new sandwiches.
author: Yun W.

description: Wow! I just had the yummiest egg salad sandwich EVER! It was a little spicy and had mystery ingredients (in a good way) ;) I am sad I haven't eaten here before! Not the friendliest of service, but the food was so good I hardly care!
author: Katrina H.

description:
The sentinel offers some great choices for lunch. They change their menus weekly so go to www.thesentinelsf.com to find out what they are serving before you go. There are a few items that they serve all year round. The Corned beef in particular is very good. At first I was disappointed that it didn't have sauerkraut. But it uses a sweet russian dressing that goes well with some quality meat.

They also have a smoked salmon/baked salmon sandwich, yes two types of salmon on the same sandwich. Good but not that filling.

I'm going to have to try this week's special tomorrow:
SEA SCALLOPS CEVICHE WITH AVOCADO+GREEN CHILIES, CHOCOLATE FLAN FOR DESSERT
author: Marv G.

description:
Had the corned beef and a lemonade today. Jesus fucking christ that was delicious. Downside? One of the worst food comas ever. I want to take a nap so bad now.

GD that was good.
author: Jon U.

description:
I have one requirement when purchasing food: it must taste good. Chef Dennis Leary tastes good. Err, I mean his sandwiches do (though he might taste good, too -- I haven't tried him yet). Everything I have bought from this fine establishment hasn't made me puke. But were I to puke, it'd probably something pretty, like rainbows. Or kittens wearing shirts with rainbows on them. Yeah. 

The first sandwich I got: The Reuben. I thought I wouldn't like it because it is named after a human name, and, well, it's kinda gross thinking about eating another human being (except for Dennis Leary -- I'd eat him). But, to my surprise, it was delicious. Because of this, I am now able to eat humans without hesitation -- thanks, Dennis! 

Second sandwich: Turkey salad. Yum. I described this sandwich as being "pleasant" to my co-workers. That's my 'tardo way of saying I'm incapable of *really* describing why it tastes good. But they also agreed it was pleasant -- hah, fooled them! So not only did I feign intelligence, but I also got a tasty treat, to boot. That's worth 8 bucks right there. 

Third selection: braised pork shoulder. This is not a sandwich. No bread here, folks. Just a lot of tasty meat. Tasty, tasty meat. And tastier whip cream-topped apples. Or pears. Or plums. Or whatever the hell they were. That's not important (although it kinda is) -- the most important thing is the whipped cream. My oh my. Heavenly. I cried. Ten times. Just kidding. Five. OK, two. Or none. But it was awesome. Seriously. 

So, yes, I highly recommend this eatery. Other things I enjoy: The super nice cashier with splendid handwriting who remembered my name on the third visit (she even spelled my name right, too!), the old-timey cash register, the never-know-what's-gonna-be-there menu, and the old-timey cash register. Wait, did I already say that? Crap. But seriously, it's an old-timey cash register -- I'd eat that, too, if I could. And it'd probably taste good.
author: michael d.

description:
Ahhh, okay.  So, I have to admit, the best way to go with Sentinel is to order their sandwiches.  Even though their specials sound pretty fancy, you can't really argue with how they seem to masterfully put together ingredients between two slices of bread.  

The salmon sandwich was pretty good, but for my personal taste I liked the heavier, meatier corned beef sandwich.  I'm still not a huge fan of their homemade pickles.  I prefer them to be more pickly than cucumbery.  (Yes, I realize my fake adjectives are not the most creative).  If they let those suckers stew a bit more in the brine then they'd be just fine.  (Sorry, couldn't resist).

Definitely a good place for a lunchtime pit stop.
author: Shay F.

description:
Tried the corned beef sandwich and...um...people, it's a rather unspectacular reuben.  They don't really give you all that much meat.  And I couldn't taste the "Russian dressing" at all.  For $9 (cash...they only accept credit card for orders over $10), it's decent (in San Francisco) but definitely nothing to recommend to your friends.

Even though all of this has been said before, I'm going to repeat it for posterity's sake (and those who hate scrolling down a web page), this is a hole-in-the-wall, meaning there is nowhere to sit down, it supposedly gets crowded at main lunch hours (although at 11:30am, there was no line), and the reuben was served with an Andes mint and a pickle.  Lastly, it's very easy to find since it's basically across from the Montgomery BART.
author: Carrie W.

description:
this place is a dream.

their version of a rueben is a dream,and comes with a big honking delicious pickle.
author: Lauren V.

description:
This place is smack up against my office. Today, as I was wandering around wondering what same old boring-ass restaurant I was gonna grab lunch from, I saw all these folks standing in a loooong line. As though I'd grown up in an Eastern Bloc country, I immediately went and stood in it, even though I had no idea what it was for. 

Am I ever glad I did. I could smell all kinds of goodness emanating from the tiny space. By the time I got my tomato and bread soup and my smoked salmon sammy, my mouth was watering. Everyone's talking about the corned beef, the reuben, the muffins, etc. Why is no one talking about THE BREAD?!?!?! OMFG, this is some of the best sammich bread I've ever sunk my teeth into. Nice crunchy top crust, warm and soft and chewy on the inside. Fuck me. 

I've found my staple lunch place. Can't wait to go and try the luscious muffins of which y'all speak.
author: kdub ..

description:
Gourmet Chef + sandwiches = tastier lunches than I usually expect.  You'll find this little corner lunch stand overrun with people most weekdays from 12-2pm standing in a long line to get some of the day's creations.  They use a lot of high quality ingredients to come up with creative interpretations of good food like their corned beef sandwich or turkey meatloaf.  They rotate items through their menu every so often which helps to keep it fresh.  

Sometimes I wonder if they are trying to be too creative and chi chi, but I do appreciate that they are trying to spice things up, and it usually succeeds.  For $8-9 sandwiches, they are still a good value that changes up the standard lunch fare.
author: Lemar H.

description: I was disappointed to find out that the corned beef was sold out, so I had the pork instead. It wasn't that great. Come on, why would you guys be out of your (apparent) best sandwich?
author: Grant M.

description:
Delicious!!

I had ordered a smoked salmon sandwich here on my first visit earlier this week and it was deliciously balanced and filling (caveat: I fill up easily)  Fresh, crispy cukes, a tender slice of smoked salmon that was medium-firm and not too salty, with a dressing that was creamy with a hint of tanginess.  Oh, and the bread?  Awesome!  I wish I knew what kind of bread it was ... I'm kind of cuisine-challenged ... because it was just strong enough to hold all the ingredients together without detracting from their taste, yet inside it tenderized to the juices of the smoked salmon.  Yum!!

Sure, it was $8.50, but it was a good $8.50.  So I'll be going back for more on future lunch breaks, bypassing the Subway on the corner and the Quizno's across the street, and the ubiquitous Lee's as well.
author: Eileen P.

description:
Went at 11:30, no big line. Noticed it when I was at Shields. I figured for $9 i would get a hefty portion of meat to quench my meat-craving. I was kinda wrong. I didn't get all that much bang for the buck. 
My bone-to-pick: for the Corned Beef, a $0.50 cent surcharge for "Healthy San Francisco" What the hell is up with that? Do the owners of this place actually think that anybody who eats here is going to go through the Healthy SF program? Hell no! If you're paying $9.50 after a tip for a friggin lunch you probably have health insurance already, it's the Financial District...
author: mike l.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for The Sentinel yet!  I've probably eaten here about three days a week on average for the past two years.

The food here is great-- easily within the top 5 of my SF sandwich list.  I love the revolving, seasonal menu and daily specials.  There's always something unique and new here.

Some of my favorite sandwiches:

--Smoked/fresh salmon with cream cheese, fennel and apples
--Yellowtail ceviche w/ avocado (not served often, but when they have it, GET IT.)
--Rare roast beef w/ horseradish and mustard greens
--Pork loin w/ figs, havarti and frisee

Most of the rolls are baked there, and the ingredients are top notch.  They're not comparable to Deli Board or Ike's in a traditional meat-packed-gut-buster sense (except maybe the rare roast beef, though even that is a little fancier), but these sandwiches fill a special niche of their own in terms of style.

And the muffins... oh god the muffins.... Get there before 10 AM and you'll thank me.  The muffins need no explaining.  They're just flat out the best.  Ever.


Most importantly:

The staff is INCREDIBLE (Monika and Teresa especially!)-- they remember my name, follow up on the random tidbits we talk about at the register, and hook me up with ludicrous amounts of free goodies.  They make this place feel like it's MY sandwich shop.  Not an easy feat considering the crowds.

Any one of these reviewers complaining about bad service either came on a bad day (I've yet to see one), or is a raging asshole (more likely).  I can understand some folks not being crazy about the food, but you can't say anything bad about the people.

I love you guys.  Keep it up!
author: John D.

description: I went here before they got bumrushed by the lunch crowd. Got the Corned Beef and Gruyere. I was so excited since i've read good reviews but when i bit into it, the bread was soggy, the cheese wasnt as melted as i had hoped and the corned beef was piping hot! I mean the meat was definitely good but i can imagine it must've taste better with it all warm. Maybe they prepared it beforehand instead of made to order. The service i received was warm and friendly and they all serve with a smile which keeps me interested in trying again. So I will give them another try another time but this round ends with 2 stars for me
author: Nick V.

description:
working in the financial district one can get pretty tired of the sandwhich for lunch.  One afternoon a co-worker was raving about the roast beef sandwich.  I had to try one; OMG, it is the best roast beef sandwhich I ever had.  The meat was super tender and juicy, the horseradish spread was to die for!  It was not hot, it was just a hint of heat and the wonderful flavor.

Next stop, the cornbeef sandwhich.
author: raven f.

description: I got the corned beef on foccacia. It was pretty good but not phenomenal. I guess this place has been on the travel channel but I didn't think that it was up to the hype but if your in the area and want a pretty good sandwich by all means...
author: David W.

description:
oh my!  the hype didnt let me down.  my friend chelsea has been going on and on about this place so i finally got to try it last week.  

i had their standard corned beef w/ gruyere, cabbage and russian dressing.  it was amazingly delicious.  i dont know what is the russian dressing but its good.  i dont normally like cabbage too much but it was really just there for crunch factor.  the corned beef was some of the best i have had and i dont normally go for corned beef either.  the real winner was the fresh made foccacia.  it was so nice and crispy on the outside and soft and chewy in the middle.

i cant wait to try what else they have.  their menu rotates, but my friend swears that everything is always good and worth getting no matter what it is.
author: Christian C.

description:
I was a very early Sentinel-goer. Early as in, "Check out the new place that opened next to the House of Shields this week!"

In the beginning it was just coffee and pastry. Then the food came with the daily rotating menu. Now they've got it all figured out with a rotating seasonal menu and we have to say, the Sentinel is now a Downtown lunch staple. 

Dennis Leary (owner and sous-chef extraordinaire) cracks me up with his grumpy, somewhat Sandwich Nazi demeanor (he's good people, though) and Holly(i) is the BEST barista/ringer ever. She can remember names like it's nobody's business and always asks after my significant other if we're not there together. 

Food advice: The Corned Beef Sandwich (w/Russian Dressing. Russian Dressing!) and the Smoked Trout sandwich can't do you wrong. It's also worth hitting up the daily special if there's pork involved. 

This is not a diet-friendly place. Also not really worth it if you don't eat meat or fish.

Indulge in a mocha when you get the chance. They hand shave the chocolate.
author: Alexis W.

description:
I eat here often as I work on New Montgomery.  The sandwiches are solid variations on sandwich classics (Reuben, Tuna salad, Pork BBQ, etc) and I find them consistently remarkable.  At least three or four types of fresh baked bread.  A lingering favorite: BBQ pork with carrot/celery root slaw.  Excellent pickles, ask if you don't get one.  The menu rotates seasonally but is always interesting and varied.

The staff are friendly and *amazingly* efficient (at lunchtime peak you can see up to eight people crammed behind the tiny counter all moving fast; sometimes your sandwich is ready before you've paid).

I've left one star off because the wait can be a little long.  Usually the speed that your sandwich comes out makes up for the line to order.

Also: excellent fresh baked muffins in AM from 7:30-9:30ish.
author: Ian F.

description: Little whole in the wall in SOMA. Not much bigger than a newsstand. Food runs out quick. Yummy cookies today; PB, sugar cookie with orange and chocolate chip.  We all split on the corned beef with gruyere and spicy pork sandwich. Yesterday's ginger cookies were really good too. Their muffins are supposed to be the best. We like them (apple and blueberry).
author: Ailene M.

description: split the lamb/eggplant and corned beef with a coworker.  corned beef was good, but the lamb was not.  no texture, just mush and couldn't really tell if there was lamb in there or not.   go with the corned beef
author: Shawn S.
