description: Nice warm pastrami pannini and cold roast beef sandwich, both fresh and tasty.  Yummy mushroom bisque soup--creamy and homey-feeling.  Even the cookie was good!  I'll be back.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I've only been here for breakfast.  The girl at the register is always very nice, she seems to know every other person's name!

I like their muffins, sometimes too caked with sugar, but good and fresh.  If you come after 10am, forget about getting any muffins, they'll be out for sure.  You'll be sad like I was, and drag your feet down to Tart to Tart.

The coffee is ok, definitely not the highlight of this little place, but it's worth getting if you get the muffins =)

Oh and lunch time sandwiches, I've seen the menu, it's a little crazy.  It's like someone wants to be different, so they make the weirdest sandwich ever, and of course everyone likes them since it's so different...  I didn't find any of their sandwiches sounding very appetizing.  Try it if you wanna trip yourself out though.
author: Art C.

description:
I was underwhelmed by the smoked salmon sandwich. For $8 (plus tip!), I expect something substantial, or to be slapped in the mouth with culinary genius. I received neither substance nor a slap.

Working Girl Cafe has bigger, and Cafe Madeleine has better, and both do it cheaper down the block. Mixt Greens gives you a sandwich + salad for $9.

It wasn't a bad sandwich, mind you, but it's more of a $5 light lunch sandwich. You ever go to Italy and see the paninis stacked up behind the glass? Really good bread with maybe one slice of meat and cheese? Because it's like this afternoon snack you have with your espresso or whatever? It's like that.

But, for $8, I was expecting the world and more, and I was disappointed.

Still, maybe I shouldn't've have had the girl sandwich. I'm willing to give them another shot because they were super-quick.
author: Stacy J.

description:
Good fresh sandwiches. Interesting combinations. Usually 4-5 choices that change daily.  Yummy desserts.  A good standard lunch option for grabbing a sandwich and heading back to work. Sadly, no salads.

But ... it's just not that inspiring. People in my office rave about it and I just don't think it is that much better than other sandwich places in the hood. Kinda expensive, no place to sit, they run out of things quickly and don't always tell you until you have reached the front of the line.
author: Jess O.

description: Oh my gawd, seriously. Lunch was disgustingly gourmet today. A veritable PILE of delicious tender marinated cevichesque scallops and fresh ripe tomatoes topped a couple of tender leaves of butter leaf lettuce. This was accompanied by fresh home-made bread and a side of peach cobbler topped with a slathering of hand-whipped cream. Luscious indeed. I'm a fan, I'll be stuck on repeat for a while with daily specials like these. Bring it on Sentinel!!
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Came here for lunch with a co-worker who goes here fairly often.

I got the spicy turkey salad sandwich on a soft roll w/ pine nuts & golden raisins.  Overall it was tasty though the "spicy" was really more the spicy/sour flavor of mustard.  The turkey salad wasn't too mayonnaise-y, which I enjoyed.  It could have had more pine nuts and golden raisins though.

It was a tasty sandwich, but not worth my $8.25, I don't think.  

I do like how the menu changes everyday, but again, it's a bit pricey.  Then again, it's in the FiDi, so I guess $8.25 isn't that bad of a deal.  Just make sure you call in advance to hear what the menu of the day is.

Oh, and the almond cake is heavenly...
author: Naoko M.

description:
The Sentinel presents me with a conundrum. How do you rate a deli whose signature sandwich sucks, and yet has an incidental item which is first-rate?

The signature item is of course the Corned Beef With Cabbage. I could see the wisdom of substituting Gruyere for the usual Swiss cheese - that adds a layer of sophistication -- but the focaccia falls apart when you try to eat the sandwich and clashes with the flavor of the corned beef. Moreover, the dressing is more like ketchup than Russian dressing. Yeccch. The corned beef was good quality but chintzy in quantity, especially when you consider that the Sentinel's Reuben is a $9 sandwich. 

Maybe it's a mistake to try to tart up a Corned Beef sandwich. If you're doing a decent job in the classic style, the meat should be excellent finely marbled corned beef, anyway. The Gruyere is a nice addition, but everything else the Sentinel tried was a dis-improvement over the classic Jewish deli style. 

Besides, it's seems pointless to have an "upscale" Corned Beef sandwich when there isn't one place in San Francisco that can execute a competent classic version. (Miller's East Coast Deli's version is fatty and nasty. Moishe's Pippic's version is dry as dust. The only one I know of that isn't a total embarrassment is from Morty's -- it's not classic, it's portion controlled, and pricey, but at least it tastes good.) 

After I finished my Corned Beef sandwich, I was disgusted, ready to huff off and give The Sentinel one star. Then I took a bite of my Blueberry/Strawberry muffin. Now, since Suzanne's Muffins went out of business, it's been hard to get a decent muffin in this town. No more. The Sentinel's muffin has a delicate crumb, lots of fruit, isn't too sweet, but isn't sugarless in a misguided effort to be healthy, either. It's a darned good muffin.

So, what to do? The Sentinel's claim to fame is their sandwiches, so I'll give one star for their Corned Beef sandwich. If I was rating their muffins, I'd give The Sentinel 4 stars, but it's not a bakery, so I'll add one star to the rating.

The bottom line: don't bother with the sandwiches -- go to Morty's or Ike's instead. But if you've been scouring the Bay Area for a good muffin, your search is over.
author: Michael K.

description:
Quick, to the point, and delicious.

I paid $8 for a pork loin and apricot sandwhich on spongy bread with mustard and jack cheese.  I'm usually not a fan of mushy bread soaked with sauce, but the apricot and mustard add a kick to the flavor that absolves any fear you might have (which I have) of overly saucy sandwiches.

The service is friendly and efficient.  I saw the main chef send back a sandwhich a la Gordon Ramsay of Hell's Kitchen.  Quality control in action = awesome.

Definitely coming back.
author: Ben N.

description:
This is a great place for lunch - the line gets HUGE around 12pm - so be prepared or Call in your order.

The chicken salad sandwich was pretty good - but I'm not jumping out of my seat over it. Perhaps there are better options on the menu.

I'd go back. But - I thought the sandwich was on the smaller side and the 8 buck price tag a bit much for a to-go joint.
author: Chili B.

description: Havn't been here in over a year!! they are quite expensive, but well worth it, the owner of this little spot is also the owner of Canteen, And let me tell you this man can bake and cook his ass off. I had the squash muffin and let me tell you they are off the hook, i could do without the sugar crystals on top!!!!! Well worth the 2.50
author: Ishtar P.

description:
I really hate to start my review this way, but, seriously, this is just a more expensive, less tasty Gregoire (of Berkeley/Oakland).

For starters, the sandwiches are just ok. They're not bad, definitely a step above your standard deli fare, but nothing to rave home about. The turkey meat loaf was pretty good, but, honestly, I feel like there was too much turkey - to the point that I felt like I was eating a turkey matzah ball. I've had a corned beef sandwich here as well, which was legitimately pretty good, but still overpriced (although the included pickle was pretty awesome - super crispy and good taste). I'll admit, I've never shelled out for the special - it's supposed to be pretty good, but I've never been particularly inclined.

The person at the counter is always friendly and the food is fast, if not the best thing in the world. On most days I'd rather make the trek to Mehfil or another fine lunch spot, but for the days when I'm feeling particularly lazy, I can't beat 50 ft from the office door. I'll probably end up coming back here again, but I wouldn't go across town for it.
author: Matt J.

description: Went at noon right on the dot. Waited less than 2 minutes to order. Got the veal meatball situation on wheat in another two minutes. It was amazing. You can tell that it's all fresh and house-made. This is definitely an ENORMOUS sandwich with three huge meatballs and plenty of delicious sauce. I didn't even come close to finishing it. Totally worth every dollar of the 9 that I paid - this was a comfort-food lunch at its best. And the people working there were super friendly, to boot. There's a reason there's so often a line outside the door!
author: Kate W.

description:
I love the concept it fits perfectly with the space.  Every day you go and peak through he door and see what nuggets of goodness await you on the chalk board that day.  Your choices are limited but who cares because each choice is crafted with nothing but the best ingredients for the discerning pallet.  

Today the best choice in my opinion was the Rockfish and mayo on a soft roll.  It was the best "tuna" sand which I have ever tasted.  Although it wasn't tuna it was a white fish with a more mild taste.  It was on a torpedo shaped soft roll with a bit of mayo and some sliced cucumbers.  Nothing else that I could detect.  It was perfect.  You actually tasted everything and felt happy.  Oh the pickles on the side were not too bad either.  The man himself (Dennis) offered me a second pickle with a smile!  

I missed out on the last bit of watermelon juice.  They ran out.  And when they run out that is all.  This it the beauty of the place, it makes you want to come back again and again hoping you get something you missed the day before. 

My only wish is the place doesn't expand beyond the space it currently resides.  This is what makes it so special.  (OK the food and chef help as well.)
author: Scott P.

description:
Not too sure what I think yet - I think it's hit or miss. 

I got the lunch special - Pork Loin with braised figs and feta, cabbage salad and dessert ($11.25) . My date got the BALT ($7.75). He ordered first and somehow mine was done first. 

When we found a place to sit, I opened my compostable (brownie points) container. I was surprised. I didn't realize that mine wasn't coming in sandwich form, instead it was two little pork loins. Fair enough. I just assumed. I actually got two salads (cabbage and corn) and the brioche with nutella for dessert. Unfortunately the little napkin roll of utensils didn't come with a knife, so I was sitting there trying to eat pork on a fork with no knife. Luckily it was tender enough to bite through. 
The cabbage was fine, by the end it was nicely soaked in the fig sauces. The best part of the meal was the corn salad. It had a hit of basil and was delicious fresh white corn. YUM.

The BALT (Basil, Avocado, Lettuce, Tomato) seemed kinda lacking though. The bread didn't look particularly delicious and he said there was very little avocado and almost no basil. He said it was good but it didn't change his life. 

The brioche and nutella was good but I think I would have rather had the chocolate chip pine nut cookie. That sounds good!

I'll go back and have a sandwich and re-assess. $8.50 for a sandwich and I want to have my life changed, you know?
author: Elsa E.

description:
3 1/2 Stars

My roommate works only a stone's throw away from this place, making me super jealous that I don't have such good food at my fingertips!! For breakfast AND lunch?? No fair!

I've ordered their little bundle of joy sandwich- Corned Beef Brisket which came on a ciabatta-like roll and was downed in the blink of an eye. I've also tried their Chicken Salad Sandwich which was filled with all sorts of goodies. My only complaints? The brioche roll the Chicken Sandwich came on was super greasy. My fingertips were shined out after the first bite. However, I think my roommate would raise a ruckus if they changed its buttery style since she adores it. I also tried their Potato, leek, and mushroom soup and was pretty disappointed with how salty it was. I had to rely on my side brioche roll to neutralize it. 

I love the little complimentary mint that comes w/ the meal and all the great drink options. Sentinel is still my go-to SOMA lunch spot. I'm so stuck on how good that Corned Beef Sandwich was, that I'm more than willing to give em' another shot. There are still a lot of menu items I want to try and their set-up is nice & simple for those on the go. Its amusing to be immersed in the Sentinel camaraderie too. On my last trip, the folks in front/back of us were gushing about how much they loved Sentinel. It's like they have their own cheering squad. =) I hope my next experience will be more than perfect so I can bump them up a star or 2 more!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
If you're looking for a tasty sandwich shop to go grab a quick lunch that's not some cheesedick chain place then the Sentinel is a good choice. The sandwiches are good (corned beef and trout are the only ones I've tried) and it's fast. The only gripe I have is there are no chips to go along with my sandwich. But the service is friendly and efficient (helps that the lady that runs it is a lovely sight for sore eyes) and the sandwiches are good.

I think they change up their menu daily which is a nice twist. Enjoy!
author: David C.

description: Great lunch spot; good prices, delicious sandwiches, friendly service. Tried the lamb curry w/ eggplant and came back to try the spicy pork, both were delicious. They even throw in a pickle and tasty chocolate mint.
author: Tom S.

description: Great for lunch. Another safe haven for Reuben fans...very tasty. Go early before stuff starts running low...Salmon with fennel also worth the trip.
author: michael p.

description: The Sentinel makes a really, REALLY good corned beef sandwich. For a small shop that would be pretty hard to find if it weren't for the consistent lunch crowd lining up along the sidewalk, it really surprised me that they managed to serve up a corned beef sandwich that wasn't greasy, salty, or messy to eat, but was at the same time significant in size and tasted amazing. The price is what you'd expect for a lunch in the financial district.
author: James M.

description: Only downfall, is this is just a 'to go" place....HOWEVER the corned beef sandwich is amazing! It's a huge sandwich good for 2 people. Don't try to eat it as leftovers cuz your foccacia bread will become a little soggy!
author: Gwen K.

description:
I never thought I would be grateful for losing my zipcard but today my inability to keep track of things was rewarded with lunch at The Sentinel. Since I have a zipcar reservation tomorrow I had to drag myself across town (okay a 10 minute bus ride from North Beach) to pick one up. And as I was walking out I thought "wait, I am only a few blocks away from The Sentinel which I have been trying to eat at since it opened!!" So off I went, placed my order for the corned beef sandwich I had been hearing such great things about as well as a pomegranateade. I thought my luck was slightly ruined when it began to rain but a 9x was pulling up right as i got to the bus stop so by the time I got back to my nice dry office the sandwich was still warm and luscious. The melted cheese, the perfectly toasted bread, the well the everything, it lived up to the hype. 

Hopefully I will be able to get back soon without having to pay a $15 zipcard replacement fee!
author: Tara A.

description:
Sentinel's smoked trout sandwich is awesome--smoked trout, fennel apple salad, really hearty  delicious bread! And their prices are really good considering you're getting a gourmet sandwich and the portions are really big.  My friend had the corned beef sandwich which I tasted, and it was really good and came on an awesome foccacia. Something about Sentinel's bread is just so good and addictive..I dunno if they buy it or it's house made at their other restaurant (Canteen).

I've only been there once, but so far so good...looking forward to going back!
author: amy k.

description:
Ok.....its really bad when you roll out of bed dreaming about the fresh muffins from The Sentinel.  I couldn't wait to get a fresh, warm muffin and I almost ordered two.  They served a wonderful squash muffin, which sounds a little weird but is ridiculously good.  I've had their pear, squash, persimmon, etc.  The squash is my new favorite.  

As far as sandwiches, I always get the corned  beef with the sauce on the side.  Its deliciously filling and I can't bring myself to try the others....its that good!
author: avenelle a.

description:
Whenever my brother visits me from San Mateo, he is all pumped up from watching a re-run of the Top Chef (or Top Chef Masters) and is anxious to test his "sophisticated palette" with all that San Francisco has to offer. So one day, when my brother came over to my place for lunch and asked me what restaurant nearby makes good sandwiches, I scoffed at him the way Paris HIlton scoffed at Tara Reid when Tara and her entourage got turned away from a night club, and said to him, "Shit son, you call yourself a gourmand and you haven't heard of the Sentinel? You are more wack than a dog learning to play the piano!" Of course, the reality was that I had never been to the Sentinel but since i heard so many people raving about it on Yelp, I thought the place would live up to the hype.

When we got there at 11:40, there wasn't a line. But a few minutes after we arrived, a line started forming and within 5 minutes, there were about 10 people behind us. So if you are dying to try this place out, it's best to get there early. 

And now, on to the sandwiches.... First of all, let me start out by saying if you don't like corned beef, don't expect the Sentinel to change your mind about it. I never really knew what corned beef was before visiting the Sentinel but I always thought it sounded a little suspect. And I should have trusted my gut instinct. The corned beef had a sweet flavor, which I didn't enjoy very much and the bread was rather greasy. I've read tons of reviews where people swear that the bread must be baked fresh since it's "so doughy and delicious" but after tasting the bread, I was more inclined to drive to the Fisherman's Wharf and get sourdough bread from the Boudin Bakery. I was hoping that the pickle (included with the sandwich)  would be redeeming but to my disappointment, it wasn't as crisp as I had hoped. Even my brother, who ordered 3 corned beef sandwiches to eat after I gave him such a hard time for not knowing about the Sentinel said, after one bite, "I don't get it. It's just a regular corned beef sandwich..." And unfortunately, he ended up throwing the sandwiches away. 

Lastly, I know this is going to sound crazy, but one of my favorite TV shows of all time is Roseanne. And one of the reason that I was rather curious to try the Sentinel was because I always imagined that corned beef sandwich would be something that Roseanne and her family would enjoy. So in that respect, I am thankful that the Sentinel allowed me to feel more "connected" to the show. Of course, the Roseanne we all know would NEVER pay $8.75 for a sandwich.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Okay, so I've tried pretty much all of their sandwiches now. All of them are pretty darned good. However, I noticed two things: 1) the sandwiches are not very consistent 2) nothing beats the corned beef

All said, very highly recommended. Yay!
author: Premshree P.

description:
wow! talk about the perfect lunch! dennis leary does it perfectly!

i was fortunate enough to have the corned beef sandwich and it was off the chain! i had a similar sandwhich a couple weeks back (at another spot) and it was so-so at best.. this melted in my mouth. 

ahhh.. i wish.. well, rather im glad i dont work nearby or id be having lunch here every day. look forward to hitting up canteen in the near future

what an amazing delight!
author: Art A.

description: As far as "trendy little sandwich shops with limited menus and tiny spaces" go, The Sentinel is probably one of the best. I had the corned beef sandwich today and I must say, it was worth the 12 block jaunt from my my office on Sansome to get there. The bread was perfection, the corned beef- tender and salty, the cabbage and Gruyere were just the right mix to make this sandwich a party in my mouth. I'd say the $8 price tag is pretty good for a sandwich of this size and quality. They also give you a pickle and a piece of candy as an added treat. I'd go back for sure if I was in the mood for a trendy little sandwich. Although the name continues to elude me...
author: Ieesha C.

description:
What kind of magic place is this?  on a drab, cold rainy day, I wandered over and joined the line patiently.  Torn between roast beef, ceviche, and chicken salad, I leapt for something new:  the corned beef.  The staff are cool, calm, friendly  - real professionals. 

Note that I'm no corn beef fan, and was delighted by warm flat bread, toasted just right with a crispyish edge and soft inside, tissue thin slices of corn beef, and the cabbage/Russian dressing topping that I can't even describe.  

go.  go now.
author: Elaine O.

description:
corn beef sandwhich 
slice of pickle
candy

$8.75 total.

note: $10 minimum for credit card.

This place is not the same anymore. I was expecting my warm bread with loads of meat,  but not anymore. What's sad is that the sandwhich was already made and sitting on the counter by the time I even had the chance to pay for my sandwich. The quality has lowered, even the soft good quality white napkins are turning (recycled) brown now.
author: Elliot Y.

description: My boyfriend and I tried two sandwiches, the corned beef and the salami with mozzarella. The clear winner was the corned beef which we both agreed was delicious (my boyfriend usually doesn't like corned beef). I didn't hate the salami, but I wouldn't order it again. All in all this place was OK, but not worth the price.
author: Francesca S.

description:
I work maybe two blocks from this little place. I think it's right across from Dada's. 

Much like the hype, this place is really good! That panna cotta desert they have is just so yummy! I think it was coconut infused with some fruits on top and what's really really good, that you should get? 

That corned beef sandwich is the best thing there! Totally yummy! I think it comes out to be 8 bucks for one of those yummers. Go try em'! My boss went here three days in a row and he's a foodie whore.
author: Miss Pigg y.

description: This place has the best espresso and lattes in the entire neighborhood. The girls are friendly, the muffins are amazing, the coffeecake is to die for. The lattes and mochas are incredible. Plus, there's oatmeal for cold days. These guys are the best that's available downtown.
author: Sophie K.

description:
Pretty much what everyone else said.  Really fresh and creative sandwiches.  The first sandwich I had there (pork) was good, but not special.  The Yellowtail sandwich, on the other hand, was fabulous!  I'm still thinking about it.

But I write to talk about the staff.  They could not be more friendly.  I mean, really.  Maybe it's because they eat so well, but every single person who works there has a smile on their face and is genuinely really nice.  Make sure you tip them well, people!

And thanks to Yelp, I learned that they make muffins in the morning.  Can't wait to try one!
author: B D.

description:
I don't know why its taken me so long to try this place, but I am seriously regretting all of those missed opportunities to eat incredible sandwiches and planning to go a lot in the future to make up for it. 

I had the veggie sandwich today which was mashed chickpeas, pickled veggies and smoked Gouda on a yummy seeded roll. The bread was incredibly fresh and tasty and the combo of ingredients was a hit. The pickled veggies were delish. Someone clearly put some thought into this food, and that's about the best thing I can hope for, especially in a FiDi lunch spot. 

Also, can I just add that although I'm not a vegetarian all of the time, I do eat vegetarian a lot, and the veggie sammie is almost always the least thoughtful, least appetizing item on menus around here. Its either a pile of cheese or a regular sandwich with the meat removed. So I really appreciated that the veggie sandwich at the sentinel was just as creative and delicious as the other options appeared to be. I will, however, plan to try the pork or roast beef next time. 

Oh and the Werther's Original in the bag made my day. Because as much as I didn't want my sandwich to end (it was that good), I couldn't wait to pop that tasty Werther's in my mouth. Good choice on the sweet treat! 

Overall, a refreshing change from the low quality, uninspired lunch fare available within a few blocks of my office.
author: Amber C.

description:
It's noon. Coworker says to me...so? what'll it be for lunch? For the past few weeks, my answer has been "The Sentinel!" 

I love the smoked salmon with it's creamy horseradish, fennel and cukes.  The bread Chef Leary uses on this sammy is buttery goodness baked up into this genius bread-like substance. I've had it a couple of times where there was a little too much horsey cream cheese, and it ruined the balance of the sandwich, but that's ok. 

I've also had the reuben --- phenomenal with the zing of good gruyere and fresh cabbage slaw. Head and shoulders above the de riguer kraut. The blueberry muffin and latte I had one morning were fantabulous. The muffin was warm and busted open with blueberry juicy flavor. I wasn't a huge fan of the turkey salad, but to be honest, I'm not a fan of poultry mayo salads. I dunno I had thought that perhaps the sentinel, if anything, could convert me. But alas, I think I just don't like them. 

I'd give it 5 stars if they had seating. But on second thought, I kind of feel like seating would detract from the atmosphere. After all, it's just Chef Leary intensely working away at a countertop in an old cigar shop. With that super cute old cash register and his color coded post it system. Anything more might ruin it --- so yeah, let's just keep it as is.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Sentinel is the place I go to try things I otherwise wouldn't - all because I trust Dennis Leary's taste buds implicitly after experiencing Canteen. 

The first time I went, he stood waiting to take my order. As I hemmed and hawed over the raw tuna special he looked at me with his penetrating eyes and said simply and firmly, "It's good." 

I immediately acquiesced and it was exquisite. 

I went back recently and ordered a hot pressed corned beef brisket sandwich, something else I would also never order. And it, too, was delicious.

The lines are manageable (never waited more than 10 minutes), Holly at the cash register is a doll, and watching Leary and his crew work is fascinating.

Though the prices make it a lunch treat rather than a daily stop, when I'm sitting on the sunny Market St steps watching the world go by and eating some of the best lunches in town, I realize that what I'm searching and paying for is an outstanding experience. 

And that's exactly what I get every time I go to the Sentinel.
author: Sharand N.

description:
Friendly employees and good food.

I walked by one day and decided to try this place out after reading all the Yelp reviews. I got the CORNED BEEF ON FLATBREAD WITH GRUYERE, CARAMELIZED ONIONS, RUSSIAN D. for $8.25

It was soooo yummy! It is a lil' pricey for such a small sandwich but in my opinion, it was well worth it!

Sentinel is the Dennis Leary take on a take-out.  What that means is soup and sandwiches that are more, for a bit more.  You will find that for a few bucks more you get fresh, tasty food.  It's nice to be able to treat yourself without breaking the piggy bank.  

I start with a zucchini/ginger soup that is clean to taste and smooth.  A bit too smooth.  Were this not a take-out some crunch, something with a different texture would help.  But this is a take-out and that sort of thing will not travel so well. 

A sandwich of fresh and smoked salmon with dill on a soft roll has just a bit too much dill.  But otherwise it's what you would expect from a former chef at Rubicon and present day owner and chef at Canteen.  Freshly prepared, fresh fish that tastes like fresh fish should.

A really welcome addition to the downtown scene.   This place shows that San Francisco can do better than other places even when it comes to the lowly sandwich.
author: David D.

description: it's windy, arts are about, San Francisco is about, there are way too many artists about, and we're all standing around the corner (because "the line is by the door" and not in front), shivering, for corned beef sandwiches.
author: James G.

description: zomg. after wanting to go here for lunch forever, i finally did. today. i am sitting with my half devoured lunch takeout box by the keyboard as i type. this lunch was amazing.  i got the special of the day, which was a turkey salad, cucumber salad, and rhubarb dessert. i love rhubarb and was excited to even see it on the menu. every element of my lunch is superb. i am in post lunchal heaven. and saving the rest for dinner.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Reasonably priced, especially considering the huge portions and great service. The eight dollar price tag wasn't particularly cheap, but the single sandwich kept me full all day. The line of ten or so people in front of us disappeared quickly as orders were efficiently taken and food came out after only a two minute wait. 

I got the ham, mustard, provolone, and pineapple sandwich. The ham was flavorful, the mustard perfectly spicy and peppery, the pineapple refreshing, and the bread... heaven! That bread just made the sandwich complete. 

The pomegranate lemonade was perfectly fruity and not too sweet. 

Next time I'm in town, I will definitely go out of my way to grab lunch here again.
author: Katie B.

description:
I recently moved my office within a block of The Sentinel and discovered it when I walked by mid-morning and smelled warm cinnamon and turned around to find out what it was.  Fresh warm coffee cake that made me melt.  The muffins? Meltingly delicious.

I'd go there every single day for the fresh salmon smoked salmon sandwich if I remembered to get up from my desk in time so I didn't have to stand in the long line.  Even though it's a long line they are super efficient and it's never as long of a wait as I think it will be.
author: Leanne W.

description:
the sentinel is in serious need of a vegetarian consultant. the meat sandwiches all look great and i've eaten with others eating the meat offerings and they all get great reviews. but the vege sandwiches are sub par...nothing special and they don't taste that great. their descriptions sound wonderful but there are small details which bring the whole thing down. since you don't have the meat and cheese to carry the whole sandwich you need to pay particular attention to the finer details. 

in the last week i had the tofu sandwich and the mushroom/chard sandwich. both were served on a pretty boring soft seed roll. nothing special there...just soft white bread. both sandwiches got soggy super fast. toasted bread would help a ton. the tofu sandwich had some good flavors- sweet chili sauce and peanuts, but the tofu did not seem marinated in sesame as they said and it wasn't grilled- just raw- which didn't add any real flavor. whole sandwich was pretty much just a big moosh. the chart and portabello sandwich didn't have a ton of flavor again the soft white roll made it pretty gross and soggy.

on the plus side their pickles are AWESOME! please.... get some vegetarians consultants in and get on it! i'd love to love this place.
author: emily y.

description:
I love my job. I'm obnoxiously lucky, I know and among the many rewards of walking to a job I love is the Sentinel. Every morning, I have to ask myself, "Is it time for another?" And another is referring to their daily changing selection of pear, cranberry, blueberry. Always warm, not to sweet, & velveteen textures.  This is when food is elevated to sorcery.  AND, this morning , I ordered the Banana Poppyseed. AND This time the nice white lady put the muffin in a paper clamshell.  She usually just throws the morning dreambombs in a paper sack.  I got really happy that the Sentinel was moving toward bad environmentally irresponsible practices as they were waaaayyy too perfect to be true. But I was dissapointed to learn that there was a REASON for the excess packaging.  VERY IMPORTANT DETAIL: The clamshell provided the most stable protection to house the steaming caramelized banana chunks in the middle of the muffin. A mere sack couldn't hold the density of the UR muffin. I HAVE NEVER EVER TASTED A MUFFIN THIS GOOD!  And I've HAD amazing muffins.  It was like a fried-banana-caramel-candy-cakey-crunchy-goeey  nestled around are the constellations of black nutty pods in a spongy universe of white flour and sugar magic.  Art.  This is ART, Muffies!  

 And they have sandwiches at lunch. That are talked about downtown.  I haven' t had it yet. I'm still dreamily lolligagging on the Sentinel sweets.  But soon...AND if it's a rainy day, the Sentinel encourages you to order anyway. If 5 or more sandwiches are bought, the assigned courier gets hers/his free! Cool, yeah? Go there, get your muffin on and tell the Sentinelists how much this city loves them! And that they aren't ever allowed to leave the City limits.

Credit to Betti-Sue Hertz, Senior Curator of Muffins.
author: Joel T.

description:
I don't know, my sammie experience has been hit or miss here.  

Huge pork loin sammie portions but absolutely meager corned beef portions.  I don't think that the after-meal mint makes up for the lack of corned beef and I don't care for pickles.

Pork loin sandwich worth 8 bucks.  Corned beef sandwich not worth 8 bucks.  

Each time I've been here, Chef Leary seems to be really uptight in this venue, where he seems totally relaxed at Canteen...in my opinion.
author: Maggie K.

description: The Corn Beef was oh so good. No tables or chairs, but the taste was worth eating on the street next to a homeless guy. I would definitely go back if I'm ever in SF again.
author: Kay L.

description:
I tried the DEVILED PORK LOIN WITH BUTTER LETTUCE, CREAM CHEESE AND WALNUTS for $8.  Its like no other and to quote a friend: "Once you had these sandwiches, you can't have any other."  The chef combines ingredients to form a delicious, unique, can't-find-any-other-place sandwich.  I loved it!  

The only change: I would have asked them to go lighter on the cheese since I like lighter foods.

Enjoy!
author: Katie T.

description: Had better roast beef sandwich in my lifetime. Take a trip to Las Vegas or Orange County for Earl's Sandwich. Better than sex.
author: Jenny J.

description: The muffins are amazing (so amazing in fact that they run out) fresh out of the oven, they also experiment with the recipes so the combinations are new everyday. The sandwiches are simple and delicious, perfectly tasty and light.
author: Abraham V.

description: I've had the corned beef sandwich twice and I think it is delicious.  I also like it that the service is really quick.  I believe I was in and out within minutes.  I will continue to go back here...it's convenient, it's good food, and the price is right.
author: Brent T.

description: The service (efficiency) has improved quite a bit lately.  The sandwiches I've had are amazing -- very messy, as some other yelpers have pointed out, but worth every calorie.  Meats are tender and delicious.
author: Jaina S.

description: opens at 11:30 lunch.  tried the $9 corned beef sandwich.  (mostly cold sandwiches otherwise).  the Russian dressing is nice, esp. the tomato ketchup base.  not the most amazing sandwich, but good enough and more worth it than a grilled cheese.  good ratio of corned beef, cabbage.
author: Rob C.

description: Turkey Meatball with cranberry sauce and coleslaw sounded like it would be amazing... but not when the coleslaw has about a cup of mayo in it.  disgusting.  but after paying $9 for the sandwich, i ate it anyway.  If you like a ton of mayo, then go here.  if you prefer to taste something besides mayo in your sandwich, then don't.
author: Nedra D.

description:
What genius thought this place up?  Oh, I should have known... Denis Leary.  Bordering SOMA and the Financial District all the lunchers seem to have caught on quickly.  They have seriously gourmet lunch items and they are quick.  The menu changes daily, so the only thing you know for sure is that you will be satisfied.  Interesting and mouth watering flavor combinations, great service and fresh baked pastries amalgamate to create the glory that is that little hole in the wall (literally) The Sentinel.

Mmmmm, mmmm, good.
author: Morgen N.

description:
Of all the places in this neighborhood to eat lunch... 
This is the only place I'd have no trouble trying everything on this menus...
author: kristin n.

description:
I had to take one star off because they gave me the wrong sandwich.  I got back to my desk only to find that I got the spicy chicken salad, when I ordered the pork.  I walked all the way back to get the pork/fig/manchego sandwich.  They were apologetic, but it was a major inconvenience.  Plus, I found the pork to be too much and too salty...maybe I should have kept the spicy chicken salad! 

This isn't the only time they made a mistake about a sandwich.  When I went with my coworker two weeks ago, they gave her a spicy chicken salad, when she ordered the eggplant.  She didn't mind & happily ate the sandwich, but I was irritated for her...though I didn't yelp about it on her behalf.  Of course, since this happened to me, I had to bring up my co-worker's incident to mark that on 2 occasions, this has happened.  Make sure you get the sandwich you ordered!!!
author: Angelica G.

description: is the corned beef with gueyere really the #74 thing to eat in 7x7s 100 things to try before you die?  whoever made this year list was obviously skinny.  I felt like I could make the sandwich at home.  The corned beef  tastes like something I could find at safeway.  I think I was expecting NYC style or something.  I'd rather eat a mcdonalds big breakfast before I die.  Ands its $3 cheaper.  Very disappointed.  The only good thing about this place is your sandwich is ready within 3 minutes.  fatty awesome.  sucks ill never be back.  pwned
author: Fatty A.

description:
Not good enough flavor with the tofu, and why do they add mayo to it? Not worth finishing the other half of the sandwich, so I bought myself a bagel instead. $8 wasted.

The tofu sandwich uses thick slabs of tofu that does not appear to have been baked or fried, so it has the standard medium texture. The chili peanut topping is adequately tasty, but there wasn't enough to do more than blandly flavor the thick slabs of tofu. The bread is fine. Service was fine.

I can't fathom why they smeared mayo on a sandwich -- this is not mentioned in the item's listing and made it that much more slimy.

If you want a bland, amateur tofu sandwich, this is the place.
author: M. N.

description: This place is awesome. I mean it's fresh food, smells great as you are coming towards the place and they keep the selection changing. The staff is really nice and it's funny how people just line up in a serpentine like pattern to get their order in. It can be a little tight since basically from what I can tell  it's a take out only place. Really good though.
author: Greg G.

description:
okay.

so you know it's bad when i have the sentinel's number on speed dial on my phone. even worse is the notion that it occupies speed dial 8 and my own flesh n blood brother is at the lowly 9 spot. and since this place is so close to my work, i call ahead for my hot corned beef and gruyere sammie lunch-- which is bad because i don't do enough walking to somewhat offset the sandwich i just inhaled with wild abandon. well, i guess it's not too bad, what with the beef being lean and not grisly or ultra fatty-chewy. all good quality stuff.

at least the sentinel really does live up to its name: the rancid burps i let loose silently in the bart train on the way home definitely keeps the baddies away. lolz jk-- i wish i were that brave... hell, who knows? it can backfire and make everyone in the car hungry all of a sudden. could quite possibly start a feeding frenzy-- headline: STANK BURPS INCITE CANNIBALISM ON BART TRAIN. *clucks tongue* hey, it could happen. you never know...

this is an excellent lunch time spot that is both convenient for me and well-priced for the value.
author: Vanessa D.

description: Had the Corned Beef sandwich and it was really good. The line moved really quickly considering it was peak lunch time and the workers were really efficient. Would definitely go there again.
author: Jenny X.

description:
I'm totally planning on increasing the stars on this review.  But I need to try some more stuff first.  

I love the concept of this sandwich shop.  Pick a few things each day based on seasonal (and I hope local) ingredients and do them very very well.  

I've had the corned beef sandwich and it was very good.  The actual corned beef portion was a little small, but it was such a good sandwich either way, and I'd rather have a little bit of good quality meat, then a ton of poor quality.

Today the soup was Mushroom, and I LOVE it.  I mean, this soup is smack your momma good.  It's a cream based soup, but it has an acid in it that I can't quite place.  Not overwhelming, but just enough to cut the richness of the soup.  And of course the fresh baked herb slab to go with it is amazing!

I also ordered the BBQ Eggplant sandwich and I really did not like it.  The eggplant actually has BBQ sauce on it, so that's not just the way they prepared it.  The texture of the eggplant (slimy) with the BBQ sauce, and the goat cheese and the BBQ sauce soaked bread, just made it unpalatable.  Which was a bummer because flavors were good.

Overall, this is still my new favorite lunch spot.  And absolutely get the mushroom soup!
author: Jessica B.

description: WHOA-HO!  5 stars for the best egg salad sandy I've ever had, EVER.  (yes, I purposefully repeated the word ever.  try it!)
author: Sarah Z.

description: I got to play with a cute baby while I waited in line, but I also got there before the lunch rush (I think) around 11:30am. I got the spicy tofu peanut sandwich and my boyfriend had the corned beef. They were both really great! They aren't massive sandwiches, but tasty and worth checking out. They don't have that many choices on the menu but that doesn't seem to bother anyone :)
author: Holly S.

description:
Outstanding Lunch!  

I brought something frozen for lunch today, but my co-workers were buzzing about going to this place ran by the same gentlemen who does Canteen.  

Would I like to order with them.  Hmmmmm, OK, twist my arm.

I had the spicy chicken salad (normally turkey salad but he probably uses whatever is fresh/good) and it was incredibly scrumptious.

Good spice, delicious light creamy dressing and large chunks of tender and flavorful chicken all on a focaccia type bread that blew my mind.

I normally do not like focaccia because it is usually spongy tastelessness infused with flecks of hard dried herbs, but this stuff was crisp-crusted, perfectly capable of neatly handling a wet filling and had a fresh-baked taste that changed my mind about what focaccia can be!

We also split one of the chocolate chip cookies, and my, that was a great cookie - not sickeningly sweet and had a nice light yet somewhat crispy texture even though the cookie was soft and delicious.

I can't wait to go back and try the corned-beef!
author: Jim K.

description:
Staggeringly good sandwiches, chatty-cute menu listings and a cool, retro feel. What more do you want with your lunch?

I've been working in SOMA for two months, eating Subway and Quiznos and languishing in limp lettuce, slimy deli meats and crappy bread. Then I stumbled on The Sentinel, and my lunchtime routine has been changed forever. I had the Turkey Meatloaf sandwich, which the girl taking orders at the door described as "juicy," which it was.  I'm looking forward to going back for the smoked trout sandwich and curried butternut squash soup.

As a librarian, I have to commend the Sentinel's super smart ordering system which utilizes color-coded post-it notes. What a great information management strategy!
author: Melissa J.

description: I really love this place. It is so San Francisco to be able to get a gourmet sandwich and homemade pickle for lunch. Most of the sandwiches are really awesome - the yellowtail and fennel stands out as my all time favorite. The meatball sandwiches are always delicious. I loved the chickpea and gouda while they had it. Only a couple of sandwiches were misses for me. It is fun that the menu is always rotating. It keeps me coming back for more!
author: Sarah N.

description: Of the top 10 sandwiches I've ever had, this place has served as least 5 of them.  I had the pork loin, fig, and Havarti today.  Awesome.
author: Trent W.

description:
My coworkers and I really liked The Sentinel--I loved it--but AFTER ONE YEAR SINCE IT'S OPENING, THINGS HAVE GONE DOWNHILL. 
 
As the first customers to arrive for a long-awaited, end-of-the-week, TGIF, let's-get-something-yummy lunch, it was awkward waiting on line until the side entry door on Stevenson was opened, even though the front doors on New Montgomery were wide open. We were told they weren't serving anyone until 11:30am, but there appeared to be some folks who squeezed in early to pick up some (pre-ordered) food. As we waited on line for about 10 minutes, IT FELT LIKE AN EXCLUSIVE CLUB THAT WAS GOING TO ASK US FOR A COVER CHARGE. Nonetheless, we were excited! Me and two coworkers ordered food: two hot sandwiches (the veal meatball and the corned beef) and one special lunch (BBQ beef). Delighted to have our food and it looked damn delicious as it always was, we were let down.
 
THERE WAS A SMALL DEAD FLY ON THE GREENS OF THE SPECIAL. Sure this crap happens every now and then, but we were surprised to be given what seemed like a semi-hard time by the chef. We whispered there was a fly in the food to the chef so that other customers wouldn't hear us. After his response, "There's no fly in here--that was a mushroom" we picked up the green with the dead fly on it and handed it to him. He kindly called us his friend and insisted that we take a replacement, although we said we'd just take it without the one lettuce leaf with the dead fly. We did appreciate the gesture and thanked him. 
 
As we got back to our desks at The Embarcadero, we chowed down on the food and encountered a couple more bothersome things: THE SANDWICH'S VEAL MEATBALL HAD PLASTIC WRAP IN IT and THERE WAS DARK SHORT HAIR IN THE SPECIAL'S BUTTERMILK PIE. [If you watch HUNG on HBO, think of the meatball like Tanya's cookies with the laminated messages baked inside them, but as a meatball with flimsy cellophane plastic that doesn't have a message.]
 
I'd venture to guess that the prep work at The Sentinel may have fallen by the wayside--greens should have been well-washed, meats should be clear of any packaging and batter should be sanitarily prepared in a clean environment. Shit like this happens sometimes. GRANTED THIS SEEMS LIKE A FEW MORE INSTANCES OF ILL-PREPARED FOOD THAN ONE WOULD EXPECT IN A SINGLE VISIT, but it just seemed all so bad... The stars were misaligned perfectly: waiting for The Sentinel to open felt like waiting on line at a club, asking for a replacement meal with a dead arthropod is found on it didn't seem all right and not knowing how to spell your basic English language name wasn't all right. [The order staff person seemed to be from a European country and asked one of us to spell our name.] 
 
Seriously, we all love The Sentinel and think that the food served here is damn good--at least it was... However, in a town of foodies where there are many good restaurants, The Sentinel has been stricken from the list of our office's go-to's for an awesome lunch. At The Sentinel TODAY, SERVICE WAS A MISS and SHODDY PREPWORK HAS RUINED THE ANTICIPATED QUALITY OF FUTURE MEALS. 
 
We've seen things like this at other eateries that have made our office's banned eatery-list: Kokkari (for a snail found in a salad), Foccacia Grill (for stomach flu) and all locations of Sellers Markets (for shoddier and smaller quality food)... Even John's Snack and Deil has semi-made the list for forgetting to put meat on Bi Bim Bap, lessening meat portions and selling out to the fad that is Kimchi Soft Tacos. When things like this happen, it's disappointing for us, but we'll hope that improvement is achieved soon.
author: Travel Swagger R.

description: Holy corned beef and cabbage, Batman! You'll see people lined up around the corner for the Sentinel's beefy goodness and for great reason - best damned sandwich downtown.
author: phil h.

description: The best corned beef sandwich ever!!  Plus a spicy pickle and piece of candy for dessert.  Find somewhere else to eat, though, because there is no seating at this tiny corner spot.  Bonus pts for at least listing some places on 2nd St with public seating.
author: Chris L.

description: Sentinel's Corned beef sandwich: easily one of the top five best sandwiches I've ever had. The only bummer is they're not open on the weekends :(
author: Cory D.

description: I got the BALT (avocado, tomato, lettuce, basil) sandwich, which was just ok. Nothing special, and even a bit pricey for what it was. They were a bit skimpy on the avocado. I added stars for how fast it was to get through the line and to get the sandwich. Maybe I'll come back, but definitely not for the BALT.
author: Suzy Q.

description: If you haven't stopped by an had their warm peach muffins in the morning, then don't.  They keep running out and I can't get one by the time I get there ;-).  What a wonderful treat in the morning.  The have many flavors - coffee cake, blueberry, peach and strawberry muffins - served warm.  Grab and go!  Absolutely perfect.  Will have to get over there for lunch too.
author: Sallye M.

description: This sandwich shop and coffee house is located at my building.  In the morning I like to pick up their coffee and freshly baked coffee cake or muffins.  They also bake their own bread for sandwiches.  At lunch time this place really gets crowded.  I recommend calling in your order for a 12 noon pick-up.  If you call at 12 noon they probably will not answer the phone because they are too busy.  My favorite sandwich is their salmon wrapped in smoked lox.  This place is not cheap but the quality of the food is off the chart.
author: Loren L.

description: I have only tried the Peach Muffin here. But Oh My God. It was amazing. Then my co-worker got a sandwich here for breakfast, I didn't even ask what was on it, I just demolished half of it.  It's soooo good! I tried going for lunch on Friday, but the line was around the corner, which, I guess is super easy seeing as this is located on the corner, but it seemed like it would be a 20 minute wait.  I decided to grab subway (shame) and as I walked back less than 3 minutes later, I noticed that the line had really moved! The person who must have been last in line when I initially walked by was not about to be served, so basically next time I'll wait in line to grab lunch here.
author: Kym P.

description:
A little piece of homemade brioche with your soup?  -Why, yes, sir.  Can I have some more?  I think I've died and gone to heaven.  

This little gem of a place is run by Chef Denis Leary of Canteen fame.  You see him in action making the sandwiches in this tiny, but quaint hole-in-the- wall of place which has only a smidgen of a counter that fits 2, standing.  

You know the food is good when patrons don't even wait to go back to their offices, but eat right outside the Sentinel.  My co-worker and I couldn't decide which sandwich to get, so he got the corned beef - served with gruyere, red and green cabbage with an aioli with a hint of horseradish.   I'm not a fan of horseradish, but his was amazing.  I got the turkey with an apricot spread, with butter leaf and paper-thin slices of fennel.  Oh boyeee, it was good!  

Leary's food is worth every Yelp and buzz.
author: Yimmy D.

description: Yum! The spicy shrimp salad with avocado was awesome - so much flavor, with just enough kick! I highly recommend this place for lunch.  Check out the specials on their website - the shrimp salad was a special. Enjoy!
author: Lauren F.

description: Huge fans of those glorious muffins! The peach has to be my absolute favorite. Definitely worth the detour to swing by - no line like lunch either.
author: Kelly M.

description: First time here and had the lamb/eggplant sando - pretty amazing.  All it needs is some cilantro and perhaps a little aioli, and then POW, it'd be a crackanwich!  My friends roast beef sandwich was perfection and piled with meat.  My other friends meat ball sandwich looked so so as the meat/sauce combo overtook the bread and blew it out.  This place is definately worth a visit, and perhaps frequent monthly.
author: Chris C.

description: The Sentinel is exactly what every downtown working professional needs -- delicious, fresh, flavorful food that's quick and not too expensive. It's like a treat during the work week! I also love getting lattes here in the morning, the coffee is really good. Though I've had to forbid myself from the baked goods. The fresh fruit muffins are fantastic and addictive.
author: Amy N.

description:
finally decided to try this place after hearing such great reviews from others.. I must say - why did I wait? I had the BALT sandwich..which stands for basil, alvocado, lettuce and tomato..also, it had goat cheese.. it was super yummy and filling sandwich! a must try!

my next sandwich from this place based on all the yelp reviews - the corned beef one! I tried a little bit from co-worker's sandwich..that will be my next one to try!
author: Linda Y.

description:
At the risk of being ostracized be fellow yelpers, i'm going to emphatically voice my disappointment with the Rueben sandwich.

I can't understand how anyone would consider The Sentinel's Rueben Sandwich any good. 

The foccacia was soggy, the cabbage overly sweet and the corned beef was chewy not tender. The corned beef hand an odd texture and did not fall apart as good corned beef should. 

I subjected myself to a second helping of the sandwich several weeks after my first experience, becuase I questioned how a sandwich with such praise could fall so short. My second sandwich did nothing to sway my opinion.

I DO NOT recommend the Rueben to anyone. This modern take on a classic sandwich misses the mark on every level. Stay away!!!
author: Len V.

description: Friendly and Fresh.  I went to the sentinel for lunch over a year ago and am still recovering from my sandwich.  I ordered what everyone recommends - the corned beef sandwich.  And...it was delish.  BUT it was super heavy and I was questioning whether I'd still be able to breathe afterwards.  I'm glad I tried the sandwich, it was really good, I liked the bread and everything seemed fresh but it was definitely too much of a sandwich to make it a usual lunch time go-to spot.  My next stop: the pork sandwich at the ferry building farmer's market (lunchtime food coma here I come).
author: Selena G.

description:
genuinely nice people are hard to come by...
holly fits that mold...
she's the cherry on top when ordering one of their delicious sandwiches...
author: chester R.

description:
This review is for the corned beef sandwich only and it was amazingly good. Need I say more? Well, yes I do! Probably 4.5/5 but I'll round up. The bread they use in this thing is terrific - like a foccacia bread or something but not quite. It's soft on the inside, crispy on the outside. The corned beef is tender and full of flavor but not overpowering. They put some kind of sauce in here, I want to say ketchup, but it's definitely not that. For $8, it is a little pricey for a sandwich, but shoot, if you're going to have a sandwich, might as well make it a good one! They're not the biggest of sandwiches, by no means submarine sized, but it's quality over quantity here. I would put this place almost on par with Ike's over in the Castro. Well, at least for their corned beef sandwiches. Their BBQ beef sandwiches didn't look all that good.

Service was great. Called in advance, went to pick up the sandwiches and they made them right there on the spot. Skipped the whole line. Not sure if you're supposed to do this, but heck, why not? I wasn't too sure about the place at first but 5 stars for the killer good first impression on the corned beef sandwiches. I'm a fan!

If you're a 6'4 lumberjack, this place isn't for you. The sandwiches are decently sized but are in no way an atomic sub. This was a refreshing lunch thanks to The Sentinel...at least due to the corned beef  ;) 

Finally a Yelp success!
author: Con L.

description: Canteen's chef (Dennis Leary) has an irresistible little side venture going here. I don't know if he's a workaholic or just THAT committed to unique restaurateuring, but we 9-5 FiDi'ers benefit from his madness, so I ain't questioning it! My colleague cringes because I refer to this place as "The Shed," but in my defense, it barely seems attached to its building since you queue up on one side to order and are right back out the other in 3-4 steps. The menu changes daily, making it easy to treat yourself to something different ... IF you can somehow manage not to order that gourmet corned beef sammich on the sinful bread every single time. I don't hand out five stars haphazardly, so this lunch spot is worth putting on your radar if you haven't yet experienced it.
author: Gregor G.

description: Really good rare roast beef, but get there early it can sell out. The service is quick, but don't expect a 'thank you' even if you tip- these ladies are just not too friendly. No big deal though- great place to grab a quick lunch downtown.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Decent enough food, although way too expensive for what they deliver. I figured when I went there and they had 6 items on the menu (two of which were sold out) that they all must be pretty good... dear god was I wrong. I ordered the "lunch special" hoping to get a good variety dish for lunch. The special was described on the menu as "mac and cheese, small salad, and a piece of almond cake with blueberries" which seemed right up my alley. I was quite surprised when my order arrived. The mac and cheese was mediocre at best (soggy noodles in a bland-beyond-bland cheese sauce) the salad consisted of literally a dozen alfalfa sprouts covered in about a teaspoon of salsa... that's it... and the "almond blueberry cake" was a piece of almond flavored sponge cake sitting on a half dozen blueberries.

If you go here, don't order ANYTHING other than one of their sandwiches, I'm told they're very good (although I wasn't particularly impressed after a snatching a bite or two from my co-worker). For what The Sentinel charges for their menu items there is no reason they can't maintain a high standard of quality across the board... especially considering their menu is tiny.
author: Kevin S.

description: I came here for lunch slightly after the rush but there was still a bit of line.  I didn't wait too long and my sandwich was ready right when I got to the register.  I got a corned beef sandwich and a watermelon lemonade drink, which were both really good.  I will definitely come back here for lunch!
author: Laurice G.

description:
First of all, it should be noted that this is a bit of an odd place.  Their menu consists of a very small set of items that they change every day. For example, this afternoon, it consisted of three items: a soup, an entree, and a salad. So be prepared to eat what they give you.

The pork shoulder was excellent. It was moist and soft, but full of flavor and not overly fatty. The brioche on the side was extremely buttery, almost like a croissant, but slightly sweeter. And finally, the home-made apricot marmalade was phenomenal. Sweet, succulent, and juicy, it was excellent.

The only disappointment was the price. I suppose it probably was worth the $11 for a full entree lunch, but I don't usually want a full entree lunch.

But it sure was tasty.
author: Joel W.

description:
Daily Candy actually brought this new lunch spot in the FiDi to my attention as I never really eat on New Montgomery anymore. Who really fiends for Chipotle anyways?!?!?

Menu options are interesting as they only offer four items (a soup, two sandwiches (a cold and hot) plus a salad). We had a choice between the following items: chilled pea soup, smoked salmon sandwich, corned beef sandwich and tuna tartare w/ginger. 

I got the smoked salmon and my colleague the corned beef which we could not wait to eat. Our stomachs were getting antsy with the wait to order and for our foods which only made our appetites bigger. 

Overall, the smoke salmon was a bit more salty that I would have liked and my colleague actually threw it away after only two bites. Hey, I don't blame her as the corned beef was devoured. Top notch in our opinions as it seems like anything hot is the better option amongst the four items. 

The corner location makes it very airy inside the "Parisian-like" space. Small kitchen with a staff of 4 people. They also have hot beverages and desserts. Caution: lines will grow longer and longer everyday as the word spreads about this new lunch spot.
author: S L.

description:
Wow - so overrated!

Went for lunch today and got the $11 special. Pork, bread salad, figs and chocolate mousse.

The pork is fine, but just fine, nothing special.
The bread salad is too salty.
I gave my figs away to a coworker because I'm not really into figs. (They were probably the best part of the meal.)
The chocolate mousse turned into a hard turd-like chunk of chocolate. Nothing creamy or mousse-y about it at all.

Maybe their breakfast options are the hit items?
author: Bill E.

description:
After reading about this place in the paper recently and then checking out the Yelp reviews, I excitedly hustled over at lunch today, since it is very near my office.  I was pleased that the line was not nearly as bad as Yelpers had led me to believe; I got there around 12:30, and there were only about 5 people in line, and it did indeed move  very quickly.

As to the food:  I ordered the smoked salmon sandwich.  Let me just say this:  if you madly adore cream cheese, you will be in heaven.  I, however, prefer extremely light cream cheese...  when I got this sandwich back to my desk, I had to take it apart and scrape off all the excess cream cheese with a knife.  When I was done, I had a nice pile o' cream cheese that probably would have covered half a dozen bagels.  Seriously.  So, I put the sandwich back together, and thought it was... good.  But not great.  The horseradish was a nice touch and gave it a bit of a zing, but aside from that, I didn't see how this sandwich was any more special than your typical lox bagel sandwich from Noah's...  I know other people have raved about the bread, but I found it too crunchy...  almost hard.

As for the pricing...  A bit pricey, sure, but the portions are big (I didn't even finish my sandwich, despite Project Cream Cheese Removal), and you get a crunchy pickle and the aforementioned Ande's mint (best part, IMHO), so you do get some added value for the price.

I will go back because I am curious to try some of the other offerings, but I don't think I'll order the salmon sandwich again.
author: Cara K.

description: Best sandwich ever in financial district. I tried corn beef sandwich and will definitely come again for it!
author: Woosung A.

description: I love Canteen and now I have to say I love The Sentinel. I met some friends here for lunch today. We've seen and heard the raving about the corned beef sandwich- and it's all true. EFFEN A RIGHT the corned beef sandwich is SO GOOD. That's all I need, wash it down with a pomegranate lemon drink and the service is OH SO SPEEDY.
author: Braden B.

description: Super sandwich! I had the smoked trout which was refreshing with the apple and fennel. My coworker got the corned beef which she let me taste-- it was soo good. The secret is in the bread- the seeded bun served with the trout sandwich was so buttery; it was almost like pastry!
author: Jessica H.

description:
The bread is clearly the star at this sandwich shop; you can smell it from half a block away! Their sandwiches are kind of like dressed up deli classics. They have a corned beef sandwich that is to die for, very similar to (but a little lighter than) a classic reuben. 

The line is often long but it moves very quickly, I think because of their color-coordinated post-it system. Not the cheapest sandwich you'll ever eat, but $9 for lunch in the fidi is standard. Definitely one of my go-to lunch spots during the week.
author: Em G.

description:
The first time I ate here was delicious.  Then the next time was pretty good.  And then I went back and it sucked.
But the first time was good enough to go back and try, try again...
author: Brad N.

description: I been to this place twice. To start off, I would recommend this place to someone and would go again. I had the Corn Beef Sandwich and the Meatball Sandwich. Corn Beef was pretty good but the meatball one was just awful. Service is snappy and friendly.
author: Louis T.

description: I love the smell when I walk by in the morning on the way to work.  They're still the best lunch place in the neighborhood.
author: ariel b.

description: Our offices just moved to the the Market and 2nd area and we have all been scouting the new lunchtime options.  I was really happy when a co-worker took me along to the Sentinel for lunch today - had an amazaing lamb and eggplant sadwich the portion was huge - I probably should have only eaten half...but it was just to good to stop!
author: julie f.

description: I hated it the first time I went there and tried a meatball special. It was literally meatballs stuck in between two pieces of bread. But stick to the regular stuff and you'll do well, the corned beef is a favorite with most people I know and I personally really like the salmon as well. The line moves really quickly at lunch but the sandwiches themselves aren't the largest so beware, or just get a good side.
author: Abhinav S.

description:
this just goes to show that san franciscans are suckers for hype. oh so and so is a  premier chef at chez whatever we must love it and tell everybody else that they must love it too.

suckers.
author: curi k.

description: Even though it was only supposed to reach a high of 68 degrees today, it jumped to 80 and I was unfortunately ill-dressed for the occasion.  I wanted something healthy, something tasty and something cold for lunch and decided to try the place I pass by every morning - The Sentinal.  The line and wait were short - about five minutes.  I got the yellowtail with fennel and avocado and boy was I happy about that decision.  It was like having yellowtail sashimi wrapped in crispy greens and soft buttery bread.  I couldn't believe the flavors - and at such a low price.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Ixchel F.

description:
Enjoyed a latte and a blueberry muffin a few weeks ago-- both were outstanding.  Followed up today (7/10/08) with the turkey salad sandwich with lemon zest and capers.  Absolutely fantastic.  

Enter on Stevenson, exit in heaven.  Well done, Sentinel.
author: Eric R.

description:
sorry, a sandwich is a sandwich and rarely ever worth $8.50.

Service was no better or no worse than any other place up and down the street that takes your order, your cash, then gives you your food. And does it really matter who the chef is? 

The sandwiches themselves are fine. But again, see line 1.
author: d. g.

description: I love the sentinel!  I used to work in the sharon building next door and I could honestly eat there every day!  The people are great that work there, they get through the line so quickly. - and the food is amazing!    They bake all their bread and desserts every morning.  Don't forget to try the muffins and coffee cake in the morning, my favorite is the sour cherry muffin.  BTW its usually warm when I get it- yummmm!
author: R L.

description:
This place is a great lunch for under $10.  I've only had the corned beef sandwich but it is so tasty that I don't know if would switch it up.  I like how they use artisinal bread instead of traditional rye.  The only reason I'm not giving it 5 Stars is b/c I do think they should have more variety of sandwiches.  I would try something else but nothing else on the menu appeals to me. 

Also, they only accept credit cards if you spend more than $10.  Although they've let me slide before.
author: Katie S.

description: Think high end sandwiches. You wait in line and take out. Standing in line at this place is like a Seinfield episode featuring the soup nazi cuz everyone wants a piece of it.....especially the corned beef on flatbread with gruyere, cabbage, russian dressing.  The paper menu pasted on the door lists about 8 different sandwiches and 2 or 3 daily specials
author: Leslie L.

description: Excellent sandwiches! I was tired of the boring usual ones, I got a fresh & smoked salmon with fennel in a brioche bun, tasty & healthy~
author: D T.

description: The corned beef is delicious here.   The only gripe I have is the long wait and the short hours... other than that  its allll goood try it!
author: Shawn A.

description: The sandwiches are tasty and they have a menu that changes daily.  Many of the sandwiches are bit heavy on the sauce or you may get served  brioche bread which has lots of butter, so if you're looking for a healthy lunch, make sure you read the menu carefully for the right choices.  The lines may be long but it moves quickly.
author: Dan C.

description: I really wasn't impressed with the corned beef.  The sandwich was decent, but definitely not worth the wait.
author: Andrew K.

description:
My relationship with Sentinel began around a year ago.  Once every few weeks, I would treat myself to a sandwich or their daily special.  Everything is absolutely amazing.  Their breads are super fresh.  The meatballs are flavorful, moist, and hearty.  BBQ pork is well complimented with the condiments.  Their complimentary pickle is pretty delicious.

Now, I haven't written a review for all this time.  But today, I felt compelled to express my deep love.  I ordered the SMOKED TROUT sandwich.  Man oh man.  That is a special sandwich.  It's like a smoked trout salad with fennel, apple, and dill.  It's perfection.  Surprisingly refreshing.  Not fishy at all.  I need another sandwich right now.
author: T. N.

description: Good coffee. Great sandwiches - I've tried the corned beef and the BBQ pork. The people who work there are great.
author: Chris R.

description:
#74 on the Big Eat SF list

probably would have tasted better had it not been a drive-by-to-go-eat-30-min-later... did make my car smell lovely though. 

note: their website says call for easy pick up. i had to call about 6 times to get someone. sometimes it was busy, sometimes it stopped ringing, not really sure what happened. they're crazy busy so understandable, but frustrating. if you want to call ahead, just dont give up, keep trying! they just need a 15-20 min heads up
author: S V.

description: I love the corned beef sandwich from The Sentinel.  They also have the best muffins I've ever had (before 9:30 a.m. - or until they run out).  I highly recommend this sandwich shop.
author: Anna P.

description:
The lunches here are delicious!  I am especially fond of the corned beef sandwich.  It is definitely worth a repeat.  

I have only been here a few times, as it is rather far from my work.  As other reviewer have noted, getting here early is the key.  I have been here around 1p, and a good 70% of the items on the menu were sold out.  There were still about 10 people in line at that time.
author: Venisa S.

description: Great gourmet sandwiches that are quick to the order and always fresh. I will always love their roast beef sandwich, it's soooooooooooo juicy with just the right touch of horseradish?? The salmon on salmon sandwich is delicious, just a little hard to keep together. I was pleasantly surprised at how flavorful the meatball sandwich was since I normally don't eat meatball. I always get the corn soup when it's in. And thanks for the toffee to top it all off. Every once in a while I will treat myself to one of these AWESOME sandwiches.
author: Kathleen T.

description: The sandwich nazi never disappoints! Get in line early!
author: Jc S.

description: Obviously people love this sandwich shop, but I don't get it.  I had a "pork barbecue" sandwich the other day that was on a soggy bun.  The pork was cut too thickly, and the coleslaw was undetectable.  Like I said, I don't get all the love for this place.
author: Alice G.

description: The corned beef sandwich was to die for... I only wish it had more meat though.... a great place to grab a sandwich Mon-Fri. Staff was friendly and efficient.
author: Robert O.

description: I was very impressed by the corned beef sandwich!  Usually I find something I like (the turkey meatloaf sandwich) and stick with it.  However at the last minute I decided to be adventurous.  Must say, the thinly sliced corned beef was tasty, every morsel of it.  It was packed with flavor and whatever sauce they had in addition to the cabbage was superb.  The mango lemonade was not bad at all either!
author: Christopher W.

description: A delicious aroma lured me in as I passed by this morning (a tough feat in a city that can really stink at times!). There is no display case so I asked what they had. The woman behind the counter began with coffee cake and pointed to it. I stopped her there and said I would take that. She cut a huge piece, while another woman rang me up ($2.75). It must have just come from the oven because it was still hot and the sugary topping had whole almonds for a nice crunch. The serving was large enough to keep me snacking until lunch. It was a delightful treat on a cold SF morning!
author: Lisa G.

description: I heard a round of awwwwwwwwws as the pastrami sandwich was wiped of the white board. luckily for me and my co-worker were able to sneak in a corned beef salad and the tuna tartare to go. delicious. i'll be back. i hope/pray that the line won't get longer than it already is.
author: Mara S.

description:
I raved about the Sentinel already but I would like to mention something special - the new Roast Beef sandwich with blue cheese.  The wheat bread is perfect - just crackly enough on the outside but soft enough not to make roast beef shoot out the back.  And a hint of sweetness.  And - my god! - rare roast beef, there was even a little bit of bloody juice left at the bottom of my sandwich wrapper today.

I could mainline the Roast Beef w/ blue cheese on wheat.  Positively transcendental.  I can't believe I'm saying this about a sandwich.
author: Steve C.

description: What a great find! A great place to pick up lunch if you work in FiDi/SOMA. The prices are not the cheapest but you definitely get your money's worth.  I had the corned beef sandwich, which is $8 (not cheap for food stand lunch standards, in my opinion, but it sure tastes like it's worth $8 or more).  I am definitely going back.
author: Christy I.

description: So, a sandwich is just a sandwich, right?  NO!!  After seeing long lines at this place for months, I decided to check it out.   Of course, I was waiting in those long lines, but it must be worth it, right?  You betcha!  I ordered the corn beef brisket with grueye cheese, pickled cabbage, and some type of aioloi spread.  I took it back to the office, and ate half of it at my desk.  The bread is fresh and tasty, and I loved the grueye pairing.  Also, I loved the little details like Andes chocolate, and a pickle (that's what all sandwiches should include on the side).  Then, this afternoon, I ate the other half of the sandwich.  It was cold from sitting in the refrig, but it was sooo yummy.  All the flavors were marinated together, and it was so deliciouso.  Definitely will add this to my regular lunch haunts!
author: Jen C.

description: bottom line:  great taste, bad texture, faster than you might think.  i got the corned beef sandwich per all the previous reviews. it definitely had the right taste and the russian sauce was a pleasant surprise, but i was not a fan of the bread, mainly because of its texture. lemonade was also a pleasant surprise, though i wish it had been warmer that day!
author: Aaron T.

description: If the Sentinel ever closed I would die of starvation
author: Anthony L.

description:
The Sentinel has gone from my preferred lunch spot to my daily lunch spot. Unlike a lot of lunch places, the Sentinel changes its menu seasonally, and the new winter menu really distinguishes itself from the typical sandwich and soup fare. The winter soups -- ones I might not usually think to order such as pumpkin or parsnip or today's excellent winter vegetable puree withe gruyere -- have consistently been great. The swiss chard sandwich is an unique and perhaps unexpected delight; everyone in my office -- mostly dudes, mostly meat-eaters -- loves it and orders it regularly over the heartier corned beef sandwich and deviled ham sandwich, both of which are delicious in their own right.

The daily specials are posted every weekday on the website -- why doesn't everybody do this? -- and the folks at the Sentinel accept phone orders in advance. The Sentinel has found a way to offer convenience without sacrificing quality.

The Sentinel is the tops!
author: Eugene P.

description: I miss my ruben sandwiches. Oh how I miss them. I miss the smell coming out of this store. And the friendly lunch lines in the Financial District on sunny days in the city.
author: Michelle G.

description: Long line, but moves fast.  $9 was a little pricey for the size of the sandwich.  Quality was good.
author: Tristan C.

description: Saw the great reviews here on Yelp and decided to check it out for myself.  I went on St. Patrick's Day and tried the corned beef sandwich.  I was worried about a long line so I arrived around noon and was surprised by hardly any line at all.  It's pretty cool how they take your order on colored post it notes for the kitchen.  I had to wait about 5 minutes for the order to come up after ordering.  The sandwich was much smaller than I expected in terms of size of bread and amount of corned beef.  Still, the tastes were all well-balanced.  The bread was a little greasy on the top, which I didn't think it needed to be.  I'll go back again and try the egg salad sandwich.
author: Erin L.

description: The Sentinel now finally has whole wheat bread. Now I can eat their deliciousness without a bad conscience!!
author: Alexandra D.

description: I love places that just do a few things and do them well. I went to the Sentinel for the first time today and it seems to be just that sort of place.
